('25', 0, 1, 2, 46) 1. NOTES
('25', 0, 2, 3, 55) MUNICIPALITIES BEWARE
('25', 0, 3, 4, 77) The Government of Bombay note regarding the Ahmedabad, Surat and Nadiad municipalities shows that it refuses to see the writing on the wall.
('25', 0, 3, 5, 218) Its dictatorial tone is now no longer in keeping with the rising spirit of the people.
('25', 0, 3, 6, 305) Its incitement to the individual ratepayers to sue the councillors who believe they have performed their duty is hardly dignified.
('25', 0, 3, 7, 436) The proper course for the Government was to let the municipalities take their own course and not to invite trouble.
('25', 0, 3, 8, 552) As it is, the Government note is calculated to precipitate a crisis.
('25', 0, 3, 9, 621) The councillors must take up the challenge and dare the Government to disregard the municipalities if they choose.
('25', 0, 3, 10, 736) The municipalities must have the right to misgovern themselves if they wish.
('25', 0, 3, 11, 813) If a city is misgoverned, it is as much the ratepayers’ fault as is the councillors’.
('25', 0, 3, 12, 899) But our wise Government whilst recognizing the independent existence of the municipalities wants to stick to the letter of the law which killeth and would itself rule instead of letting the municipalities alone so long as they do not cost the Government anything.
('25', 0, 3, 13, 1163) The municipalities must now take up the challenge and prepare for action on their part.
('25', 0, 3, 14, 1251) Government may succeed; in getting a few ratepayers to file suits.
('25', 0, 3, 15, 1318) That will be the least it can do.
('25', 0, 3, 16, 1352) The most it can do is to disband the municipalities concerned.
('25', 0, 3, 17, 1415) And the most of the Government should prove most welcome, if only the protestants are a strong body.
('25', 0, 3, 18, 1516) Assuming that they are, they must simply educate the ratepayers to understand what is happening and to prepare them for battle.
('25', 0, 3, 19, 1644) I can see swaraj peeping even through the Government note if the latter take and the former are ready for action.
('25', 0, 3, 20, 1758) So long as there is no disbandment, the municipalities have all power; as soon as there is disbandment, the Government is powerless assuming of course that the ratepayers are strong, intelligent and united.
('25', 0, 3, 21, 1965) The ratepayers are all that but they require to be organized for action.
('25', 0, 3, 22, 2038) Hitherto the people have been the football of officials or so called representatives.
('25', 0, 3, 23, 2124) Non co operation enables the people to become the players in the game.
('25', 0, 3, 24, 2195) Representatives must represent or they perish.
('25', 0, 4, 25, 2242) THE VISITORS TO THE CONGRESS
('25', 0, 5, 26, 2271) The Reception Committee of the Congress is trying to make the Congress session a purely business session.
('25', 0, 5, 27, 2377) In its anxiety to do so, it
('25', 1, 0, 1, 2405) 2 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDNI
('25', 1, 1, 2, 2445) has restricted its own number and the number of visitors.
('25', 1, 1, 3, 2503) It was impossible to avoid limitation of the number of visitors when the number of delegates was limited.
('25', 1, 1, 4, 2609) The question therefore before the Committee was to devise a method of selection.
('25', 1, 1, 5, 2690) The only qualification possible was a monetary qualification subject to free tickets for a few distinguished guests.
('25', 1, 1, 6, 2807) The idea is purely to restrict the number of applicants, not to make money.
('25', 1, 1, 7, 2883) For the first time, the annual gathering will cease to be an instrument for collecting funds for the annual expenditure.
('25', 1, 1, 8, 3004) Elaborate preparations including exhibition, musical concerts and popular lectures by all the celebrated speakers of the day for a fee of eight annas per day are in progress.
('25', 1, 1, 9, 3179) The prohibitive fee has been imposed only for visitors to the Congress session, the idea being to discourage applications from visitors.
('25', 1, 1, 10, 3316) I am anxious that the public should understand and appreciate the position of the Reception Committee upon whose shoulders devolves the responsibility of organizing the first session under the new constitution and under exceptional circumstances.
('25', 1, 1, 11, 3563) The success of the Congress depends principally upon the willing and hearty co operation of every member of the public.
('25', 1, 2, 12, 3683) WAR ON THE KHADI CAP
('25', 1, 3, 13, 3704) Mr. Dharamadas Udharam of Karachi writes, saying that he was cashiered by his employers Messrs Forbes Campbell and Co., for having dared to wear the khadi cap.
('25', 1, 3, 14, 3864) I congratulate him upon his courage in accepting dismissal rather than giving up his cap.
('25', 1, 3, 15, 3954) If he were not demoralized, every clerk serving no matter where would invite dismissal by a simultaneous adoption of the khadi cap.
('25', 1, 3, 16, 4086) This would really have the effect of the firms recognizing the inevitable and seeing the folly of warring against harmless dress.
('25', 1, 3, 17, 4216) Indeed this war is being waged to strike awe among employees and keep them submissive and even unmanly.
('25', 1, 3, 18, 4320) In Madras the Director of Public Instruction will not allow the inspectors of schools to introduce spinning wheels if only because, the Director says, they are given a political significance.
('25', 1, 3, 19, 4512) On the same reasoning even a lecture on abstinence should be taboo because it has for non co operators a political significance.
('25', 1, 3, 20, 4641) This war against swadeshi in a variety of ways shows that it is distasteful to the Government.
('25', 1, 3, 21, 4736) In other words the Government cannot tolerate the economic independence of India.
('25', 1, 3, 22, 4818) Should these indications not make us resolute in the prosecution of the swadeshi programme?
('25', 2, 0, 1, 4910) VOL. 25 : 27 OCTOBER, 1921 22 JANUARY, 1922 3
('25', 2, 1, 2, 4956) SOLDIERS
('25', 2, 2, 3, 4965) The prosecution of the Brothers and their companions and the Manifesto 1 have reached the barracks, and soldiers are inquiring how they can support themselves if they leave.
('25', 2, 2, 4, 5139) One correspondent asks on their behalf as to what would happen to them under swaraj.
('25', 2, 2, 5, 5224) As for the first, the Working Committee has shown them the way.
('25', 2, 2, 6, 5288) Every soldier can easily become a weaver and carder.
('25', 2, 2, 7, 5341) Carding requires strength of arm which every soldier must have.
('25', 2, 2, 8, 5405) And a carder in Bombay earns anything between two to three rupees per day.
('25', 2, 2, 9, 5480) Many weavers of the Punjab have left the handloom for the sword of the hireling.
('25', 2, 2, 10, 5561) I consider the former to be infinitely preferable to the latter.
('25', 2, 2, 11, 5626) I refuse to call the profession of the sepoy honourable when he has no choice as to the time when and the persons or people against whom he is called upon to use his sword.
('25', 2, 2, 12, 5799) The sepoy’s services have more often been utilized for enslaving us than for protecting us, whereas the weaver today can truly become the liberator of his country and hence a true soldier.
('25', 2, 2, 13, 5988) A friend has suggested, that agriculture should also be added to weaving and carding advised by the Congress.
('25', 2, 2, 14, 6098) It cannot be as an immediate measure, because, agriculture cannot be taken up with ease, and it requires a capital outlay which renders it impracticable for our purpose.
('25', 2, 2, 15, 6268) What will happen during swaraj is easily answered.
('25', 2, 2, 16, 6319) The soldiers will not then be hirelings, but they will form the national militia for defensive and protective purposes alone.
('25', 2, 2, 17, 6445) They will have a voice in the moulding of the affairs of the nation.
('25', 2, 2, 18, 6514) And they will certainly never be sent to cut down inoffensive Turks or Arabs in the West or equally inoffensive Chinese or Burmese in the East.

('25', 3, 1, 2, 7157) necessary because of my experience of our silence being a result of our weakness.
('25', 3, 1, 3, 7239) Unfortunately it is not confined to the individual.
('25', 3, 1, 4, 7291) It has become a national vice.
('25', 3, 1, 5, 7322) When I cited Mr. Tyagi, his case was merely the latest illustration of that vice.
('25', 3, 1, 6, 7404) As I have explained before now, bad as the Moplah madness is, the fact of others having submitted to the madness is worse.
('25', 3, 1, 7, 7527) Why did they live to tell the tale of their forcible conversions?
('25', 3, 1, 8, 7593) Nobody can keep our religion for us.
('25', 3, 1, 9, 7630) Each one of us man or woman must be one’s own defender.
('25', 3, 1, 10, 7686) God who has given us religion has given also the power of defending it.
('25', 3, 1, 11, 7758) Everyone has not the power to strike; all, the lame, the blind and the dumb have the power to die.
('25', 3, 1, 12, 7857) The cowardly assault by the magistrate was an attack on Mr. Tyagi’s manhood and therefore his religion.
('25', 3, 1, 13, 7961) By some act of his, be it called defiances, impudence, insolence, he ought to have invited more slaps and”created a peaceful scene”.

('25', 3, 1, 15, 8141) But I do not blame Mr. Tyagi or anybody.
('25', 3, 1, 16, 8182) Manliness has been deliberately killed out of us.
('25', 3, 1, 17, 8232) And we have been disarmed into mute submission.
('25', 3, 1, 18, 8280) As the author of non violence in its modern presentation I am anxious to guard myself against our weakness being apotheosized.
('25', 3, 1, 19, 8407) I would far rather not shower congratulations for bravery till we are positive about it.
('25', 3, 1, 20, 8496) For the rest, we have every reason to be thankful for the progress we have made in shedding our fear and awe of authority.
('25', 3, 1, 21, 8619) Non co operation arms both the weak and the strong with a powerful weapon.
('25', 3, 1, 22, 8694) And I should not be ashamed of our submission to insults even out of weakness so long as we realized that it was due to weakness and attempted every time to outgrow it.
('25', 3, 1, 23, 8863) Babu Bhagwandas is curious to know what could be worse than fear.
('25', 3, 1, 24, 8929) I had in mind cowardice.
('25', 3, 1, 25, 8954) It is curious to note that whilst Babu Bhagwandas has in view of Mr. Tyagi’s statement and in ignorance of my amends, rightly protested against my condemnation of weakness I hastily inferred in Mr. Tyagi’s case, Maulana Mahomed Ali has, as will appear from his letter 1 printed elsewhere, energetically protested against his action being called a defiance.
('25', 3, 1, 26, 9311) The word”defence” occurring in my notes at the end was a misprint for”defiance”.
('25', 3, 2, 27, 9392) These protests are to me most welcome signs of the national desire to be correct to a fault.
('25', 3, 2, 28, 9485) The Maulana will not appropriate even credit for

('25', 4, 1, 3, 9939) Let us close the controversy with the hope and the prayer, that our country may become brave and yet gentle and chivalrous to a nicety.

('25', 4, 8, 17, 11019) 3. A GAOL LETTER
('25', 4, 9, 18, 11036) “NONE SHALL PREVAIL BUT GOD”
('25', 4, 10, 19, 11065) JAIL, KARACHI, October 18, 1921 DEAR BAPU Naturally I have long been thinking of writing to you, but for one reason or another I put it off from day to day.
('25', 4, 10, 20, 11222) However, when I read in the papers more than one reference from your pen to my wife’s action after my arrest at Waltair and to her subsequent activities, I felt impelled to write to you, if only a line,—a thing so difficult for
('25', 5, 0, 1, 11450) 6 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDNI
('25', 5, 1, 2, 11490) me as you have publically admitted!—just to tell you how deeply you have touched me.
('25', 5, 1, 3, 11575) As I have told you once perhaps, ours was a”love marriage” from the very first, which is somewhat uncommon in India; but even apart from that every year of our married life made my wife a dearer partner to me than she was before, and the way she took the last few eventful years of internment and incarceration and of the”risks” we have been running since our release at the end of 1919, endeared her to me more than ever.
('25', 5, 1, 4, 11998) But to tell you the truth she was never half so dear to me as I found her at Waltair when she stepped into the little Railway Police station, and jauntily asking me not to worry about her or the girls, bade me good bye and marched off steadily to the train—all within a minute or two.
('25', 5, 1, 5, 12283) Well, I have read more than one reference in your writings, to my own self or to”the Brothers” all too complimentary and I am too”natural” to deny that every such reference gave me pleasure and quickened my pulse.
('25', 5, 1, 6, 12497) More than once I have read a”defence” or an”apology” from your pen when you stood up for us against some critic’s onslaught and cheered us up at a time when we were tempted to be not a little irascible.
('25', 5, 1, 7, 12700) But nothing you have yet written in praise or in defence of us has gladdened my heart so much as your repeated reference to my dear brave wife!
('25', 5, 1, 8, 12844) Indeed I have been so deeply touched that I am even inclined to forgive you and not be jealous of you for the seductive praise you have showered on her!
('25', 5, 1, 9, 12997) So there!
('25', 5, 1, 10, 13007) I only hope this very trying trial will now soon be over and she will be free once more to continue her work and earn more seductive praise from you.
('25', 5, 1, 11, 13157) By the way, I wonder if you ever saw my letter to Tairsee in which I gave him some idea of the things as they actually happened on the fourth day of the Magisterial Inquiry.
('25', 5, 1, 12, 13331) You who know how vilely even the Chronicle reported my speeches can perhaps understand how risky it is to form one’s opinion about affairs and incidents”reported” by”amateur” journalists innocent of all knowledge of stenography and so interested in hearing and seeing things when they become unusually lively as to ignore altogether the duty of noting them down for the paper they represent.
('25', 5, 1, 13, 13723) When I was not in a prison, I had not enough time at my disposal, nor enough patience to go about correcting every day the inaccuracies in the reports of my speeches.
('25', 5, 1, 14, 13890) Now that prison life gives me more leisure and preparation for a convict’s life necessitates the cultivation of greater patience, I am not as free as I used to be to leave such inaccuracies uncorrected.
('25', 5, 1, 15, 14093) But surely that is no reason for people to
('25', 6, 0, 1, 14136) VOL. 25 : 27 OCTOBER, 1921 22 JANUARY, 1922 7
('25', 6, 1, 2, 14182) place implicit reliance in the printed word.
('25', 6, 1, 3, 14227) When I read the meagre and inaccurate and wholly misleading reports of the court proceeding of the fourth day, I felt that we would be misjudged by some people at least, and as I was referring in my letter to Tairsee to the awful topsyturvydom of the Chronicle which misplaced paragraphs and sentences by the dozens in the report of my statement, I also took the opportunity of mentioning some of the circumstances which led to the”defiance” of the Court.
('25', 6, 1, 4, 14683) But really we were not”out for mischief”.
('25', 6, 1, 5, 14725) For three days the proceedings went on smoothly and the Court could not accuse us of”defiance” any more than the Counsel for the Crown could accuse us of”defence.” But the trouble began with Maulana Hussain Ahmed Saheb’s statement.
('25', 6, 1, 6, 14957) The Court refused to call a qualified interpreter, and it was this that led Kitchlew to insist on speaking in Urdu when the Magistrate wanted to begin with another of the co accused for whom the interpreter would not, he said, be needed.
('25', 6, 1, 7, 15195) On the following day the atmosphere was entirely changed though we do not know what led to the change over night.
('25', 6, 1, 8, 15309) It was the Court that was”defiant”.
('25', 6, 1, 9, 15345) Kitchlew’s statement which was on the same lines as mine was objected to at every fresh sentence and the Magistrate would not take it down.
('25', 6, 1, 10, 15485) Then he insisted on asking the Shankaracharya to get up if he wanted to make a statement, which, the Shankaracharya said, he could not do on religious grounds.
('25', 6, 1, 11, 15645) It was this which compelled me to expostulate with the Magistrate without any passion.
('25', 6, 1, 12, 15732) I asked him whether he would insist on a religious personage of the Shankaracharya’s position in the Hindu hierarchy paying respect to the conventions of a court even if he thereby had to show disregard of what he considered divine law itself.
('25', 6, 1, 13, 15976) The Magistrate belonged to a community the origin of which in the history of India dated back to a migration from its own motherland for fear of having to disregard what it considered divine law.
('25', 6, 1, 14, 16172) He had such a great belief in the respect due to a British law court.
('25', 6, 1, 15, 16242) Had he no belief in God?
('25', 6, 1, 16, 16267) And all that appears in the papers is the bare interrogatory:”Have you no belief in God?” His reply to my appeal was an order in the worst possible tone to sit down.
('25', 6, 1, 17, 16433) But while I refused to comply, I never said,”Let me see what you can do” I said he could use force; but there was no law which could compel an accused person to sit down.
('25', 6, 1, 18, 16604) Poor Shaukat did his best to placate the Magistrate and pleaded with him not to interrupt him while he was making his statement, as it put him off completely.
('25', 6, 1, 19, 16763) But clearly the Magistrate was determined that nothing like my statement of the previous day should go on record
('25', 7, 0, 1, 16876) 8 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDNI
('25', 7, 1, 2, 16916) now or be even heard by those co operations and others who attended his court.
('25', 7, 1, 3, 16995) When Maulana Hussain Ahmed Saheb began his statement, he neither got it interpreted by the Court interpreter (who had already confessed his incompetence to interpret an exposition of Islamic law) nor made the least effort to understand what the Maulana Saheb was saying.
('25', 7, 1, 4, 17266) Nothing was taken down.
('25', 7, 1, 5, 17290) But even this was not enough.
('25', 7, 1, 6, 17320) His indifference was impudent enough, but he added to that one or two direct insults, such as,”It is not necessary to recite the entire Quran here.” Maulana Niser Ahmed Saheb’s very brief statement fared no better.
('25', 7, 1, 7, 17535) And so indifferent was the Magistrate to every requirement of law and procedure that hecommitted us to the Sessions without having received the remainder of my statement which at his own request I had promised to give in writing if he sent me a shorthand typist.
('25', 7, 1, 8, 17798) But then the whole thing was meant to be a farce; for on the very second day when even the Prosecution evidence was not half finished, he passed order on the Public Prosecutor’s application for summons being issued for two witnesses to the effect that it served no purpose to lengthen proceedings unnecessarily, and it would suffice if these witnesses were summoned for the Sessions trial!
('25', 7, 1, 9, 18188) A foregone conclusion even for the Magistrate!!
('25', 7, 1, 10, 18236) And on the 29th before the inquiry was over, the Judicial Commissioner comes himself to inspect the Hall for the Sessions and discusses the plans with the Public Prosecutor!!!
('25', 7, 1, 11, 18412) As I said to the Courts they might as well have sent the carpenters to prepare the scaffold!
('25', 7, 1, 12, 18505) When any reference was made to Islamic law, the Magistrate was impatient and used to say,”We have nothing to do with fatwas here”.
('25', 7, 1, 13, 18636) Shaukat was so exasperated that he said to him,”What is the use of your asking me about such trifles?
('25', 7, 1, 14, 18738) Ask me what Islamic law lays down for such a set of circumstances.” But all in vain, and even Shaukat, could stand this no longer and”the whole blessed show”!
('25', 7, 1, 15, 18897) But would you believe it, soon after this inquiry was over and the Magistrate retired for a time, he was a new man once more!
('25', 7, 1, 16, 19023) In the second case against Shaukat and in the next case against me, he was once more the man he had been on the third day.
('25', 7, 1, 17, 19146) What brought about this second metamorphosis I cannot say.
('25', 7, 1, 18, 19205) But you can judge of the”normal” atmosphere of the Court (including the accused) from the fact that on the last day the Public Prosecutor came hurrying to me and asked,”Will you mind coming back into the court?
('25', 7, 1, 19, 19416) One of the witnesses has put in the wrong exhibit and I should like to recall him.” I agreed and said:”Anything you please,” and when the C.l.D. reporter had sworn again that the exhibit he was then
('25', 8, 0, 1, 19615) VOL. 25 : 27 OCTOBER, 1921 22 JANUARY, 1922 9
('25', 8, 1, 2, 19661) putting in was my speech, I pleasantly told the Magistrate I waived my right of demanding the witness’s prosecution for perjury for swearing before that quite another document was my speech, and the Magistrate equally pleasantly thanked me!
('25', 8, 1, 3, 19902) The fact is the Magistrate, as we all knew, was always an automaton (and I told him on the eventful day I was sorry that a fellow countryman of mine was being used to do a dirty job), but on the day following my statement he came”wound up.” Since then, I understand, even those from whom he expected praise for his loyalty and compliance have expressed their indignation at his spoiling a”historic state trial”, which was intended to typify”justice”?
('25', 8, 1, 4, 20353) under”the New Dispensation” by his disregard of law and procedure.
('25', 8, 1, 5, 20420) That is why Ross Alston of Allahabad and Alim are coming to improve the thing as best they can, and a qualified interpreter is coming from Lahore.
('25', 8, 1, 6, 20567) But the whole thing was a farce and nothing can improve it.
('25', 8, 1, 7, 20627) For our part, we have no desire to be defiant and are not out for mischief.
('25', 8, 1, 8, 20703) Nevertheless we are not going to be dumb driven cattle, and non violence does not require that passivity.
('25', 8, 1, 9, 20809) Violence has much to answer for and many a Mussulman will have his eyes opened on the day of judgment when the true limits of”violence” are to be defined once more by his own leading case.
('25', 8, 1, 10, 20998) But non violence too has a good deal to answer for, and I already see that its apostle is already disillusioning some of its meek votaries who would cover cowardice with that label.
('25', 8, 1, 11, 21180) And good bye now.
('25', 8, 1, 12, 21198) Love to Devdas and the little ones and affectionate salaams to Ba.
('25', 8, 1, 13, 21265) The cheque must have been sent to the Khilafat Fund.
('25', 8, 1, 14, 21318) Mother and my wife do not need any financial assistance, but we are such awful beggars that we will swallow everything for our cause.
('25', 8, 1, 15, 21452) Our affectionate greetings to your own great and dear self.
('25', 8, 1, 16, 21512) Yours ever, MAHOMED ALI
('25', 8, 2, 17, 21536) I am sure that the reader will appreciate my sharing the foregoing letter with him for more reasons than one.
('25', 8, 2, 18, 21646) In my opinion it is a human document showing the whole of the man in the Maulana.
('25', 8, 2, 19, 21728) The letter had naturally to be passed by the Magistrate.
('25', 8, 2, 20, 21785) I had not the heart to expunge a single word from the letter.
('25', 8, 2, 21, 21847) Young India, 27 10 1921
('25', 9, 0, 1, 21871) 10 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDNI
('25', 9, 1, 2, 21912) 4. HONOUR THE PRINCE
('25', 9, 2, 3, 21933) The reader must not be surprised at the title of this writing.
('25', 9, 2, 4, 21996) Supposing that the Prince was a blood brother in a high place, supposing that he was to be exploited by neighbours for their own base ends, supposing further that he was in the hands of my neighbours, that my voice could not effectively reach him and that he was being brought to my village by the said neighbours, would I not honour him best by dissociating myself from all the ceremonial that might be arranged in his”honour” in the process of exploitation and by letting him know by every means at my disposal that he was being exploited?
('25', 9, 2, 5, 22538) Would I not be a traitor to him if I did not warn him against entering the trap prepared for him by my neighbours?
('25', 9, 2, 6, 22653) I have no manner of doubt that the Prince’s visit is being exploited for advertising the”benign” British rule in India.
('25', 9, 2, 7, 22773) It is a crime against us if His Royal Highness is being brought for personal pleasure and sport when India is seething with discontent when the masses are saturated with disaffection towards the system under which they are governed, when famine is raging in Khulna and the Ceded Districts and when an armed conflict is raging in Malabar; it is a crime against India to spend millions of rupees on a mere show when millions of men are living in a state of chronic starvation.
('25', 9, 2, 8, 23248) Eight lakhs of rupees have been voted away by the Bombay Council alone for the pageant.
('25', 9, 2, 9, 23336) The visit is being heralded by repression in the land.
('25', 9, 2, 10, 23391) In Sind over fifty six non co operators are in jail.
('25', 9, 2, 11, 23444) Some of the bravest of Mussulmans are being tried for holding certain opinions.
('25', 9, 2, 12, 23524) Nineteen Bengal workers have been just imprisoned including Mr. Sengupta, the leading barrister of the place.
('25', 9, 2, 13, 23634) A Mussulman Pir and three other selfless workers are already in jail for a similar”crime”.
('25', 9, 2, 14, 23725) Several leaders of Karnatak are also imprisoned, and now its chief man is on trial for saying what I have said repeatedly in these columns and what Congressmen have been saying all over during the past twelve months.
('25', 9, 2, 15, 23942) Several leaders of the Central Provinces have been similarly deprived of their liberty.
('25', 9, 2, 16, 24030) A most popular doctor, Dr. Paranjapye, a man univer sally respected for his selflessness, is suffering rigorous imprisonment like a common felon.
('25', 9, 2, 17, 24176) I have by no means exhausted the list of imprisonments of non co operators.
('25', 9, 2, 18, 24252) Whether they are a test of real crime or an answer to growing disaffection, the Prince’s visit is, to say the least, most inopportune.
('25', 9, 2, 19, 24387) There is no doubt that the people do not
('25', 10, 0, 1, 24428) VOL. 25 : 27 OCTOBER, 1921 22 JANUARY, 1922 11
('25', 10, 1, 2, 24475) want His Royal Highness to visit India at the present juncture.
('25', 10, 1, 3, 24539) They have expressed their opinion in no uncertain terms.
('25', 10, 1, 4, 24596) They have declared that Bombay should observe hartal on the day of his landing at Bombay.
('25', 10, 1, 5, 24686) It is a clear imposition upon the people to bring the Prince in the teeth of their opposition.
('25', 10, 2, 6, 24781) What are we to do in the circumstances?
('25', 10, 2, 7, 24821) We must organize a complete boycott of all functions held in the Prince’s honour.
('25', 10, 2, 8, 24903) We must religiously refrain from attending charities, fetes or fireworks organized for the purpose.
('25', 10, 2, 9, 25003) We must refuse to illuminate or to send our children to see the organized illuminations.
('25', 10, 2, 10, 25092) To this end we must publish leaflets by the million and distribute them amongst the people telling them what their duty in the matter is and it would be true honour done to the Prince if Bombay on the day of his landing wears the appearance of a deserted city.
('25', 10, 3, 11, 25353) But we must isolate the Prince from the person.
('25', 10, 3, 12, 25401) We have no ill will against the Prince as man.
('25', 10, 3, 13, 25448) He probably knows nothing of the feeling in India, he probably knows nothing about repression.
('25', 10, 3, 14, 25543) Equally probably he is ignorant of the fact that the Punjab wound is still bleeding, that the treachery towards India in the matter of the Khilafat is still rankling in every Indian breast, and that on the Government’s own admission the reformed councils contain members who, though nominally elected, do not in any sense represent even the few lakhs who are on the electoral rolls.
('25', 10, 3, 15, 25926) To do or to attempt to do any harm to the person of the Prince would be not only cruel and inhuman, but it would be on our part a piece of treachery towards ourselves and him, for we have voluntarily pledged ourselves to be and remain non violent.
('25', 10, 3, 16, 26174) Any injury or insult to the Prince by us will be a greater wrong done by us to Islam and India than any the English have done.
('25', 10, 3, 17, 26301) They know no better.
('25', 10, 3, 18, 26322) We can lay no such claim to ignorance, we have with our eyes open and before God and man promised not to hurt a single individual in any way connected with the system we are straining every nerve to destroy.
('25', 10, 3, 19, 26530) It must therefore be our duty to take every precaution to protect his person as our own from all harm.
('25', 10, 4, 20, 26633) In spite of all our effort, we know that there will be some who would want to take part in the various functions from fear or hope or choice.
('25', 10, 4, 21, 26775) They have as much right to do what they like as we have to do what we like.
('25', 10, 4, 22, 26851) That is the test of the freedom we wish to have and enjoy.
('25', 10, 4, 23, 26910) Let us, whilst we are being subjected by an insolent bureau cracy to a severe irritation, exercise the greatest restraint.
('25', 10, 4, 24, 27033) And if we
('25', 11, 0, 1, 27043) 12 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDNI
('25', 11, 1, 2, 27084) can exhibit our firm resolve to have nothing to do with it by disso ciating ourselves from its pageant at the same time that we show forbearance towards those who differ from us, we would advance our cause in a most effective manner.
('25', 11, 2, 3, 27318) Young India, 27 10 1921
('25', 11, 3, 4, 27342) 5. THE SECRET OF IT
('25', 11, 4, 5, 27362) There is no doubt that non co operation is an education which is developing and crystallizing public opinion.
('25', 11, 4, 6, 27472) And as soon as it is organized enough for effective action, we have swaraj.
('25', 11, 4, 7, 27548) We cannot organize public opinion in a violent atmosphere.
('25', 11, 4, 8, 27607) Just as those who have been forced by the Moplahs to recite the kalma are no Mussulmans, even so those who call themselves non co operators from fashion or compulsion are no non co operators.
('25', 11, 4, 9, 27799) They are a hindrance and no help.
('25', 11, 4, 10, 27833) Our tyranny, if we impose our will on others, will be infinitely worse than that of the handful of Englishmen who form the bureaucracy.
('25', 11, 4, 11, 27969) Theirs is a terrorism imposed by a minority struggling to exist in the midst of opposition.
('25', 11, 4, 12, 28061) Ours will be a terrorism imposed by a majority and therefore worse and really more godless than the first.
('25', 11, 4, 13, 28168) We must therefore eliminate compulsion in any shape from our struggle.
('25', 11, 4, 14, 28239) If we are only a handful holding freely the doctrine of non co operation, we may have to die in the attempt to convert others to our view, but we shall have truly defended and represented our cause.
('25', 11, 4, 15, 28438) If however we enlist under our banner men by force, we shall be denying our cause and God, and if we seem to succeed for the moment, we shall have succeeded in establishing a worse terror.
('25', 11, 5, 16, 28627) We shall also retard our cause if we suppress opinion by intolerance.
('25', 11, 5, 17, 28697) For then we shall never know who is with us and who is against us.
('25', 11, 5, 18, 28764) The indispensable condition therefore of success is that we encourage the greatest freedom of opinion.
('25', 11, 5, 19, 28867) It is the least we can learn from the present”masters”.
('25', 11, 5, 20, 28923) Their Penal Code contains drastic punishments for holding opinions they do not like.
('25', 11, 5, 21, 29008) And they have arrested some of the noblest of our countrymen for expression of their opinion.
('25', 11, 5, 22, 29102) Our non co operation is a defiantly open protest against that system.
('25', 11, 5, 23, 29172) We may not in the very act of fighting the restraint on opinion be guilty ourselves of imposing it on others.
('25', 11, 5, 24, 29282) These reflections are due to a sense of uneasiness I feel about
('25', 12, 0, 1, 29346) VOL. 25 : 27 OCTOBER, 1921 22 JANUARY, 1922 13
('25', 12, 1, 2, 29393) publishing the names of correspondents who express opinions we may not relish.
('25', 12, 1, 3, 29472) I do not wish to expose them to the mental violence of the readers who may not like those opinions.
('25', 12, 1, 4, 29572) We must have the courage and the charity to hear or read all sorts of nasty things said about us or to us.
('25', 12, 1, 5, 29679) It gives us an opportunity of converting them.
('25', 12, 1, 6, 29726) I propose to make the attempt in respect of a correspondent who has sent me a formidable list of questions about the struggle which deserve public notice.
('25', 12, 1, 7, 29881) He commences thus:
('25', 12, 2, 8, 29900) You will admit that both your followers and non followers are in a state of suspense as regards the aims of your political activities.
('25', 12, 2, 9, 30035) Can you therefore be charitable enough to enlighten them by answering the following questions?
('25', 12, 3, 10, 30130) 1. Are you really a Mahatma?
('25', 12, 3, 11, 30159) I do not feel like being one.
('25', 12, 3, 12, 30189) But I do know that I am among the humblest of God’s creatures.
('25', 12, 4, 13, 30252) 2. If so, will you define the word Mahatma?
('25', 12, 4, 14, 30296) Not being acquainted with one, I cannot give any definition.
('25', 12, 5, 15, 30357) 3. If not, did you ever tell your followers that you are not one?
('25', 12, 5, 16, 30423) The more I repudiate, the more it is used.
('25', 12, 6, 17, 30466) 4. Is your”soul force” attainable by the ignorant masses?
('25', 12, 6, 18, 30524) They have it already in abundance.
('25', 12, 6, 19, 30559) Once upon a time an expedition of French scientists set out in search of knowledge and in due course reached India.
('25', 12, 6, 20, 30675) They tried hard to find it, as, they had expected, among the learned ones but failed.
('25', 12, 6, 21, 30761) Unexpectedly they found it in a pariah home.
('25', 12, 7, 22, 30806) 5. You say, machinery has been the bane of civilization.
('25', 12, 7, 23, 30863) Then why do you allow yourself to travel in railway trains and motor cars?
('25', 12, 7, 24, 30938) There are certain things which you cannot escape all at once, even whilst you are avoiding them.
('25', 12, 7, 25, 31035) This earthy case in which I am locked up is the bane of my life, but I am obliged to put up with it and even indulge in it as this friend knows.
('25', 12, 7, 26, 31180) But does he seriously doubt that the machine age was responsible for the organized murders during the late war?
('25', 12, 7, 27, 31292) Asphyxiating gas and such other abominations have not advanced us by an inch.
('25', 12, 8, 28, 31370) 6. Is it a fact that formerly you travelled third class in railway trains and now you travel in special trains and first class carriages?
('25', 12, 8, 29, 31508) the correspondent is correctly informed.
('25', 12, 8, 30, 31549) The Mahatma ship is responsible for the special trains, and the earthy case for the degradation to the second class.
('25', 13, 0, 1, 31666) 14 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDNI
('25', 13, 1, 2, 31707) 7. In what relation do you stand to Count Tolstoy?
('25', 13, 1, 3, 31758) As a devoted admirer who owes much in life to him.
('25', 13, 2, 4, 31809) 8. Why do you not define swaraj?
('25', 13, 2, 5, 31842) Do you not feel that you are in duty bound to define the word at least to your followers?
('25', 13, 2, 6, 31932) In the first place the word is indefinable in the second place, if the correspondent will turn to the file of Young India, he will find a workable definition there.
('25', 13, 2, 7, 32097) I will try another here.
('25', 13, 2, 8, 32122) It means complete freedom of opinion and action without interference with another’s right to equal freedom of opinion and action.
('25', 13, 2, 9, 32252) Therefore it means India’s complete control of sources of revenue and expenditure without interference from or with any other country.
('25', 13, 3, 10, 32387) 9. What will be your own position when swaraj is obtained?, I would certainly like a prolonged and perhaps well deserved holiday.
('25', 13, 4, 11, 32517) 10. When swaraj is attained, how are the political and religious interests of Mussulmans to be safeguarded?
('25', 13, 4, 12, 32625) They will not need any safeguarding, because every Indian will be as free as every other Indian, and because there will then be mutual toleration, respect and love, and therefore mutual trust.
('25', 13, 5, 13, 32818) 11. Do you honestly believe that Government will pack up and beat a hasty retreat from India on the 31st of October 1921 or at any other time within this year that you will be pleased to fix?
('25', 13, 5, 14, 33010) The Government is the system, and I do believe that it can be destroyed even before the 31st October, if the Hindus, the Mussulmans, the Sikhs, the Parsis, the Christians and the Jews of India will.
('25', 13, 5, 15, 33209) I am still hoping that they will destroy it before the end of the year.
('25', 13, 5, 16, 33281) But under the new system not a single Englishman who wishes to remain in India as her faithful servant need leave the country.
('25', 13, 6, 17, 33408) 12. Do you not think that the Government is too weak to check your propaganda?
('25', 13, 6, 18, 33487) I certainly do, and it is becoming daily weaker.
('25', 13, 7, 19, 33536) 13. Would you leave your own son undefended if (which God forbid) he was being prosecuted for murder, not for sedition?
('25', 13, 7, 20, 33656) I really believe that I have the courage to do so.
('25', 13, 7, 21, 33707) I certainly had the hardihood to give that advice to many a dear friend.
('25', 13, 7, 22, 33780) I have already advised a dear friend of the Andhra district to stake the whole of his valuable property by not defending a civil suit which has been brought against him from pure political malice.
('25', 14, 0, 1, 33977) VOL. 25 : 27 OCTOBER, 1921 22 JANUARY, 1922 15
('25', 14, 1, 2, 34024) 14. What should your son (for example) do if some one defrauded him of some money and had made himself scarce?
('25', 14, 1, 3, 34135) My son if he is a good non co operator would certainly let the thief keep the money.
('25', 14, 1, 4, 34220) Maulana Shaukat Ali was robbed of Rs. 600 nine months ago.
('25', 14, 1, 5, 34279) He knew the person who had robbed him.
('25', 14, 1, 6, 34318) He thought no more about it.
('25', 14, 2, 7, 34347) 15. What was the effect of your satyagraha on the Punjab?
('25', 14, 2, 8, 34405) Sir Michael O’Dwyer would not let the message of satyagraha reach the Punjab.
('25', 14, 2, 9, 34483) Some Punjabis therefore got excited; a few went mad.
('25', 14, 2, 10, 34536) Sir Michael O’Dwyer became madder still and butchered innocent men by deputy.
('25', 14, 2, 11, 34614) But satyagraha is a powerful tonic, and now the Punjab is as lively as any other province of India, and is showing in spite of her mercurial population a degree of self restraint that is worthy of emulation by the rest of the provinces.
('25', 14, 3, 12, 34851) 16. Do you really believe that non co operation Call remain non violent?
('25', 14, 3, 13, 34924) Certainly.
('25', 14, 3, 14, 34935) The wonderful restraint shown by the people over the arrests in Sind, Karnatak and East Bengal is proof of it.
('25', 14, 4, 15, 35046) 17. How do the forcible conversions of Hindus and pillage of Hindu homes reflect upon the unity of Hindus and Mohammedans in India?
('25', 14, 4, 16, 35178) They have put a severe strain upon Hindu patience, but it has stood the strain and its survival proves that the unity is based on knowledge.
('25', 14, 4, 17, 35319) No Mussulman approves of the Moplah fanaticism.
('25', 14, 5, 18, 35367) 18. What is the actual cause of this rupture of Hindu Muslim unity in Malabar?
('25', 14, 5, 19, 35446) There is no rupture of the unity in the disturbed area.
('25', 14, 5, 20, 35502) The Moplahs could not at any time have considered Hindus as their brethren.
('25', 14, 5, 21, 35578) The causes of the violence are that as in the Punjab in 1919, so in Malabar now the message of non co operation was only vaguely delivered when its progress was arrested by the authorities.
('25', 14, 5, 22, 35768) The Moplahs were never particularly friendly to the Malabar Hindus.
('25', 14, 5, 23, 35836) They had looted them before.
('25', 14, 5, 24, 35865) Their notions of Islam were of a very crude type.
('25', 14, 5, 25, 35915) They were kept in utter darkness by the Government and neglected both by Mussulmans and Hindus.
('25', 14, 5, 26, 36011) Being wild and brave but ignorant, they have mistaken the mission of the Khilafat and acted in a savage, inhuman and irreligious manner.
('25', 14, 5, 27, 36148) It is quite improper to judge Islam or the Mussulmans of the rest of India by the present conduct of the Moplahs.
('25', 14, 6, 28, 36262) 19. Can you say what made you to couple the Khilafat with the Punjab wrongs?
('25', 14, 6, 29, 36339) The Khilafat wrong was born before the Punjab wrong, and I
('25', 15, 0, 1, 36398) 16 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDNI
('25', 15, 1, 2, 36439) made it my own in the year 1918 at the Delhi War Conference (vide my open letter to the Viceroy) 1. Non co operation was conceived at Delhi in 1919 before the Punjab wrong had taken definite shape.
('25', 15, 1, 3, 36637) The latter was tacked to the Khilafat, when it became clear that it required as drastic a remedy as the Khilafat.
('25', 15, 2, 4, 36751) 20. Can you say why the Mohammedans of India are so demonstrative for the Khilafat, when the Mohammedans of other Islamic countries do not seem to care for it?
('25', 15, 2, 5, 36911) I do not know that non Indian Mussulmans do not care for the Khilafat, but if they do not and the Indian Mussulmans do, for me it is proof enough that the latter have developed greater religious consciousness than the former.
('25', 15, 3, 6, 37137) 21. Since the Sultan of Turkey has failed to defend the Muslim holy places, has he any right now to be considered a Khalifa?
('25', 15, 3, 7, 37262) This is hardly a question for a Hindu to answer.
('25', 15, 3, 8, 37311) But if I may venture a reply, the Khilafat rests in the Turks by right of valiant defence for hundreds of years.
('25', 15, 3, 9, 37424) The Sultan may have failed, the Turks have not.
('25', 15, 3, 10, 37472) The Khilafat agitation does not centre round an individual but round an idea, which is at once temporal, spiritual and political.
('25', 15, 3, 11, 37602) If the Turks cannot defend, if the Mussulmans of the world do not by their power of opinion and active sympathy stand by the Turks, both they and the latter will suffer irretrievably.
('25', 15, 3, 12, 37786) Such an event will be a calamity for the world, for I believe that Islam has its place in the world as much as Christianity and every other religion.
('25', 15, 3, 13, 37936) Chivalry demands the support of the Turks in the hour of their need.
('25', 15, 4, 14, 38005) 22. Is the economic law that man must buy in the best and the cheapest .
('25', 15, 4, 15, 38078) market wrong?
('25', 15, 4, 16, 38092) It is one of the most inhuman among the maxims laid down by modern economists.
('25', 15, 4, 17, 38171) Nor do we always regulate human relations by any such sordid considerations.
('25', 15, 4, 18, 38248) An Englishman pays more (and rightly) for the English collier in preference to cheap (say) Italian labour.
('25', 15, 4, 19, 38355) Any attempt to introduce cheap labour into England will lead to a revolution.
('25', 15, 4, 20, 38433) It would be sinful for me to dismiss a highly paid faithful servant because I can get a more efficient and cheaper servant although the latter may be equally faithful.
('25', 15, 4, 21, 38601) The economics that disregard moral and sentimental considerations are like wax works that being life like still lack the life of the living flesh.
('25', 15, 4, 22, 38748) At every crucial

('25', 16, 1, 2, 38850) moment these new fangled economic laws have broken down in practice.
('25', 16, 1, 3, 38919) And nations or individuals who accept them as guiding maxims must perish.

('25', 16, 2, 7, 39395) 23. Is picketing non violent?

('25', 16, 2, 9, 39490) It was the easiest thing to resort to violence in picketing, but the volunteers all over have exercised great restraint.
('25', 16, 3, 10, 39611) 24. Do you explain the beauty (spiritual or otherwise) of bonfires, when many people are going half naked in the country and are shivering at the thought of the coming winter?
('25', 16, 3, 11, 39787) I do; for I know that their half nakedness is due to our criminal neglect of the fundamental law of life in India that she should wear only hand spun just as she must eat only home cooked food.
('25', 16, 3, 12, 39981) My giving my discarded foreign clothes to them will only prolong the agony.
('25', 16, 3, 13, 40057) But the warmth generated by the bonfires will last for the coming winter, and if the bonfires are kept up till the last piece is burnt, the warmth will last for ever, and each successive winter will see the nation more and more invigorated,

('25', 16, 5, 15, 40322) 6. UNTOUCHABILITY IN HINDU SHASTRAS

('25', 18, 1, 2, 42916) 8. SPEECH ON SWADESHI, AHMEDABAD
('25', 18, 2, 3, 42949) October 29, 1921
('25', 18, 3, 4, 42966) BROTHERS AND SISTERS, I do not have a single word to say now.
('25', 18, 3, 5, 43028) I cannot think of one, even if I try hard.
('25', 18, 3, 6, 43071) My present mental condition does not permit me to make a speech anywhere or to take part in a procession.
('25', 18, 3, 7, 43177) In any case, why should I have to make speeches or take part in processions in Bombay, Ahmedabad or Gujarat?
('25', 18, 3, 8, 43286) The work should be carried on as if I was not present in Gujarat.
('25', 18, 3, 9, 43352) If I have still to rouse Gujarat through my exhortations, then I must admit that we shall not get swaraj this year.
('25', 18, 3, 10, 43468) The very meaning of swaraj is that Gujarat should be ready to stand on its own feet and even forget me.
('25', 18, 3, 11, 43572) Young and old, all should show such fearlessness that, even if the best and the most important men fall or are imprisoned, people will remain undaunted and say that the struggle started by Gandhi is now, theirs, that, if Gandhi has gone mad and lost his head, they will not follow his example.
('25', 18, 3, 12, 43866) When we have this temper, it will be swaraj.
('25', 18, 3, 13, 43911) When I was invited to come here, I asked them to consult Vallabhbhai.
('25', 18, 3, 14, 43981) I follow the wishes of that leader.
('25', 18, 3, 15, 44017) The leader who has been shaking the whole of Gujarat knows best whether or not I should speak here.
('25', 18, 3, 16, 44117) I can never do anything in disregard of his wishes.
('25', 18, 3, 17, 44169) I can offer him advice and make suggestions, but I cannot do anything against his wishes.
('25', 18, 3, 18, 44259) Not to trust anyone, in the first instance, is a sign of wisdom.
('25', 18, 3, 19, 44324) But having trusted a person, one must trust one’s head to his judgment.
('25', 18, 3, 20, 44396) It will not then do to find fault with him over every little matter.
('25', 18, 3, 21, 44465) What else may I tell you today?
('25', 18, 3, 22, 44497) Whatever I had to say I have told you already.
('25', 18, 3, 23, 44544) I like to light an oven.
('25', 18, 3, 24, 44569) If I am asked to apply the match stick to any oven, I would do it only too readily.
('25', 18, 3, 25, 44653) I am a believer in non violence.
('25', 18, 3, 26, 44686) There is non violence and love in every fibre of my being.
('25', 18, 3, 27, 44745) I have no desire to harm anyone; I have never wished ill to anybody; I have never thought of killing anyone.

('25', 23, 4, 7, 54914) 10. HOW STRONG?
('25', 23, 5, 8, 54930) How strong the municipalities of Ahmedabad, Nadiad and Surat are should be known in a few days.
('25', 23, 5, 9, 55026) All the three have rejected Government control over their education departments and have been growing from strength to strength till this day.
('25', 23, 5, 10, 55169) It is said that now the Government has decided to test them.
('25', 23, 5, 11, 55230) Its note is in the nature of a threat [to the municipalities] and incitement to ratepayers.
('25', 23, 5, 12, 55322) It says that those who supported the resolution to free education [from Government control] have rendered themselves liable to prosecution by any ratepayer.
('25', 23, 5, 13, 55479) We know the motive behind this suggestion.
('25', 23, 5, 14, 55522) The Government’s second step now is likely to be to get some ratepayer to sue one of the councillors.
('25', 23, 5, 15, 55624) I trust that the Government will find no ratepayer to sue a councillor who has acted out of a sense of duty and I also trust that, if tiny such ratepayer comes forward, the councillor will remain fearless.
('25', 23, 5, 16, 55830) If we do not develop the strength to brave such risks, how can we claim to be fit for swaraj?
('25', 23, 5, 17, 55924) Another thing the Government can do is to suspend the munici palities and to carry on the administration of the cities itself by appointing committees.
('25', 23, 5, 18, 56076) This is the utmost it can do.
('25', 23, 5, 19, 56106) If it does that, I see in the situation the possibility of our winning swaraj.
('25', 23, 5, 20, 56185) If the Government acts in this manner and if we are ready, we shall get the battle we wanted; how can a battle coming thus unexpectedly fail to please a warrior?
('25', 23, 5, 21, 56347) As a drowning man clutches at a straw, the Government catches hold of whatever comes to hand and sinks the deeper.
('25', 23, 5, 22, 56462) Are we ready?
('25', 23, 5, 23, 56476) If the residents of the three cities are ready, the Government is bound to beat a retreat.
('25', 23, 5, 24, 56567) It will certainly be ridiculous of the Government to get someone to file a suit.
('25', 23, 5, 25, 56648) The second step is to supersede the municipalities.
('25', 23, 5, 26, 56700) It is a step which should be welcomed.
('25', 23, 5, 27, 56739) So long as the municipalities are not superseded, power will remain in the hands of the councillors themselves.
('25', 23, 5, 28, 56851) When they are superseded,
('25', 24, 0, 1, 56877) VOL. 25 : 27 OCTOBER, 1921 22 JANUARY, 1922 25
('25', 24, 1, 2, 56924) power will certainly not pass into the Government’s hands but it will be in the hands of the people.
('25', 24, 1, 3, 57025) This is the meaning of civic power.
('25', 24, 1, 4, 57061) The power which the councillors have has been given to them by the citizens, not by the Government.
('25', 24, 1, 5, 57161) As long as the citizens had not awakened, they counted for little with the officials and the councillors.
('25', 24, 1, 6, 57267) They could make the former dance as they pleased.
('25', 24, 1, 7, 57317) Now times have changed.
('25', 24, 1, 8, 57341) The citizens have ceased to be puppets, they have become, or should become, actors in a drama.

('25', 24, 1, 10, 57523) Do the citizens have this degree of awakening among them?
('25', 24, 1, 11, 57581) Are the councillors really and in truth the voice of the citizens?
('25', 24, 1, 12, 57648) This will be known now.
('25', 24, 1, 13, 57672) The councillors should explain the Government note fully to the citizens and make them understand their duty.

('25', 24, 1, 18, 58220) Ours is a fight with truth as a weapon, so that neither will the Government succeed if it resorts to fraud nor we if we are guilty of hypocrisy.
('25', 24, 1, 19, 58365) If the citizens have really acquired consciousness, no one can deprive them of it.
('25', 24, 1, 20, 58448) If they have not, the councillors cannot create it.

('25', 24, 1, 22, 58692) The Govern ment’s strength lies in our weakness.

('25', 24, 1, 24, 59014) They should know with their minds whom to trust and, through their hearts, that happiness can only follow suffering; should know with their minds and their hearts that, just as our dealings in the family should be pure, so also must our social conduct be pure; this means that, as our homes should be clean,
('25', 25, 0, 1, 59322) 26 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDNI
('25', 25, 1, 2, 59363) so our streets and our towns should be clean; as the home should be free from strife, so should society be free from it and, as we would be ready to lay down our lives for the family, so should we be ready to lay it down for society; they should know, as following from all this, that, if the relationship between the king and his subjects becomes vitiated, that is, becomes a relationship between the privileged and the unprivileged, between the employer and the employee, or between master and slave, we should have no more to do with that king, with that system of government.

('25', 25, 4, 6, 60049) 11. UNDERSTANDING AS DISTINCT FROM LITERACY
('25', 25, 5, 7, 60093) My plight is beyond description.
('25', 25, 5, 8, 60126) A Garasia 1 friend of the Gohel class wrote a letter to me on 12th April, which I have kept aside all these days.
('25', 25, 5, 9, 60240) It was not written for publication, but discusses suggestions for action by me.
('25', 25, 5, 10, 60320) It has been travelling all along with me.
('25', 25, 5, 11, 60362) Every week I take it up and put it away hoping to deal with it later on.
('25', 25, 5, 12, 60435) The letter is written in a beautiful and legible handwriting, but is rather long.
('25', 25, 5, 13, 60517) Anyone who writes a letter of nine pages to me can hardly expect me to read and think over it.
('25', 25, 5, 14, 60612) It is because I liked the opening sentences that I preserved the letter, and I have now been able to read the whole of it.
('25', 25, 5, 15, 60735) I should like this gentleman and others who may write to me to understand my position.
('25', 25, 5, 16, 60822) They should bear in mind that, as a rule, one who expresses all his ideas in a clear hand on a single page will receive an early reply.
('25', 25, 5, 17, 60958) If the best of ideas have been expressed in a single sentence; why cannot we state in one sentence what we want?
('25', 25, 5, 18, 61071) As we go ahead with our work, we shall realize that we can carry on public work with the fewest words.
('25', 25, 5, 19, 61174) I have nowhere come across such compressed language as the”military” language of the British.
('25', 25, 5, 20, 61268) I have seen orders being given in a single word.
('25', 25, 5, 21, 61317) Even words are abbreviated.
('25', 25, 5, 22, 61345) There are strong reasons for this.
('25', 25, 5, 23, 61380) Where action is required, the maze of words is cut down to a minimum.

('25', 27, 1, 2, 64106) against a big force and could carry death in their pockets, so to say.

('25', 27, 2, 8, 64912) His dharma is to die, and not to run away.

('25', 27, 2, 12, 65190) What should an unarmed Kathi youth do against a giant who is armed from head to foot and protected by armour?
('25', 27, 2, 13, 65300) Will he let a poor girl fall into the latter’s hands or will he lay down his life before the giant, trusting the girl to God’s protection, and thus teach her too a lesson in unarmed courage?

('25', 27, 3, 22, 66311) As long as India is in bondage, a true Kshatriya can neither sleep nor rest in peace nor enjoy wearing good clothes.

('25', 28, 3, 11, 67082) 12. MY NOTES
('25', 28, 4, 12, 67095) MESSAGE TO THE”DHEDS”
('25', 28, 5, 13, 67117) A leaflet in Gujarati under this heading has been distributed by the Government among our Dhed brothers.
('25', 28, 5, 14, 67222) The leaflet says that a rumour is current to the effect that the houses of those Dheds who do not join non co operation will be burnt down and that the Government will not protect them.
('25', 28, 5, 15, 67408) The message states that these rumours are false, and that”measures are being taken for the progress of all sections of the people, without any distinctions”.
('25', 28, 6, 16, 67566) If anyone has threatened our Dhed brothers or burnt the house of any of them, then he cannot be called a non co operator, or a Hindu or even an Indian.
('25', 28, 6, 17, 67718) I simply cannot believe that such a threat has been held out by anyone.
('25', 28, 6, 18, 67790) If it has been held out, however, what protection can the Government offer the Dhed brothers?
('25', 28, 6, 19, 67884) What protection has it given in the past?
('25', 28, 6, 20, 67926) How has the Government been able to protect Dheds when rude Hindus abuse them in trains?
('25', 28, 6, 21, 68015) What protection does it give to those who, on their identity being discovered in offices, are harassed by the officers themselves, and to those who are without wells, houses and schools?
('25', 28, 6, 22, 68202) I should indeed like to know what the Government has done to improve their condition.
('25', 28, 7, 23, 68288) Yes, the Government has certainly done one thing.
('25', 28, 7, 24, 68338) There is no doubt that it has got much forced work out of them, taught some of them to eat beef and encouraged them in their vices.
('25', 28, 7, 25, 68470) Their moralcondition has not been improved one bit.
('25', 28, 7, 26, 68522) Permission has, of course, now been given for a meeting of theirs to be held in the Town Hall.
('25', 28, 7, 27, 68617) The meeting is for honouring the Prince.
('25', 28, 7, 28, 68658) This serves the
('25', 29, 0, 1, 68674) 30 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDNI
('25', 29, 1, 2, 68715) Government’s own interest.
('25', 29, 1, 3, 68742) So far as I know, this is the first time that a meeting of Antyajas is to take place in the Town Hall in Bombay.
('25', 29, 1, 4, 68855) This is nothing but flattery or bribing.
('25', 29, 1, 5, 68896) Moreover, the Government will readily welcome anyone who may want to join in honouring the Prince.
('25', 29, 1, 6, 68995) By acting thus, it is insulting the innocent Prince of Wales and using him to serve its own interest.
('25', 29, 1, 7, 69097) If the poor man knew how he is to be honoured, it is doubtful whether he would come to India at this time; if, nevertheless, he did come, it would speak no end for the British people’s sense of discipline.
('25', 29, 1, 8, 69303) At the call of duty, both the King and his subjects would be ready to make any sacrifices.
('25', 29, 1, 9, 69394) If the sacrifice was not for base self interest those who made them would be fit for moksha.
('25', 29, 1, 10, 69487) But my purpose is more to point out to the Hindus their duty than to dwell on the shortcomings of the Government or of the British.
('25', 29, 1, 11, 69619) It is because the Hindus have not understood their dharma that we see attempts being made to lure our Dhed brothers with indu cements.
('25', 29, 1, 12, 69754) I visualize endless occasions of quarrelling in these attempts to drag them to opposite sides.
('25', 29, 1, 13, 69849) Hence these two developments, the Government’s message and the Town Hall meeting, hold a lesson both for the Antyajas and the others.
('25', 29, 1, 14, 69983) The former should not allow themselves to be deceived by the message or the meeting in the Town Hall.
('25', 29, 1, 15, 70085) Let them fight the Hindus in a civilized way for what they consider their rights, respect the rules of Hindu society, give up eating meat, etc., especially beef, clean themselves physically after doing sanitary work, give up dissoluteness and so clean their hearts as well.
('25', 29, 1, 16, 70359) Other Hindus should show regard for the Antyajas, admit them in Congress committees, understand their hardships, defend them if they are molested by anyone, look upon them as their own brothers and get rid of the notion that contact with them is sinful.
('25', 29, 1, 17, 70613) However, a thoughtful and considerate Hindu told me in the course of a conversation that, according to the Hindu religion, touch, even the vibrations emanating from prana 1, have an effect on the other person and it is, therefore, considered advisable that one should stay away from such people.
('25', 29, 1, 18, 70909) He added:”It is because the Hindus knew about such intangible effects and guarded themselves against them that they have survived for thousands of years and have been able to compose wonderful Shastras.” Stated thus, the idea is true.
('25', 29, 1, 19, 71144) Contact with dirt—association with
('25', 29, 2, 20, 71179) 1 Life force
('25', 30, 0, 1, 71192) VOL. 25 : 27 OCTOBER, 1921 22 JANUARY, 1922 31
('25', 30, 1, 2, 71239) the wicked—defiles us while the company of the good cleanses us.
('25', 30, 1, 3, 71304) But all this is not said in the Shastras to foster contempt or teach exclusiveness.
('25', 30, 1, 4, 71388) It is said to persuade people to live in solitude and exercise self control, and refers not to contact with Antyajas but to contact with all human beings.
('25', 30, 1, 5, 71543) We have to purify ourselves inwardly and we can do this better by serving our Antyaja brothers and improving their lot.
('25', 30, 1, 6, 71663) We put our hands even into gutters in order to clean them, and are none the worse for contact with their contents.
('25', 30, 1, 7, 71778) If, moreover, we always think of others’ evils and keep away from everyone, we should become utter hypocrites because, when we dwell on others’ evils, we regard ourselves as so perfect that we think we have nothing to set right.
('25', 30, 1, 8, 72007) In other words, we become the lowest of the low.
('25', 30, 1, 9, 72056) The Dheds and the Bhangis are within ourselves.
('25', 30, 1, 10, 72104) We need to rid ourselves of them, take a bath on coming into contact with them.
('25', 30, 1, 11, 72184) Many of the Dheds and Bhangis outside of us, though engaged in sanitary work, are so simple, so good and upright that they deserve reverence.
('25', 30, 1, 12, 72326) The Dheds and Bhangis have no monopoly of vice nor have the other communities of virtue.
('25', 30, 1, 13, 72415) We should, therefore, take care lest, failing to understand the meaning of certain statements in the Hindu Shastras and some of their ideas, we stick to their letter and fall.
('25', 30, 2, 14, 72591) SWADESHI AND”BRAHMACHARYA”
('25', 30, 3, 15, 72618) A friend writes to say that while swadeshi is gathering momentum in the country, there is no advance in regard to brahmacharya.
('25', 30, 3, 16, 72746) How will swaraj be achieved so long as men and women do not hold their minds under control?
('25', 30, 3, 17, 72838) This seems a fine idea, but there is no necessary relation between the two things.
('25', 30, 3, 18, 72921) Swadeshi and brahmacharya are two distinct matters.
('25', 30, 3, 19, 72973) Khadi is sacred as compared to foreign cloth.
('25', 30, 3, 20, 73019) The wheat from Charotar is sacred as compared to American wheat.
('25', 30, 3, 21, 73084) But just as one who eats wheat from Charotar may yet be wicked and sensual, so may also be a person who wears khadi.
('25', 30, 3, 22, 73201) Therefore, by attributing greater sanctity to khadi or swadeshi we shall only be harming ourselves.
('25', 30, 3, 23, 73301) It would not be possible to propagate swadeshi at all if khadi dress came to be regarded as the means to perfection.
('25', 30, 3, 24, 73418) The good and the wicked, the healthy and the sick, the righteous and the sinful— all should purify themselves at least to the extent of adopting khadi.
('25', 30, 3, 25, 73570) There is patriotism in it, and it comprehends the duty of compassion and friendship towards one’s countrymen and one’s neighbours.
('25', 30, 3, 26, 73701) Hence I regard wearing of khadi also as a form of self purification.
('25', 30, 3, 27, 73770) If crores of people achieve even this little measure of self purification, the sum total of the merit
('25', 31, 0, 1, 73872) 32 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDNI
('25', 31, 1, 2, 73913) earned thereby would be so high that we would regain that birthright of ours which we have lost.
('25', 31, 1, 3, 74010) At present, we are striving for government by ourselves, whether perfect or imperfect.
('25', 31, 1, 4, 74097) For this, swadeshi is essential and sufficient.
('25', 31, 1, 5, 74145) Only a few will observe brahmacharya, though we wish that all should.
('25', 31, 1, 6, 74215) If everyone observed it, we would gain the kingdom both of this world and the other.
('25', 31, 1, 7, 74300) It is part of our dharma to observe it but, by linking it up with swadeshi, we make the latter, which is easy to follow, as difficult as brahmacharya.
('25', 31, 1, 8, 74451) Having thus seen and explained the difference between the two, I would certainly add that every worker whether man or woman, should observe brahmacharya till we have won swaraj.
('25', 31, 1, 9, 74629) We, workers, are so few in number and, on reflection we shall find that we are so poor, too, that we have neither the time for begetting children nor the means of bringing them up.
('25', 31, 1, 10, 74810) Who would benefit by children being born to a diseased person?
('25', 31, 1, 11, 74873) What an immoral thing it would be for a consumptive to beget children?
('25', 31, 1, 12, 74944) If this is so, what are we to say about slaves?
('25', 31, 1, 13, 74992) The great tragedy is that, while thinking of the gratification of our desires, we do not think at all about the offspring.
('25', 31, 1, 14, 75115) We are such slaves to our desires that we have lost all good sense.
('25', 31, 1, 15, 75183) The birth of children is the accidental result of our indulgence, and not the desired, worthy and sacred fruit of a man of self control having done his duty as a householder to limited extent only.
('25', 31, 1, 16, 75381) Very often it is an unwanted and painful fruit.
('25', 31, 1, 17, 75429) I am certain that those dedicated persons at any rate who are engrossed in the service of the people cannot possibly desire sex pleasure.
('25', 31, 1, 18, 75567) How can they spare time for it, either?
('25', 31, 1, 19, 75607) It is in the hope that there will be no such person that I am making my modest offering to this swaraj yajna.
('25', 31, 1, 20, 75717) If the ultimate aim is merely to get power transferred to the people, I am sure I am not so childish as to spend myself in meaningless efforts to secure this toy.
('25', 31, 1, 21, 75880) I indeed believe that those who accept even this outward freedom as their goal for the present and work for it will realize that they will not achieve it till they become truthful, compassionate, brave and fearless, adopt simplicity in their lives and follow swadeshi.
('25', 31, 1, 22, 76149) While making this effort, some at least cannot escape laying their hands on the ratnachintamani 1. I have joined this effort and am ever unperturbed because I know that it will raise the moral level of the nation, and I certainly wish, therefore, that
('25', 31, 2, 23, 76401) 1 A fabulous jewel supposed to have the virtue of fulfilling a wish instantly
('25', 32, 0, 1, 76479) VOL. 25 : 27 OCTOBER, 1921 22 JANUARY, 1922 33
('25', 32, 1, 2, 76526) volunteers, both men and women, will take a pledge to observe brahmacharya till we have won swaraj.
('25', 32, 1, 3, 76626) They should not cheat themselves when taking it, should not take it at my asking.
('25', 32, 1, 4, 76708) They will be able to keep the pledge and it will bear fruit only if it is taken with understanding and determination .
('25', 32, 2, 5, 76827) THE NAMES RAMA AND RAHIM
('25', 32, 3, 6, 76852) Writing to me, a Sikh gentleman says that swadeshi is all right, but I who believe in God, why do I not put the name of God before all else?
('25', 32, 3, 7, 76993) Why do I not ask everyone to pray, repeating the name by which he knows God, Khuda, Ishwar or Rama, whichever it may be?
('25', 32, 3, 8, 77114) It is true that I do not do this.
('25', 32, 3, 9, 77148) I am certain that one cannot attain heaven through mere repetition of words.
('25', 32, 3, 10, 77225) One must be fit for such repetition.
('25', 32, 3, 11, 77262) I believe that, so long as we wear foreign cloth, we are not fit to take the name Ishwar or Allah.
('25', 32, 3, 12, 77361) A man who cuts another’s throat with Rama’s name on his lips profanes that name.
('25', 32, 3, 13, 77442) Likewise, the Indian who, refusing to use the cloth woven by the hands of another Indian, gets his requirements from hundreds of miles away and so cuts the throat of his brother, too is not fit to take the name of God.
('25', 32, 3, 14, 77661) In this connection, I have already pointed out the importance of the spinning wheel.
('25', 32, 3, 15, 77746) Spinning is such restful work that, as we make the hand one with the yarn, we can attune our hearts to God.
('25', 32, 3, 16, 77854) Devotion to God, like brahmacharya, cannot be linked with swadeshi.
('25', 32, 3, 17, 77922) Even a person whose lips do not utter God’s name would, if he follows swadeshi, gain to that extent.
('25', 32, 3, 18, 78023) Even an atheist following swadeshi would benefit himself and the country thereby.
('25', 32, 3, 19, 78105) One who has God ever in his mind and heart will of course do much good to himself and the country.
('25', 32, 3, 20, 78204) Swadeshi is the power which takes us towards God, as it raises us higher.
('25', 32, 3, 21, 78278) I have written all this about the suggestion of this friend in order to make it clear that, if we do not worship God, we cannot look upon our struggle as a holy one.
('25', 32, 3, 22, 78444) We who are fighting to defend our dharma should certainly not forsake God’s name, should ever keep repeating it in the depth of our hearts.
('25', 32, 3, 23, 78584) We should repeat it with each heart beat, that is, unceasingly.
('25', 32, 3, 24, 78648) Swadeshi helps us to do this, but the two ideas do not mean the same thing.
('25', 32, 3, 25, 78724) While swadesh is the dharma attaching to the body, chanting the name of God is a property of the atman.
('25', 32, 4, 26, 78828) “PEOPLE’S FAIR”
('25', 32, 5, 27, 78844) “People’s Fair” means a fair for the people.
('25', 32, 5, 28, 78889) Two Parsi sisters
('25', 33, 0, 1, 78907) 34 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDNI
('25', 33, 1, 2, 78948) write to me to say that a people’s fair is to be held at the time of the Prince of Wales’s visit and some persons believe that people could attend it.
('25', 33, 1, 3, 79099) They say that they can understand the idea of not joining in honouring the Prince, but why should one not attend fairs, fireworks, etc., of which the municipality will bear the cost?
('25', 33, 1, 4, 79282) This argument is not correct for, if expenditure is the only thing to be taken into consideration, the Prince will be honoured at our cost.
('25', 33, 1, 5, 79422) The money which the Government spends is ours.
('25', 33, 1, 6, 79469) Our argument is that we should not attend a function in arranging which we have had no voice, even if the expenses are met with our money.
('25', 33, 1, 7, 79608) If a robber held a feast at our expense, would we attend it?
('25', 33, 1, 8, 79669) Even so, I can see no difference between a party for honouring the Prince and a function for celebrating his visit.
('25', 33, 1, 9, 79785) If we should keep away from one, we should keep away from both.
('25', 33, 2, 10, 79849) INTELLIGENCE AND THE SPINNING WHEEL
('25', 33, 3, 11, 79885) I have been receiving numerous criticisms on a statement made by the Poet in his article 1. It is to the effect that the spinning wheel will curb the mind of the man who plies it.
('25', 33, 3, 12, 80065) I do not wish to publish the criticisms since the Poet’s statement is merely an inference.
('25', 33, 3, 13, 80156) Millions of spinning wheels are in use in the country today.
('25', 33, 3, 14, 80217) I know that among the people who ply the wheel are lawyers, doctors and philosophers from all provinces.
('25', 33, 3, 15, 80322) Suffice it to say that the evidence of their experience is against the Poet’s inference.
('25', 33, 3, 16, 80411) I have questioned hundreds of students and they have not found the spinning wheel to be an enemy of intelligence.
('25', 33, 3, 17, 80525) The experience of doctors and lawyers is similar.
('25', 33, 3, 18, 80575) A well known novelist of Bengal once came to see me merely to tell me his experience.
('25', 33, 3, 19, 80661) He said that he plied the spinning wheel regularly and that, in consequence, his art had improved.
('25', 33, 3, 20, 80760) I do not wish to read too much into all this.
('25', 33, 3, 21, 80806) I only wish to show that the intelligence of the intelligent is sharpened by body labour of any kind and, if the work is beneficial to the people, it becomes sanctified.
('25', 33, 3, 22, 80976) Spinning, being clean, light and pleasant work is the best form of such body labour and is, in the present plight of the country, the wish fulfilling tree of heaven for us.
('25', 33, 4, 23, 81149) “APPEAL TO ISMAILI FIRKA JAMAT’’
('25', 33, 5, 24, 81182) Writing under this heading, Mr. Fidahussain Daudbhai
('25', 33, 6, 25, 81235) 1“The Call of Truth” by Rabindranath Tagore in the October issue of The Modern Review, Calcutta

('25', 34, 1, 2, 81378) Poonawala says that all Muslims, Khojas, Bohras and others owe it as duty to give the fullest co operation in swadeshi; if they do not, they will have to suffer in future.
('25', 34, 1, 3, 81550) This is my belief too.

('25', 34, 1, 6, 81668) I have only mentioned the central idea.
('25', 34, 1, 7, 81708) I have not considered it necessary to publish the whole of it as the other arguments advanced in it are well known.

('25', 34, 3, 10, 81862) 13. LETTER TO MAIN MOHAMMED HAJI JAN MOHAMMED CHOTANI
('25', 34, 4, 11, 81916) October 31, 1921
('25', 34, 5, 12, 81933) DEAR CHOTANI MIAN, I thank you for your letter offering one lakh spinning wheels.
('25', 34, 5, 13, 82015) I am sure that the fact of your very liberal donation will strike the imagination of India and particularly the Mussulmans.
('25', 34, 5, 14, 82139) In forwarding your letter to the Bombay Provincial Congress Committee I shall ask the Secretaries to bear in mind your desire that the members of the Maiman Community should receive preference.
('25', 34, 5, 15, 82333) I do not know whether you have fixed any particular sum in your own mind that you wish to devote for the purpose, for experience teaches me that a cheap spinning wheel in time becomes an expensive wheel.
('25', 34, 5, 16, 82537) A good wheel, substantial and heavy, will not cost less than six rupees.
('25', 34, 5, 17, 82610) If, therefore, you do not want to make so large a donation I would suggest your reducing the number of charkhas.
('25', 34, 5, 18, 82723) And I would also suggest you not using the whole of the amount you may wish to devote so much for spinning as for paying a somewhat higher rate to the poor women for the yarn that they might spin and for engaging a special staff for doing the work.
('25', 34, 5, 19, 82972) This will enable you to use your donation practically under your supervision and in the most economical manner as is being done in Kathiawar.
('25', 34, 5, 20, 83114) Of course, I venture to send you these observations for your guidance.
('25', 34, 5, 21, 83185) The merit of your act is in no way affected by them.
('25', 34, 5, 22, 83238) Yours sincerely,
('25', 34, 6, 23, 83255) M. K. GANDHI

('25', 35, 2, 3, 83365) New Year’s Day 1 Silence Day [October 31, 1921]

('25', 35, 3, 5, 83498) My vow of spinning begins from today—to spin half an hour every day before the second meal, and forgo the meal in case I fail to do so.
('25', 35, 3, 6, 83634) This is not a very great thing, but, thanks to the vow, my spinning will now be somewhat regular.
('25', 35, 3, 7, 83732) The vow is not binding when I am in a train.

('25', 35, 3, 9, 83842) Why did you write these?
('25', 35, 3, 10, 83867) Your duty was to leave your [sick] bed early.

('25', 36, 9, 9, 85191) 17. LETTER TO MATHURADAS TRIKUMJI
('25', 36, 10, 10, 85225) November 1, 1921
('25', 36, 11, 11, 85242) It is dawn.
('25', 36, 11, 12, 85254) Your letter is lying before me.
('25', 36, 11, 13, 85286) Why should you apologize for what you wrote?
('25', 36, 11, 14, 85331) There may be an element of egoism in my article or conduct without my being aware of it.
('25', 36, 11, 15, 85420) The word klesha [anguish] here should be interpreted in a different way, though I cannot say how.
('25', 36, 11, 16, 85518) I feel pain when I see others suffer.
('25', 36, 11, 17, 85556) It is the nature of compassion that whenever one is unable to relieve the suffering of others one suffers unbearably.
('25', 36, 11, 18, 85674) Logic will not avail when one is describing the condition of one’s mind.
('25', 36, 11, 19, 85747) I have given a graphic description of my feelings.
('25', 36, 11, 20, 85798) It may be that these feelings were not quite pure.
('25', 36, 11, 21, 85849) However, my state of mind at the time of writing the article 2 had also in it a yearning for moksha— my aspiration for moksha was by no means weak then—but the fact is that I am no more than an aspirant after moksha.
('25', 36, 11, 22, 86066) But I am not yet fit for moksha in this life.
('25', 36, 11, 23, 86112) My tapascharya is not intense enough.
('25', 36, 11, 24, 86150) I can control my passions no doubt, but I have not yet become completely free from them.
('25', 36, 11, 25, 86239) I can control the palate, but the tongue has not yet ceased relishing good food.
('25', 36, 11, 26, 86320) He who can restrain the senses is a man of self control; but the man whose senses have become, through constant practice, incapable of enjoying their objects has transcended self control, has in fact attained moksha.
('25', 36, 11, 27, 86537) I would not be tempted to give up my striving after moksha even for the sake of swaraj, but that does not mean that I have attained moksha.
('25', 36, 11, 28, 86677) You will, therefore, notice many
