('25', 38, 1, 2, 88777) 19. NOTES
('25', 38, 2, 3, 88787) HUNGER STRIKE
('25', 38, 3, 4, 88801) I cannot sufficiently warn non co operation prisoners against the danger of hastily embarking upon hunger strikes in their prisons.
('25', 38, 3, 5, 88933) It cannot be justified as a means for removing irksome jail restrictions.
('25', 38, 3, 6, 89007) For a jail is nothing if it does not impose upon us restrictions which we will not submit to in ordinary life.
('25', 38, 3, 7, 89118) A hunger strikewould be justified when inhumanity is practised, or food issued which offends one’s religious sense or which is unfit for human consumption.
('25', 38, 3, 8, 89274) It should be rejected when it is offered in an insulting manner.
('25', 38, 3, 9, 89339) In other words it should be rejected when acceptance would prove us to be slaves of hunger.
('25', 38, 4, 10, 89431) AT LAST
('25', 38, 5, 11, 89439) Mr. Sengupta the leader of Chittagong and the soul of the Assam Bengal Railway strike movement has at last got his imprisonment with eighteen others.
('25', 38, 5, 12, 89589) It is not a long spell.
('25', 38, 5, 13, 89613) He and his companions have got only three months’ rigorous imprisonment.
('25', 38, 5, 14, 89686) Mrs. Sengupta writing about her husband says he was quite happy over the prospect of being sentenced.
('25', 38, 5, 15, 89788) I was told whilst in Chittagong that its citizens had nearly attained swaraj.”Nearly” is an elusive word.
('25', 38, 5, 16, 89894) It may be next to completion or it may be farthest away from it, and yet”nearly” may be used for either state.
('25', 38, 5, 17, 90005) But if the people of Chittagong want to attain swaraj completely, they must spin and weave all their cloth in their own homes and offer no temptation to dealers in foreign cloth.
('25', 38, 5, 18, 90184) Its courts must be deserted and the Government schools must be empty.
('25', 38, 5, 19, 90254) In that case the citizens may not even need civil disobedience.
('25', 38, 5, 20, 90318) But they may not have that measure of strength or unanimity.
('25', 38, 5, 21, 90379) Still if the majority desire swaraj, it cannot be stopped by the minority.
('25', 38, 5, 22, 90454) The majority however in order to establish its authority must go through the fire of suffering, by means of civil disobedience.
('25', 38, 6, 23, 90582) WHY SUFFER?
('25', 38, 7, 24, 90594) Let there be no mistake about the meaning of these imprisonments.
('25', 38, 7, 25, 90660) They are not courted with the object of embarrassing the Government, though as a matter of fact they do.
('25', 38, 7, 26, 90765) They are courted for the sake of discipline and suffering.
('25', 38, 7, 27, 90824) They are courted because we consider it to be wrong to be free under a Government we hold to be wholly bad.
('25', 38, 7, 28, 90932) No stone should be left unturned by us to make the Government realize that we are in no way amenable to its control.
('25', 39, 0, 1, 91049) 40 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDNI
('25', 39, 1, 2, 91090) no government has yet tolerated such open defiance however respectful it may be.
('25', 39, 1, 3, 91171) It might safely therefore be said that if we are yet outside the prison walls, the cause lies as much with us as with the Government.
('25', 39, 1, 4, 91305) We are moving cautiously in our corporate capacity.
('25', 39, 1, 5, 91357) We are still voluntarily obeying many of its laws.
('25', 39, 1, 6, 91408) There was, for instance, nothing to prevent me from disregarding the Madras Government’s order and courting arrest, 1 but I avoided it.
('25', 39, 1, 7, 91544) There is nothing to prevent me save my prudence or weakness from going without permission into the barracks and being arrested for trespass.
('25', 39, 1, 8, 91685) I certainly believe the barracks to be the nation’s property and not that of a Government which l no longer recognize as representative of the people.
('25', 39, 1, 9, 91836) Thus there is an apparent inconsistency between the statement on the one hand that it is painful to remain outside the prison walls under a bad Government and this deliberate avoidance on the other hand of arrest upon grounds which are not strictly moral but largely expedient.
('25', 39, 1, 10, 92114) We thus avoid imprisonment, because first, we think that the nation is not ready for complete civil revolt, secondly, we think that the atmosphere of voluntary obedience and non violence has not been firmly established, and thirdly, we have not done any constructive corporate work to inspire self confidence.
('25', 39, 1, 11, 92424) We therefore refrain from offering civil disobedience amounting to peaceful rebellion, but court imprisonment merely in the ordinary pursuit of our programme and in defence of complete freedom of opinion and action short of revolt.
('25', 39, 2, 12, 92656) Thus it is clear that our remaining outside the jails of a bad Government has to be justified upon very exceptional grounds, and that our swaraj is attained when we are in jail or when we have bent the Government to our will.
('25', 39, 2, 13, 92882) Whether therefore the Government feel embarrassed or happy over our incarceration, the only safe and honourable place for us is the prison.
('25', 39, 2, 14, 93022) And if this position be accepted, it follows that when imprisonment comes to us in the ordinary discharge of our duty, we must feel happy because we feel stronger, because we pay the price of due performance of duty.
('25', 39, 2, 15, 93239) And if exhibition of real strength is the best propaganda, we must believe that every imprisonment strengthens the people and thus brings swaraj nearer.
('25', 39, 3, 16, 93392) SOMETHING STRIKING
('25', 39, 4, 17, 93411) But friends whisper into my ears, we must do something striking
('25', 39, 5, 18, 93475) 1 Vide”Notes”, 29 9 1921, under the sub title”Afflicted Madras”.
('25', 40, 0, 1, 93540) VOL. 25 : 27 OCTOBER, 1921 22 JANUARY, 1922 41
('25', 40, 1, 2, 93587) when the Prince comes.
('25', 40, 1, 3, 93610) Certainly not for the sake of impressing him, certainly not for the sake of demonstration.
('25', 40, 1, 4, 93701) But I would use the occasion of his imposed visit for stimulating us into greater activity.
('25', 40, 1, 5, 93793) That would constitute the most glorious impression upon the Prince and the world, because we would have made an impression upon ourselves.
('25', 40, 1, 6, 93932) The shortest way to swaraj lies through self impression, self expression and self reliance, both corporate and individual.
('25', 40, 1, 7, 94055) I would certainly love the idea of filling the jails before the Prince arrives, but I see no way to it except after very vigorous swadeshi.
('25', 40, 1, 8, 94195) There is great progress undoubtedly in that direction, but there is not revolutionary or lightning speed.
('25', 40, 1, 9, 94301) Arithmetical progression will not answer, geometrical progression is absolutely necessary.
('25', 40, 1, 10, 94392) It is not enough for us to be washed by the swadeshi spirit, we must be flooded with it.
('25', 40, 1, 11, 94481) Then thousands of us involuntarily, as if by a common impulse, will march forward to civil disobedience.

('25', 40, 2, 14, 94863) WEEDING OUT
('25', 40, 3, 15, 94875) The Government of Madras is fast weeding out all tall poppies.
('25', 40, 3, 16, 94938) Mr. Yakub Hasan and Dr. Varadarajulu are the latest victims.
('25', 40, 3, 17, 94999) Mr. Yakub Hasan is known to everybody as an indefatigable Khilafat worker and nationalist.

('25', 40, 3, 19, 95230) In a weak moment he allowed himself to be released before his time.
('25', 40, 3, 20, 95298) He tendered a handsome apology for a weakness which anybody in Mr. Yakub Hasan’s position might have been guilty of The Government of Madras has given him an opportunity of showing the stuff of which he is made.
('25', 40, 3, 21, 95510) Dr. Varadarajulu is’ not so well known outside the Madras Presidency, but he is locally known for his ability and industry, and respected for his self effacing love of the country.’ He has been organizing a band of earnest workers and has been doing most effective swadeshi work He has been now arrested for some speech or other of his like Mr. Yakub Hasan for his Tanjore speech.
('25', 40, 3, 22, 95891) The fear of an outbreak of violence has now almost gone.
('25', 40, 3, 23, 95948) People have realized, that their progress lies in remaining perfectly non violent.
('25', 40, 3, 24, 96031) Every such arrest leads to greater diminution of Government prestige and exposes it to contempt or
('25', 41, 0, 1, 96130) 42 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDNI
('25', 41, 1, 2, 96171) ridicule.
('25', 41, 1, 3, 96181) The ridicule and the contempt poured upon it by non co operators are not half as damaging as the ridicule and contempt invited by the Government itself by means of the arrests.
('25', 41, 2, 4, 96358) A REST CURE
('25', 41, 3, 5, 96370) And prisons have lost their terror for the people.
('25', 41, 3, 6, 96421) Hardly a non co operator save in one or two cases has betrayed the slightest hesitation to go to gaol.
('25', 41, 3, 7, 96524) On the contrary the majority have regarded it as a rest cure.
('25', 41, 3, 8, 96586) Given an atmosphere of non violence, —a prime necessity—disappearance of fear of jail and greateractivity by reason of imprisonments, and we have an ideal state for the establishment of swaraj.
('25', 41, 4, 9, 96780) PROOF OF HEALTH
('25', 41, 5, 10, 96796) That imprisonments instead of producing demoralization act as an incentive to healthier national growth is evidenced by two letters received from accurate observers.
('25', 41, 5, 11, 96962) A friend writes from Barisal:

('25', 42, 2, 6, 98877) THE LOGICAL RESULT
('25', 42, 3, 7, 98896) The logical result of all this reasoning is that we must quickly organize ourselves for courting arrests wholesale, and that not rudely, roughly or blusteringly, certainly never violently, but peacefully, quietly, courteously, humbly, prayerfully and courageously.

('25', 42, 4, 10, 99432) REQUISITE CONDITIONS
('25', 42, 5, 11, 99453) Those only can take up civil disobedience, who believe in willing obedience even to irksome laws imposed by the state so long as they do not hurt their conscience or religion, and are prepared equally willingly to suffer the penalty of civil disobedience.
('25', 42, 5, 12, 99709) Disobedience to be civil has to be absolutely non violent, the underlying principle being the winning over of the opponent by suffering, i.e., love.
('25', 42, 5, 13, 99858) For the purpose of the Khilafat, the Punjab or swaraj, civil resist ers must implicitly believe in the necessity of Hindu Muslim unity based not upon expediency but upon real affection.
('25', 42, 5, 14, 100044) Civil resisters must believe in swadeshi and therefore use only hand spun.
('25', 42, 5, 15, 100119) Humanly speaking, if not even one out of the two hundred and fifty districts of India is thus ready, I consider the attainment of swaraj during this year nearly impossible.
('25', 42, 5, 16, 100292) If one district can be found where ninety per cent of the population have completely boycotted foreign cloth and are manufacturing all the cloth required by them by hand spinning and hand weaving, if the whole of the population of that district, whether Hindu, Mussulman, Parsi, Sikh, Christian or Jewish, is living in perfect amity, if the whole of its Hindu population is purged of the sin of untouchability and if at least one in every ten of its in habitants is capable of suffering imprisonment or even mounting the gallows, and if while that district is civilly, peacefully and honourably resisting the
('25', 43, 0, 1, 100901) 44 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDNI
('25', 43, 1, 2, 100942) Government, the rest of India remains non violent and united and prosecutes the programme of swadeshi, I hold it to be perfectly possible to establish swaraj during this year.
('25', 43, 1, 3, 101118) I shall hope, that there are several such districts ready.
('25', 43, 1, 4, 101177) In any case the method now to adopt is for workers to concentrate on and develop their own districts without reference to the rest.
('25', 43, 1, 5, 101309) They must not invite imprisonment till they are ready, nor must they avoid it if it comes to them unsought.

('25', 43, 2, 9, 101759) DIVIDE AND RULE
('25', 43, 3, 10, 101775) A correspondent draws moral from the arrest of Mr. Yakub Hasan in Madras, and imprisonments of Mr. Ansari in Delhi, of Pir Mujadid in Sindh and Pir Badshah Mian in Bengal, that the Government are trying to divide us, that they are bribing the Hindus into submission by leaving them mostly alone, and that by the time the Congress meets no Mussulman non co operator of note will be left free to attend and guide the Congress regarding its policy on questions affecting the Mussulmans.
('25', 43, 3, 11, 102259) I hope that the correspondent’s prognostication is not true and that the Government will not commit any such fatal mistake.
('25', 43, 3, 12, 102383) I think the Government has realized that it cannot divide Hindu and Mussulman non co operators.

('25', 44, 4, 10, 103970) After seeing you off at Guntakal we went to Adoni where we received a wire form Mr. Harisarvottam Rao calling us to Cuddapah because three Congress workers had been arrested there.

('25', 44, 5, 17, 104653) 144, gagging us for two months.

('25', 44, 5, 20, 104974) The case then began and we were charged under Sec.

('25', 44, 6, 25, 105265) Everyone was amazed to see that we were allowed to go to our place in the city without any sort of police custody.
('25', 44, 6, 26, 105380) We returned to the court at four and the Magistrate asked us to furnish securities which we refused to do.
('25', 44, 6, 27, 105487) The Magistrate then sentenced us to six months’ simple imprisonment and said,”Gentlemen, it is a painful duty to sentence men of your stamp.” He then shook hands with us.
('25', 44, 6, 28, 105658) The Superintendent then embraced us and said,”I wish to work hand in hand with you for the good of the country.” Even then they did not take us in custody.
('25', 44, 6, 29, 105814) We went to the mosque, said our prayers and walked to the station with the people of the town and there we found a sub inspector and two constables waiting to take us to Central Jail, Vellore.
('25', 44, 6, 30, 106007) This sort of behaviour was never expected from the police as they behaved with Mr. Ramamurti and others very roughly.

('25', 45, 3, 9, 106932) TEN PRECIOUS REASONS
('25', 45, 4, 10, 106953) The Bihar Government Publicity Bureau has issued leaflets in Hindustani giving ten reasons why foreign cloth should not be boycotted.
('25', 45, 4, 11, 107087) The reader should know how the reforms are working and the public is being misled at its own expense.
('25', 45, 4, 12, 107189) Here are the reasons: 1. Cloth manufactured in India is not sufficient for our needs.
('25', 45, 4, 13, 107275) 2. People being used to wearing fine cloth for a long time find it heavy to wear garments made from Indian yarn.
('25', 45, 4, 14, 107388) 3. Even Indian mills use foreign yarn for the fine cloth they weave.
('25', 45, 4, 15, 107457) 4. If we give up foreign cloth, we shall be in the same plight we were in 1905, when owing to swadeshi agitation Indian mills sent up prices and drained our wealth.
('25', 45, 4, 16, 107622) Thus mill owners mill fatten themselves on our ruin.
('25', 45, 4, 17, 107675) 5. So long as foreign cloth is imported, there is competition between Indian cloth and foreign cloth, and thus the null owners cannot raise prices very high.
('25', 45, 4, 18, 107833) 6. There are not enough mills and handlooms in India for the cloth required.
('25', 45, 4, 19, 107910) 7. Hand spinning is not profitable because it yields no more than two annas per day.
('25', 45, 4, 20, 107995) 8. Handlooms produce very little; therefore much cannot be produced from them.
('25', 45, 4, 21, 108074) 9. By such boycott there will be great unrest and commotion, and India’s progress will be greatly arrested.
('25', 46, 0, 1, 108182) VOL. 25 : 27 OCTOBER, 1921 22 JANUARY, 1922 47
('25', 46, 1, 2, 108229) 10. By the rise in the price of cloth the poor will suffer much and discontent will spread all over.
('25', 46, 2, 3, 108330) I hope that Lord Sinha 1 knows nothing of these precious reasons, but he cannot escape responsibility.
('25', 46, 2, 4, 108433) I admit that it is not humanly possible for any man to control the details of all the departments of a big province.
('25', 46, 2, 5, 108550) But that is just the reason why no self respecting person should serve this Government.
('25', 46, 2, 6, 108638) The system is designed to drain India dry and perpetuate the foreign yoke in the interest of the foreign capitalist, chiefly the Lancashire manufacturer.
('25', 46, 2, 7, 108792) But for this selfishness running through every department, the circular I have translated will be an impossibility.

('25', 50, 4, 23, 119946) 21. CO OPERATION
('25', 50, 5, 24, 119963) Probably very few workers have noticed that progress of hand spinning means the greatest voluntary co operation the world has ever seen.
('25', 50, 5, 25, 120100) It means co operation among millions of human beings scattered over a very wide area and working for their daily bread.
('25', 50, 5, 26, 120220) No doubt agriculture has required much co operative effort, but hand spinning requires still greater and more honest co operation.
('25', 50, 6, 27, 120351) 1 From Cardinal Newman’s poem”Lead Kindly Light”
('25', 51, 0, 1, 120400) 52 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDNI
('25', 51, 1, 2, 120441) grows more by nature’s honesty than by man’s.
('25', 51, 1, 3, 120487) Manufacture of yarn in our cottages is dependent solely on human honesty.
('25', 51, 1, 4, 120561) Hand spinning is impossible without the willing and intelligent co operation of millions of human beings.

('25', 51, 1, 8, 121074) He has evidently imagined that in advocating hand spinning I am propagating my ideas about machinery.
('25', 51, 1, 9, 121176) I am doing nothing of the kind.

('25', 51, 1, 12, 121454) The spinning wheel itself is a piece of valuable machinery, and in my own humble way I have tried to secure improvements in it in keeping with the special conditions of India.
('25', 51, 1, 13, 121630) The only question therefore that a lover of India and humanity has to address himself to is how best to devise practical means of alleviating India’s wretchedness and misery.
('25', 51, 1, 14, 121805) No scheme of irrigation or other agricultural improvement that human ingenuity can conceive can deal with the vastly scattered population of India or provide work for masses of mankind who are constantly thrown out of employment.
('25', 51, 1, 15, 122035) Imagine a nation working only five hours per day on an average, and this not by choice but by force of circumstances, and you have a realistic picture of India.
('25', 51, 1, 16, 122196) If the reader would visualize the picture, he must dismiss from his mind the busy fuss of the city life or the grinding fatigue of the factory life or the slavery of the plantations.

('25', 51, 1, 22, 122947) Does anyone still doubt that it is only hand spinning and nothing else?

('25', 52, 0, 1, 123081) VOL. 25 : 27 OCTOBER, 1921 22 JANUARY, 1922 53

('25', 56, 6, 14, 132771) 26. SPEECH ON CIVIL DISOBEDIENCE, A,I.C.C., DELHI
('25', 56, 7, 15, 132821) November 4, 1921
('25', 56, 8, 16, 132838) Mr. Gandhi in moving the resolution 1 .
('25', 56, 8, 17, 132878) said that if asked as to the progress made by India during the last ten months he would unhesitatingly say that India had been able to make tremendous headway.
('25', 56, 8, 18, 133038) If they were simply to gauge the quantity of progress there was every reason to feel proud of it, but if he were to judge that progress in terms of swaraj as a physician and was asked to say whether it was sufficient for the removal of the triple disease that they were suffering from, then he had to confess it fell far short of the requirements.
('25', 56, 8, 19, 133386) Hence the necessity of repetition and emphasis, in the course of the civil disobedience resolution, of the complete fulfilment of all vital items of the programme of non co operation so far sanctioned, particularly those mentioned in the resolution.
('25', 56, 8, 20, 133636) He read to the audience a telegram from Maulana Mahomed Ali’s Private Secretary depicting the hardships they were undergoing by being treated as ordinary prisoners.
('25', 56, 8, 21, 133801) He therefore warned all against light heartedly launching on civil disobedience.
('25', 56, 8, 22, 133882) He continued, certainly they should not expect gentleness from this Government nor had they any right to expect it.
('25', 56, 9, 23, 133998) 1 Vide”The All India Congress Committee”, 10 11 1921.
('25', 57, 0, 1, 134052) 58 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDNI
('25', 57, 1, 2, 134093) were prepared to give no quarter to the Government and should expect none.
('25', 57, 1, 3, 134168) The bigger the injustice and hardships they were put to and the greater the patience and unflinching determination they observed, the sooner would swaraj come.
('25', 57, 2, 4, 134328) Proceeding, Mr. Gandhi defined civil disobedience as civil revolution which, wherever practised, would mean an end of Government authority in that particular area and open defiance of Government and its laws.
('25', 57, 2, 5, 134537) It was a gigantic step and, although provincial autonomy was being granted to provincial organizations in this matter, he advised all to wait before launching on it and see what he did, if it was at all possible in his own district of Gujarat, and after seeing the result they should follow his example which should open the eyes of the whole world to their wonderful achievement.
('25', 57, 2, 6, 134918) He knew that at present mass civil disobedience was impossible and he would be quite satisfied if in such a big continent only one tahsil or district fully prepared should practise it rather than that the whole unprepared masses should partake in it.
('25', 57, 2, 7, 135169) He advised caution and virtually asked them to wait till he gave the lead from Gujarat in the course of the next fortnight.
('25', 57, 2, 8, 135293) He reiterated his warning that in view of the gigantic step which the resolution allowed nothing should be done without full recognition of the realities so that once a step was taken there should be no tracing back .
('25', 57, 3, 9, 135511) When Mr. Gandhi concluded his opening speech, a volley of amendments rushed forth .
('25', 57, 3, 10, 135595) to secure relaxations in the conditions.
('25', 57, 3, 11, 135636) Mr. Gandhi and the supporters of his view emphasized that, having pledged and believing that it was only through complete fulfilment of swadeshi programme that they could attain swaraj, it would be laying the axe at the very root of the edifice so far built if they were to omit strict compliance with the swadeshi programme.
('25', 57, 3, 12, 135962) It was much better to have only one tahsil or one district in the whole of India which could practise civil disobedience rather than the entire country unprepared for it.
('25', 57, 4, 13, 136133) After heated discussion .
('25', 57, 4, 14, 136159) all amendments for deletion of strict swadeshi clauses were defeated .
('25', 57, 4, 15, 136230) Mr. Gandhi urged that they should arrive at a conclusion which all of them should feel as the right one and should earnestly and sincerely try to put into practice.

('25', 59, 1, 2, 138713) 29. DUTY OF HINDUS
('25', 59, 2, 3, 138732) I draw the attention of all Hindus to the touching letter given below 1 which I have received from the Antyajashram at Godhra.
('25', 59, 2, 4, 138859) Every Hindu should hang his head in shame on reading this letter.
('25', 59, 2, 5, 138925) We, and not the boy’s parents, are responsible for the beating which he got.
('25', 59, 2, 6, 139002) We have despised Antyajas, given them our leftovers and rotten food to eat, persuading ourselves that we were doing a virtuous deed.
('25', 59, 2, 7, 139135) We paid them as little as possible and drove them to begging.
('25', 59, 2, 8, 139197) Not only have we made them carry our filth, but we have also made them eat filth.
('25', 59, 2, 9, 139279) We have been giving them our discarded garments to serve as finery.
('25', 59, 2, 10, 139347) The result is that the Antyajas now like begging and feel proud when they get left overs.
('25', 59, 2, 11, 139437) When parents return home with rotten grain, the children dance with joy.
('25', 59, 2, 12, 139510) The master whose slaves rejoice in their slavery has sinned beyond measure.
('25', 59, 2, 13, 139586) This is the position of the Hindus.
('25', 59, 2, 14, 139622) The child who got a beating for his reformed habits and for refusing to eat left overs was our child.
('25', 59, 2, 15, 139724) After reading this article, let all parents look at their children and ask themselves how they would feel if the latter were in the same plight as the other child.
('25', 59, 2, 16, 139888) And how pure was that boy!
('25', 59, 2, 17, 139915) Though beaten he refused to eat meat!
('25', 59, 2, 18, 139953) What must be the mental condition of those who regard such a child as untouchable?
('25', 59, 2, 19, 140036) Will they be able to enjoy swaraj?
('25', 59, 2, 20, 140071) Will they protect others?
('25', 59, 2, 21, 140097) At the moment, however, I do not wish to say anything about untouchability to the caste Hindu parents.
('25', 59, 2, 22, 140200) Will they not have even simple compassion on their”untouchable” brothers?
('25', 59, 2, 23, 140274) Is it also in the Shastras to give them dirty, left over food and pay them as little as possible?
('25', 59, 2, 24, 140372) I request all parents: 1. Not to give Antyajas cooked food; 2. to give them only uncooked grain; 3. not to give them garments of foreign cloth or worn out and dirty clothes; 4. to raise their wages, if they are low, and 5. whatever they give, to give it with love.

('25', 59, 3, 27, 140775) The parents disliked their children’s reformed habits and treated them very harshly.

('25', 60, 4, 6, 141197) DELHI, Silence Day [November 7, 1921] 1
('25', 60, 5, 7, 141237) MAHADEV, Dil means the self, because it means the heart.
('25', 60, 5, 8, 141294) Tandurust [healthy] is a hackneyed word.
('25', 60, 5, 9, 141335) I wanted to write to you about [the health of] your body, but how could I be content with wishing you only physical health?

('25', 60, 5, 13, 141637) Jamnalal has been persistently claiming to be a son, but somehow I cannot put myself in the position of a father to him.
('25', 60, 5, 14, 141758) About one bhajan of yours, I felt that I had read it.
('25', 60, 5, 15, 141812) However, why should not a similar one suggest itself to you?

('25', 60, 5, 17, 141963) Your thinking constantly about the atman during your illness covered swaraj as well.
('25', 60, 5, 18, 142048) It was not at all necessary to think about swaraj separately.
('25', 60, 5, 19, 142110) We must perform the duties arising from the existence of the body.
('25', 60, 5, 20, 142177) Eating, bathing, going from place to place for begging, all these we do, thinking them to be legitimate activities, and show aversion only to bread labour; purification of the mind is achieved by mental yajna, that of the atman by yajna of the atman, and of the body by yajna of the body [i.e., physical labour].
('25', 60, 5, 21, 142490) Man cannot make a proper return for the food he gets for his body by doing mental work.
('25', 60, 5, 22, 142578) One does yajna [of the body] if one labours without expecting food in return.
('25', 60, 5, 23, 142656) At the present time and in this country, yajna of the body can

('25', 61, 1, 6, 143460) And because it is only a duty attaching to the body, the latter can be free from the obligation of performing this yajna when it does not consume food.
('25', 61, 1, 7, 143612) But unlike in the case of prayer which being an act of the mind or the heart, a man like me believes or persuades himself that he is performing it all the twenty four hours and does not have a fixed time for it every day, one cannot persuade oneself that one is performing bodily yajna without actually doing so, since it is an act to be performed by the body.

('25', 64, 4, 13, 151633) 32. NOTES
('25', 64, 5, 14, 151643) A PLEA FOR SPINNING
('25', 64, 6, 15, 151663) A determined opposition was put up against the conditions regarding swadeshi that were laid down in the civil disobedience resolution passed by the All India Congress Committee at Delhi.
('25', 64, 6, 16, 151850) It was directed against two requirements, namely that the civil resister offering resistance in terms of that resolution was bound to know hand spinning and use only hand spun and hand woven khadi; and that in the event of a district or tahsil offering civil disobedience en masse the district or the tahsil concerned must manufacture its own yarn and cloth by the hand.
('25', 64, 6, 17, 152221) The opposition betrayed woeful ignora nce of the importance of hand spinning.
('25', 64, 6, 18, 152299) Nothing but hand spinning can banish pauperism from the land.
('25', 64, 6, 19, 152361) Paupers cannot become willing sufferers.
('25', 64, 6, 20, 152402) They have never known the pain of plenty to appreciate the happiness of voluntarily suffering hunger or other bodily discomfort.
('25', 64, 6, 21, 152531) Swaraj for them can only mean ability to support themselves without begging.
('25', 64, 6, 22, 152608) To awaken among them a feeling of discontent with their lot without providing them with the means of removing the cause thereof is to court certain destruction, anarchy, outrage and plunder in which they themselves will be the chief victims.
('25', 64, 6, 23, 152850) Hand spinning alone can possibly supply them with supplementary and additional earnings.
('25', 64, 6, 24, 152939) Hand weaving for many and carding for a limited number can provide complete livelihood.
('25', 64, 6, 25, 153027) But hand weaving is not a lost art.
('25', 64, 6, 26, 153063) Several million men know hand weaving.

('25', 66, 1, 20, 157735) Apart therefore from the sentimental and national value of Hindustani, the necessity of all national workers learning Hindustani and the national proceedings being conducted in Hindustani is being increasingly felt.

('25', 73, 1, 5, 173563) Contrast this with the false show, the pomp and the extravagance at Simla and at the new Delhi!
('25', 73, 1, 6, 173659) As the outer, so the inner.
('25', 73, 1, 7, 173687) The most important business of the nation was finished ill a most business like manner inside of twelve hours.
('25', 73, 1, 8, 173798) Nothing was done or allowed without the closest scrutiny.
('25', 73, 1, 9, 173856) The resolution on the dispute between the President and the Working Committee was discussed in the calmest manner possible.
('25', 73, 1, 10, 173980) Jealous of its own rights, the Committee ratified the decision of the Working Committee that the right of interpretation of substantive law belonged to it rather than the President.
('25', 73, 1, 11, 174162) It would not however allow anything to appear in the resolution which could by any stretch of imagination be considered discourteous to the President.
('25', 73, 1, 12, 174313) The resolution of the session was, however, the one on civil disobedience which I give below: Whereas there is not much over one month for the fulfilment of the national determination to establish swaraj before the end of the year, and whereas the nation has demonstrated its capacity for exemplary self restraint by observing perfect non violence over the arrest and imprisonment of the Ali Brothers and the other leaders, and whereas it is desirable for the nation to demonstrate its capacity for further suffering and discipline, discipline sufficient for the attainment of swaraj, the All India Congress Committee authorizes every province on its own responsibility to undertake civil disobedience including non payment of taxes, in the manner that may be considered the most suitable by the respective Provincial Congress Committees subject to the following conditions: 1. In the event of individual civil disobedience, the individual must know hand spinning, and must have completely fulfilled that part of the programme which is applicable to him or her, e.g., he or she must have entirely discarded the use of foreign cloth and adopted only hand spun and hand woven garments, must be a believer in Hindu Muslim unity and in the unity amongst all the communities professing different religions in India as an article of faith, must believe in non violence as absolutely essential for the redress of the Khilafat and the Punjab wrongs and the attainment of swaraj, and if a Hindu, must by his personal conduct show that he regards untouchability as a blot upon nationalism.
('25', 73, 2, 13, 175893) 2. In the event of mass civil disobedience, a district or tahsil should be treated as a unit, and therein a vast majority of the population must have
('25', 74, 0, 1, 176043) VOL. 25 : 27 OCTOBER , 1921 22 JANUARY, 1922 75
('25', 74, 1, 2, 176091) adopted full swadeshi and must be clothed out of cloth hand spun and hand woven in that district or tahsil, and must believe in and practise all the other items of non co operation:
('25', 74, 2, 3, 176273) Provided that no civil resister should expect to be supported out of public funds, and members of the families of civil resisters undergoing sentence will be expected to support themselves by carding, hand spinning and hand weaving or any other means;

('25', 75, 2, 12, 179660) 34. THE MOMENTOUS ISSUE
('25', 75, 3, 13, 179684) The next few weeks should see civil disobedience in full working order in some part of India.
('25', 75, 3, 14, 179778) With illustrations of partial and individual civil disobedience the country has become familiar.
('25', 75, 3, 15, 179875) Complete civil disobedience is rebellion without the element of violence in it.
('25', 75, 3, 16, 179955) An out and out civil resister simply ignores the authority of the state.
('25', 75, 3, 17, 180028) He becomes an outlaw claiming to disregard every unmoral state law.
('25', 75, 3, 18, 180096) Thus, for instance, he may refuse to pay taxes, he may refuse to recognize the authority of the state in his daily intercourse.
('25', 75, 3, 19, 180224) He may refuse to obey the law of trespass and claim to enter military barracks in order to speak to the soldiers, he may refuse to submit to Limitations upon the manner of picketing and may picket within the prescribed area.
('25', 75, 3, 20, 180449) In doing all this he never uses force and never resists force when it is used against him.
('25', 75, 3, 21, 180540) In fact, he invites imprisonment and other uses of force against himself.
('25', 75, 3, 22, 180614) This he does because and when he finds the bodily freedom he seemingly enjoys to be an intolerable burden.
('25', 75, 3, 23, 180721) He argues to himself, that a state allows personal freedom only in so far as the citizen submits to its regula tions.
('25', 75, 3, 24, 180839) Submission to the state law is the price a citizen pays for his
('25', 75, 4, 25, 180903) 1 For Mehta’s protest against this, vide “A Protest”, 1 12 1921.
('25', 76, 0, 1, 180968) VOL. 25 : 27 OCTOBER , 1921 22 JANUARY, 1922 77
('25', 76, 1, 2, 181016) personal liberty.
('25', 76, 1, 3, 181034) Submission, therefore, to a state wholly or largely unjust is an immoral barter for liberty.
('25', 76, 1, 4, 181127) A citizen who thus realizes the evil nature of a state is not satisfied to live on its sufferance, and therefore appears to the others who do not share his belief to be a nuisance to society whilst he is endeavouring to compel the state without committing a moral breach to arrest him.
('25', 76, 1, 5, 181413) Thus considered, civil resistance is a most powerful expression of a soul’s anguish and an eloquent protest against the continuance of an evil state.
('25', 76, 1, 6, 181563) Is not this the history of all reform?
('25', 76, 1, 7, 181602) Have not reformers, much to the disgust of their fellows, discarded even innocent symbols associated with an evil practice ?
('25', 76, 1, 8, 181727) When a body of men disown the state under which they have hitherto lived, they nearly establish their own government.
('25', 76, 1, 9, 181845) I say nearly, for they do not go to the point of using force when they are resisted by the state.
('25', 76, 1, 10, 181943) Their “business” as of the individual is to be locked up or shot by the state, unless it recognizes their separate existence, in other words bows to their will.
('25', 76, 1, 11, 182104) Thus three thousand Indians in South Africa after due notice to the Government of the Transvaal crossed the Transvaal border in 1914 1 in defiance of the Transvaal immigration law and compelled the Government to arrest them.
('25', 76, 1, 12, 182329) When it failed to provoke them to violence or to coerce them into submission, it yielded to their demand.
('25', 76, 1, 13, 182435) A body of civil resisters is, therefore, like an army subject to all the discipline of a soldier, only harder because of want of excitement of an ordinary soldier’s life.
('25', 76, 1, 14, 182606) And as a civil resistance army is or ought to be free from passion because free from the spirit of retaliation, it requires the fewest number of soldiers.
('25', 76, 1, 15, 182761) Indeed one PERFECT civil resister is enough to win the battle of Right against Wrong.
('25', 76, 1, 16, 182847) Though, therefore, the All India Congress Committee has authorized civil disobedience by Provincial Congress Committees on their own responsibility, I hope they will put due emphasis on the word “responsibility” and not start civil disobedience with a light heart.
('25', 76, 1, 17, 183112) Every condition must be given its full effect.
('25', 76, 1, 18, 183159) The mention of Hindu Muslim unity, non violence, swadeshi and removal of untouchability means that they have not yet become an integral part of our national life.
('25', 76, 1, 19, 183322) If an individual or a mass have still misgivings about Hindu Muslim unity, if they have still any doubt about the necessity of non violence for the attainment of our triple goal, if they
('25', 76, 2, 20, 183509) 1 On November 6, 1913; ” Is India Aroused”, 28 9 1907.
('25', 77, 0, 1, 183564) 78 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('25', 77, 1, 2, 183605) have not yet enforced swadeshi in its completeness if the Hindus among that mass have still the poison of untouchability in them that mass or that individual are not ready for civil disobedience.
('25', 77, 1, 3, 183801) Indeed it would be best to watch and wait whilst the experiment is being carried on in one area.
('25', 77, 1, 4, 183898) Reverting to the analogy of the army, those division that watch and wait are just as much co operating actively as the division that is actually fighting.
('25', 77, 1, 5, 184053) The only time, whilst the experiment is going on, that individual civil disobedience may be resorted to simultaneously, is when the Government obstruct even the silent prosecution of swadeshi.

('25', 77, 3, 12, 185186) 35. HOW CELIBACY CAN BE OBSERVED
('25', 77, 4, 13, 185219) A volunteer has written to me a very pathetic letter saying that, despite his earnest efforts, he cannot observe brahmacharya.
('25', 77, 4, 14, 185346) He suffers from discharges in sleep and often wished to commit suicide.
('25', 77, 4, 15, 185418) I see panic in this mentality.
('25', 77, 4, 16, 185449) As long as a man is not doing a wrong deliberately or a man and a woman do not look at each other with a lustful eye, there is no cause for concern.
('25', 77, 4, 17, 185598) Having learnt to control our mind while we are awake, we should trust to God for what happens in sleep.
('25', 77, 4, 18, 185702) If there is a discharge in sleep, we should understand that the mind is not yet totally free from lust.
('25', 77, 4, 19, 185806) “Sense cravings subside in a man who refrains from gratifying them, but pleasure in their objects remains; it vanishes only when he has had a vision of the supreme.” 1

('25', 78, 0, 1, 185995) VOL. 25 : 27 OCTOBER , 1921 22 JANUARY, 1922 79
('25', 78, 1, 2, 186043) This is a statement of experience and is literally true.
('25', 78, 1, 3, 186100) Sinning is possible only so long as the atman has not realized itself.
('25', 78, 1, 4, 186171) Once it is illuminated, all possibility of sin vanishes.
('25', 78, 1, 5, 186228) One who constantly strives to observe brahmacharya should follow these rules: 1. He should be moderate in eating.
('25', 78, 1, 6, 186342) 2. He should eschew from his diet spices, excessive ghee, fried articles, sweets, meat, etc.
('25', 78, 1, 7, 186435) 3. He should of course never take liquor, but even tea, coffee, and other similar drinks may be taken only for medicinal purposes.
('25', 78, 1, 8, 186566) 4. He should wash his private parts with cold water twice or thrice [a day] and should pour cold water over them.
('25', 78, 1, 9, 186680) 5. He should never take heavy meals.
('25', 78, 1, 10, 186717) 6. He should give up late meals in the evening.
('25', 78, 1, 11, 186765) 7. His last meal should always be light so that he goes to bed with an empty stomach.
('25', 78, 1, 12, 186851) 8. He should not read erotic books, should not talk above or listen to such things.
('25', 78, 1, 13, 186935) 9. He should look upon every woman as his sister and never look at anyone with greedy eyes.

('25', 78, 1, 16, 187229) Beauty lies in virtue and this is not a thing which can be perceived by the senses.

('25', 78, 1, 18, 187449) 10. He should never be alone with a woman.
('25', 78, 1, 19, 187492) 11. He should always keep his body and mind well occupied.
('25', 78, 1, 20, 187551) I believe regular spinning to be a great help.

('25', 79, 4, 15, 189575) 36. MY NOTES
('25', 79, 5, 16, 189588) AN ADVISER
('25', 79, 6, 17, 189599) Says one adviser: “There was a comment once in The Indian Social Reformer to the effect that Gandhi blindly clings to his inner voice and then does not care to think over or even wish to know what other great men think about him.” He then politely adds that, if this criticism is justified, it is a matter of regret.
('25', 79, 6, 18, 189916) He proceeds to quote from famous British writers who say that every public servant must take into account what his critics or opponents say against him and, therefore, he advises me that I ought to read and ponder over the criticism by the learned Mrs. Annie Besant 1 and others.
('25', 79, 6, 19, 190196) He concludes the letter with an apology for quoting from British writers.
('25', 79, 6, 20, 190270) I get many such
('25', 79, 7, 21, 190286) 1 1847 1933; President of the Theosophical Society; founder of the Central Hindu College, Benares; President, Indian National Congress, 1917
('25', 80, 0, 1, 190427) VOL. 25 : 27 OCTOBER , 1921 22 JANUARY, 1922 81
('25', 80, 1, 2, 190475) letters, and I like to have them.
('25', 80, 1, 3, 190509) The correspondent need not have apologized at all.
('25', 80, 1, 4, 190560) I do not look down upon British writers.
('25', 80, 1, 5, 190601) I have read the works of Many and profited from them.
('25', 80, 1, 6, 190655) I literally adore some British writers.
('25', 80, 1, 7, 190695) It is the duty of every humble and sensible man to read and reflect over adverse criticisms.
('25', 80, 1, 8, 190788) A man learns more from his critics than from his followers.
('25', 80, 1, 9, 190848) Hence I think first about how many people disapprove of my views rather than how many approve.
('25', 80, 1, 10, 190943) And if I do not easily change my views once formulated, one good reason for it is that usually I have already examined with care what is said against them.
('25', 80, 1, 11, 191099) There is not a single criticism by the learned Mrs. Annie Besant which has escaped my careful consideration.
('25', 80, 1, 12, 191208) One thing, however, is true.
('25', 80, 1, 13, 191237) I give prime importance to my inner voice.
('25', 80, 1, 14, 191280) Opposed to it, even the works of great men have, they ought to have, no weight with me.
('25', 80, 1, 15, 191368) No other course would be right for a swarajist.
('25', 80, 1, 16, 191416) If a man does not give the first importance to his inner voice, he will forfeit his humanity and lose all his worth.
('25', 80, 1, 17, 191533) We should know, to be sure, that everyone does not hear the inner voice.
('25', 80, 1, 18, 191606) It is heard only by one who is ever devoted to study and is a man of discrimination, humility and faith.
('25', 80, 1, 19, 191711) I do not neglect to study and am not devoid of discrimination and humility.
('25', 80, 1, 20, 191787) Faith I certainly have.

('25', 80, 1, 22, 191857) I believe, therefore, that I hear the inner voice.
('25', 80, 1, 23, 191908) Everyone can be what I am and hear the inner voice.
('25', 80, 1, 24, 191960) The man who hears it has gained the strongest support.
('25', 80, 1, 25, 192015) He can then examine the words of the greatest of men.
('25', 80, 1, 26, 192069) He may sometimes err in his judgment, but, when he does so, he admits the error in all humility and expiates for it.
('25', 80, 2, 27, 192186) CIVIL DISOBEDIENCE
('25', 80, 3, 28, 192205) The same correspondent asks me: “If you advise civil disobedience, why don’t you, at the same time, advise refusal to submit to the penalty for disobedience?” Such refusal however, would only lead to anarchy, because there would be nothing “civil” about it.
('25', 80, 3, 29, 192463) The word “civil” suggests that the order alone is to be disregarded, not the penalty.
('25', 80, 3, 30, 192549) In any case, there can be no question of refusing to submit to the penalty.
('25', 80, 3, 31, 192625) Civil disobedience has its source in soul force.
('25', 80, 3, 32, 192674) Glorying in his physical might, the tyrant seeks to conquer the world.

('25', 81, 2, 5, 193371) A QUESTION INSPIRED BY FEAR
('25', 81, 3, 6, 193399) The same correspondent asks: “Supposing as a result of non co operation, the British severed their connection with us; how can we be sure, in that case, that India will not be invaded by Afghanistan or some other power?

('25', 81, 7, 22, 194793) November 10, 1921
('25', 81, 8, 23, 194811) Mahatma Gandhi supported the resolution and in doing so made a speech in the course of which he said that while seconding the resolution of congratulations to the Ali Brothers and others, he wished to say that if they wanted to release the Ali Brothers and other non co operators from jail within the year, then they should follow the programme of non violent non co operation.
('25', 81, 8, 24, 195189) The Ali Brothers had sent a message to say that they wished to be released only by the orders of swaraj government.

('25', 82, 0, 1, 195378) VOL. 25 : 27 OCTOBER , 1921 22 JANUARY, 1922 83
('25', 82, 1, 2, 195426) wrongs there was only one way to do so.
('25', 82, 1, 3, 195466) He wished to congratulate the Punjab on its progress but the Province had not made progress sufficient for winning swaraj within the year.
('25', 82, 2, 4, 195605) In the first place, the Prince’s visit should be totally boycotted.
('25', 82, 2, 5, 195673) A resolution to that effect had been passed by their Municipal Committee but attempts were being made to secure a reversal of that resolution, but he firmly hoped that they would not allow themselves to be disgraced.
('25', 82, 2, 6, 195890) He congratulated the Municipality on its decision.
('25', 82, 2, 7, 195941) They were not the enemies of the Prince nor did they wish to insult him.
('25', 82, 2, 8, 196014) He went further and said that if anybody would dare touch a single hair of the Prince, they should be ready to protect him (the Prince) with their lives.
('25', 82, 2, 9, 196168) That was their duty.

('25', 89, 1, 2, 211063) 41. SPEECH ON BIRTH ANNIVERSARY OF RAJCHANDRA, AHMEDABAD
('25', 89, 2, 3, 211120) November 16, 1921
('25', 89, 3, 4, 211138) SISTERS AND BROTHERS,
('25', 89, 4, 5, 211160) I wish to refresh your memory.
('25', 89, 4, 6, 211191) You may have forgotten the occasion, but I have not.
('25', 89, 4, 7, 211244) After my return from England, we had met in the Premabhai Hall in Ahmedabad to celebrate the birth anniversary of this illustrious person.
('25', 89, 4, 8, 211383) I had said then that, if we continued our disorderly noises, far from adoring the great man to respect whom we had gathered, we would be profaning his name.
('25', 89, 4, 9, 211540) After this, with some difficulty people were made to keep quiet for a while.
('25', 89, 4, 10, 211617) Much water has flowed down the Sabarmati river since then.
('25', 89, 4, 11, 211676) We, too, have gone through many experiences, both sweet and bitter, and have learnt to some extent the lesson of keeping order at meetings.
('25', 89, 4, 12, 211816) It is one of the simplest rules of civilized behaviour to arrive at a meeting in time and not to leave one’s seat till it ends.
('25', 89, 4, 13, 211944) If I may say the same thing with reference to our subject today, this rule is the first lesson in the path of compassion.
('25', 89, 4, 14, 212066) We must suffer inconvenience ourselves so that others may be comfortable.
('25', 89, 4, 15, 212140) It is licence, not discipline, to act upon the impulse of the moment without pausing to consider how our action may affect others in the world.
('25', 89, 4, 16, 212284) Such behaviour argues the Satanic temperament, not the godly.
('25', 89, 4, 17, 212346) It is the Satanic way to embrace disorder as order.
('25', 89, 4, 18, 212398) Where it is all noise and no consideration or respect for anyone, it is the Satanic way which the people follow.
('25', 89, 4, 19, 212511) We cannot point to one specific mark through which we may recognize an action as being Satanic.
('25', 89, 4, 20, 212607) Every action is prompted by mixed motives.
('25', 89, 4, 21, 212650) An action which springs from restlessness in the heart and creates the very image of restlessness, should be regarded as characteristic of the Satanic way.
('25', 89, 4, 22, 212806) I stand first, these days, in using the word “Satanic”.
('25', 89, 4, 23, 212862) Not that I am enamoured of it.
('25', 89, 4, 24, 212893) The world may imagine that I am, but my conscience tells me that I am prompted by nothing but compassion in using it.
('25', 89, 4, 25, 213011) There is no hatred and no anger behind it.
('25', 89, 4, 26, 213054) I describe things as I see them.
('25', 89, 4, 27, 213087) In this, I merely follow the way of compassion.
('25', 89, 4, 28, 213135) Today’s occasion is twice welcome as affording an opportunity for reflection over the meaning of compassion.
('25', 89, 4, 29, 213244) We revere the person for honouring whose memory we have gathered here.
('25', 89, 4, 30, 213315) I, too, rank myself among his adorers.
('25', 89, 4, 31, 213354) A critic can
('25', 90, 0, 1, 213367) VOL. 25 : 27 OCTOBER , 1921 22 JANUARY, 1922 91
('25', 90, 1, 2, 213415) never be this.
('25', 90, 1, 3, 213430) This is, therefore, not the place for sceptics.
('25', 90, 1, 4, 213478) Even such persons may attend in a spirit of humility to get their doubts resolved.
('25', 90, 1, 5, 213561) If, however, the motive is to find food for one’s scepticism, the rule of civilized behaviour requires that one should leave this place.
('25', 90, 1, 6, 213698) Everyone in the world should have freedom.
('25', 90, 1, 7, 213741) The sceptic should certainly have a place where he can be himself, but likewise the devotee or the worshipper, too, should have a place where he can go ahead with his work undisturbed by criticism.
('25', 90, 1, 8, 213939) I assume, therefore, that only those who love the poet and hold him in reverence have come to this meeting.
('25', 90, 1, 9, 214047) It is to these persons that I say that today’s occasion is twice welcome.
('25', 90, 1, 10, 214121) The man in whose hallowed memory we have gathered here was the living embodiment of this religion of compassion.
('25', 90, 1, 11, 214234) He understood it well and had perfected it in his life.
('25', 90, 1, 12, 214290) This same compassion inspires our present activities in the country.
('25', 90, 1, 13, 214359) It is not anger which prompts them.
('25', 90, 1, 14, 214395) The situation as it has developed has given us sufficient reason to be angry and has hurt us deeply.
('25', 90, 1, 15, 214496) But, even at this unhappy hour we pause and think how we may act so as not to hurt the opponents; how, on the contrary, we may do a good turn even to them.
('25', 90, 1, 16, 214652) Non co opera tion springs from compassion and not from anger.
('25', 90, 1, 17, 214714) Afraid that we may be in the wrong, we refuse to be angry with the opponent and, instead, ourselves flee from him.
('25', 90, 1, 18, 214829) This certainly leads to serious results.
('25', 90, 1, 19, 214870) Those persons or institutions against which we employ non co operation are indeed hurt by our action, but the religion of compassion does not teach that we may never hurt anyone.
('25', 90, 1, 20, 215049) That is not the meaning of compassion I have learnt from the Poet.
('25', 90, 1, 21, 215116) True compassion lies in doing what is good or performing our duty even at the cost of inflicting pain on others through our action.
('25', 90, 1, 22, 215248) I have often declared that I have learnt, and learnt much, from the lives of many persons.
('25', 90, 1, 23, 215339) But it is from the Poet’s life that I have learnt most.
('25', 90, 1, 24, 215395) It was from his life that I understood the way of compassion.

('25', 99, 1, 2, 234125) 44. NOTES
('25', 99, 2, 3, 234135) MY INCONSISTENCY
('25', 99, 3, 4, 234152) A correspondent asks some pertinent questions in the following pungent fashion:
('25', 99, 4, 5, 234232) When the Zulus broke out for liberty against the British usurpers, you helped the British in suppressing the so called rebellion.
('25', 99, 4, 6, 234362) Is it a rebellion to try to shake off the foreign yoke?
('25', 99, 4, 7, 234418) Was Joan of Arc a rebel?
('25', 99, 4, 8, 234443) Was George Washington a rebel?
('25', 99, 4, 9, 234474) Is De Valera one?
('25', 99, 4, 10, 234492) You may say that the Zulus had recourse to violence.
('25', 99, 4, 11, 234545) I then ask, was the end bad or the means?
('25', 99, 4, 12, 234587) The latter may have been so but certainly not the former; so you will be kind enough to explain the riddle.
('25', 99, 4, 13, 234695) In the last War, when the gallant Germans and Austrians were fighting so bravely against a world combination, you raised recruits for the British to fight against the nations that had done India no harm.
('25', 99, 4, 14, 234899) Whenever there is a war between two races, one has to hear both parties before coming to a decision, either for or against any of them.
('25', 99, 4, 15, 235035) In the last war we had a one sided version only and that from a nation certainly not renowned for truthfulness or honesty.
('25', 99, 4, 16, 235158) You have all along been an advocate of passive resistance and non violence.
('25', 99, 4, 17, 235234) Why then did you induce people to take part in a war the merits of which they knew not, and for the aggrandizement of a race so miserably wallowing in the mire of imperialism?
('25', 99, 4, 18, 235410) You may say you had faith in the British bureaucracy.

('25', 100, 0, 1, 236438) VOL. 25 : 27 OCTOBER , 1921 22 JANUARY, 1922 101
('25', 100, 1, 2, 236487) WHY DID I ASSIST IN WAR
('25', 100, 2, 3, 236511) Not only did I offer my services at the time of the Zulu revolt 1
('25', 100, 3, 4, 236577) but before that at the time of the Boer War 2 and not only did I raise recruits in India during the late War, but I raised an ambulance corps in 1914 in London 3. If therefore I have sinned, the cup of my sins is full to the brim.
('25', 100, 3, 5, 236808) I lost no occasion of serving the Government at all times.
('25', 100, 3, 6, 236867) Two questions presented themselves to me during all those crises.
('25', 100, 3, 7, 236933) What was my duty as a citizen of the empire as I then believed myself to be and what was my duty as an out and out believer in the religion of ahimsa—non violence?
('25', 100, 3, 8, 237097) I know now, that I was wrong in thinking that I was a citizen of the empire.
('25', 100, 3, 9, 237174) But on those four occasions I did honestly believe that in spite of the many disabilities that my country; was labouring under, it was making its way towards freedom, and that on the whole the Government from the popular standpoint was not wholly bad and that the British administrators were honest though insular and dense.
('25', 100, 3, 10, 237499) Holding that view, I set about doing what an ordinary Englishman would do in the circumstances.
('25', 100, 3, 11, 237595) I was not wise or important enough to take independent action.
('25', 100, 3, 12, 237658) I had no business to judge or scrutinize ministerial decisions with the solemnity of a tribunal.
('25', 100, 3, 13, 237755) It did not impute malice to the ministers either at the time of the Boer War, the Zulu revolt or the late War.
('25', 100, 3, 14, 237866) I did not consider Englishmen nor do I now consider them as particularly bad or worse than other human beings.
('25', 100, 3, 15, 237977) I considered and still consider them to be as capable of high motives and actions as any other body of men and equally capable of making mistakes.
('25', 100, 3, 16, 238124) I therefore felt, that I sufficiently discharged my duty as a man and a citizen by offering my humble services to the empire in the hour of its need whether local or general.
('25', 100, 3, 17, 238299) That is how I would expect every Indian to act by his country under swaraj.
('25', 100, 3, 18, 238375) I would be deeply distressed, if on every conceivable occasion every one of us were to be a law unto oneself and to scrutinize in golden scales every action of our future national assembly.
('25', 100, 3, 19, 238565) I would surrender my judgment in most
('25', 100, 4, 20, 238603) 1 Vide “Speech at Congress Meeting”, 24 4 1906; “Indian Volunteers”, 23 6 1906 ;Indian Stretcher Bearer Corps”, ‘19 7 1906. 2 Vide “Indian Ambulance Corps”, 13 12 1899;”Indian Ambulance Corps in Natal” , 14 3 1900; “The Natal Volunteer Indian Ambulance Corps”, 12 11 1904. 3 Vide “Letter to Secretary for Interior”, 21 1 1914; ”Speech at Mass Meeting”, 25 1 1914.

('25', 101, 1, 2, 239009) matters to national representatives, taking particular care in making my choice of such representatives.
('25', 101, 1, 3, 239114) I know that in no other manner would a democratic government be possible for one single day.
('25', 101, 1, 4, 239207) The whole situation is now changed for me.
('25', 101, 1, 5, 239250) My eyes, I fancy, are opened.
('25', 101, 1, 6, 239280) Experience has made me wiser.
('25', 101, 1, 7, 239310) I consider the existing system of Government to the wholly bad and requiring special national effort to end or mend it.
('25', 101, 1, 8, 239430) It does not possess within itself any capacity for self improvement.
('25', 101, 1, 9, 239499) That I still believe many English administrators to be honest does not assist me, because I consider them to be as blind and deluded as I was myself.
('25', 101, 1, 10, 239649) Therefore I can take no pride in calling the empire mine or describing myself as a citizen.
('25', 101, 1, 11, 239741) On the contrary, I fully realize that I am a pariah untouchable of the empire.
('25', 101, 1, 12, 239820) I must therefore constantly pray for its radical reconstruction or total destruction, even as a Hindu pariah would be fully justified in so praying about Hinduism or Hindu society.
('25', 101, 1, 13, 240001) The next point, that of ahimsa, is more abstruse.
('25', 101, 1, 14, 240051) My conception of ahimsa impels me always to dissociate myself from almost everyone of the activities I am engaged in.
('25', 101, 1, 15, 240169) My soul refuses to be satisfied so long as it is a helpless witness of a single wrong or a single misery.
('25', 101, 1, 16, 240275) But it is not possible for me, a weak, frail, miserable being, to mend every wrong or to hold myself free of blame for all the wrong I see.
('25', 101, 1, 17, 240415) The spirit in me pulls one way, the flesh in me pulls in the opposite direction.
('25', 101, 1, 18, 240496) There is freedom from the action of these two forces, but that freedom is attainable only by slow and painful stages.
('25', 101, 1, 19, 240614) I cannot attain freedom by a mechanical refusal to act, but only by intelligent action in a detached manner.
('25', 101, 1, 20, 240723) This struggle resolves itself into an incessant crucifixion of the flesh so that the spirit may become entirely free.
('25', 101, 2, 21, 240841) MORE CASES IN POINT
('25', 101, 3, 22, 240861) I was again an ordinary citizen no wiser than my fellows, myself believing in ahimsa and the rest not believing in it at all but refusing to do their duty of assisting the Government because they were actuated by anger and malice.
('25', 101, 3, 23, 241092) They were refusing out of their ignorance and weakness.
('25', 101, 3, 24, 241148) As a fellow worker, it became my duty to guide them aright.
('25', 101, 3, 25, 241208) I therefore placed before them their clear duty, explained the doctrine of ahimsa to them and let them make their choice which they did.
('25', 101, 3, 26, 241345) I do not repent of my action in terms of ahimsa.
('25', 101, 3, 27, 241394) For under swaraj too I would not hesitate to advise those who would bear arms to do so and fight for the country.

('25', 102, 1, 2, 241557) WHAT OF THE FUTURE ?
('25', 102, 2, 3, 241578) That brings me to the second question.
('25', 102, 2, 4, 241617) Under swaraj of my dream there is no necessity for arms at all.
('25', 102, 2, 5, 241681) But I do not expect that dream to materialize in its fullness as a result of the present effort, first because the effort is not directed to that end as an immediate goal and secondly because I do not consider myself advanced enough to be able to prescribe a detailed course of conduct to the nation for such preparation.
('25', 102, 2, 6, 242003) I am still myself too full of passion and other frailties of human nature to feel the call or the capacity.
('25', 102, 2, 7, 242111) All I claim for myself is, that I am incessantly trying to overcome every one of my weaknesses.
('25', 102, 2, 8, 242207) I have attained great capacity, I believe, for suppressing and curbing my senses, but I have not become incapable of sin, i.e., of being acted upon by my senses.
('25', 102, 2, 9, 242369) I believe it to be possible for every human being to attain that blessed and indescribable sinless state in which he feels within himself the presence of God to the exclusion of everything else.
('25', 102, 2, 10, 242564) It is, I must confess, as yet a distant scene.
('25', 102, 2, 11, 242611) And therefore, it is not possible for me to show the nation a present way to complete non violence in practice.
('25', 102, 3, 12, 242723) RAILWAYS AND TELEGRAPHS
('25', 102, 4, 13, 242747) The question about railways and telegraphs is really too insignificant in relation to the great doctrine I have just discussed.
('25', 102, 4, 14, 242875) I am not myself banishing the personal use of these conveniences myself.
('25', 102, 4, 15, 242948) I certainly to not expect the nation to discard their use nor do I expect their disuse under swaraj.
('25', 102, 4, 16, 243049) But I do expect the nation under swaraj not to believe that these agencies necessarily advance our moral growth or are indispensable for our material progress.
('25', 102, 4, 17, 243209) I would advise the nation to make a limited use of these agencies and not to be feverishly anxious to connect seven hundred fifty thousand villages of India by telegraph and railways.
('25', 102, 4, 18, 243393) The nation, when it feels the glow of freedom, will realize that they were needed by our rulers more for our enslavement than for enlightenment.
('25', 102, 4, 19, 243538) Progress is a lame woman.
('25', 102, 4, 20, 243564) It can only come hopping.
('25', 102, 4, 21, 243590) You cannot send it by wire or rail.

('25', 108, 2, 6, 256717) THE BAR SINISTER
('25', 108, 3, 7, 256734) I believe in God working through us and for or against individuals and nations as surely as I believe in the sun rising regularly at the appointed hour from day to day.
('25', 108, 3, 8, 256903) When therefore I hear that a particular school debars untouchables from attendance, a shudder runs through me and I know that we are not yet fit for swaraj.
('25', 108, 3, 9, 257060) A letter from the Madras Presidency lies before me, complaining that the head master of a school even instigated his boys against the pending admission of a Panchama boy.
('25', 108, 3, 10, 257231) I am hoping that such unthinkable prejudice is fast becoming a thing of rare occurrence.
('25', 108, 3, 11, 257320) I have no manner of doubt, that if we seem yet to be far from swaraj, it is because of our weaknesses and our not having carried out the self imposed conditions, one of the greatest of which is the removal of the bar sinister against one sixth of our countrymen.
('25', 108, 3, 12, 257583) The Congress workers should realize the necessity of conducting a vigorous campaign against it.
('25', 108, 3, 13, 257679) It need not in any way interfere with their swadeshi work, for the simple reason that intensive swadeshi work itself is one of the most potent influences in favour of our suppressed countrymen.

('25', 110, 3, 22, 263303) AN INGENIOUS SUGGESTION
('25', 110, 4, 23, 263327) The interest that is being taken in the khadi movement all over India is really remarkable.
('25', 110, 4, 24, 263419) The suggestion about popularizing khadi through the theatres comes from a Poona graduate.
('25', 110, 4, 25, 263509) A Punjab correspondent bases this upon his experience of the Punjab.

('25', 111, 0, 1, 263653) 112 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('25', 111, 1, 2, 263695) adopted to keep up the warmth of the body is by wearing cotton padded garments and by using cotton padded blankets.
('25', 111, 1, 3, 263811) They really give greater warmth to the body even than woollen vests and woollen rugs.
('25', 111, 1, 4, 263897) But the cotton clothing gets indescribably dirty after a time.
('25', 111, 1, 5, 263960) What the correspondent suggests is that these garments or the cotton inside them should be renewed every winter.
('25', 111, 1, 6, 264073) The blankets lend themselves to renewal in the easiest manner.
('25', 111, 1, 7, 264136) So what he says is that the cotton used for padding should be recarded and spun for manufacturing khadi.
('25', 111, 1, 8, 264241) The first covers if they are foreign must naturally be destroyed, and one need not go into the merits of destruction for justifying the burning of these things which have gathered dirt in many cases for years.
('25', 111, 1, 9, 264451) But after the covers are made of khadi, they can be used for summer wear after removing the padding.
('25', 111, 1, 10, 264552) And for the winter following, according to the correspondent’s suggestion, new cotton should be purchased.
('25', 111, 1, 11, 264659) For an industrious home the suggestion is really fine, and for the poor most economical.
('25', 111, 1, 12, 264748) For there is no waste and cleanliness is ensured.
('25', 111, 1, 13, 264798) If the poor people will but learn the necessary simple tailoring, they can have warm or cool health giving clothing from year to year to suit the different seasons without much cost.
('25', 111, 1, 14, 264981) If the whole thing is managed judiciously, the reader will observe that a family can be clothed and covered by purchasing a certain quantity of cotton from year to year and at the most paying the family weaver for weaving.
('25', 111, 1, 15, 265204) The cost of carding and spinning and tailoring is saved.
('25', 111, 1, 16, 265261) These things can be attended to without difficulty during leisure hours and without encroaching upon the hours required for recreation, or, as the late Lord Kelvin used to say of himself, recreation might be had from change of occupation.
('25', 111, 1, 17, 265500) But I know the Punjabi as well as I know the Gujarati.

('25', 111, 1, 22, 265983) To make India industrial by concentrating labour in one place is to kill the nation.
('25', 111, 1, 23, 266068) To make India industrious by providing healthy and necessary supplementary occupation in the cottage is to make India healthy, wealthy and therefore happy and contented.

('25', 112, 1, 2, 266396) 45. THE PEN OR THE SWORD
('25', 112, 2, 3, 266421) In Lahore on the Mall there is a statue of John Lawrence with a defiant look in the face with the pen in the right hand and the sword in the left.
('25', 112, 2, 4, 266568) The writing underneath is, “Will you have the pen or the sword ?” As a work of art it is said to be very good.
('25', 112, 2, 5, 266679) But it has always been a matter of offence to the citizens of Lahore.
('25', 112, 2, 6, 266749) They neither want the pen nor the sword imposed upon them.
('25', 112, 3, 7, 266808) The statue is municipal property.
('25', 112, 3, 8, 266842) It was put up in the early eighties when the sense of self respect was not so keen as now, though I understand that even when it was put up, some of the citizens keenly felt the indignity.
('25', 112, 3, 9, 267031) Recently the Lahore Municipality passed a resolution by a majority vote ordering removal of the statue to the Town Hall building pending final disposal.
('25', 112, 3, 10, 267184) The resolution was sent in due course to the Government as all resolutions are.
('25', 112, 3, 11, 267264) Three Or four days after, an engineer was sent by the Municipality to see how the statue could be removed.
('25', 112, 3, 12, 267371) Without any notice to the Municipality, the Deputy Commissioner sent a party of police to turn away the engineer and his men.
('25', 112, 3, 13, 267497) And when the Municipality wanted to know why and how this undue interference took place, the Commissioner issued the following orders 1. .
('25', 112, 4, 14, 267636) It is clear that the Deputy Commissioner was guilty of assault in having sent the police to turn out the engineer who was doing his legal duty.
('25', 112, 4, 15, 267780) The Commissioner’s order is an illustration of the meaning of the pen.
('25', 112, 4, 16, 267851) The Commissioner’s pen is just as much an outrage as the Deputy Commissioner’s sword.
('25', 112, 4, 17, 267937) The commissioner, because he has the sword, has arrogated to himself judicial powers which do not belong to him.
('25', 112, 4, 18, 268050) Whether the Municipality has or has not the power to dispose of its own property is purely for a court of law to decide.

('25', 114, 4, 8, 271731) A correspondent from the United Provinces writes:

('25', 115, 1, 2, 273842) In so far as non co operators indulge in abuse, it is undoubtedly violence, and a breach of the pledge of non violence.
('25', 115, 1, 3, 273962) But I must dissent from the opinion that”practically every speech is a mere list of invectives and imprecations.” I assure the write that the speeches are as full of invectives against ourselves as against the Government, and they are more full of argument in favour of non violence, Hindu Muslim unity and swadeshi than of invectives.

('25', 115, 1, 8, 274605) When therefore we call a thief or a rogue a rogue, we do not abuse him.
('25', 115, 1, 9, 274677) A leper takes no offence being described as such.

('25', 115, 1, 12, 274972) I am fully aware, that the use of even deserved adjectives may be a sign of violence as it would be when it is used to excite violence against the person condemned.
('25', 115, 1, 13, 275137) Condemnation is legitimately used when it is employed to wean the person from his bad habit or the audience from association with him.

('25', 115, 1, 21, 275886) Only all these seers and prophets had no evil intention in them.
('25', 115, 1, 22, 275951) They had to describe persons and things as they were and resort to language so as to enable us to make our choice between good and evil.

('25', 117, 3, 5, 278914) 48. CIVIL v.
('25', 117, 3, 6, 278927) CRIMINAL
('25', 117, 4, 7, 278936) When a man wilfully breaks his own laws, the disobedience becomes criminal.
('25', 117, 4, 8, 279012) For he commits the breach not against himself but against someone else, and not only escapes punishment for the breach for there is none provided against himself by the maker of laws, but he avoids also the inconvenience caused by their observance.
('25', 117, 4, 9, 279261) What is true of the individual is true of the corporation.
('25', 117, 4, 10, 279320) At the present moment one observes this criminal breach by the Government of its own laws throughout India.
('25', 117, 4, 11, 279428) Sections of the Penal Code and the Criminal Procedure Code are being freely abused.
('25', 117, 4, 12, 279512) And because non co operators refrain from questioning orders issued by officials, bare faced illegalities are being committed by them with impunity.
('25', 117, 4, 13, 279661) We have seen this in Bulandshahr, in Chittagong, all over Sind, and nowhere so systematically and so deliberately as in the Madras Presidency.
('25', 117, 4, 14, 279804) Mr. Yakub Hassan has pointed out with great justification that his arrest and conviction are contrary to the spirit of the Viceregal pledge.
('25', 117, 4, 15, 279945) Indeed it is against not only the spirit of Lord Reading’s pledge but it is against the letter even of his predecessor’s communique in which it was declared in solemn tones that so long as non co operation remained non violent there would be no repression.
('25', 117, 4, 16, 280202) No one dare accuse Mr. Yakub Hassan of having incited to violence in his Tanjore address before an audience of picked representatives.
('25', 117, 4, 17, 280337) Nor was any violence done in the Tanjore district as a result of his speech.
('25', 117, 4, 18, 280414) The Magistrate in the case of Mr. Iyer of the Deshabhaktan actually admitted that there was not a trace of violence in the writing that was impeached and that it actually contained exhortations to non violence.

('25', 118, 0, 1, 281131) VOL.25 : 27 OCTOBER, 1921 22 JANUARY, 1922 119
('25', 118, 1, 2, 281178) violence?
('25', 118, 1, 3, 281188) In not one of these cases I have mentioned has there been any outbreak of violence as a result of the speeches and writings concerned.
('25', 118, 1, 4, 281323) And so we see that the Government is guilty of criminal breach of its own laws.
('25', 118, 1, 5, 281403) And what legal remedy has the afflicted individual against the Government?
('25', 118, 1, 6, 281478) There is certainly no sanction provided against the Government in law when it prostitutes the law itself to its own base ends.
('25', 118, 1, 7, 281605) When therefore a Government thus becomes lawless in an organized manner, civil disobedience becomes a sacred duty and is the only remedy open specially to those who had no hand in the making of the Government or its laws.
('25', 118, 1, 8, 281827) Another remedy there certainly is, and that is armed revolt.
('25', 118, 1, 9, 281888) Civil disobedience is a complete, effective and bloodless substitute.
('25', 118, 1, 10, 281958) And it is as well that by exemplary restraint and discipline in the way of submission to unjust and even illegal orders we have created the necessary atmosphere for civil disobedience.
('25', 118, 1, 11, 282143) For thereby on the one hand the tyrannical nature of the Government has been made more manifest, and on the other by willing obedience we have fitted ourselves for civil disobedience.
('25', 118, 2, 12, 282327) It is equally as well that civil disobedience is being confined even now to the smallest area possible.
('25', 118, 2, 13, 282431) It must be admitted that it is an abnormal state, even as a corrupt and unpopular Government should be in civilized society like disease an abnormal state.
('25', 118, 2, 14, 282587) Therefore, only when a citizen has disciplined himself in the art of voluntary obedi ence to the state laws is he justified on rare occasions deliber ately but non violently to disobey them, and expose himself to the penalty of the breach.
('25', 118, 2, 15, 282827) If then we are to achieve the maximum result in the minimum of time, whilst fiercest disobedience is going on in a limited area, perfect submission to the laws must be yielded in all the other parts so as to test the nation’s capacity for voluntary obedience and for understanding the virtue of civil disobedience.

('25', 118, 3, 17, 283338) We must expect the Government to take the strictest measures to suppress this impending defiance of authority, for on it depends its very existence.
('25', 118, 3, 18, 283487) Its instinct of self preservation alone will actuate measures of repression adequate for suppression.
('25', 118, 3, 19, 283589) And if it fails, the Government of necessity disappears.

('25', 119, 1, 4, 284026) I may be arrested, thousands who take part in the peaceful revolt may also be arrested, imprisoned, even tortured.

('25', 119, 2, 15, 285021) 49. INTROSPECTION
('25', 119, 3, 16, 285039) Correspondents have written to me in pathetic language asking me not to commit suicide in January, should swaraj be not attained by then and should I find myself outside the prison walls.

('25', 119, 3, 23, 285837) All these mentors of mine seem to forget that I am but a seeker after Truth.

('25', 119, 3, 26, 286003) But I admit that I have not yet
('25', 119, 4, 27, 286035) 1 Vide “The All India Congress Committee”, 10 11 1921.

('25', 120, 1, 2, 286167) found it.
('25', 120, 1, 3, 286177) To find Truth completely is to realize oneself and one’s destiny, i.e., to become perfect.
('25', 120, 1, 4, 286268) I am painfully conscious of my imperfections, and therein lies all the strength I possess, because it is a rare thing for a man to know his own limitations.
('25', 120, 2, 5, 286425) If I was a perfect man, I own I should not feel the miseries of my neighbours as I do.
('25', 120, 2, 6, 286512) As a perfect man I should take note of them, prescribe a remedy and compel adoption by the force of unchallengeable Truth in me.
