('25', 120, 2, 8, 286799) That being so, I would be less than human if with all my knowledge of avoidable misery pervading the land and of the sight of mere skeletons under the very shadow of the Lord of the Universe, I did not feel with and for all the suffering but dumb millions of India.
('25', 120, 2, 9, 287065) The hope of a steady decline in that misery sustains me; but suppose that with all my sensitiveness to sufferings, to pleasure and pain, cold and heat and with all my endeavour to carry the healing message of the spinning wheel to the heart, I have reached only the ear and never pierced the heart, suppose further that at the end of the year I find that the people are as sceptical as they are today about the present possibility of attainment of swaraj by means of the peaceful revolution of the wheel; suppose further, that I find that all the excitement during the past twelve months and more has been only an excitement and a stimulation but no settled belief in the programme, and lastly suppose that the message of peace has not penetrated the hearts of Englishmen, should I not doubt my tapasya and feel my unworthiness for leading the struggle?
('25', 120, 2, 10, 287919) As a true man, what should I do?
('25', 120, 2, 11, 287952) Should I not kneel down in all humility before my Maker and ask Him to take away this useless body and make me a fitter instrument of service?
('25', 120, 3, 12, 288095) Swaraj does consist in the change of government and its real control by the people, but that would be merely the form.
('25', 120, 3, 13, 288214) The substance that I am hankering after is a definite acceptance of the means and therefore a real change of heart on the part of the people.
('25', 120, 3, 14, 288356) I am certain that it does not require ages for Hindus to discard the error of untouchability, for Hindus and Mussulmans to shed enmity and accept heart friendship as an eternal factor of national life, for all to adopt the charkha as the only universal means of attaining India’s economic salvation and finally for all to believe that India’s freedom lies only through non violence and no other method.
('25', 120, 3, 15, 288759) Definite,
('25', 121, 0, 1, 288769) 122 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('25', 121, 1, 2, 288811) intelligent and free adoption by the nation of this programme I hold as the attainment of the substance.
('25', 121, 1, 3, 288916) The symbol, the transfer of power, is sure to follow, even as the seed truly laid must develop into a tree.
('25', 121, 1, 4, 289024) The reader will thus perceive that what I accidentally stated to friends for the first time in Poona and then repeated to others was but a confession of my imperfections and an expression of my feeling of unworthiness for the great cause which for the time being I seem to be leading.
('25', 121, 1, 5, 289309) I have enunciated no doctrine of despair.
('25', 121, 1, 6, 289351) On the contrary I have felt never so sanguine as I do at the time of writing that we will gain the substance during this year I have stated at the same time as a practical idealist, that I should no more feel worthy to lead a cause which I might feel myself diffident of handling.

('25', 121, 4, 11, 290131) November 17, 1921
('25', 121, 5, 12, 290149) Mahatma Gandhi in the course of his speech said he had come to Bombay almost against his wish as he had got some urgent work in hand, which had been entrusted to him by the All India Congress Committee and he was unable to spare a single moment for any other purpose.
('25', 121, 5, 13, 290417) But at the urgent request of Mr. H. S. Khatri and Mrs. S. G. Banker, who had sent him repeated telegrams, he had come down to Bombay to be present at the meeting.
('25', 121, 5, 14, 290580) He congratulated the people on the perfect calm they had so far preserved in spite of the provocation which they had been offered by arresting some of their volunteers and their captain for sticking posters on the walls asking the people to boycott the festivities in connection with the Prince’s visit.
('25', 121, 5, 15, 290884) He did not see anything objectionable in the posters; on the other hand, they were doing honour to the Prince, because they were telling him the truth.
('25', 121, 5, 16, 291036) There could be nooffence at all in telling the Prince the truth.
('25', 121, 5, 17, 291101) In fact it was their duty to tell him the truth that the welcome which was being extended to him was given by the officials
('25', 121, 6, 18, 291225) 1 At 10.30 a.m., behind Elphinstone Mills
('25', 122, 0, 1, 291267) VOL.25 : 27 OCTOBER, 1921 22 JANUARY, 1922 123
('25', 122, 1, 2, 291314) and that the people—the large majority of people—had no share in it.
('25', 122, 1, 3, 291383) The Mahatma advised the people to keep the peace and be non violent even if all the posters were taken away from them, for Indians had to get redress for their Khilafat and Punjab wrongs.
('25', 122, 1, 4, 291571) Non violence was their creed and they had to keep to that principle whatever it might cost them.
('25', 122, 1, 5, 291668) Therefore, he congratulated the people of Bombay on their non violence.
('25', 122, 1, 6, 291740) When civil disobedience was once begun either in Bardoli, Anand or Nadiad talukas he wanted the people of Bombay to keep perfectly quiet, whatever might happen there.
('25', 122, 1, 7, 291907) Formerly people were afraid of going to jail, but now everyone was anxious to get into it; men and even women had come to him and asked him anxiously whether they could not go to jail.
('25', 122, 1, 8, 292092) To soldiers it was the same whether they died in their duty, whether they went to jail, or whether they remained quiet doing their duty.
('25', 122, 1, 9, 292229) In every case they had to obey the orders which were given to them.
('25', 122, 1, 10, 292297) They were the army of swaraj and every one of them had to obey the orders given to him.

('25', 122, 1, 12, 292552) Then only could they have swaraj.

('25', 122, 1, 21, 293402) The same advice he had also given to his Muslim friends.

('25', 128, 2, 8, 307343) 53. APPEAL TO BOMBAY CITIZENS
('25', 128, 3, 9, 307373) November 19, I921 1
('25', 128, 4, 10, 307393) MEN AND WOMEN OF BOMBAY, It is not possible to describe to you the agony I have suffered during the past two days.
('25', 128, 4, 11, 307508) I am writing this now at 3.30 a.m.
('25', 128, 4, 12, 307543) in perfect peace.
('25', 128, 4, 13, 307561) After two hours’ prayer and meditation I have found it.
('25', 128, 4, 14, 307617) I must refuse to eat or drink anything but water till the Hindus and Mussulmans of Bombay have made peace with the Parsis, the Christians and the Jews, and till the non co operators have made peace with the co operators.
('25', 128, 4, 15, 307838) The swaraj that I have witnessed during the last two days has stunk in my nostrils.
('25', 128, 4, 16, 307922) Hindu Muslim unity has been a menace to the handful of Parsis, Christians and Jews.
('25', 128, 4, 17, 308006) The non violence of the non co operators has been worse than the violence of co operators.
('25', 128, 4, 18, 308097) For with non violence on our lips we have terrorized those who have differed from us and in so doing we have denied our God.
('25', 128, 4, 19, 308222) There is only one God for us all, whether we find him through the Koran, the Bible, the Zend Avesta, the Talmud or the Gita.
('25', 128, 4, 20, 308347) And He is God of Truth and Love.
('25', 128, 4, 21, 308380) I have no interest in living save for proving this faith in me.
('25', 128, 4, 22, 308444) I cannot hate an Englishman or anyone else.
('25', 128, 4, 23, 308488) I have spoken and written much against his institutions, especially the one he has set up in India.
('25', 128, 4, 24, 308588) I shall continue to do so if I live.
('25', 128, 4, 25, 308625) But you must not mistake my condemnation of the system for that of the man.
('25', 128, 4, 26, 308701) My religion requires me to love him as I love myself.
('25', 128, 4, 27, 308755) I would deny God if I did not attempt to prove it at this critical moment.

('25', 130, 6, 10, 311853) 55. AN APPEAL TO THE MAVALIS
('25', 130, 7, 11, 311882) [November 20, 1921] 2
('25', 130, 8, 12, 311904) TO THE MAVALIS OF BOMBAY, The most terrible mistake I have made is, that I thought non co operators had acquired influence over you and that you had understood the relative value, the political wisdom of non violence though not the moral necessity of it.
('25', 130, 8, 13, 312159) I had thought that you had sufficiently understood the interests of your country not to meddle with the movement to its detriment and that therefore you would have wisdom enough not to give way to your worst passions.
('25', 130, 8, 14, 312377) But it cuts me to the quick to find that you have used the mass awakening for your own lust for plunder, rapine and even indulging in your worst animal appetite.
('25', 130, 8, 15, 312539) Whether you call yourself a Hindu, Mussulman, Parsi, Christian or Jew, you have certainly failed to consider even your own religious interests.
('25', 130, 8, 16, 312683) Some of my friends would, I know, accuse me of ignorance of human nature.
('25', 130, 8, 17, 312757) If I believed the charge, I would plead guilty and retire from human assemblies and return only after acquiring knowledge of human nature.
('25', 130, 8, 18, 312896) But I know that I had no difficulty in controlling even the Indian Mavalis in South Africa.

('25', 132, 5, 6, 315921) 56. EATING STEEL PELLETS

('25', 134, 1, 11, 320781) This is the ideal of patriotism for which I live; and death in the attempt to demonstrate it will be as dear to me as life itself.

('25', 134, 4, 21, 321597) 57. WHAT IS TRUTH?
('25', 134, 5, 22, 321616) There is a story in the gospel, in which a judge inquired,”What is truth?”, but got no answer.
('25', 134, 5, 23, 321711) The holy books of Hindus tell of Harishchandra who sacrificed his all at the altar of Truth and let himself, his wife, and his son be sold to a Chandala.
('25', 134, 5, 24, 321865) (What, by the way, must be the position about untouchability in those early days?) Imam Hussein and Hussein lost their lives for the sake of truth.
('25', 135, 0, 1, 322013) 136 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('25', 135, 1, 2, 322055) The fact remains, however, that the question posed by that judge has not been answered.
('25', 135, 1, 3, 322143) Harishchandra renounced his all for the sake of the truth as he knew it and so won immortal fame.
('25', 135, 1, 4, 322241) Imam Hussein gave up his dear life for truth as he understood it.
('25', 135, 1, 5, 322307) But Harishchandra’s truth and Imam Hussein’s truth may or may not be our truth.
('25', 135, 1, 6, 322387) Beyond these limited truths, however, there is one absolute Truth which is total and all embracing.
('25', 135, 1, 7, 322487) But it is indescribable, because it is God.
('25', 135, 1, 8, 322531) Or say, rather, God is Truth.
('25', 135, 1, 9, 322561) All else is unreal and false.
('25', 135, 1, 10, 322591) Other things, therefore, can be true only in a relative sense.
('25', 135, 1, 11, 322654) He, therefore, who understands truth, follows nothing but truth in thought, speech and action, comes to know God and gains the seer’s vision of the past, the present and the future.
('25', 135, 1, 12, 322836) He attains moksha though still encased in the physical frame.
('25', 135, 1, 13, 322898) If we get one single person, before the 31st of December, who would practise truth to such perfection, swaraj should be ours this very day.
('25', 135, 1, 14, 323038) Some of us are no more than satya agrahis, those, in other words, who aspire to follow truth scrupulously, but they hardly succeed in doing so even in the limited sphere of speech.
('25', 135, 1, 15, 323219) We thus see that observance of the vow of truth is no easy matter.
('25', 135, 1, 16, 323286) A friend remarked:”You have taken the vow of truth; and yet you misread the telegram from Mr. Das 1 so as to interpret it in your favour and announced Bengal’s contribution to be 25 lakhs instead of what it was, 15 lakhs.
('25', 135, 1, 17, 323508) Were you not, in this case, guilty of a subtle form of untruth?” I did not deliberately interpret the telegram in my favour.
('25', 135, 1, 18, 323633) I am not in the habit of reading meanings which suit me.
('25', 135, 1, 19, 323690) But I was certainly hasty in interpreting the telegram.
('25', 135, 1, 20, 323746) It was received late at night after 12. I state this fact not by way of extenuation but to show that truth must shine as brightly as ever even when one has mounted the gallows.
('25', 135, 1, 21, 323923) He who yearns to follow the truth at all times and under all conditions must not be guilty of such haste.
('25', 135, 1, 22, 324029) One who always follows truth is never guilty of untruth in word or deed even unknowingly.
('25', 135, 1, 23, 324119) In fact such a person becomes incapable of acting in this manner.
('25', 135, 1, 24, 324185) According to this definition, I certainly lapsed from truth.
('25', 135, 1, 25, 324246) My only consolation is that I never claim anything beyond a sincere endeavour to keep the vow of truth.

('25', 135, 2, 27, 324379) 1 C.R. Das

('25', 138, 5, 10, 329334) 60. STATEMENT BEFORE BREAKING FAST
('25', 138, 6, 11, 329369) [November 21, 1921]
('25', 138, 7, 12, 329389) Mr. Gandhi broke his fast in the midst of a gathering of co operators, non co operators, Hindus, Mussulmans, Christians and Parsis.
('25', 138, 7, 13, 329521) There were speeches of goodwill by a representative of each community.
('25', 138, 7, 14, 329592) The members of the Working Committee were also present.
('25', 138, 7, 15, 329648) Mr. Gandhi made a statement in Gujarati before breaking his fast.
('25', 138, 7, 16, 329714) The following is its translation:
('25', 138, 8, 17, 329748) FRIENDS, It delights my heart to see Hindus, Mussulmans, Parsis and Christians met together in this little assembly.
('25', 138, 8, 18, 329865) I hope that our frugal fruit repast of this morning will be a sign of our permanent friendship.
('25', 138, 8, 19, 329961) Though a born optimist, I am not in the habit of building castles in the air.
('25', 138, 8, 20, 330039) This meeting therefore cannot deceive me.
('25', 138, 8, 21, 330081) We shall be able to realize the hope of permanent friendship between all communities, only if we who have assembled together will incessantly strive to build it up.
('25', 138, 8, 22, 330246) I am breaking my fast upon the strength of your assurances.
('25', 138, 8, 23, 330306) 1 I have not been unmindful of the affection with which innumerable friends have surrounded me during these four days.
('25', 138, 8, 24, 330425) I shall ever remain grateful to them.
('25', 138, 8, 25, 330463) Being drawn by them I am plunging into this stormy ocean out of the haven of peace in which I have been during these few days.
('25', 138, 8, 26, 330590) I assure you that in spite of the tales of misery that have been poured into my ears, I have enjoyed peace because of a hungry stomach.
('25', 138, 8, 27, 330726) I know that I cannot enjoy it after breaking the fast.
('25', 138, 8, 28, 330781) I am too human not to be touched by the sorrows of others, and when I find no remedy for alleviating them, my human nature so agitates me that I pine to embrace death like a long lost dear
('25', 138, 9, 29, 330970) 1 Vide “Citizens Appeal”, 24 11 1921.
('25', 139, 0, 1, 331008) 140 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('25', 139, 1, 2, 331050) friend.
('25', 139, 1, 3, 331058) Therefore I warn all the friends here that if real peace is not established in Bombay and if disturbances break out again and if as a result they find me driven to a still severer ordeal, they must not be surprised or troubled.
('25', 139, 1, 4, 331286) If they have any doubt about peace having been established, if each community has still bitterness of feeling and suspicion and it we are all not prepared to forget and forgive past wrongs, I would much rather that they did not press me to break the fast.
('25', 139, 1, 5, 331542) Such a restraint I would regard as a test of true friendship.
('25', 139, 1, 6, 331604) I venture to saddle special responsibility upon Hindus and Mussulmans.
('25', 139, 1, 7, 331675) The majority of them are non co operators.
('25', 139, 1, 8, 331718) Non violence is the creed they have accepted for the time being.
('25', 139, 1, 9, 331783) They have the strength of numbers.
('25', 139, 1, 10, 331818) They can stand in spite of the opposition of the smaller communities without Government aid.
('25', 139, 1, 11, 331911) If therefore they will remain friendly and charitable towards the smaller communities, all will be well.
('25', 139, 1, 12, 332016) I will beseech the Parsis, the Christians and the Jews to bear in mind the new awakening in India.
('25', 139, 1, 13, 332115) They will see many coloured waters in the ocean of Hindu and Mussulman humanity.
('25', 139, 1, 14, 332196) They will see dirty waters on the shore.
('25', 139, 1, 15, 332237) I would ask them to bear with their Hindu or Mussulman neighbours who may misbehave with them and immediately report to the Hindu and Mussulman leaders through their own leaders with a view to getting justice.
('25', 139, 1, 16, 332447) Indeed I am hoping that as a result of the unfortunate discord a Mahajan will come into being for the disposal of all inter racial disputes.
('25', 139, 1, 17, 332588) The value of this assembly in my opinion consists in the fact that worshippers of the same one God we are enabled to partake of this harmless repast together in spite of our differences of opinion.
('25', 139, 1, 18, 332786) We have not assembled with the object today of reducing such differences, certainly not of surrendering a single principle we may hold dear, but we have met in order to demonstrate that we can remain true to our principles and yet also remain free from ill will towards one another.
('25', 139, 1, 19, 333069) May God bless our effort.

('25', 139, 2, 21, 333119) 61. TO CO WORKERS
('25', 139, 3, 22, 333137) November 22, 1921
('25', 139, 4, 23, 333155) COMRADES, Past few days have been a fiery ordeal for us, and God is to be
('25', 140, 0, 1, 333229) VOL.25 : 27 OCTOBER, 1921 22 JANUARY, 1922 141
('25', 140, 1, 2, 333276) thanked that some of us have not been found wanting.
('25', 140, 1, 3, 333329) The broken heads before me and the dead bodies of which I have heard on, unimpeachable authority are sufficient evidence of the fact.
('25', 140, 1, 4, 333463) Workers have lost their lives or limbs, or have suffered bruises in the act of preserving peace, of weaning mad countrymen from their wrath.
('25', 140, 1, 5, 333604) These deaths and injuries show, that in spite of the error of many of our countrymen, some of us are prepared to die for the attainment of our goal.
('25', 140, 1, 6, 333753) If all of us had imbibed the spirit of non violence, or if some had and the others had remained passive, no blood need have been spilt.
('25', 140, 1, 7, 333889) But it was not to be.
('25', 140, 1, 8, 333911) Some must therefore voluntarily give their blood in order that a bloodless atmosphere may be created.
('25', 140, 1, 9, 334013) So long as there are people weak enough to do violence, there will be others weak enough to seek the aid of those who have superior skill or means for doing it.
('25', 140, 1, 10, 334174) And that is why the Parsis and the Christians sought and received the assistance of the Government such that the Government openly took sides, and armed and aided the latter in retaliatory madness, and criminally neglected to protect a single life among those, who though undoubtedly guilty in the first instance were the victims of the pardonable wrath of the Parsis, the Christians and the Jews.
('25', 140, 1, 11, 334572) The Government has thus appeared in its nakedness as a party doing violence not merely to preserve peace but to sustain the aggressive violence of its injured supporters.
('25', 140, 1, 12, 334743) Its police and military looked on with callous indifference whilst the Christians in their justifiable indignation deprived innocent men of their white caps and hammered those who would not surrender them, or whilst the Parsis assaulted or shot, not in self defence but because the victims happened to be Hindus or Mussulmans or non co operators.
('25', 140, 1, 13, 335090) I can excuse the aggrieved Parsis and Christians, but can find no excuse for the criminal conduct of the police and the military in taking sides.
('25', 140, 1, 14, 335236) So the task before the workers is to take the blows from the Government and our erring countrymen.
('25', 140, 1, 15, 335335) This is the only way open to us of sterilizing the forces of violence.
('25', 140, 1, 16, 335406) The way to immediate swaraj lies through our gaining control over the forces of violence, and that not by greater violence but by moral influence.
('25', 140, 1, 17, 335553) We must see as clearly as daylight that it is impossible for us to be trained and armed for violence effective enough for displacing the existing Government.
('25', 140, 1, 18, 335711) Some people imagine, that after all we could not have better advertised our indignation against the welcome to the Prince than by letting loose the mob frenzy on the fateful seventeenth.
('25', 141, 0, 1, 335898) 142 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('25', 141, 1, 2, 335940) reasoning betrays at once ignorance and weakness, ignorance of the fact that our goal was not injury to the welcome, and weakness because we still hanker after advertising our strength to others instead of being satisfied with the consciousness of its possession.
('25', 141, 1, 3, 336204) I wish I could convince everyone, that we materially retarded our progress to our triple goal.
('25', 141, 1, 4, 336299) But all is not lost if the workers realize and act up to their responsibility.
('25', 141, 1, 5, 336378) We must secure the full co operation of the rowdies of Bombay.
('25', 141, 1, 6, 336441) We must know the mill hands.
('25', 141, 1, 7, 336470) They must either work for the Government or for us, i.e., for violence or against it.
('25', 141, 1, 8, 336556) There is no middle way.
('25', 141, 1, 9, 336580) They must not interfere with us.
('25', 141, 1, 10, 336613) They must either be amenable to our love or helplessly submit to the bayonet.
('25', 141, 1, 11, 336691) They may not seek shelter under the banner of non violence for the purpose of doing violence.

('25', 141, 1, 13, 336923) Similarly we must reach the rowdy element, befriend them and help them to understand the religious character of the struggle.
('25', 141, 1, 14, 337049) We must neither neglect them nor pander to them.

('25', 141, 1, 16, 337129) The peace that we are aiming at is not a patched up peace.
('25', 141, 1, 17, 337188) We must have fair guarantees of its continuance without the aid of the Government, sometimes even in spite of its activity to the contrary.
('25', 141, 1, 18, 337328) There must be a heart union between Hindus, Mussulmans, Parsis, Christians and Jews.

('25', 141, 1, 21, 337533) We must go out of our way to conquer their distrust.
('25', 141, 1, 22, 337586) We must not molest them if they do not become full non co operators or do not adopt swadeshi or the white khadi cap which has become its symbol.
('25', 141, 1, 23, 337731) We must not be irritated against them even if they side with the Government on every occasion.
('25', 141, 1, 24, 337826) We have to make them ours by right of loving service.
('25', 141, 1, 25, 337880) This is the necessity of our situation.
('25', 141, 1, 26, 337920) The alternative is a civil war.
('25', 141, 1, 27, 337952) And a civil war, with a third power only too happy to consolidate itself by siding now with the one and then with the other, must be held an impossibility for the near future.
('25', 141, 1, 28, 338128) And what is true of the smaller communities is also true of the co operators.
('25', 141, 1, 29, 338206) We must not be impatient with or intolerant to them.
('25', 141, 1, 30, 338259) We are bound to recognize their freedom to co operate with the Government if we claim the freedom to non co operate.
('25', 141, 1, 31, 338376) What would we have felt if we were in a minority and the co operators being in a
('25', 142, 0, 1, 338457) VOL.25 : 27 OCTOBER, 1921 22 JANUARY, 1922 143
('25', 142, 1, 2, 338504) majority had used violence against us?
('25', 142, 1, 3, 338543) Non co operation cum non violence is the most expeditious method known to the world of winning over opponents.
('25', 142, 1, 4, 338654) And our struggle consists in winning opponents including Englishmen over to our side.
('25', 142, 1, 5, 338740) We can only do so by being free from ill will against the weakest or the strongest of them.

('25', 142, 3, 7, 338969) Your faithful comrade,

('25', 142, 5, 9, 339029) 62. NOTES
('25', 142, 6, 10, 339039) FOR SHAUKAT ALI
('25', 142, 7, 11, 339055) During these days of great trial for me, I have felt the gravest need of Maulana Shaukat Ali by my side.

('25', 142, 7, 13, 339233) There are many stalwart and good Mussulmans I know.

('25', 142, 7, 15, 339352) Now I feel that I have to represent him and to speak to the Mussulmans things I used always to reserve for him.
('25', 142, 7, 16, 339464) I observe that one of my appeals has already been misinterpreted.
('25', 142, 7, 17, 339530) If Maulana Shaukat Ali was by me, I would not perhaps have needed to write the paragraph relating specially to Mussulmans.
('25', 142, 7, 18, 339653) Probably if he was in Bombay on the 17th, the disturbance would not have occurred at all.
('25', 142, 7, 19, 339743) Many things could have been prevented.
('25', 142, 7, 20, 339782) Indeed on the 17th if Mian Chhotani had been in Bombay, if Mr. Ahmed Haji Khatri had not been laid up in bed, things would have taken a different turn.
('25', 142, 7, 21, 339934) But I do not wish to cry over spilt milk.
('25', 142, 7, 22, 339976) I have introduced Maulana Shaukat Ali in the matter to tell my Mussulman friends that I shall shoulder the additional burden and that I expect them not to misunderstand me.
('25', 142, 7, 23, 340149) I consider their interest a special trust which I shall not be consciously guilty of betraying.
('25', 142, 7, 24, 340245) I expect too friends unhesitatingly to tell me wherein I err, and I assure them that I shall make the fullest confession if I am satisfied of my error.
('25', 142, 7, 25, 340397) Only I warn them betimes, that as I do nothing hastily and without good grounds, they must not be surprised if I do

('25', 143, 1, 2, 340555) not easily admit errors.
('25', 143, 1, 3, 340580) That it is necessary for me to pen this paragraph shows that each has to write about or to the other with the greatest delicacy.
('25', 143, 1, 4, 340709) It is a torturing performance like walking on thin ice.
('25', 143, 1, 5, 340765) But we must take facts and things as they are and turn them to the best account.
('25', 143, 2, 6, 340846) GOOD AND BAD
('25', 143, 3, 7, 340859) The reader will appreciate the statement that during these four days I have been receiving accounts both good and bad.
('25', 143, 3, 8, 340978) Non co operators injured!
('25', 143, 3, 9, 341004) Hindus and Mussulmans assaulting Parsis!
('25', 143, 3, 10, 341045) Parsis shooting them!
('25', 143, 3, 11, 341067) Christians assaulting those wearing khadi caps or dress!
('25', 143, 3, 12, 341124) Hindus and Mussulmans assaulting Christians!
('25', 143, 3, 13, 341169) These bits of information are interspersed with the news that Parsis are saving Hindus and Mussulmans from the other Parsis, some Christians saving Hindus and Mussulmans, the latter sheltering both, non co operators at great peril to their lives seeking to bring about peace.
('25', 143, 3, 14, 341445) It has never been my misfortune to be torn between two powerful and conflicting emotions.
('25', 143, 3, 15, 341535) And then to guide friends in such a difficult situation, to send them to enter the jaws of Death and yet for me to avoid death !
('25', 143, 3, 16, 341664) It is the fast that has been my outward staff and it is heart prayer that has been my inward strength.
('25', 143, 3, 17, 341767) On the 17th I felt as if all my strength had vanished.

('25', 143, 3, 19, 341875) Where was the power of ahimsa in me?
('25', 143, 3, 20, 341912) What was I to do?
('25', 143, 3, 21, 341930) I could not, I would not, ask the aggrieved parties to seek Government aid.
('25', 143, 3, 22, 342006) We had no panchayats to deal out justice.

('25', 143, 3, 24, 342111) I could not and would not organize a trained physical force party.
('25', 143, 3, 25, 342178) What relief could I give to the sufferers from mob violence?
('25', 143, 3, 26, 342239) If I allowed myself to be torn to pieces by justly incensed Parsis or Christians, I would only give rise to greater bloodshed.
('25', 143, 3, 27, 342366) Whilst as a soldier I must avoid no unavoidable risk, I must not recklessly run the risk of being killed.
('25', 143, 3, 28, 342472) Then what was I to do?

('25', 143, 3, 31, 342697) For me, a bankrupt, that was the only thing left.
('25', 143, 3, 32, 342747) I could not draw upon the people from their innocence.
('25', 143, 3, 33, 342802) They dishonoured the cheque I presented personally on the 17th.

('25', 144, 1, 2, 343064) further credit to enable me to transact His business.
('25', 144, 1, 3, 343118) I could only do so by humbling myself, crawling in the dust before Him, denying myself the food He has given.
('25', 144, 1, 4, 343228) I must in thousand ways show Him that I am in earnest, and if I am not found worthy to conduct His business, ask Him to recall me and refashion me according to my worth and His will.
('25', 144, 1, 5, 343411) And so I have tacked up the fast.
('25', 144, 1, 6, 343445) The news of the hurt received by co workers or the hurt received by the combatants no longer perturbs me.

('25', 155, 4, 9, 369172) 68. MY NOTES
('25', 155, 5, 10, 369185) AFTER THE FAST
('25', 155, 6, 11, 369200) I have started writing these Notes after ending my fast, while most of the material for young India was written during the fast.
('25', 155, 6, 12, 369329) I find no difference, however, between my thoughts then and now.
('25', 155, 6, 13, 369394) The views I held before I commenced the fast remain unchanged.
('25', 155, 7, 14, 369457) ONE CHANGE
('25', 155, 8, 15, 369468) Only in one respect have I changed my view.
('25', 155, 8, 16, 369512) That, again, is not due to the fast, but to what I myself saw in Bombay on Thursday the 17th instant and to the incidents on Friday and Saturday which were reported to me.
('25', 155, 8, 17, 369684) I can now see that we are not yet ready for civil disobedience.
('25', 155, 8, 18, 369748) To start it in Bardoli at present will only mean losing the game.
('25', 155, 8, 19, 369814) The primary aim of civil disobedience is to win swaraj, secure justice on the Khilafat issue and make the Government of India apologise to the people for the Punjab incidents.
('25', 155, 8, 20, 369990) It is certain that not a single one of the three aims can be gained through civil disobedience under the present circumstances.
('25', 155, 8, 21, 370118) Bombay and Bardoli Anand have such close links that each side wants to and can help the other.
('25', 155, 8, 22, 370213) If we start civil disobedience in Bardoli and Anand and consequently Bombay turns violent, a little reflection is enough to show that not only will Bombay not help us, but that actually it will harm the cause.
('25', 155, 8, 23, 370423) Undisciplined disobedience is nothing but the fullest co operation with the Government.
('25', 155, 8, 24, 370511) Have we still to learn that this Government is kept in power by our weakness, our habit of breaking laws at will and our violence?
('25', 155, 8, 25, 370642) Even the non co operation of some lawyers has not weakened the Government as much as our remaining peaceful.
('25', 155, 8, 26, 370751) Similarly, it is strengthened more by our violence than by the
('25', 156, 0, 1, 370814) VOL.25 : 27 OCTOBER, 1921 22 JANUARY, 1922 157
('25', 156, 1, 2, 370861) co operation of the other pleaders, because our rioting gives it an opportunity for repression, for starting a reign of terror and thereby consolidating its power.
('25', 156, 1, 3, 371025) Thus, unruly behaviour at one place with civil disobedience at another is as futile as grinding corn in a quern and then collecting in a dish the flour as it comes out of it or soiling a piece of cloth immediately it has been washed.
('25', 156, 1, 4, 371259) One may go on pouring water in a leaky jar, but not a drop will remain.
('25', 156, 1, 5, 371331) In the same way, no amount of discipline exhibited in an atmosphere of violence will avail us.
('25', 156, 1, 6, 371426) We must first create an atmosphere of discipline and peace throughout the country.
('25', 156, 1, 7, 371509) Happily or unhappily for us, we make the claim that the whole of India is with us, with the non co operation movement.
('25', 156, 1, 8, 371628) It is our Claim that not only are the many lakhs enrolled on the Congress register with us, but that we have such influence over the crores outside that they too are with us.
('25', 156, 1, 9, 371803) We must claim this.
('25', 156, 1, 10, 371823) If the people are not with us, for whom are we to struggle and win swaraj?
('25', 156, 1, 11, 371898) If they are with the Government, can we compel them to be free?
('25', 156, 1, 12, 371962) Our present movement for swaraj and for the redress of the Khilafat and the Punjab wrongs rests on our claim that we voice the people’s grievances and that we are employing means which they have accepted, that is, that people want to win swaraj through peaceful methods.
('25', 156, 1, 13, 372233) If this belief of mine is not right, I, we, have committed a grave error.
('25', 156, 1, 14, 372307) If those of us who have faith in non violent means are only a handful, it means not that we can do nothing but that our plan should be different.
('25', 156, 1, 15, 372453) In that case, non co operators being led to prison need not be followed by crowds.
('25', 156, 1, 16, 372536) If, like those who co operate with the Government, we too enjoyed no regard from the people, we could have offered civil disobedience to our heart’s content, because then nobody would have violated peace in our name.
('25', 156, 2, 17, 372753) DIFFERENCE
('25', 156, 3, 18, 372764) The civil disobedience, which we soon expected to start in Gujarat was to be offered on behalf of the whole country.
('25', 156, 3, 19, 372881) We had hoped that, through it, we would win swaraj and strengthen the movement for Khilafat.
('25', 156, 3, 20, 372974) Hence, it was necessary that the whole country should preserve peace and thus show its moral support.
('25', 156, 3, 21, 373076) Apart from this, anyone may offer civil disobedience for a local grievance, as people are doing just now in Chirala Perala and Mulshi Peta.
('25', 156, 3, 22, 373216) We have even sympathy for the people in these places and we may help them if we can.
('25', 156, 3, 23, 373301) In any case, we can remain neutral.
('25', 156, 3, 24, 373337) But the effect of violence
('25', 157, 0, 1, 373364) 158 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('25', 157, 1, 2, 373406) is so harmful that, if we impulsively start it in Bombay to show our sympathy with Chirala Perala, the people there would have to suffer all the more.
('25', 157, 2, 3, 373557) GREATEST NEED
('25', 157, 3, 4, 373571) So the first and the greatest need of the hour is to see that an atmosphere of peace prevails everywhere.
('25', 157, 3, 5, 373677) If we still have any doubt about the need for peace, we should shed it.
('25', 157, 3, 6, 373749) We must get control over the goondas.
('25', 157, 3, 7, 373787) They, too, are our brothers.
('25', 157, 3, 8, 373816) We cannot disown them nor can we afford to submit to them.
('25', 157, 3, 9, 373875) If we allow ourselves to be ruled by them, the country will not have swaraj but goonda raj.
('25', 157, 3, 10, 373967) To let them rule is to destroy both themselves and us.
('25', 157, 3, 11, 374022) We must know, however, that the public will not tolerate goonda raj even for a moment.
('25', 157, 3, 12, 374109) Rather than incur the risk of immediate danger to life and property held by goonda raj, the public will instantly welcome the protection offered by the Government.
('25', 157, 3, 13, 374273) We must, therefore, find out the goondas, discuss things with them in a friendly spirit, explain to them what is best for our dharma and our country and entreat them not to obstruct national work by their rioting.
('25', 157, 3, 14, 374487) Let nobody suppose that all this will take a long time.
('25', 157, 3, 15, 374543) It can be done in Bombay in a fortnight.
('25', 157, 3, 16, 374584) I look upon the goondas as plain and simple folk misguided into wrong ways through their karma.

('25', 157, 3, 22, 375178) This is not to be decided after we have won swaraj.
('25', 157, 3, 23, 375230) It is rather a pre condition of our winning it that we answer the question now.
('25', 157, 3, 24, 375310) If we cannot win them over through love, we certainly do not have the strength of arms to control them.
('25', 157, 3, 25, 375414) Besides, a person like me would at any rate prefer to die at their hands rather than try to save his life by killing them.
('25', 157, 4, 26, 375537) DIFFICULTIES IN THIS
('25', 157, 5, 27, 375558) This change is easy to bring about, but there are difficulties in the way.
('25', 157, 5, 28, 375633) At present, six different views prevail in the country.
('25', 157, 5, 29, 375689) 1. People who believe that swaraj is impossible except through violence and bloodshed.
('25', 157, 5, 30, 375776) They are, therefore, utilizing the prevailing
('25', 158, 0, 1, 375822) VOL.25 : 27 OCTOBER, 1921 22 JANUARY, 1922 159
('25', 158, 1, 2, 375869) atmosphere of peace to prepare for violence.
('25', 158, 1, 3, 375914) 2. Those who think that our interests will be served through both the methods, of violence and of non violence, used simultaneo usly, and so welcome incidents of violence.
('25', 158, 1, 4, 376086) The aim of these people is not self purification but only harassment of the Government.
('25', 158, 1, 5, 376174) 3. Those who do not like a non violent experiment anywhere to be abandoned because of continuing outbreaks of violence despite all efforts to check them.
('25', 158, 1, 6, 376328) 4. Those who believe that we may attempt only what can be achieved with the Government’s co operation.
('25', 158, 1, 7, 376431) 5. Those who accept the method of peace as an experiment, advocate it as a policy, and are unhappy inwardly while the experiment is in progress.
('25', 158, 1, 8, 376576) 6. Those who work with the conviction that the method of non violence is the only way for winning the country’s freedom and bringing about Hindu Muslim unity, and disapprove of rioting by people, whether planned or unplanned.
('25', 158, 1, 9, 376802) A little reflection ought to show us that persons belonging only to the fifth and sixth categories help us and they alone will advance our cause.
('25', 158, 1, 10, 376948) Persons of all other categories harm us.
('25', 158, 1, 11, 376989) We have to win them over through gentleness, persuasion and service.
('25', 158, 1, 12, 377058) The fourth category, of those who believe in co operation, is not really so dangerous as to do us much harm.
('25', 158, 1, 13, 377167) Moreover, we know who belong to this category; they have their own organization and carry on their activities in public.
('25', 158, 1, 14, 377288) People in the first three categories have no organization, no institution or association to which they belong.
('25', 158, 1, 15, 377399) They are scattered all over the country and influence the people whenever they can.
('25', 158, 1, 16, 377483) As they are isolated individuals, it is difficult to reach them.
('25', 158, 1, 17, 377548) But whenever there is trouble, they come out in the open and spread lawlessness among the people.
('25', 158, 1, 18, 377646) When some of these, with an honest but a mistaken motive, infiltrate into non co operators’ bodies, and propagate their own views through them, their activities become more harmful and dangerous.
('25', 158, 1, 19, 377842) People of all these three categories were active in Bombay from Thursday to Sunday.
('25', 158, 1, 20, 377926) That is why we used to hear all kinds of rumours and the very crowd which had come round and had started dispersing was persuaded by some other persons to collect again.

('25', 161, 4, 24, 384084) 70. LETTER TO SHANKERLAL BANKER
('25', 161, 5, 25, 384116) SABARMATI, Tuesday, [November 29, 1921]1
('25', 161, 6, 26, 384157) DEAR SHANKERLAL, You would have received my reply sent yesterday.
('25', 161, 6, 27, 384223) It is good that you met Sir Prabhashankar2 and others.
('25', 161, 6, 28, 384278) The important thing is that we should love our colleagues while adhering to our own programme.
('25', 161, 6, 29, 384373) If our faith is in peace there is no other way.

('25', 162, 1, 8, 385001) Vandemataram from MOHANDAS
('25', 162, 2, 9, 385028) From a copy of the Gujarati : S. N. 32570
('25', 162, 3, 10, 385070) 71. NOTES
('25', 162, 4, 11, 385080) REVERSE OF TRUTH
('25', 162, 5, 12, 385097) The Government of Bombay has contradicted my statement 1 to the effect that the police and the military took sides during the recent trouble and that not they but the citizens restored peace.
('25', 162, 5, 13, 385289) I am sorry for the contradiction.
('25', 162, 5, 14, 385323) I was unprepared for it.
('25', 162, 5, 15, 385348) I must add to my charges a third now to complete the picture.
('25', 162, 5, 16, 385410) The police or the military were powerless to protect the life and property of the citizens.
('25', 162, 5, 17, 385502) On the seventeenth I observed that they could not prevent tram cars and motors from being burnt.
('25', 162, 5, 18, 385599) They could not prevent the liquor shop in Bhindi Bazar from being reduced to ashes.
('25', 162, 5, 19, 385683) Nor did they do better on eighteenth or nineteenth.
('25', 162, 5, 20, 385735) Incendiarism and looting went on unchecked.
('25', 162, 5, 21, 385779) When anybody applied for protection, he was flatly told that they could not spare any more men, all hands being occupied in connection with the welcome to the Prince.
('25', 162, 5, 22, 385946) Could the police and the military possibly restore peace when they were able to protect none and nothing in the disturbed area?
('25', 162, 5, 23, 386074) The credit for restoration of peace is not claimed for non co operators alone.
('25', 162, 5, 24, 386153) I claim it for both co operators and non co operators, for Hindus, Mussulmans, Parsis and Christians including Englishmen.
('25', 162, 5, 25, 386276) If all the peace loving citizens had not joined, order could not have been restored.
('25', 162, 5, 26, 386361) I claim the credit for Mian Chhotani.
('25', 162, 5, 27, 386399) On the 20th instant but for Sir Pheroze Shethna who succeeded in inducing the military to stay their hands, a crowd would have been fired upon whereas it was
('25', 162, 6, 28, 386557) 1 Vide “A Deep Stain”, 18 11 1921.
('25', 163, 0, 1, 386592) 164 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('25', 163, 1, 2, 386634) dispersed within five minutes by the efforts of Dr. Pavri and Mr. Banker.
('25', 163, 1, 3, 386708) I can multiply instances of such dispersal on behalf of the citizens irrespective of creed or party.
('25', 163, 1, 4, 386809) Mrs. Naidu was often asked by the military to help disperse crowds.
('25', 163, 1, 5, 386877) Indeed if co operating and non co operating Parsis had not helped, it would have been impossible to restore peace.
('25', 163, 1, 6, 386992) At the peace breakfast it was Mr. H. P. Modi who claimed the credit for the citizens.
('25', 163, 1, 7, 387078) Though Mr. Purushottamdas administered a polite rebuke to the non co operators for the previous excitement, he did not disclaim the credit for the establishment of peace on behalf of the citizens.
('25', 163, 1, 8, 387275) Mr. Natarajan too gave unstinted praise to those who had brought about the much desired peace.
('25', 163, 1, 9, 387370) Mr. K. T. Paul and Mr. Douglas did no less.
('25', 163, 1, 10, 387414) Mr. Vimadalal in proposing thanks specially mentioned Mian Chhotani.
('25', 163, 1, 11, 387483) As to taking sides, whilst the police failed to protect the Parsis, many of the latter admitted to me that they looked on whilst Parsis hooligans were dealing destruction.
('25', 163, 1, 12, 387655) But I do not wish to labour this point.
('25', 163, 1, 13, 387695) I have no desire to blame individual members of the police or military.
('25', 163, 1, 14, 387767) I hope one day to bring them over to the side of truth and innocence.
('25', 163, 1, 15, 387837) Most are Indians, and I certainly do not despair of Englishmen responding in the end if only non co operators will be true to their creed of non violence.
('25', 163, 1, 16, 387992) Credit may however be given for the forbearance of the police and the military in that they did not want only take life, they did not attempt terrorism.
('25', 163, 1, 17, 388145) Let me close this chapter by instancing Malabar and Madras.
('25', 163, 1, 18, 388205) Because the people are not permitted to work, the Malabar trouble is still going on; because people did not or could not work, murder in the strike area in Madras was rampant for close on two months.
('25', 163, 1, 19, 388405) The Government of Bombay may, if they choose, claim the credit for refraining from interference with the people who were trying to restore peace.
('25', 163, 2, 20, 388551) WHO WAS AT THE BOTTOM?
('25', 163, 3, 21, 388574) People were not wanting who persisted in saying that the whole trouble was engineered and kept up by the secret police.
('25', 163, 3, 22, 388694) Throughout the six years I have been in India, I have been hearing such charges against the C.I.D. I have myself received the attentions of that body.
('25', 163, 3, 23, 388845) But I am unable to subscribe to the wild rumours that are set afloat about it.
('25', 163, 3, 24, 388924) I admit that it is corrupt, that many charges can be borne out, but there is much exaggeration in them.
('25', 163, 3, 25, 389028) It would be terrible if they were all true.
('25', 163, 3, 26, 389072) And it would be proof of our rank cowardice.
('25', 163, 3, 27, 389117) Many things imputed to the department are possible only among the people
('25', 164, 0, 1, 389190) VOL.25 : 27 OCTOBER, 1921 22 JANUARY, 1922 165
('25', 164, 1, 2, 389237) bereft of personal bravery and self respect.
('25', 164, 1, 3, 389282) During the Bombay disturbances, responsible men credited the secret police with having set afloat all the rumours about assault on Mrs. Naidu, myself and others, about damage to mosques and churches, etc.
('25', 164, 1, 4, 389487) The C.I.D. was reputed to have brought about the fires and the wrecking of tram cars.
('25', 164, 1, 5, 389573) I am unable to believe all these statements; and if they are true, the people of Bombay must be easily gullible and too foolish to exercise the rights of citizenship.
('25', 164, 1, 6, 389740) Among the qualities required to enable us to attain swaraj is certainly ability to checkmate the C.I.D. If we can be easily incited to things that hurt us or introduced to believe things we ought not to we can never gain our end.
('25', 164, 1, 7, 389970) If we are openly and truly non violent, we cannot possibly go wrong.
('25', 164, 1, 8, 390039) Either the C.I.D. or we work upon the inflammable material in our midst.
('25', 164, 1, 9, 390112) If we cannot keep it under control, we must bid good bye to all idea of freedom in the near future.
('25', 164, 2, 10, 390212) BEWARE OF RUMOURS
('25', 164, 3, 11, 390230) One of the many lessons to be learnt from the events is that we must never believe rumours and that we must have Congress and Khilafat offices in every ward or large street where people can verify rumours.
('25', 164, 3, 12, 390436) If we are acting as one man with one minds—and we must if we are to succeed—we must learn never to act without thinking and on mere rumours.
('25', 164, 3, 13, 390577) Three fourths of the panic was caused by mischievous rumours.
('25', 164, 3, 14, 390639) What does it matter if the people hear of temples destroyed or some big leader killed or injured?
('25', 164, 3, 15, 390737) They may not act without advice.
('25', 164, 3, 16, 390770) Does an individual soldier act on his own behalf on hearing of a general’s death or of a desecration of his mosque or temple?
('25', 164, 3, 17, 390896) If he were to act so, he would harm the cause and be liable even to be shot.
('25', 164, 3, 18, 390973) It is much more necessary for us to act in concert when we are willing soldiers of peace and more capable of restraint than armed soldiers and when we have to win not a single battle but the freedom of our country and religions.
('25', 164, 4, 19, 391202) OBLIGATORY EXAGGERATION
('25', 164, 5, 20, 391226) Exaggeration is always worthy of condemnation but there is one exception to the rule.
('25', 164, 5, 21, 391312) It is obligatory in connection with our own faults.
('25', 164, 5, 22, 391364) We are short sighted regarding them, and they appear in their true bearing only when they are magnified a thousand fold.
('25', 164, 5, 23, 391485) We are long sighted regarding other people’s faults.
('25', 164, 5, 24, 391538) Understatement in their case is therefore a necessity.
('25', 164, 5, 25, 391593) And if we perform the two processes
('25', 165, 0, 1, 391629) 166 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('25', 165, 1, 2, 391671) simultaneously and conscientiously, we are likely to arrive at the happy mean.
('25', 165, 1, 3, 391750) Mussulman friends have quarrelled with my saying that theirs was the leading part in the riots.
('25', 165, 1, 4, 391846) And both they and the Hindus have taken exception to my statement that they were the aggressors and therefore the guilty party.
('25', 165, 1, 5, 391974) I have given the greatest consideration to both the objections and have come to the conclusion that I must adhere to my original statement.
('25', 165, 1, 6, 392114) We shall never cleanse ourselves, unless we know the whole truth against ourselves.
('25', 165, 1, 7, 392198) I would be untrue to the Mussulmans if I did not say what I knew or felt, and I would be no Hindu, if for fear of losing Hindu esteem or otherwise I did not tell the truth.
('25', 165, 1, 8, 392371) Needless to say it is no part of my business to consider the legal consequences of such statements.
('25', 165, 1, 9, 392471) The Government may do what it chooses.
('25', 165, 1, 10, 392510) If the Parsis and Christians are wise, they will not play into its hands.
('25', 165, 1, 11, 392584) But as a non co operator I am unconcerned with legal consequences.
('25', 165, 1, 12, 392651) Those who did damage were non co operators, sympa thisers or mere mischief makers.
('25', 165, 1, 13, 392734) The first two must feel delighted, if innocent, to be imprisoned, for we court imprisonment of the innoc ent.
('25', 165, 1, 14, 392844) If they have done wrong, they need not be sorry for punishment.
('25', 165, 1, 15, 392908) The mischief makers need not expect protection from me.
('25', 165, 1, 16, 392964) Therefore the best protection I am capable of giving, the best service I am capable of rendering is to tell the truth in utter disregard of consequ ence.
('25', 165, 1, 17, 393118) It is not possible on any other terms to carry on this great struggle affecting crores of people in which you are always dealing with novel situations and uncertain elements.
('25', 165, 1, 18, 393293) Our only infallible weapons in the midst of such uncertainties are truth and non violence.
('25', 165, 2, 19, 393384) FEAR OF IMPRISONMENT
('25', 165, 3, 20, 393405) Much though we have advanced in shedding fear of imprisonment, there is still a disinclination to seek it and an anxiety to avoid it.
('25', 165, 3, 21, 393539) We must remain scrupulously honest and non violent, and at the same time be anxious almost to find ourselves in the jails of the Government.
('25', 165, 3, 22, 393680) It must be positively irksome if not painful for us to enjoy so called freedom under a Government we seek to end or mend.
('25', 165, 3, 23, 393802) We must feel that we are paying some unlawful or heavy price for retaining our liberty.
('25', 165, 3, 24, 393890) If therefore when being innocent we are imprisoned, we must rejoice became we must feel that freedom is near.
('25', 165, 3, 25, 394000) Is not freedom nearer for the imprisonment of hundreds who are now cheerfully undergoing it for the sake of the country?
('25', 165, 3, 26, 394121) What can be
('25', 166, 0, 1, 394133) VOL. 25 : 27 OCTOBER, 1921 22 JANUARY, 1922 167
('25', 166, 1, 2, 394181) better for non co operators of Bombay than that though innocent, they should be imprisoned for the sake of the guilty?
('25', 166, 2, 3, 394300) A PURE HEART
('25', 166, 3, 4, 394313) But my remarks will be appreciated only by those who have changed hearts,—not by those Hindus and Mussulmans who still believe that the Parsis or the Christians were more in the wrong than the Hindus and the Mussulmans.
('25', 166, 3, 5, 394533) The many letters of protest I have received show that many Hindus and Mussulmans believe the Parsis and the Christians gave the first offence.
('25', 166, 3, 6, 394676) Although I know the contrary, I am prepared to assume that they did.
('25', 166, 3, 7, 394745) Are not Hindus and Mussulmans still bound by virtue of their pledge, of their numbers and of their religion not to retaliate but to be friend and protect them even if they have to go out of their way to do it?
('25', 166, 4, 8, 394955) MAULANA BARI’S”FATVA”
('25', 166, 5, 9, 394977) Let Maulana Abdul Bari speak.
('25', 166, 5, 10, 395007) I offer no apology for reproducing the fatva he issued on learning the particulars about the Bombay disturbances:

('25', 166, 13, 21, 395636) RIGHTS OF MINORITIES
('25', 166, 14, 22, 395657) Unless therefore we remove the last trace of ill will against Parsis, Christians or Jews, we shall fail in our purpose.
('25', 166, 14, 23, 395777) The condition of such protection is not that minorities accept our political or other opinion.
('25', 166, 14, 24, 395872) That would be no protection.
('25', 166, 14, 25, 395901) Protection so be true has to be given in spite of the dissent, even opposition of minorities.
('25', 166, 14, 26, 395995) Indeed we must jealously guard the rights of minorities if we are to have perfect freedom of opinion in the country.
('25', 166, 14, 27, 396112) Even a child must be able to express its opinion freely.
('25', 166, 14, 28, 396169) The rule of majority would be a barbarous imposition, if it were utilized to crush the minority.
('25', 166, 14, 29, 396266) What we want in a
('25', 167, 0, 1, 396284) 168 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('25', 167, 1, 2, 396326) free India is not a dead level but a variety of opinion and conduct in which the sanest will prevail by the weight not of might but of right.
('25', 167, 1, 3, 396468) We have been groaning too long under the weight of authority.
('25', 167, 1, 4, 396530) And the weight of majority can be as brutal as that of the bullets of a minority.
('25', 167, 1, 5, 396612) We must therefore be patient with our Parsi or Christian brother if we will be free.

('25', 167, 2, 8, 397172) AN ECHO FROM BENGAL
('25', 167, 3, 9, 397192) Here is an apposite letter from Bengal written by a friend who knows what he is talking about.
('25', 167, 3, 10, 397287) He says:
('25', 167, 4, 11, 397296) I desire to tell you, that if civil disobedience is begun in Eastern Bengal, the consequences will be much more serious.
('25', 167, 4, 12, 397417) The Mussulmans there number more than 70 per cent of the total population.
('25', 167, 4, 13, 397492) The majority of them are turbulent.
('25', 167, 4, 14, 397528) As soon as the passions of these men are roused, they will fall upon the Hindus, commit horrible outrages and terrorize the Hindu landlords and creditors.
('25', 167, 4, 15, 397683) The saner and the more respectable section among them will fail to control the turbulent.
('25', 167, 4, 16, 397773) Hindu Muslim unity will vanish at the first touch.
('25', 167, 4, 17, 397824) In Calcutta too the state of things will be extremely bad.
('25', 167, 4, 18, 397883) I earnestly request you to take a much less optimistic view of men and things in India.
('25', 167, 4, 19, 397971) Excuse me for saying that you know more of men and things of South Africa than of men and things in the parent country.
('25', 167, 4, 20, 398091) You seem now to be against starting civil disobedience.
('25', 167, 4, 21, 398147) But if you change your mind, I cannot look upon the results except with a feeling of horror or dismay.
('25', 167, 4, 22, 398250) Your noblest ideals will be shattered to pieces and the country will be a prey to greater oppression and trouble.
('25', 167, 4, 23, 398364) What you have done during these years will be undone.
('25', 167, 4, 24, 398418) This is not the only warning of the kind received by me.
('25', 167, 4, 25, 398475) Bombay is one of the greatest nerve centres.
('25', 167, 4, 26, 398520) It has naturally therefore stirred people.
('25', 167, 4, 27, 398563) The protection of the rights of minorities means the protection of the weak.
('25', 167, 4, 28, 398640) And protection of the weak means protection of old men, children and women and all those who may be helpless.
('25', 167, 4, 29, 398750) And if today the united strength of Hindus and Mussulmans is used against Parsis and Christians, tomorrow the unity will break under the strain of cupidity or false religiousity,—not a delectable picture of

('25', 168, 1, 2, 399005) swaraj by any means.
('25', 168, 1, 3, 399026) For India, there is no alternative to non violence, complete and true, if she is to be free.
('25', 168, 1, 4, 399119) Non violence then must not be used as a preparation for violence.
('25', 168, 1, 5, 399185) To realize this is to realize swaraj and religion.

('25', 168, 1, 7, 399312) And by way of trial let them use their joint strength to protect the minorities and they will learn to protect one another.
('25', 168, 2, 8, 399436) NOT POLICY BUT CREED
('25', 168, 3, 9, 399457) And this cannot be done unless the year’s experience teaches us to regard non violence as our final creed for the attainment and retention of India’s freedom and of the unity of all the sects and denominations of India.
('25', 168, 3, 10, 399677) This still leaves each community free to fight for the preservation of its religion, and all together to fight for India’s defence.
('25', 168, 3, 11, 399809) But non violence must not be a policy or expedient to be tried for gaining India’s freedom or consolidating unity.
('25', 168, 3, 12, 399924) Hindus and Mussulmans must therefore begin by loving and serving Parsis, Jews and Christians including Englishmen, whether they are co operators or other.
('25', 168, 3, 13, 400079) And if we are to do this, our speeches must be free from bitterness and in the process of conversion, we must not touch even a child in order to remove its foreign cap, nor use force against drunkards to wean them from drink.
('25', 168, 3, 14, 400305) We must rest our cause solely upon appeal to reason, to the head and the heart, never to brute force whether verbal or physical.
('25', 168, 3, 15, 400434) When we have millions of the people of India freely and intelligently on our side, we have swaraj.
('25', 168, 3, 16, 400533) The greatest fear of co operators is that non violence is a cloak for violence and that in spite of the effort of the well meaning, the movement is bound ultimately to pass into the hands of the unruly and the turbulent.
('25', 168, 3, 17, 400754) We cannot dispel this fear by argument.
('25', 168, 3, 18, 400794) We can only do so by an unbroken chain of facts which need no proof.
('25', 168, 3, 19, 400863) Whilst we have made much headway, we cannot claim that we have neither speech nor action to our debit.
('25', 168, 3, 20, 400966) Love, charity, humility, gentleness do not need any articulate proof.
('25', 168, 3, 21, 401036) We must therefore put greater stress on non violence and less on non co operation.
('25', 168, 3, 22, 401119) Non violence is non co operation.
('25', 168, 3, 23, 401153) The Government’s haven of refuge is violence.
('25', 168, 3, 24, 401199) Is ours non violence?
('25', 168, 3, 25, 401221) Have we finally withdrawn ourselves from their school of violence?
('25', 168, 3, 26, 401288) It is their greatest educational institution.
('25', 168, 3, 27, 401334) The day we demolish the prestige of violence in its entirety, that day we establish swaraj.
('25', 168, 3, 28, 401426) And to be able to do this, we must learn to love the Englishman whilst we hate his system under which he pretends to

('25', 169, 2, 4, 401709) PRACTICAL HINTS
('25', 169, 3, 5, 401725) If then we love our opponents, our love must show itself in our actions.
('25', 169, 3, 6, 401798) We must invite them to our platforms and give them a patient and courteous hearing, we must not revile them in speaking of them, we must not cry”shame” when we hear their names, we must render them social service as readily as we would render to those who agree with us.
('25', 169, 3, 7, 402069) All we may not do is to render them political service or give them political association.
('25', 169, 3, 8, 402159) We must avoid all exciting speeches and avoid all noises: Mahatma Gandhi ki jai and other sounds should be strictly forbidden.
('25', 169, 3, 9, 402286) We must be able to conduct our meetings without such noises.
('25', 169, 3, 10, 402347) And if we do not attract vast crowds without such noises we shall fare all the better without them.
('25', 169, 3, 11, 402447) I would regard a district or tahsil that cannot be brought under such restraint to be unfit for civil disobedience.
('25', 169, 3, 12, 402563) Picketing should be regarded with the gravest suspicion.

('25', 169, 3, 14, 402704) There has been verbal violence or a show of violence.
('25', 169, 3, 15, 402758) It is better therefore to suspend picketing at least for the time being or till we have attained much greater self control and gained greater experience.
('25', 169, 3, 16, 402912) We may confine our attention just now to working among the drinking class.
('25', 169, 4, 17, 402987) HARTALS
('25', 169, 5, 18, 402995) The hartals wherever the Prince is taken may be proclaimed if absolute peace can be guaranteed and compulsion of any kind whatever avoided.
('25', 169, 5, 19, 403135) If the tram cars run, we must not interfere with them.

('25', 169, 5, 21, 403256) If a single man wishes to keep his shop open, we must protect him in his freedom.
('25', 169, 5, 22, 403338) It has a great value only if it is strictly voluntary.
('25', 169, 6, 23, 403393) PARSIS AND CHRISTIANS
('25', 169, 7, 24, 403415) Parsis and Christians of Bombay have before them a time of great trial and temptation.
('25', 169, 7, 25, 403502) It is just possible that they will be tempted to file complaints against Hindus and Mussulmans.
('25', 169, 7, 26, 403598) It will be a fatal blunder to succumb to the temptation.
('25', 169, 7, 27, 403655) They ought to rise to the occasion and refrain from seeking relief or reparation through courts of law.

('25', 169, 7, 29, 403830) They know that the sanest element among Hindus and

('25', 170, 1, 2, 403929) Mussulmans deeply regret the unfortunate quarrel and are ashamed of the Hindu and Mussulman aggression.
('25', 170, 1, 3, 404033) Parsis and Christians should now seek only such relief as a non official committee can secure for them.
('25', 170, 1, 4, 404137) Whilst it is true that Hindus and Mussulmans must keep their heads cool even if the latter seek reparation through the Government, they will put a severe strain upon human nature if they prefer official action to non official.
('25', 170, 2, 5, 404364) OF THE GOVERNMENT
('25', 170, 3, 6, 404382) Correspondents, whilst congratulating me for apologizing to the Parsis, Christians and Jews, have rebuked me for not doing likewise by the Government.
('25', 170, 3, 7, 404533) In making the suggestion, they have missed the central point of apology.
('25', 170, 3, 8, 404606) I cannot apologize to a system of its administrators when that system is responsible for the troubles at least equally with, if not more than, non co operators.
('25', 170, 3, 9, 404767) I start with the assumption that the administrators of the system relish these troubles and invite them by providing for them first in the way of giving provocation by unpopular measures and secondly by making frightful preparations to crush any outburst of popular resentment.
('25', 170, 3, 10, 405045) Apology has been tendered to administrators as men in as much as it has been tendered to Christians, Englishmen and co operators.
('25', 170, 3, 11, 405175) I have said that in as much as non co operators insulted a single person who took part in the welcome to the Prince, they insulted the Prince and broke the pledge of non violence.
('25', 170, 3, 12, 405355) I am not aware of non co operators having in any shape or form injured the Government during the three disgraceful days.
('25', 170, 3, 13, 405476) On the contrary I feel and know that the misguided mischief makers strengthened the Government.

('25', 170, 3, 17, 405964) Indeed, if non violence became the common creed of both the Government and the people, there would be little room for any quarrel ending in non co operation.

('25', 171, 4, 15, 407753) STRIKES
('25', 171, 5, 16, 407761) When hartal takes place what should mill hands and other employees do, who cannot get leave from their unsympathetic or alien employers?
('25', 171, 5, 17, 407898) In terms of non violence there can be but one answer.
('25', 171, 5, 18, 407952) An employee who gives himself leave uses violence, for he commits a criminal breach of the contract of his service.
('25', 171, 5, 19, 408068) He cannot absent himself without the permission of his employer.
('25', 171, 5, 20, 408133) All he can do is to resign if he is not satisfied with his employer.
('25', 171, 5, 21, 408202) But this too a body of employees may not do all of a sudden.
('25', 171, 5, 22, 408263) For they may not in order to enforce their political opinion threaten to leave without due notice.
('25', 171, 5, 23, 408362) In short mill hands and such other employees should not be encouraged to coerce their employers into giving leave.
('25', 171, 5, 24, 408477) Non violent action is not quite so simple as one may imagine.
('25', 171, 5, 25, 408539) I have heard men describing as non violent the holding tight of the legs of persons proceeding to drink shops.
('25', 171, 5, 26, 408650) Similarly youngsters have classed foul abuse of liquor dealers among non violent acts.

('25', 172, 0, 1, 408774) VOL. 25 : 27 OCTOBER, 1921 22 JANUARY, 1922 173
('25', 172, 1, 2, 408822) and bore bitter fruit in Bombay We must be true to ourselves if we wish to give non violence a fair trial.
('25', 172, 1, 3, 408929) Even if we cannot make our thought non violent, we must so regulate our speech and action as to make them completely innocuous.
('25', 172, 1, 4, 409057) If we find it impossible or too difficult to practise we must give up the attempt but we must not blame one of the greatest doctrines of life for our incapacity.
('25', 172, 1, 5, 409219) If failure has to be written against us, it won’t be failure of non violence but of the violent to respond to it.
('25', 172, 2, 6, 409333) AN ANDHRA DEFINITION
('25', 172, 3, 7, 409354) Swaraj has been variously defined.
('25', 172, 3, 8, 409389) Mr. Gopal Krishnayya who has been tried a second time and sentenced to undergo further imprisonment to run concurrently with the first made a long statement before the Magistrate.
('25', 172, 3, 9, 409569) It is more a theological discussion of his belief than a statement of his political creed.
('25', 172, 3, 10, 409660) It certainly shows that there was neither violence nor incitement to it in the speech that was the subject matter of prosecution.
('25', 172, 3, 11, 409790) But I am concerned only with his interesting definition of swaraj.
('25', 172, 3, 12, 409857) Here it is:
('25', 172, 4, 13, 409869) It is not the common political suffering that is to weld together the Hindu and the Muslim like the Greeks of old during the Persian invasions, but the mutual respect, regard and love for each other’s dharma.
('25', 172, 4, 14, 410078) and the necessity for its individuated preservation that can and shall achieve it.
('25', 172, 4, 15, 410161) Swaraj, therefore, means the preservation of Hindu dharma, Muslim dharma, Christian dharma, Parsi dharma, Sikh dharma, in short swadharma of all and a
('25', 172, 5, 16, 410312) co ordinated federation of all, which are now being threatened with destruction by positivist godless philosophy, industrial anarchy and spiritual famine that beset the world at the present moment.
('25', 172, 5, 17, 410510) Surely we are nearing our goal when men of character are being imprisoned for their religious beliefs.

('25', 173, 4, 13, 412515) The Government has decided that the wearing of what are called Gandhi caps constitutes an offence under section 228 I.P.C. Gentlemen are warned that this order will be enforced.
('25', 173, 5, 14, 412693) Consequently a volunteer who wore a khadi cap in spite of the order was fined Rs. 10/ which he refused to pay.
('25', 173, 5, 15, 412804) He preferred to go to jail for ten days.
('25', 173, 5, 16, 412845) I reproduce below the Section 228:
('25', 173, 6, 17, 412880) Whoever intentionally offers any insult or causes any interruption to a public servant while such public servant is sitting in any stage of a judicial proceeding, shall be punished with simple imprisonment for a term which may extend to six months or with fine which may extend to one thousand rupees or both.
('25', 173, 6, 18, 413190) Thus the wearing of a khadi cap is henceforth to constitute an insult to a public servant in Bengal!
('25', 173, 6, 19, 413291) I hope that the S.D.O. has arrogated to himself powers that have never been given to him or any other magistrate by the Bengal Government.
('25', 173, 6, 20, 413430) In any event if the order is at all general, bare headed Bengal will soon begin to patronize khadi caps if only out of sheer sense of self respect.

('25', 174, 1, 2, 413703) imprisonment for the offence of wearing a khadi cap.

('25', 174, 5, 14, 415053) IMPLICATIONS OF REMOVAL OF UNTOUCHABILITY
('25', 174, 6, 15, 415095) I take the following from the letter of a Bengali friend:
('25', 174, 7, 16, 415153) You have placed the removal of untouchability in the fore front of the programme of national work.
('25', 174, 7, 17, 415252) But you have not, so far as I am aware, given any clear explanation as to what exactly you intend it to mean.
('25', 174, 7, 18, 415362) The question of intermarriage apart, it may be taken to mean any one of three possible courses.
('25', 174, 7, 19, 415458) It may mean either not considering the touch of a man ceremonially unclean or agreeing to take water at his hands or not refusing to partake of food, more particularly rice, prepared by him.
('25', 174, 7, 20, 415649) I can generally answer the question by saying that removal of untouchability means disappearance of a fifth caste.
('25', 174, 7, 21, 415764) It therefore does mean at least that mere touch of a man shall not be regarded as a pollution.
('25', 174, 7, 22, 415859) The so called untouchable should enjoy the same freedom that the touchables do.
('25', 174, 7, 23, 415939) Generally speaking therefore water handled by
('25', 175, 0, 1, 415985) 176 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('25', 175, 1, 2, 416027) the erstwhile untouchable will not be regarded as polluted.
('25', 175, 1, 3, 416087) Removal of untouchability does not include partaking of rice or other food cooked by the untouchable or any other.
('25', 175, 1, 4, 416202) That is a matter of reform in the institution of caste and not covered by the programme about untouchability.
('25', 175, 1, 5, 416312) Restrictions about marriage and inter dining may be undesirable and may require modification.
('25', 175, 1, 6, 416406) But I do not regard them as a blot upon Hinduism, as I do untouchability.
('25', 175, 1, 7, 416480) The latter puts a class of human beings beyond the pale of social service and therefore is an inhuman institution.

('25', 176, 1, 2, 418286) contemplates the President as a mere figure head whom the Working Committee can order about as it likes.

('25', 183, 1, 2, 433600) 78. SPEECH AT BARDOLI
('25', 183, 2, 3, 433622) [December 3, 192l] 1
('25', 183, 3, 4, 433643) He said he had nothing but the heartiest congratulations to offer to the people of the taluk from what he had been able to see within the two days of his stay.
('25', 183, 3, 5, 433803) It was a great tribute to the people that they had gone such a long way in removing the bar of untouchability from their minds and the general standard of peace they had maintained did them the greatest credit.
('25', 183, 3, 6, 434014) But it was not without the deepest regret that he learned that much had been left to be desired in the matter of swadeshi which was the very essence.
('25', 183, 3, 7, 434164) They were still dependent on outside generosity for their khaddar, which showed that weaving had not yet accompanied spinning in the villages.
('25', 183, 3, 8, 434307) This was necessarily a serious disqualification.
('25', 183, 3, 9, 434356) It was no difficult task to set up a few handlooms in every village.
('25', 183, 3, 10, 434425) The reason the women spun coarse and weak yarn was that the yarn had never been put to the test of weaving in their own villages.
('25', 183, 3, 11, 434555) It was not enough that the vast majority of his audience had worn khaddar.
('25', 183, 3, 12, 434630) He could not ignore the fact that most of the women had not worn due to want of a sufficient supply of khaddar.
('25', 183, 3, 13, 434742) The remedy was in their own hands.
('25', 183, 3, 14, 434777) He was sure they would not agree to having their flour kneaded from outside to save trouble in the kitchen.
('25', 183, 3, 15, 434885) The arrangement would be absurd and equally so was the spinning without weaving.
('25', 183, 3, 16, 434966) If they took it into their minds he knew they could accomplish it soon.
('25', 183, 3, 17, 435038) Swaraj in their case was a matter of months, certainly not of years.
('25', 183, 3, 18, 435107) He wished that now that they had accomplished such a great deal, they worked harder still for perfection.
('25', 183, 3, 19, 435213) If they had hitherto welcomed the untouchables in their midst in public meetings and also allowed them the use of their wells, they might legitimately be expected now to go a step further and visit their homes for example, and persuade suspicious parents to send their children to national schools.
('25', 183, 4, 20, 435512) Boycott of Government educational and other institutions too might be secured in the future by the methods different from and better than those that had been adopted in certain cases in their taluk.
('25', 183, 4, 21, 435711) After all, fasting too as had been reported to have been undertaken by some of the volunteers with a view to compel parents by appealing to their sense of pity to withdraw their children, was a form of moral violence.
('25', 183, 4, 22, 435929) Such a course generally resulted in unwilling submission which was hardly to be desired by the non co operators who advocated the utmost freedom for all.
('25', 183, 4, 23, 436083) But he was anxious that his reference to any defects in the splendid achievement of Bardoli should not be misunderstood as an expression of disappointment.
('25', 183, 4, 24, 436239) Whilst he was unable to give full marks to Bardoli tahsil declaring it fit for the immediate adoption of civil disobedience it gave him the greatest pleasure to be able to assure
