('25', 184, 3, 8, 437262) 79. MASTER KEY
('25', 184, 4, 9, 437277) The three fold suffering, water of love alone can cool.
('25', 184, 4, 10, 437333) —TULSIDAS In big institutions, they have a special key which fits the locks on all doors.
('25', 184, 4, 11, 437423) The key for each room opens that room and no other; but one officer has a key which fits all locks.
('25', 184, 4, 12, 437523) In English, they call this latter,”the master key”.
('25', 184, 4, 13, 437575) I have used its equivalent in Gujarati, vadi chavi, as the title of this article.
('25', 184, 5, 14, 437657) Through the boycott programmes, people are expected to keep away from legislatures, students from schools and colleges and litigants from law courts.
('25', 184, 5, 15, 437807) If these three classes of people are not sufficiently influenced by our appeals, doubts about the success of these programmes arise.
('25', 184, 6, 16, 437940) But love is the master key in these cases—and the sovereign remedy.
('25', 184, 7, 17, 438008) Non co operation without love is Satanic; non co operation with love is godly.
('25', 184, 7, 18, 438087) It was out of love that the Prophet carried on non co operation with the Arabs of Mecca for full 13 years.
('25', 184, 7, 19, 438194) He opened their eyes with his love.
('25', 184, 7, 20, 438230) It was certainly not hatred which impelled Mira to non co operate with Kumbha Rana.
('25', 184, 7, 21, 438314) She lovingly submitted to the punishment which the Rana inflicted on her.
('25', 184, 7, 22, 438388) Our non co operation also springs from love.
('25', 184, 7, 23, 438433) Without it, everything is hollow.
('25', 184, 7, 24, 438467) Love is not merely the master key, it is the only key.
('25', 184, 7, 25, 438522) If those who have left Government schools hate the others who have not, then sacrifice is lifeless and dry.
('25', 184, 7, 26, 438630) Our boycott of councils will have no meaning if we cherish ill feeling for those who get elected to them.
('25', 184, 7, 27, 438736) To try to win over with love those who differ from us is the way of
('25', 185, 0, 1, 438804) 186 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('25', 185, 1, 2, 438846) dharma, to get angry with them is the Satanic way—the atheist’s way.
('25', 185, 1, 3, 438915) Be it admitted to our shame and disgrace that our sacrifice has been vitiated, in some measure, by anger, ill will and similar feelings and this is why it has not shone to the best effect, nor yielded results.
('25', 185, 1, 4, 439125) If all those who joined the boycott had borne no ill will to those who did not join, our position today would have been extremely good; we would have been about to win swaraj.
('25', 185, 1, 5, 439301) So our foremost duty is to shower love on people.
('25', 185, 1, 6, 439351) Doing this does not mean becoming one of them.
('25', 185, 1, 7, 439398) That would be unthinking love.
('25', 185, 1, 8, 439429) It would mean our being a party to what they do.
('25', 185, 1, 9, 439478) That is real love through which we love even our opponents, decline to look upon them as fools and serve them.
('25', 185, 1, 10, 439589) It is nothing to wonder at if one Hindu loves another Hindu; a Hindu’s goodness lies in loving a Muslim equally well and respecting his manners and customs.
('25', 185, 1, 11, 439746) Is there anything extraordinary in a person who co operates with the Government being on good terms with another such person?
('25', 185, 1, 12, 439872) Real strength and humility in a non co operator lie in loving an advocate of co operation and being patient with him despite acute differences with him.
('25', 185, 1, 13, 440025) We show no dignity in running down such a person, pouring contempt on him and hooting at him.
('25', 185, 1, 14, 440119) Dignity lies in going barefoot to his house and being of service to him.
('25', 185, 1, 15, 440192) We have not properly attended to this part of our duty.
('25', 185, 1, 16, 440248) Though I have been writing about it, I am sorry that I have not stressed the point as well as I should.
('25', 185, 1, 17, 440352) The experience in Bombay has opened my eyes.
('25', 185, 1, 18, 440397) It has brought home to me the shallowness of my tolerance.
('25', 185, 1, 19, 440456) If every time I had strongly condemned verbal attacks on those co operating with the Government, we would have advanced much further by now.
('25', 185, 1, 20, 440597) If, every time a cap was snatched away, I had expressed my strongest disapproval of the action, things would have been much better today than they are.
('25', 185, 1, 21, 440749) I know that, for a mar who has the privilege of being the leader of such a great fight, it is a heinous sin not to exercise the utmost vigilance.
('25', 185, 1, 22, 440895) If the general in this battle is much too weak or mild or feels himself helpless, he had better give up his leadership.
('25', 185, 1, 23, 441015) Now that we have realized our error, let us not be guilty of it again.
('25', 185, 1, 24, 441086) We should now banish from our minds all resentment against those who co operate, against Parsis, Christians and Englishmen.

('25', 186, 4, 6, 441925) 80. HINDU MUSLIM PARSI
('25', 186, 5, 7, 441948) I continue to be flooded with letters from Hindus and Parsis, both men and women.
('25', 186, 5, 8, 442030) The correspondents blame each other’s community.
('25', 186, 5, 9, 442079) This is not the way to forge real unity.
('25', 186, 5, 10, 442120) Hindus and Muslims should remember that Parsis are a small community and are mostly concentrated in one place.
('25', 186, 5, 11, 442231) That is why their faults are immediately noticed and their virtues are easily forgotten.
('25', 186, 5, 12, 442320) If we always see only faults in other members of our family, we shall end by imagining that we are the only perfect ones in the world.
('25', 186, 5, 13, 442455) All others will seem to us so full of defects that we shall feel defiled even by their touch.
('25', 186, 5, 14, 442549) But the truth is that a person who always points at others’ evils is himself generally the greatest sinner of all.

('25', 186, 5, 17, 442830) If we see only our own faults, we shall ourselves rise and raise others too.
('25', 186, 5, 18, 442907) Our great error has been that we forgot tolerance.
('25', 186, 5, 19, 442958) Having accepted a new religion, we forgot its restraints and became fanatics.
('25', 186, 5, 20, 443036) We discovered non co oper ation and came to understand its efficacy, and so we believed that all those who did not understand it lacked intelligence and wisdom, that they were traitors and sinners.
('25', 186, 5, 21, 443234) By doing this, we only disgraced our non co operation.

('25', 186, 5, 23, 443385) We lost patience.

('25', 187, 1, 4, 443915) We did not remember the sacrifices made by some of them.
('25', 187, 1, 5, 443972) But some people ask me:”What about the fact that it was the Parsis who started all the trouble?” Would we not do better to think what we would have done, had we been only a lakh?
('25', 187, 1, 6, 444151) If we but imagine ourselves reduced from the twenty two crores or the seven crores that we are to the number of one lakh and think how we would behave then, we would understand what it is to be in such a plight.

('25', 188, 1, 2, 446289) 81. FORTHCOMING SESSION OF CONGRESS
('25', 188, 2, 3, 446325) When this issue is out, there will be 20 days to go before the Congress session.
('25', 188, 2, 4, 446406) This session will be completely different from the previous ones.
('25', 188, 2, 5, 446472) Though it may not celebrate the winning of swaraj, it will have to do something very like it, i.e., will have to prove its fitness for swaraj in everything it does.
('25', 188, 2, 6, 446637) Efficiency in management, perfection of manners, and a spirit of fearlessness and independence which will leave nothing to be desired—we shall have to display all this.
('25', 188, 3, 7, 446806) Our management should be so perfect that we must not appear to have lost sight of the smallest detail.
('25', 188, 3, 8, 446909) The arrangements for board, lodging, bathing and sanitation should be satisfying in every way.
('25', 188, 3, 9, 447004) There should be a place for throwing refuse, and a place for storing water.

('25', 188, 3, 12, 447225) Though latrines will be used by all, everything must present a clean appearance.

('25', 188, 3, 14, 447511) Khadinagar ought to provide an object lesson in cleanliness.

('25', 188, 4, 16, 447770) They should not enter grounds to which entry is forbidden and should not insist on going towards a place when stopped.
('25', 188, 4, 17, 447889) They should see that, in any part which they enter, they do not inconvenience others.

('25', 189, 3, 20, 450121) MY IGNORANCE
('25', 189, 4, 21, 450134) There is no limit to my ignorance of the geography of Gujarat.

('25', 190, 1, 4, 451093) I do not put the burden of reforming Dakor on the Anand taluk, but I shall treat the former as a barometer registering the improvement which takes place in the Anand taluk.
('25', 190, 2, 5, 451266) CHANGE THE HEART
('25', 190, 3, 6, 451283) The reforms I need, the reforms which can win success for Anand and Bardoli, will be useless if they are superficial.
('25', 190, 3, 7, 451401) They should go deep.
('25', 190, 3, 8, 451422) People’s hearts should be changed.
('25', 190, 3, 9, 451457) There should be no pretence of fearlessness; but fear should be truly destroyed.
('25', 190, 3, 10, 451538) Peace should not be put on but should be intelligently practised.
('25', 190, 3, 11, 451604) Khadi should not be merely worn but passionately loved.
('25', 190, 3, 12, 451660) The spinning wheel should not be formally worshipped but plied in every home as a religious duty.

('25', 190, 3, 14, 451794) If we remain slaves at heart, we would never attain freedom.
('25', 190, 4, 15, 451855) A NOVEL STRUGGLE
('25', 190, 5, 16, 451872) This is a test of satyagraha, of our firmness in clinging to truth.
('25', 190, 5, 17, 451940) To this day, there has been no nation in the world which claimed to adhere to truth and won its freedom.

('25', 190, 5, 20, 452189) It has enslaved us.
('25', 190, 5, 21, 452209) To a slave, his master seems free and he strives to be like the latter and so finds pleasure in enslaving others.
('25', 190, 5, 22, 452323) Such a slave never becomes really free, but is always subservient to anyone stronger than he is.
('25', 190, 6, 23, 452420) TRUTH MEANS TRUTH
('25', 190, 7, 24, 452438) But, at the moment, I do not wish to take the reader so deep into the matter.

('25', 193, 2, 4, 457982) SACRED WITHIN LIMITS
('25', 193, 3, 5, 458003) I have often shown that the sanctity of khadi lies in the fact of its being swadeshi.
('25', 193, 3, 6, 458089) Wheat is sacred grain, but it is eaten by a sannyasi and also by a thief.

('25', 193, 3, 23, 459908) Similarly, we should not attend the marriage if a young man of twenty five, on the death of his wife, gets himself engaged to another girl on the cremation ground itself and goes the very next day to marry her.

('25', 198, 4, 8, 468819) 87. NOTES
('25', 198, 5, 9, 468829) NO DESPAIR
('25', 198, 6, 10, 468840) What will happen in the Punjab where Lalaji is to be imprisoned and in Assam where Messrs Phooken and Bardolai have been already convicted and similarly in Ajmer where Maulana Mohiuddin, Chairman of both the Khilafat and the Congress Committees, has been imprisoned?—such was the question asked by anxious inquirers.
('25', 198, 6, 11, 469157) My answer was that the cause would progress for the incarceration of these chiefs.
('25', 198, 6, 12, 469240) As a result of these imprisonments I should expect greater restraint, a greater sense of responsibility in these provinces.
('25', 198, 6, 13, 469364) I should expect a greater output of khadi, a greater awakening among the students and the lawyers.
('25', 198, 6, 14, 469463) Bravery of the leaders must prove infectious, if we are fit to govern ourselves.
('25', 198, 6, 15, 469544) We must rise higher with repression not after.
('25', 198, 6, 16, 469591) It will pay a government based on force to resort to repression each time people are cowed down by it even though they may revive in the end.
('25', 198, 6, 17, 469733) Governments by force live for the day and thrive only upon repression.
('25', 198, 6, 18, 469804) They die a natural death when their forcible measures do not answer the purpose for which they are intended.
('25', 198, 6, 19, 469913) We never deserved our leaders, if after their withdrawal we could not make their spirit exhibit itself in and through us.
('25', 198, 7, 20, 470035) SIKH IMMOLATION
('25', 198, 8, 21, 470051) The Sikh countrymen are solving their own and India’s problem.
('25', 198, 8, 22, 470114) All their best men are offering themselves as sacrifice for the sake of their faith.
('25', 198, 8, 23, 470199) In soldierly fashion one after another they are seeking imprisonment without fuss and flutter and without the slightest violence.
('25', 198, 8, 24, 470329) If the same calm courage continues, they willwithout a shadow of doubt solve their own and with it also
('25', 199, 0, 1, 470433) 200 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('25', 199, 1, 2, 470475) solving India’s problem.
('25', 199, 1, 3, 470500) All India is watching with eager expectation this religious manifestation among the Sikhs.
('25', 199, 2, 4, 470591) REWARD OF ADOPTION
('25', 199, 3, 5, 470610) It is surprising that, so far as I know, no wire has been received by the Bombay Press regarding Mr. Stokes arrest in Lahore.
('25', 199, 3, 6, 470736) I see a paragraph in The Tribune referring to the event.
('25', 199, 3, 7, 470793) I cannot imagine that no wire has been despatched about such a sensational arrest.
('25', 199, 3, 8, 470876) My inference is that the wires notifying the arrest have been suppressed or delayed as were the wires about the arrest of the Ali Brothers.
('25', 199, 3, 9, 471016) Mr. Stokes was arrested on the 3rd instant at Lahore cantonment in connection with articles contributed by him to The Tribune as calculated to”spread sedition and promote hatred between different classes of His Majesty’s subjects.” The District Magistrate offered to release Mr. Stokes on bail but he refused to be so released.
('25', 199, 3, 10, 471344) This is a unique move on the part of the Government.
('25', 199, 3, 11, 471397) Mr. Stokes is an American who has naturalized himself as a British subject and who has made India his home in a manner in which perhaps no other American or Englishman has.
('25', 199, 3, 12, 471570) He rendered eminent services during the War and is known in the highest quarters as a well wisher of the Government.
('25', 199, 3, 13, 471687) No one can suspect him of ill will.
('25', 199, 3, 14, 471723) But that he should feel with and like an Indian and share his sorrows and throw himself into the struggle has proved too much for the Government.
('25', 199, 3, 15, 471869) To leave him free to criticize the Government was intolerable and so his white skin has proved no protection for him.
('25', 199, 3, 16, 471987) The Government is determined to quash the movement at any cost.
('25', 199, 3, 17, 472051) But it is beyond its ability to do so.
('25', 199, 3, 18, 472090) Mr. Stokes’ arrest perhaps demonstrates the weakness of the Government’s case as not even Lalaji’s does.
('25', 199, 3, 19, 472195) Lalaji has no reward of war service to his credit.
('25', 199, 3, 20, 472246) Lalaji is known to be”an agitator”.
('25', 199, 3, 21, 472282) He is not a white man.
('25', 199, 3, 22, 472305) When therefore Mr. Stokes is put away the strongest suspicion arises in respect of the bona fides of the Government case even in the estimation of an outsider.
('25', 199, 4, 23, 472465) BARDOLI
('25', 199, 5, 24, 472473) I have paid in the company of Maulana Azad Sobhani the much expected visit to Bardoli taluka.
('25', 199, 5, 25, 472567) It has a population of nearly one hundred thousand.
('25', 199, 5, 26, 472619) It has about 140 villages.
('25', 199, 5, 27, 472646) It had about sixty five Government schools.
('25', 199, 5, 28, 472690) Of these fifty one have been nationalized.
('25', 199, 5, 29, 472733) The Government schools are continued in some cases but have an attendance of less than 10 boys.
('25', 199, 5, 30, 472829) The national schools have charge of
('25', 200, 0, 1, 472865) VOL. 25 : 27 OCTOBER, 1921 22 JANUARY, 1922 201
('25', 200, 1, 2, 472913) over six thousand children including a few hundred girls.
('25', 200, 1, 3, 472971) Hand spin ning is compulsory in all these schools, though it is not yet being regularly taught or practised.
('25', 200, 1, 4, 473080) Most of the schools have been nationa lized only during the past three months.
('25', 200, 1, 5, 473159) In all the villages I found the women taking keen interest in the national movement.
('25', 200, 1, 6, 473244) We met thousands of people and visited six villages during the two days of our stay.
('25', 200, 1, 7, 473329) The majority of men were dressed from top to toe in hand spun khadi and a large number of women too were so dressed.
('25', 200, 1, 8, 473446) Those who were not complained that they could not obtain khadi.
('25', 200, 1, 9, 473510) This does not however mean that the people, either men or women, have given up the use of their old foreign stock.
('25', 200, 1, 10, 473625) Many, I am sorry to say, still use it for domestic wear.
('25', 200, 1, 11, 473682) Much is still left to be done in the shape of manufacture of khadi.
('25', 200, 1, 12, 473750) There is a good number of wheels but very few looms in the taluka.
('25', 200, 1, 13, 473817) The reader will be pained to hear that its staple crop is cotton which has hitherto been all exported.
('25', 200, 1, 14, 473920) There is complete harmony between Hindus and Mussulmans.
('25', 200, 1, 15, 473977) The relations with the co operators have not been bitter.
('25', 200, 1, 16, 474035) The untouchables freely attend meetings.
('25', 200, 1, 17, 474076) I have however suggested that it can hardly be considered satisfactory so long as the managers of national schools do not go out of their way to bring untouchable children to their schools and villagers do not take a personal interest in the welfare of these suppressed countrymen.
('25', 200, 1, 18, 474358) Many liquor shops are deserted.
('25', 200, 1, 19, 474390) From all the accounts received by me there has been little or no intimidation resorted to in order to achieve this very wonderful result.
('25', 200, 1, 20, 474528) In two or three cases volunteers visited villages, and on the parents hesitating to withdraw their children from Government school; sat dharna 1 and fasted until the poor bewildered parents had complied with their request.
('25', 200, 1, 21, 474751) I told the workers, that even this kind of pressure bordered on violence, for we had no right to make people conform to our opinion by fasting.
('25', 200, 1, 22, 474895) One may conceivably fast for enforcing one’s right but not for imposing one’s opinion on another.
('25', 200, 2, 23, 474993) There was, too, a social boycott of a liquor dealer who had not kept his promise.
('25', 200, 2, 24, 475075) I have advised even against such a boycott among a people so helpless as ours.
('25', 200, 2, 25, 475154) Strong public opinion must for the time being be our only remedy for correcting internal abuses.
('25', 200, 2, 26, 475251) Social boycott such as stopping barbers, washermen, etc., is undoubtedly a punishment which may be good in a free society but it becomes oppressive in a country which has for years been governed by force.
('25', 200, 3, 27, 475456) 1 Sitting at one spot for the purpose of exerting moral pressure
('25', 201, 0, 1, 475521) 202 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('25', 201, 1, 2, 475563) But I was remarkably struck by the almost completely peaceful manner in which the taluka of Bardoli has made a radical change for the better in many departments of life.
('25', 201, 1, 3, 475733) It was an agreeable surprise, too, to find the movement being handled by elderly men who have never taken part in politics.
('25', 201, 1, 4, 475857) The reader will be pleasingly astonished to find that all the wonderful work in Bardoli has been done by unpaid volunteers.
('25', 201, 1, 5, 475981) Bardoli happens to be a taluka in which there are few paupers and most people have easy means of livelihood.
('25', 201, 1, 6, 476090) This manifestation of public life is all the more remarkable on that account and is mainly if not entirely due to the utterly selfless services of a band of able and enthusiastic workers who only know to do or die.
('25', 201, 1, 7, 476305) But in spite of all this great work I was reluctantly obliged to give my verdict in which Maulana Azad Sobhani fully concurred and which was accepted by the noble band of workers, that Bardoli, before it challenged the might of a great empire, must complete its swadeshi programme to the extent of manufacturing sufficient hand spun to clothe itself, must freely admit untouchables into the national schools and must be so far non violent that solitary unarmed co operators and English and other officials might feel absolutely secure in their midst.
('25', 201, 1, 8, 476856) And these conditions, God willing, the good people of Bardoli have undertaken to fulfil in a few months’ time.
('25', 201, 1, 9, 476967) An elderly co operator put down six months at the outside.
('25', 201, 1, 10, 477026) An enthusiastic young man who knew what he was talking about put down the period at one month.
('25', 201, 1, 11, 477121) I close this happy recollection of our visit to Bardoli by informing the reader, that several co operators whom I met testified to the peaceful and zealous manner in which the volunteers had worked in this taluka which, let us hope, will still have the privilege, if necessary, of giving battle to the Government.
('25', 201, 2, 12, 477435) PRESIDENT ELECT
('25', 201, 3, 13, 477451) Lord Ronaldshay has addressed a homily to the President elect and warned him in effect that if he does not behave himself at Ahmedabad, His Excellency will teach him a lesson.
('25', 201, 3, 14, 477627) I know that it will not be the President’s fault if he misses the lesson.
('25', 201, 3, 15, 477701) He has sacrificed his all for his country.
('25', 201, 3, 16, 477744) He is taking up the high office of President at the most critical period in the history of the country.
('25', 201, 3, 17, 477848) He is tirelessly infusing new life into Bengal.
('25', 201, 3, 18, 477896) He is preaching and practising the gospel of non violence in season and out of season.
('25', 201, 3, 19, 477983) He will need all the loyal co operation that we can give him in his arduous task.
('25', 201, 3, 20, 478065) It will be rendered light if all the delegates come prepared with full and
('25', 202, 0, 1, 478140) VOL. 25 : 27 OCTOBER, 1921 22 JANUARY, 1922 203

('25', 202, 2, 3, 478283) DELEGATES
('25', 202, 3, 4, 478293) I am hoping that in every case delegates will have been elected in accordance with the constitution.
('25', 202, 3, 5, 478394) The delegates should thus be the real representatives of the electors who have had their names registered in Congress books.
('25', 202, 3, 6, 478519) Where a delegate has been imprisoned, a by election should take place to fill the vacancy.
('25', 202, 3, 7, 478610) There should be a full house to pass the necessary resolutions.
('25', 202, 3, 8, 478674) My ideal of a delegate is that he bears a spotless private and public character, that he knows the condition of his district in terms of the Congress programme, that he knows hand spinning so as to be able to teach it, that he habitually wears hand spun khadi, that he believes in non violence as his creed for the attainment of the national goal and for the perpetuation of Hindu Muslim Sikh Parsi Christian Jew unity, that he practises in his own person all that part of the programme of non co operation which is applicable to him, that he has prepared himself for imprisonment and placed at the disposal of the nation the bulk if not the whole of his time.
('25', 202, 3, 9, 479335) In addition if he is a Hindu, he must have discarded untouchability and done some service during the year to the untouchables of his district.
('25', 202, 3, 10, 479478) It is surely not much to expect six thousand staunch, true and fearless whole time workers for the service of thirty crores of people.
('25', 202, 3, 11, 479613) I would expect too the full proportion of Mussulman and Sikh delegates.
('25', 202, 3, 12, 479685) I hope too that every province will send a fair number of women and untouchables as delegates.
('25', 202, 4, 13, 479780) MEN AND MEASURES
('25', 202, 5, 14, 479797) Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru has sent the following frank and full reply in answer to my inquiry regarding the charge 1 brought against him by a correspondent of transferring his condemnation of the existing system of Government to its English authors and adminis trators:
('25', 202, 6, 15, 480065) I spoke on three occasions at the Provincial Conference at Agra.
('25', 202, 6, 16, 480130) I cannot repeat the language I used but I am very clear as to what I meant.
('25', 202, 6, 17, 480206) On the first occasion I protested against some veiled references to violence.
('25', 202, 6, 18, 480284) Hasrat Mohani was our President and in his presidential address he expressed his dissatisfaction with the creed of non violence.
('25', 202, 6, 19, 480413) Several other speakers used
('25', 202, 7, 20, 480441) 1 Vide”What Is Abuse?”, 17 11 1921
('25', 203, 0, 1, 480476) 204 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('25', 203, 1, 2, 480518) violent language and apparently looked forward to a time when violence would have full play.
('25', 203, 1, 3, 480611) All this took place on the Karachi Resolution.
('25', 203, 1, 4, 480658) I laid stress on the non violent character of the struggle and said that swadeshi was our only hope.
('25', 203, 2, 5, 480759) On the second day, I proposed the swadeshi resolution.
('25', 203, 2, 6, 480814) Notice of an amendment involving a boycott of British goods had been given.
('25', 203, 2, 7, 480890) It was on this occasion that I probably used the phrases and words which have been misunderstood by Mr. Gandhi’s questioner.
('25', 203, 2, 8, 481015) My whole argument was that so far no way but that of swadeshi had been shown to us to achieve our freedom.
('25', 203, 2, 9, 481122) I dealt with violence and disposed of it.
('25', 203, 2, 10, 481164) I then dealt with various other objections.
('25', 203, 2, 11, 481208) I stated that I desired most earnestly to rid India of English domination and the charkha and swadeshi were apparently the only means to bring this about.
('25', 203, 3, 12, 481363) I spoke a third time in answer to the amendment about boycott of British goods.
('25', 203, 3, 13, 481443) I had opposed this amendment, and a very heated debate had taken place, about a score of speakers having spoken on either side.
('25', 203, 3, 14, 481571) The amendment was put to the vote and lost.
('25', 203, 4, 15, 481615) It is evident that I have been misreported by some papers.
('25', 203, 4, 16, 481674) I have not so far seen any report of my speeches and do not know which paper can have done so.
('25', 203, 4, 17, 481769) My references to”English domination” or the”English Government” have been made to apply to the English people.
('25', 203, 4, 18, 481880) I may have used the words vaxzstksa dks fganksLrku ls vyx djuk 1 or some such language, and the reporter may have seized hold of this without reference to the context.
('25', 203, 4, 19, 482048) As a matter of fact, the very circumstance that I proposed to expel”the English” by swadeshi ought to have convinced the listener that I referred to the system and not to individuals.
('25', 203, 4, 20, 482232) It would be absurd to try to expel a single Englishman by the charkha.
('25', 203, 5, 21, 482303) I cannot of course say that my feeling towards Englishmen as such is entirely impersonal.
('25', 203, 5, 22, 482393) I hate the system but sometimes, in spite of myself, I cannot help feeling ill will towards a certain individual for some time at least, and sometimes the ill will is transferred to the English people as a whole.
('25', 203, 5, 23, 482606) But the feeling is always momentary.
('25', 203, 5, 24, 482643) I am really surprised at the general absence of ill will against the English.
('25', 203, 6, 25, 482721) It is somewhat curious that the sentences to which exception has been taken occurred in a speech opposing a boycott of British goods.
('25', 203, 6, 26, 482855) I opposed this on the ground, inter alia, that it was opposed to the basic
('25', 203, 7, 27, 482930) principle of non co operation, that it was based on hate and not love and so
('25', 203, 8, 28, 483007) 1 “To expel the English from India”
('25', 204, 0, 1, 483043) VOL. 25 : 27 OCTOBER, 1921 22 JANUARY, 1922 205
('25', 204, 1, 2, 483091) No one who heard me and who understood Urdu could have gone away with the impression that I was taking part in a crusade against individual Englishmen.
('25', 204, 2, 3, 483243) It is always difficult to differentiate between a man and his action.
('25', 204, 2, 4, 483313) I can well believe that if an Englishman insulted me, I would flare up and hit him.
('25', 204, 2, 5, 483397) But I think this would be weakness on my part.
('25', 204, 2, 6, 483444) I have not enough control over myself.
('25', 204, 2, 7, 483483) I am apt to lose temper at the slightest provocation.
('25', 204, 2, 8, 483537) I am occasionally very angry with Englishmen.
('25', 204, 2, 9, 483583) But I have never
('25', 204, 3, 10, 483600) experienced the desire to”expel” Englishmen as such.
('25', 204, 3, 11, 483653) In spite of everything I am a great admirer of the English, and in many things l feel even now that an Englishman can understand me better than the average Indian.
('25', 204, 3, 12, 483817) The letter illustrates the danger of relying on newspaper reports.
('25', 204, 3, 13, 483884) The late Sir Pherozeshah Mehta so dreaded the reports that he never made an important pronouncement except in writing.
('25', 204, 3, 14, 484003) The late Mr. Gokhale used often to insist upon revising reports of his own speeches.
('25', 204, 3, 15, 484088) If these masters of oratory were in danger of being misreported, what is to be said of those who make their speeches in Hindustani and have the misfortune to be reported in English?
('25', 204, 3, 16, 484270) In spite of all the goodwill in the world, reporters have rarely succeeded in reporting my speeches correctly.
('25', 204, 3, 17, 484381) Indeed the best thing would be not to report speeches at all, except when they have undergone revision by the speakers themselves.
('25', 204, 3, 18, 484512) If this simple rule were followed much misunderstanding could be avoided.
('25', 204, 4, 19, 484586) Young India, 8 12 1921
('25', 204, 5, 20, 484609) 88. IN EARNEST
('25', 204, 6, 21, 484624) The arrest of Lala Lajpat Rai and Messrs Lalkhan, Santanam and Gopichand in the Punjab, of Messrs Phooken and Bardolai in Assam, Babu Jitendralal Bannerjee in Bengal, Maulana Mohiuddin and others in Ajmer and Mr. Harkarannath Mishra and others in Lucknow means business.
('25', 204, 6, 22, 484895) It shows not merely that the Government is in earnest but that it is not going to tolerate non co operation any longer; no longer is it a question of putting down violence, it is one of compelling co operation.
('25', 204, 6, 23, 485106) And this is as it should be.
('25', 204, 6, 24, 485135) The Government had to appear in its true colours some day or other.
('25', 204, 6, 25, 485203) No Prince had such welcome as is being offered to the Prince of Wales.
('25', 204, 6, 26, 485274) The chosen leaders of the people are being put away so that the latter may accept the lead of the Government and so that there may be no hartal on the
('25', 205, 0, 1, 485425) 206 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('25', 205, 1, 2, 485467) day of the Prince’s entry into the various provinces.
('25', 205, 1, 3, 485521) All this the Government of India, constituted as it is, has a right to do, and we non co operate because it claims and exercises such right on due occasion.
('25', 205, 1, 4, 485678) The right consists in its imposing its will upon the people, not recognizing that of the people to have their own way except on pain of being imprisoned.
('25', 205, 1, 5, 485832) The issue is clear, and neatly summed up in the Lawrence statue whose removal the Government will not allow although it is the property in law of the people.
('25', 205, 1, 6, 485990) It must govern by the pen or the sword.
('25', 205, 1, 7, 486030) Once more the choice has been offered to the people.
('25', 205, 1, 8, 486083) Will they accept the honourable imposition of the sword and reject the degrading dictation of the pen?
('25', 205, 1, 9, 486186) The people cannot complain if after fifteen months’ training they do not know what to do.
('25', 205, 1, 10, 486276) Indeed the best thing they can do is to do nothing, i.e., to remain as they were and continue as if nothing extraordinary had happened.
('25', 205, 1, 11, 486412) England did not stop the War because Lord Kitchner died.”Business as usual” was her motto.
('25', 205, 1, 12, 486503) She was well organized for violence—well enough to do without a general or to find an endless succession of generals.
('25', 205, 1, 13, 486621) Are we so well organized for non violence as to do without leaders, i.e., have an endless succession of them?
('25', 205, 1, 14, 486731) In the person of Lala Lajpat Rai the Government have arrested one of the greatest of us.
('25', 205, 1, 15, 486820) His name is known all over India.
('25', 205, 1, 16, 486854) His self sacrifice has enshrined him in the hearts of his countrymen.
('25', 205, 1, 17, 486924) He has laboured as very few have for non violence side by side with the freest expression and organization of public opinion.
('25', 205, 1, 18, 487050) His arrest typifies as nothing else can the attitude of the Government.
('25', 205, 1, 19, 487122) The Punjab has lost no time in choosing a successor.
('25', 205, 1, 20, 487175) The Punjabis could not have made a better choice than by electing Agha Sufdar.
('25', 205, 1, 21, 487254) He is one of the truest of Mussulmans and one of the bravest of Indians.
('25', 205, 1, 22, 487327) His services are all rendered in a most unassuming manner.
('25', 205, 1, 23, 487386) I have no doubt that he will command the same loyal co operation that Lalaji has.
('25', 205, 1, 24, 487468) The best honour that the Punjabis can do to Lalaji is to continue his work as if he was in their midst.
('25', 205, 1, 25, 487572) It is blind, foolish and selfish love which dissolves with the disappearance permanent or temporary of the earthy tabernacle which holds the deathless spirit.
('25', 205, 1, 26, 487731) The Punjabis may not always get an Agha Sufdar to guide them in the place of Lalaji.
('25', 205, 1, 27, 487816) He may be removed from their midst sooner than we may expect.
('25', 205, 1, 28, 487878) In well ordered organizations leaders are elected for convenience of work, not for extraordinary merit.
('25', 205, 1, 29, 487982) A leader is only first among equals.
('25', 205, 1, 30, 488019) Some one must be put first,
('25', 206, 0, 1, 488047) VOL. 25 : 27 OCTOBER, 1921 22 JANUARY, 1922 207
('25', 206, 1, 2, 488095) but he is and should be no stronger than the weakest link in the chain.
('25', 206, 1, 3, 488167) Having therefore made our selection we must follow him, or the chain is broken and all is lost.
('25', 206, 1, 4, 488263) I wish I could impart my faith to the people that nothing much remains to be done in order to take us to the heaven.
('25', 206, 1, 5, 488380) The way is clear before us.
('25', 206, 1, 6, 488408) The President elect has stated it in unequivocal terms:
('25', 206, 2, 7, 488464) My first word and my last word to you is never to forsake the ideal of non violent non co operation.
('25', 206, 2, 8, 488565) I know it is a difficult creed to follow.
('25', 206, 2, 9, 488607) I know that sometimes the provocation is so great that it is extremely difficult to remain non violent in thought, word and deed.
('25', 206, 2, 10, 488737) The success of the movement however depends upon this great principle.
('25', 206, 2, 11, 488808) In order to enable us to enforce this great principle in our own lives we must avoid all occasions for provocation.
('25', 206, 2, 12, 488924) We therefore need no demonstrations now nor big meetings, we must discipline those who have become awakened to withstand provocation and to do constructive national work which is organisation of carding, hand spinning and hand weaving so as to enable the nation to supplement her slender resources and to find work for the idle hours of the millions.
('25', 206, 2, 13, 489275) Hindu Muslim unity is an article of faith with us.
('25', 206, 2, 14, 489326) It is not to be cultivated or demonstrated except by all working together for national uplift and therefore devoting their time exclusively to manufacture of khadi.
('25', 206, 3, 15, 489491) As soon as we have attained a complete boycott of foreign cloth and begun to manufacture our own khadi in our respective provinces and villages, we can become free probably without having to resort to mass civil disobedience.
('25', 206, 3, 16, 489717) Therefore aggressive civil disobedience should be avoided, at least till after finishing the boycott of foreign cloth and qualifying for the manufacture of hand spun khadi.
('25', 206, 3, 17, 489890) Defensive civil disobedience which is forced on us in the prosecution of our campaign we ought to welcome whenever it comes.
('25', 206, 3, 18, 490015) It will be a distinct sign of weakness and unfitness for swaraj, if these imprisonments dishearten or demoralize us.
('25', 206, 3, 19, 490132) He is no soldier who is afraid or unwilling to pay the toll demanded of him.
('25', 206, 3, 20, 490209) The more he is called upon to pay, the more glad he is to find himself the first to have to pay.
('25', 206, 3, 21, 490306) Let us believe and know that we must provide the Government jails with all the work they can take.

('25', 216, 2, 4, 513004) Pity and hatred may be the same to a man who has become perfect.
('25', 216, 2, 5, 513069) Only he will then have little cause for killing.
('25', 216, 2, 6, 513118) For me an imperfect being love and hate are two distinct and opposite sensations, and reading the Bhagavad Gita in its applicability to imperfect men, I find it hard to believe that we can kill without being angered.
('25', 216, 2, 7, 513335) In my humble opinion it is a prostitution of the Vedanta to apply to imperfect beings conduct possible only for perfect beings.
('25', 216, 2, 8, 513463) 2. I advised the cultured untouchables of Travancore that they might singly demand entrance to temples if they could exercise restraint and stand insults from the keepers without seeking the assistance of courts of law.
('25', 216, 2, 9, 513683) My advise to untouchables generally is not to test the right of entry into temples whilst the evil of untouchability is otherwise still in existence.
('25', 216, 2, 10, 513833) In no case have I advised entry into sanctuaries.
('25', 216, 2, 11, 513883) In theory I do claim that custodians of Hindu temples should throw open to untouchables those parts which are open to other classes.
('25', 216, 3, 12, 514016) S. GOVINDSWAMI IYER: If you believe in non co operation, you cannot join the students’ military Corps.
('25', 216, 3, 13, 514119) Young India, 8 12 1921
('25', 216, 4, 14, 514142) 93. SWADESHI IN THE UNITED PROVINCES
('25', 216, 5, 15, 514179) The progress of swadeshi in the U. P., a report 1 of which has been prepared by the U.P. Provincial Congress Committee, is full of lessons for the other provinces of India, both as regards the success achieved in the several lines of organizing work as well as the difficulties that had to be encountered.
('25', 216, 5, 16, 514485) The work was considered under the following heads (1) Distribution of charkhas; (2) organizing a khadi depot; (3) supplying hand spun yarn to weavers and inducing them to weave only such yarn; and (4) organizing the boycott The U. P. Provincial Congress Committee deserves congratula tions upon its progress in swadeshi.
('25', 216, 5, 17, 514806) I hope however that it will not be satisfied till its khadi is all made of hand spun yarn.
('25', 216, 5, 18, 514897) Development of hand spinning is the key to the solution of India’s poverty.
('25', 216, 5, 19, 514973) Experts are required to improve and regularize the quality of hand spun yarn.
('25', 216, 5, 20, 515051) Young Indian, 8 12 1921
('25', 216, 6, 21, 515075) 1 Only the opening paragraph of the condensed report published in Young India,1 12 1921 is reproduced here.
('25', 217, 0, 1, 515183) 218 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('25', 217, 1, 2, 515225) 94. LOVE NOT HATE
('25', 217, 2, 3, 515243) SABARMATI,
('25', 217, 3, 4, 515254) December 8, 1921
('25', 217, 4, 5, 515271) A telegram from Allahabad says Pandit Motilal Nehru, Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru, Pandit Shamlal Nehru and Mr. George Joseph, Editor of the Independent have been arrested.
('25', 217, 4, 6, 515439) It was received at 11 o’clock last night.
('25', 217, 4, 7, 515481) It positively filled me with joy.
('25', 217, 4, 8, 515515) I thanked God for it.
('25', 217, 4, 9, 515537) I had not expected Panditji’s arrest.
('25', 217, 4, 10, 515575) In our discussions I used to tell Panditji that he would be about the last to be arrested.
('25', 217, 4, 11, 515666) Sir Harcourt Butler would not have the courage to lay hands upon him.
('25', 217, 4, 12, 515736) His friend Rajasaheb of Mahmudabad would decline to remain in office if he was to be arrested.
('25', 217, 4, 13, 515831) I marvel at Sir Harcourt Butler’s philosophic courage.
('25', 217, 4, 14, 515886) Panditji has been working against tremendous odds.
('25', 217, 4, 15, 515937) He has been battling against his old enemy asthma.
('25', 217, 4, 16, 515988) I know that he has never worked for his rich clients, nor even for the afflicted Punjab as he has slaved for pauper India.
('25', 217, 4, 17, 516111) I have pleaded with him to take rest.
('25', 217, 4, 18, 516149) He has refused to do so.
('25', 217, 4, 19, 516174) It rejoice to think that he will now have respite from the toil that was wearing him out.
('25', 217, 4, 20, 516264) But my joy was greater for the thought, that what I had feared would not happen before the end of the year because of the sin of Bombay was now happening by reason of the innocent suffering of the greatest and the best in the land.
('25', 217, 4, 21, 516496) These arrests of the totally innocent is real swaraj.
('25', 217, 4, 22, 516550) Now there is no shame in the Ali Brothers and their companions remaining in jail.
('25', 217, 4, 23, 516632) India has not been found undeserving of their immolation.
('25', 217, 4, 24, 516690) But my joy, which I hope thousands share with me, is conditional upon perfect peace being observed whilst our leaders are one after another taken away from us.
('25', 217, 4, 25, 516850) Victory is complete if non violence reigns supreme in spite of the arrests.
('25', 217, 4, 26, 516926) Disastrous defeat is a certainty if we cannot control all the elements so as to ensure peace.
('25', 217, 4, 27, 517020) We are out to be killed without killing.
('25', 217, 4, 28, 517061) We have stipulated to go to prison without feeling angry or injured.
('25', 217, 4, 29, 517130) We must not quarrel with the condition of our own creating.
('25', 217, 4, 30, 517190) On the contrary our non violence teaches us to love our enemies.
('25', 217, 4, 31, 517255) By non violent non co operation we seek to conquer the wrath of the English administrators and heir supporters.
('25', 217, 4, 32, 517367) We must love them and pray to God that they might have wisdom to
('25', 218, 0, 1, 517432) VOL. 25 : 27 OCTOBER, 1921 22 JANUARY, 1922 219
('25', 218, 1, 2, 517480) see what appears us to be their errors.
('25', 218, 1, 3, 517520) It must be the prayer of the strong and not of the weak.
('25', 218, 1, 4, 517577) In our strength must we humble ourselves before our Maker.
('25', 218, 1, 5, 517636) In the moment of our trial and our triumph let me declare my faith, I believe in loving my enemies.
('25', 218, 1, 6, 517736) I believe in non violence as the only remedy open to the Hindus, Mussulmans, Sikhs, Parsis, Christians and Jews of India.
('25', 218, 1, 7, 517858) I believe in the power of suffering to melt the stoniest heart.
('25', 218, 1, 8, 517922) The brunt of the battle must fall on the first three.
('25', 218, 1, 9, 517976) The last named three are afraid of the combination of the first three.
('25', 218, 1, 10, 518047) We must by our honest conduct demonstrate to them that they are our kinsmen.
('25', 218, 1, 11, 518124) We must by our conduct demonstrate to every Englishman that he is as safe in the remotest corner of India as he professes to feel behind the machine gun.
('25', 218, 1, 12, 518278) Islam, Hinduism, Sikhism, Christianity, Zoroastrianism and Judaism—in fact religion is on its trial.
('25', 218, 1, 13, 518379) Either we believe in God and His righteousness or we do not.
('25', 218, 1, 14, 518440) My association with the noblest of Mussulmans has taught me to see that Islam has spread not by the power of the sword but by the prayerful love of an unbroken line of its saints and fakirs.
('25', 218, 1, 15, 518631) Warrant there is in Islam for drawing the sword; but the conditions laid down are so strict that they are not capable of being fulfilled by everybody.
('25', 218, 1, 16, 518782) Where is the unerring general to order jehad?
('25', 218, 1, 17, 518828) Where is the suffering, the love and the purification that must precede the very idea of drawing the sword?
('25', 218, 1, 18, 518936) Hindus are at least as much bound by similar restrictions as the Mussulmans of India.
('25', 218, 1, 19, 519022) The Sikhs have their recent proud history to warn them against the use of force.
('25', 218, 1, 20, 519103) We are too imperfect, too impure and too selfish as yet to resort to an armed conflict in the cause of God as Shaukat Ali would say.
('25', 218, 1, 21, 519236) Will a purified India ever need to draw the sword?
('25', 218, 1, 22, 519287) And it was the definite process of purification we commenced last year at Calcutta.
('25', 218, 1, 23, 519371) What must we then do?
('25', 218, 1, 24, 519393) Surely remain non violent and yet strong enough to offer as many willing victims as the Government may require for imprisonment.
('25', 218, 1, 25, 519522) Our work must continue with clock work regularity.
('25', 218, 1, 26, 519573) Each province must elect its own succession of leaders.
('25', 218, 1, 27, 519629) Lalaji has set a brilliant example by making all the necessary arrangements.
('25', 218, 1, 28, 519706) The chairman and the secretary must be given in each province emergency powers.
('25', 218, 1, 29, 519786) The executive committees must be the smallest possible.
('25', 218, 1, 30, 519842) Every Congressman must be a volunteer.
('25', 218, 1, 31, 519881) Whilst we must not avoid arrest we must not provoke it by giving unnecessary offence.
('25', 219, 0, 1, 519967) 220 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('25', 219, 1, 2, 520009) We must vigorously prosecute the swadeshi campaign till we are fully organized for the manufacture of all the hand spun khadi we require and have brought about a complete boycott of foreign cloth.
('25', 219, 1, 3, 520206) We must hold the Congress at any cost in spite of the arrest of everyone of the leaders unless the Government dissolve it by force.
('25', 219, 1, 4, 520338) And if we are neither cowed down nor provoked to violence but are able to continue national work, we have certainly attained swaraj.
('25', 219, 1, 5, 520471) For no power on earth can stop the onward march of a peaceful, determined and godly people.
('25', 219, 2, 6, 520563) M. K. GANDHI Young India, 8 12 1921
('25', 219, 3, 7, 520599) 95. COMPLAINT OF THE UNTOUCHABLES
('25', 219, 4, 8, 520633) Two Antyaja Friends write as follows: 1
('25', 219, 5, 9, 520673) There is, in this complaint, a measure of ignorance and of anger arising from ignorance, but, that apart, the letter deserves consideration.
('25', 219, 5, 10, 520814) By passing resolutions and talking about their problem we have raised hopes in them.
('25', 219, 5, 11, 520899) It was absolutely necessary to do this.
('25', 219, 5, 12, 520939) It was necessary also that hopes should be raised in them and to tell those Antyaja friends that what has happened should be sufficient answer to them.
('25', 219, 5, 13, 521091) Another answer can be that they lay the entire burden on me.
('25', 219, 5, 14, 521152) I can understand the sting in their words.
('25', 219, 5, 15, 521195) They accuse me of being satisfied with the more or less that I do myself and of being gullible enough to be taken in by others who only befool me.
('25', 219, 5, 16, 521342) However, if I do something, there are others who may be doing less but still they do it.
('25', 219, 5, 17, 521431) Untouchability is an attitude of the mind, not a concrete object.
('25', 219, 5, 18, 521497) To eradicate it, therefore, is not as easy as to persuade pupils to leave schools.
('25', 219, 5, 19, 521580) No agitation, therefore, like the one with regard to schools can be suggested in respect of untouchability.
('25', 219, 5, 20, 521688) A change of heart is necessary for this reform, as it is for accepting the principle of non violence.
('25', 219, 5, 21, 521790) The movement, therefore, can only be carried on along the same line as that for non violence.
('25', 219, 5, 22, 521884) Just as the extent to which the latter has been accepted by the people can be measured from the occasional incidents of violence which occur, so can progress in the removal of untouchability be measured from occasional evidence of
('25', 219, 6, 23, 522115) 1 Not reproduced here
('25', 220, 0, 1, 522137) VOL. 25 : 27 OCTOBER, 1921 22 JANUARY, 1922 221
('25', 220, 1, 2, 522185) its survival.
('25', 220, 1, 3, 522199) No rule of arithmetic can be applied to judge this.
('25', 220, 1, 4, 522251) You cannot work out as an arithmetical exercise,”If so many Hindus have mixed with so many unit touchables within such a period of time, what time will it take for all the crores of Hindus to mix with all the millions of untouchables?”—and ascertain the progress from the answer.
('25', 220, 1, 5, 522531) But we get a measure of the progress from incidents which occur from time to time.
('25', 220, 1, 6, 522614) The issue was first discussed as a principle in the Gujarat Vidyapith.
('25', 220, 1, 7, 522685) As a result, the principle of admitting Antyaja pupils in its schools was accepted even at the risk of putting its very existence in danger, and some members who had tendered their resignations on this issue were allowed to leave the Vidyapith.
('25', 220, 1, 8, 522930) If, again, the existence of an institution like the Dakshinamurti Bhavan is in serious danger today, the reason is the same.
('25', 220, 1, 9, 523055) The teachers who are the very soul of the Bhavan are fighting a life and death struggle there to get the principle accepted.
('25', 220, 1, 10, 523180) I cannot claim credit for either of these two results.
('25', 220, 1, 11, 523235) I would have been defeated if the majority of the members of the Vidyapith had opposed me.
('25', 220, 1, 12, 523326) But, on the contrary, they themselves believed in the principle independently of my view.
('25', 220, 1, 13, 523416) In the holy fight which is being waged in the Dakshinamurti Bhavan, I cannot claim to have a hand even as an individual member.
('25', 220, 1, 14, 523544) It was because of this issue that several proffered donations to the Tilak Swaraj Fund were withheld, but the managers of the Fund did not care for the loss.
('25', 220, 1, 15, 523702) Antyajas have freely attended hundreds of public meetings in Gujarat and elsewhere.
('25', 220, 1, 16, 523786) The All lndia Congress Committee has sanctioned an expenditure of more than Rs. 50,000 for Antyaja welfare activities at various places.
('25', 220, 1, 17, 523923) This amount excludes the money already spent by the Provincial Committees.
('25', 220, 1, 18, 523998) Non co operators have thus been working all over India and independently of party considerations.
('25', 220, 1, 19, 524096) In every province, enthusiastic young men of character have been, with the utmost sincerity of purpose, sacrificing their all in the service of Antyajas.
('25', 220, 1, 20, 524250) This is the first time that, in every constituency, Antyaja brothers have been elected delegates though they had expressed no such desire.
('25', 220, 1, 21, 524389) This for the satisfaction of the authors of the letter and other Antyaja friends like them who feel disappointed.
('25', 220, 1, 22, 524503) But, while we may draw their attention to such a movement having spread, we must admit at the same time that there is some truth in their complaint.
('25', 220, 1, 23, 524652) Many persons simply make a show of mixing [with Antyajas] in order to hoodwink others, and are not sincere about the matter.
('25', 220, 1, 24, 524777) Mixing with them in this spirit will yield bitter fruit.
('25', 221, 0, 1, 524834) 222 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('25', 221, 1, 2, 524876) practice of untouchability is an offence against dharma and its disappearance will bear fruit only if the prejudice is shed from the heart.
('25', 221, 1, 3, 525016) The campaign against it is not a political move so that we may do just enough to throw dust in people’s eyes.
('25', 221, 1, 4, 525126) Nor is the movement undertaken in order to please or bribe Antyajas.
('25', 221, 1, 5, 525195) Our only object is to satisfy our own conscience; our very conception of this evil is that, as long as Hindu society does not rid itself of it, it will continue to block our path invisibly, if not visibly, and will prevent our success in winning swaraj The consequences of karma are hard to comprehend; its law admits of no exception.
('25', 221, 1, 6, 525530) We always reap, visibly or invisibly, the fruits of our good and bad deeds, of our sins and virtuous acts.
('25', 221, 2, 7, 525637) There is not a shred of doubt in my mind that so long as we have not cleansed our hearts of this evil and have not accepted the path of non violence, so long as Hindus and Muslims have not become sincerely united, we shall not be free.
('25', 221, 2, 8, 525873) Our progress in all these three fields is impossible to measure by any visible yardstick.
('25', 221, 2, 9, 525963) Till we succeed in regard to all three, we shall not get swaraj and when we get it, we shall have succeeded in them.
('25', 221, 2, 10, 526080) So long as Hindu society turns a deaf ear to the six crores of Antyajas crying for justice at our doors, we shall not get swaraj, never.
('25', 221, 3, 11, 526217) But even if caste Hindus wash off their sins, will Antyajas ascend to heaven in consequence?
('25', 221, 3, 12, 526310) For that, they themselves should strive.
('25', 221, 3, 13, 526351) They should give up drinking, refuse to eat leftovers, stop eating meat and, though for the sake of service, engaged in the most uncleanly work, remain clean and worship God.
('25', 221, 3, 14, 526526) All this is for them to attend to.
('25', 221, 3, 15, 526561) Others cannot do it for them.
('25', 221, 3, 16, 526591) To banish hunger from among them, they have the spinning wheel and the handloom at their service.
('25', 221, 3, 17, 526689) Thousands of Antyajas have taken them up and prospered.
('25', 221, 3, 18, 526745) The swadeshi movement is such that it feeds and strengthens all the limbs and I, for one, am certain that it is swadeshi which will, in time, end our abject poverty.
('25', 221, 4, 19, 526911) [From Gujarati]
('25', 221, 5, 20, 526927) Navajivan, 8 12 1921
('25', 222, 0, 1, 526948) VOL. 25 : 27 OCTOBER, 1921 22 JANUARY, 1922 223

('25', 226, 4, 8, 532438) 104. EXTRACT FROM LETTER TO SHYAM SUNDER CHAKRAVARTY2
('25', 226, 5, 9, 532492) [AHMEDABAD,
('25', 226, 6, 10, 532504) After December 10, 1921]
('25', 226, 7, 11, 532529) It is a delightful thing to hear of these arrests; two things are needed to ensure early establishment of swaraj—a ceaseless stream of civil resisters, and a non violent atmosphere.
('25', 226, 7, 12, 532711) I hope that Bengal will lead in both these matters.
('25', 226, 8, 13, 532763) Seven Months with Mahatma Gandhi, p.
('25', 226, 9, 14, 532800) 105. ONE YEAR’S TIME LIMIT
('25', 226, 10, 15, 532827) I am being implored, on the one hand, not to carry out my threat to retire to the Himalayas if we do not get swaraj by the end of this year.
('25', 226, 10, 16, 532968) On the other hand, I am asked what face I shall show to the people if we fail to get swaraj.
('25', 226, 10, 17, 533061) How great will be the people’s disappointment?
('25', 226, 10, 18, 533108) Having made a promise, I shall now realize what an error I have made.
('25', 226, 10, 19, 533178) I expect that readers of Navajivan will not think in this manner.
('25', 226, 10, 20, 533244) But I know that some of them do.
('25', 226, 10, 21, 533277) My promise was conditional.
('25', 226, 10, 22, 533305) Laying down conditions which could be easily fulfilled, I told the people:”Fulfill these conditions and win swaraj.” But friends can argue that, when laying down conditions, a man of practical wisdom would consider the other party’s capacity to fulfil them.
('25', 226, 10, 23, 533563) This is true.
('25', 226, 10, 24, 533577) It is also true that I claim to be such a man.
('25', 226, 10, 25, 533624) If I think I cannot make this claim, I should not remain in public life.
('25', 226, 11, 26, 533697) 1 On the arrest of C. R. Das on December 10 2 This was written when the addressee, editor, Servant of Calcutta became the President of the Bengal Congress Committee after the arrest of C. R. Das on December 10, 1921
('25', 227, 0, 1, 533913) 228 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('25', 227, 1, 2, 533955) If, therefore, people are obliged to ask, at the end of the year, When they would get the promised swaraj, my claim of practical wisdom would have been disproved and I must betake myself to the Himalayas.
('25', 227, 2, 3, 534160) However, if the people clearly realize that the only way to get swaraj is the one I have pointed out and feel that they have covered a long distance on the road, have almost reached its end, they will have no ground for reproaching me nor I any reason for running away to the Himalayas.
('25', 227, 2, 4, 534447) We shall then almost have won swaraj.
('25', 227, 2, 5, 534485) One who has discovered the path to liberation always obeys the yama and niyama disciplines, who observes his chains loosening day by day, has as good as attained liberation.
('25', 227, 2, 6, 534659) He does not swerve from his path.
('25', 227, 2, 7, 534693) As the days pass, he goes from strength to strength.
('25', 227, 2, 8, 534746) He needs no guide.
('25', 227, 2, 9, 534765) The man who doubts has his moorings nowhere and is doomed to perish.
('25', 227, 2, 10, 534834) Though moving on the road, he does not advance because he does not know where he is.
('25', 227, 3, 11, 534919) Similarly, if all the delegates who will be assembling [for the Congress] in this month agree without much argument that the path we have taken is the only one which can lead to swaraj, that we already see swaraj in the distance, that we have achieved more during this year than during any previous year and that they, the delegates, are determined to adhere to this path—then, I would say, we have as good as got swaraj.
('25', 227, 3, 12, 535341) It is due to lack of effort on our part that something will still remain to be secured.
('25', 227, 3, 13, 535429) A little more effort and our swaraj will be complete.
('25', 227, 4, 14, 535483) Those who believe, and those who have spread the belief, that Gandhi will somehow get them swaraj before December, both these classes of persons are, whether or not they know it, their own and the country’s enemies; they have not understood the meaning of swaraj at all.
('25', 227, 4, 15, 535754) Swaraj means self reliance.
('25', 227, 4, 16, 535782) To hope that I shall get swaraj for them is the opposite of self reliance.
('25', 227, 4, 17, 535857) I can only point out the means; it is then for the people to work and secure swaraj.
('25', 227, 4, 18, 535942) I am a vaidya; I prescribe the medicine, explain the manner of taking it, mention the other things to be taken with it and specify the quantity to be taken every time.
('25', 227, 4, 19, 536110) It is ultimately for the patient to act and do the best he can.
('25', 227, 4, 20, 536174) If, at the end of the year, the people have not realized through their own experience that swaraj will be won through non violence, through unity of Hindus, Muslims, Sikhs, Parsis, Christians and Jews,
('25', 228, 0, 1, 536376) VOL. 25 : 27 OCTOBER, 1921 22 JANUARY, 1922 229
('25', 228, 1, 2, 536424) through swadeshi and the removal of untouchability, then I shall have been proved totally deficient in practical wisdom and I must retire to the Himalayas.
('25', 228, 2, 3, 536580) It is true that I had expected much more than this.
('25', 228, 2, 4, 536632) I had expected that we would not only discover the path during this year, but would also see the image of swaraj before our eyes, would have arrived at a settlement with the rulers and, non co operation having been withdrawn, would have commenced genuine co operation.
('25', 228, 2, 5, 536901) I am afraid we shall not see ourselves placed in this happy position during the days which remain.
('25', 228, 2, 6, 537000) On the contrary, our non co operation will have become more intense and co operation will appear to be out of the question altogether.
('25', 228, 2, 7, 537135) But this phase itself will bring co operation nearer.
('25', 228, 2, 8, 537189) It is the darkest before dawn.
('25', 228, 2, 9, 537220) The pain before delivery being almost unbearable, the woman doubts whether the delivery will ever take place.
('25', 228, 2, 10, 537330) In the same way, the hour of birth of our freedom will be the most difficult period for us.
('25', 228, 3, 11, 537422) Bombay put an obstacle in our path.
('25', 228, 3, 12, 537458) We ourselves had planned to start a fight and invite suffering upon ourselves; Bombay made this impossible.
('25', 228, 3, 13, 537566) But, fortunately for us, the Government itself has given us an opportunity of doing so, having intensified repression.
('25', 228, 3, 14, 537685) If we fearlessly avail ourselves of the opportunity it has offered, we shall see before long freedom become a reality.
('25', 228, 4, 15, 537804) Why do I not, however, say categorically that this will not happen during the present year?
('25', 228, 4, 16, 537896) I do not say this because I do not know for certain.
('25', 228, 4, 17, 537949) I am not omniscient.
('25', 228, 4, 18, 537970) I am not God.
('25', 228, 4, 19, 537984) I believe God to be omnipotent.
('25', 228, 4, 20, 538016) No one knows when He will bring about profound changes in our hearts.
('25', 228, 4, 21, 538086) Did I know that, on the 17th November, even while I was voicing great optimism, heartbreaking things were being done?
('25', 228, 4, 22, 538204) How can I be sure that, while I am myself uncertain whether we shall see freedom become a reality during the days which remain, God is not actually preparing this result?
('25', 228, 4, 23, 538375) If I am the doctor, I am the patient too.
('25', 228, 4, 24, 538417) I have not won the freedom for which I have been striving.
('25', 228, 4, 25, 538476) I have discovered the path and I will never abandon it.
('25', 228, 4, 26, 538532) But the freedom which I want is still far away.
('25', 228, 4, 27, 538580) I would not be surprised, however, if I got it in this month.
('25', 228, 4, 28, 538642) I can assure the readers that I have spared no efforts.
('25', 228, 4, 29, 538698) I am in truth seeking my own moksha through my efforts to win swaraj for India.
('25', 228, 4, 30, 538778) When I feel that instead of progressing towards moksha, I am forging chains for myself, that instead of rising I am falling, no one will be able to hold me back.
('25', 228, 4, 31, 538940) At present, though, I
('25', 229, 0, 1, 538962) 230 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('25', 229, 1, 2, 539004) do not feel that my bonds have become stronger.
('25', 229, 1, 3, 539052) I state most emphatically that I do not know what the state of my mind will be on the 1st of January.
('25', 229, 1, 4, 539154) The reader will thus see that the struggle for swaraj is a spiritual effort for me, a means of attaining moksha.
('25', 229, 1, 5, 539267) My effort is purely selfish and will remain so.
('25', 229, 1, 6, 539315) In one sense, I do not wish to see freedom become a reality this year.
('25', 229, 1, 7, 539386) I wish to see all fanciful notions about me dispelled.
('25', 229, 1, 8, 539441) I want people to know that I am but a small creature.
('25', 229, 1, 9, 539495) I see nothing but harm to the people and to me in my being looked upon as a giant.
('25', 229, 1, 10, 539578) I shall not mind if people believe that my calculations have been wrong, that I am a fool or that I am an impractical man.
('25', 229, 1, 11, 539701) Instead of their believing that they got anything through my strength, it is much better that they should believe every achievement to be the result of their own tapascharya and self purification—much better indeed that it should be so in fact.
('25', 229, 1, 12, 539946) I only want the people to have this faith in me.”He fearlessly placed before us that he thought to be the truth at the time.” I desire no better certificate than this.
('25', 229, 1, 13, 540114) I do not deserve anything more.

('25', 229, 3, 15, 540162) Navajivan, 11 12 1921
('25', 229, 4, 16, 540184) 106. BARDOLI
('25', 229, 5, 17, 540197) I shall never forget Maulana Azad Sobhani’s and my visit to the Bardoli taluka.
('25', 229, 5, 18, 540277) Both of us marvelled at the simplicity, goodness, sincerity and determination of the people in that taluka.
('25', 229, 5, 19, 540385) There is no doubt that the work there has been done very well.
('25', 229, 5, 20, 540448) We have both felt that, on the whole, that taluka can organize itself for civil disobedience in the shortest time.
('25', 229, 5, 21, 540563) There are about sixty five Government schools there.
('25', 229, 5, 22, 540616) Fifty one of these have already become national schools.
('25', 229, 5, 23, 540673) And there is no doubt that enthusiasm mounts wherever schools become national.
('25', 229, 5, 24, 540752) It is only a few weeks since schools came under the control of the people and, therefore, the progress is rather slow.
('25', 229, 5, 25, 540871) Children are required to work on the spinning wheel.
('25', 229, 5, 26, 540924) The use of khadi has increased very much among men.
('25', 229, 5, 27, 540976) All were seen wearing a shirt, dhoti, or half pants, and a cap.
('25', 229, 5, 28, 541040) There was a fairly good number of women in khadi saris at the meeting.
('25', 229, 5, 29, 541111) There is excellent unity among Hindus and Muslims.
('25', 229, 5, 30, 541162) People do not object to contact with the Dheds and the Bhangis who attend
('25', 230, 0, 1, 541236) VOL. 25 : 27 OCTOBER, 1921 22 JANUARY, 1922 231
('25', 230, 1, 2, 541284) meetings and they are allowed to sit with others.
('25', 230, 1, 3, 541334) The people of the taluka have behaved very peacefully while doing all this.
('25', 230, 1, 4, 541410) They have also maintained good relations with the officials, nor is there any hostility towards those who co operate with the Government.
('25', 230, 1, 5, 541548) We cannot but congratulate the people on this progress.
('25', 230, 2, 6, 541604) The picture, however, is not complete.
('25', 230, 2, 7, 541643) The people should have such measure of control over the schools that no person would even think of Government schools or of the education given in them.
('25', 230, 2, 8, 541796) Schools should be so organized that children do not roam about but under teachers of upright character, learn to build their own character.
('25', 230, 2, 9, 541936) Hindu boys and girls should learn Sanskrit and study the Gita, and Muslim children should learn Arabic and study the Koran.
('25', 230, 2, 10, 542060) All children should spin beautiful, strong, well twisted yarn of even texture; some of them should card and weave as well.
('25', 230, 2, 11, 542183) Khadi should become more popular among women and all men and women should exclusively wear khadi.
('25', 230, 2, 12, 542281) Not only this but the khadi required by the taluka should be spun and woven locally and mill made yarn should not be used at all.
('25', 230, 2, 13, 542411) Progress in this is very slow.
('25', 230, 2, 14, 542442) The looms are few in number.
('25', 230, 2, 15, 542471) In comparison, the number of spinning wheels is quite good, but there should be many more of them and they should be in regular operation.
('25', 230, 2, 16, 542610) It should be impossible, or very difficult, to get foreign or millmade cloth in Bardoli.
('25', 230, 3, 17, 542699) It is not enough that Dheds and Bhangis can attend meetings freely.
('25', 230, 3, 18, 542767) The meaning of ending the practice of untouchability should be fully grasped.
('25', 230, 3, 19, 542845) People should come to love Dheds and Bhangis.
('25', 230, 3, 20, 542891) Their children should freely attend national schools; if they do not, we should go and fetch them, persuading the parents to send them.
('25', 230, 3, 21, 543027) We should visit their localities and inquire about their hardships.
('25', 230, 3, 22, 543095) We should plead with them and persuade them to give up their bad habits.
('25', 230, 3, 23, 543168) It is good indeed that there are no quarrels at all between Hindus and Muslims, but the ill feeling that they harbour against each other must disappear.
('25', 230, 3, 24, 543321) Our conduct towards Parsis, Christians and those who co operate with the Government should be so courteous that they do not entertain the slightest fear of non co operators.
('25', 230, 3, 25, 543495) We may get liquor booths closed only if we can do so by reasoning with the owners.
('25', 230, 3, 26, 543578) The latter must not be ostracized and kept out of common gatherings.
('25', 230, 3, 27, 543647) We may bring them and the drink addicts to listen to us, as well as we can, with love.
('25', 230, 3, 28, 543734) There should not be even the slightest appearance of coercion on them.
('25', 230, 3, 29, 543805) They should feel absolutely secure.
('25', 231, 0, 1, 543841) 232 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('25', 231, 1, 2, 543883) A whole army of volunteers need not go to bring the pupils out of schools, need not go into a village and start a fast.
('25', 231, 1, 3, 544003) Only if the people are awakened in the right manner and they voluntarily withdraw their children from Government schools will the results be genuine.
('25', 231, 2, 4, 544153) I have certainly formed the impression that the people have done very good work.
('25', 231, 2, 5, 544234) But they betray some ignorance in their work.
('25', 231, 2, 6, 544280) People seem to think that it will be necessary to wear khadi only till December end, that afterwards they will not have to run schools and will not need to mix with the Dheds and Bhangis.
('25', 231, 2, 7, 544468) Work done in such a spirit will be insincere and will have a bad rather than a good effect.
('25', 231, 2, 8, 544560) I do not now think it possible that we shall have power in our hands in December.
('25', 231, 2, 9, 544642) But, even after we have got it, we shall be wearing cloth spun and woven in our talukas or villages, our schools will not be run by any outsiders and their management will be entirely in our hands.
('25', 231, 2, 10, 544840) Instead of two authorities, as at present, there will be only one when we have swaraj.
('25', 231, 2, 11, 544927) If the Government is ours, of course the control will be ours.
('25', 231, 2, 12, 544990) We shall have to be as hard working then as we are now and shoulder as much responsibility then as we do now.
('25', 231, 2, 13, 545100) We shall, even then, mix with the Dheds and Bhangis and love them.
('25', 231, 2, 14, 545167) In what we are doing today, we are training ourselves for swaraj and making ourselves fit for it.
('25', 231, 2, 15, 545265) In effecting any changes, therefore, we should understand their meaning and know that they will stay afterwards.
('25', 231, 2, 16, 545378) Only then shall we be fit [for swaraj].
('25', 231, 3, 17, 545418) I believe that the Bardoli taluka is fully capable of doing all this.
('25', 231, 3, 18, 545488) The deficiency I have pointed out is partly due to lack of time and, partly, to ignorance.
('25', 231, 3, 19, 545579) I am, therefore, not at all disappointed; I believe that the people will be able to overcome these shortcomings within a very short time and be completely fit for offering civil disobedience.
('25', 231, 4, 20, 545771) The supporters of the Government whom It met also testified to everything having been done peacefully and told me that Bardoli would be ready in six months’ time.
('25', 231, 4, 21, 545934) Shri Kunvarji, who is the soul of the taluka, believes that they will succeed in a month’s time in spreading spinning and weaving and other activities.
('25', 231, 4, 22, 546086) The reports of either are likely to contain an element of unconscious exaggeration.
('25', 231, 4, 23, 546170) However, the good m on my mind that they will not take long to deserve a certificate of fitness.
('25', 231, 4, 24, 546267) What impressed me especially was that the workers were not only young men, but included grown ups as well.
('25', 231, 4, 25, 546374) The women, too, take interest.
('25', 231, 4, 26, 546405) The volunteers do honorary work.
('25', 231, 4, 27, 546438) Whatever expenses
('25', 232, 0, 1, 546456) VOL. 25 : 27 OCTOBER, 1921 22 JANUARY, 1922 233
('25', 232, 1, 2, 546504) are incurred are met by Bardoli itself.
('25', 232, 1, 3, 546544) Hence, the entire taluka, and not merely a certain section of it, can be said to have awakened.
('25', 232, 1, 4, 546640) Bardoli’s responsibility has now increased.
('25', 232, 1, 5, 546684) Bardoli inspired me, when I was in Delhi, to give concrete shape to the plan of civil disobedience and this increased the enthusiasm in other provinces too.
('25', 232, 1, 6, 546841) In consequence, some great fighters are in jail.
('25', 232, 1, 7, 546890) Having thus been instrumental in rousing enthusiasm, Bardoli cannot rest now.
('25', 232, 1, 8, 546968) It must complete the process of self purification and, for this purpose, it must put in a Herculean Effort.
('25', 232, 1, 9, 547076) The required effort will be easy to make if people work wisely and unceasingly and if their change of heart is genuine.
('25', 232, 1, 10, 547196) The reader will see that I have not discussed the question whether or not the people have the capacity to suffer, to go to jail or to face bullets.
('25', 232, 1, 11, 547344) I have not even inquired of anyone.
('25', 232, 1, 12, 547380) It is my experience and my faith that, when a person does his duty faithfully, he soon gets the strength to suffer.
('25', 232, 1, 13, 547496) Bardoli, moreover, is making all this effort in order to be fit to go to jail; how can I, then, insult it by asking the question of whether it has the necessary strength?
('25', 232, 1, 14, 547667) At this time, going to jail is a difficult thing.
('25', 232, 1, 15, 547717) It is, of course, easy to keep out.
('25', 232, 1, 16, 547753) If a person does not spin, does not wear khadi, is not honest or polite, has ill will towards all and refuses to mix with the Dheds and Bhangis will anyone ask such a person to go to jail?
('25', 232, 1, 17, 547942) A taluka which clings to the practice of untouchability will never be invited to court imprisonment.
('25', 232, 1, 18, 548043) I, therefore, do not at all doubt Bardoli’s courage or its readiness to go to jail.
