('25', 232, 4, 21, 548165) 107. MY NOTES!
('25', 232, 5, 22, 548180) WELCOME COLONEL PRATAPSINGHJI
('25', 232, 6, 23, 548210) I have been hearing for a week now that, at the time of the Congress session, the Government will hand over control of Ahmedabad to Colonel Pratapsinghji and his men and that the Colonel has undertaken to deal with the delegates attending the Congress.
('25', 232, 6, 24, 548463) I am absolutely sure that the rumour is unfounded.
('25', 232, 6, 25, 548514) The Government is not so timid or wicked or foolish as this rumour suggests.
('25', 232, 6, 26, 548591) It is sufficiently equipped to put down the Congress
('25', 233, 0, 1, 548644) 234 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('25', 233, 1, 2, 548686) delegates.
('25', 233, 1, 3, 548697) I do not believe that the Government would like to survive with Colonel Pratapsingh’s help.
('25', 233, 1, 4, 548789) I am told, however, that the simple minded mill workers have been frightened and feel agitated.
('25', 233, 1, 5, 548885) No one should hear such rumours or, having heard them, spread them further.
('25', 233, 1, 6, 548961) If there is danger of any kind, the Congress will let the people know.
('25', 233, 1, 7, 549032) It is a sign of cowardice to get frightened by any and every kind of rumour, and cowards cannot win swaraj or preserve it after winning it.
('25', 233, 1, 8, 549172) Such fear, moreover, is also a sign of lack of faith in God.
('25', 233, 1, 9, 549233) Why can we not tell ourselves,”God’s will be done”, and remain calm?
('25', 233, 1, 10, 549302) Let us suppose, however, that Colonel Pratapsinghji arrives with his men.
('25', 233, 1, 11, 549376) Is that any reason to get frightened?
('25', 233, 1, 12, 549414) He, too, is one of us.
('25', 233, 1, 13, 549437) His men also are our own people.
('25', 233, 1, 14, 549470) We should offer him our services, welcome him and cheerfully face his men’s bullets as well.
('25', 233, 1, 15, 549563) Why should we at all give them a chance to shoot?
('25', 233, 1, 16, 549613) Will they molest people going about their way peacefully?
('25', 233, 1, 17, 549671) If they do, we may let them and continue on our way.
('25', 233, 1, 18, 549724) Will they snatch away our khadi caps?
('25', 233, 1, 19, 549762) If they try to, we should hold fast to our caps and submit to the blows.
('25', 233, 1, 20, 549835) If, despite that, they succeed in snatching away the cap, we should put on another, come out again and submit to more blows.
('25', 233, 1, 21, 549960) In the end, they will get weary of the business.
('25', 233, 1, 22, 550009) Those who cannot submit to blows may not pass along the road on which they are stationed, but should not in any case put away the white cap.
('25', 233, 1, 23, 550150) A vegetarian, for instance, will not go to any country, like the Arctic region, in which he cannot live without meat.
('25', 233, 1, 24, 550268) If by chance he finds himself in such a place, he will meet death but not eat meat.
('25', 233, 1, 25, 550352) That alone is dharma which is followed at the cost of one’s life; anything else is mere convenience or amusement.
('25', 233, 2, 26, 550466) If we have resolved to give up fear of white soldiers, why should we fear Colonel Pratapsingh’s brown men?
('25', 233, 3, 27, 550573) Fear is a sign of our harbouring violence and hostility.
('25', 233, 3, 28, 550630) Anyone whom we regard as an enemy is sure to become so.
('25', 233, 3, 29, 550686) If we treat even an enemy as a friend, he will certainly become one in the course of time.
('25', 233, 3, 30, 550777) Man is made by his thoughts.
('25', 233, 3, 31, 550806) We reap as we sow.
('25', 233, 3, 32, 550825) It cannot happen that one sows friendship and reaps enmity.
('25', 233, 3, 33, 550885) Our non co operation is a means of winning over even an enemy with love.
('25', 233, 4, 34, 550958) This is not only the Hindus’ dharma.
('25', 233, 4, 35, 550995) Islam teaches the same thing.
('25', 233, 4, 36, 551025) It gives the first place to patience.
('25', 233, 4, 37, 551063) It has room for war, but only as a last resort and when one’s side is less numerous than the tyrant’s, when refusing to fight may be a sign of cowardice and when the person who leads the host into the battle is an illustrious soul trusted
('25', 234, 0, 1, 551302) VOL. 25 : 27 OCTOBER, 1921 22 JANUARY, 1922 235
('25', 234, 1, 2, 551350) by all and without any selfish aim.
('25', 234, 1, 3, 551386) This is not, cannot be, the position in India.
('25', 234, 1, 4, 551433) We are more numerous than the opponent.
('25', 234, 1, 5, 551473) There is no one to be our leader in fighting.
('25', 234, 1, 6, 551519) For us to fight will be no sign of manliness.
('25', 234, 1, 7, 551565) We have not exhausted all other means.
('25', 234, 1, 8, 551604) We have not yet fully learnt the lesson of peace and not completely adopted swadeshi.
('25', 234, 1, 9, 551690) We have not learnt to be truthful; we, Hindus and Muslims, have not yet rid ourselves of mutual ill will and a large number of us love co operation with the Government.
('25', 234, 1, 10, 551859) I have heard many aalims say that, in these circumstances, fighting will be not jehad but fasad.
('25', 234, 1, 11, 551956) From the point of view of whichever religion we consider the matters we can arrive at only one conclusion.
('25', 234, 1, 12, 552063) We wish to conquer the enemy with love and therefore, whether it is a white army or a black one which is sent, our attitude towards it should be the same.
('25', 234, 1, 13, 552218) Accordingly, we should be ready to say”Welcome, Colonel”, if Colonel Pratapsinghji, or some other Colonel, does indeed come with his men, though I believe that no Colonel Pratapsinghji is coming to teach us a lesson.
('25', 234, 2, 14, 552435) HAS DAS BEEN ARRESTED?

('25', 235, 2, 12, 555130) TO PARSI BROTHERS AND SISTERS
('25', 235, 3, 13, 555160) I know that in many places our Parsi brothers and sisters feel uncomfortable and are afraid of Hindus and Muslims.

('25', 252, 3, 16, 590889) Though non co operation was, in the first instance, conceived in connection with the Khilafat, neither I nor my first associates ever thought that non co operation with the British Government involved any sacrifice whatsoever of the country’s interests.
('25', 252, 3, 17, 591143) On the contrary, we believed that if we could compel surrender to the just demands of the Mussulmans of India regarding the Khilafat, we could also compel surrender in the matter of the Punjab and, consequently, in the matter of swaraj.
('25', 252, 3, 18, 591380) Non violence was believed from the very commencement to be an integral part of non co operation, and if the former failed the latter failed ipso facto.
('25', 252, 3, 19, 591532) Indeed the recent happenings have furnished abundant proof of the progress of non violence.

('25', 253, 1, 10, 593153) But having known our state, is it not most natural for us to cry out for the fresh air of swaraj?
('25', 253, 1, 11, 593251) I am unable to accept any blame for having set the time limit.
('25', 253, 1, 12, 593314) I would have been wrong not to do so, knowing as I did that if the people fulfilled the conditions which were capable of easy fulfilment, swaraj was a certainty inside of twelve months.
('25', 253, 1, 13, 593500) If the atmosphere of non violence is truly established, I make bold to say that we shall achieve the substance even during the remaining days of this year, though we might have to wait for the form yet a while.
('25', 253, 1, 14, 593711) The time limit was not fixed in order to rouse the teeming millions, but it was fixed in order to rivet the attention of Congressmen and Congresswomen on their sense of immediate duty and on the grand consequence of its fulfilment.

('25', 254, 1, 2, 594907) Provincial Congress Committee, Mr. Jiaram Saksena, speaks for itself:
('25', 254, 2, 3, 594977) Of all the local office bearers of the U.P. Provincial Congress Committee, I am the only unfortunate Secretary who is yet out of jail.
('25', 254, 2, 4, 595112) It has, therefore, fallen to my lot to inform you of what has recently happened here.
('25', 254, 3, 5, 595198) The Provincial Congress Committee office was searched at about midnight and the registers of the U.P. Congress Committee, Executive Council and other subordinate bodies were taken away by the Deputy Superintendent of Police who conducted the seareh.
('25', 254, 3, 6, 595448) Besides, the Khilafat Committee office and the houses of the gentlemen arrested were searched.
('25', 254, 4, 7, 595543) We have now started civil disobedience in Allahabad in an organized and systematic form.
('25', 254, 4, 8, 595632) National Volunteers are being briskly recruited.
('25', 254, 4, 9, 595681) Yesterday a batch of a dozen volunteers was sent out for a round in the city with national badges on their arms, singing patriotic songs.
('25', 254, 4, 10, 595819) none was taken in custody.
('25', 254, 4, 11, 595846) Today the same batch with another of a dozen volunteers paraded the town.
('25', 254, 4, 12, 595920) No arrests took place today.
('25', 254, 5, 13, 595949) Of equal value is the following from a Lahore correspondent: 2
('25', 254, 6, 14, 596012) The general atmosphere is very good.
('25', 254, 6, 15, 596049) People are fearless and non violent.
('25', 254, 6, 16, 596086) The City Congress Committees are sending out volunteers to hold meetings in different parts of the town at the same hour, to read out the same written speech, and to sing the same song and disperse within ten or fifteen minutes.
('25', 254, 6, 17, 596315) Yesterday (the 8th instant) twenty such meetings were held in twenty centres .
('25', 254, 6, 18, 596394) Fear of arrest or the jail is gone.
('25', 254, 7, 19, 596430) Surely, this is a record of which any country would be proud.
('25', 254, 8, 20, 596492) LEST WE FORGET
('25', 254, 9, 21, 596507) The same Lahore correspondent, however, regretfully mentions that the khadi movement has suffered a set back and that khadi is not so much in evidence in Lahore as it used to be some time ago.
('25', 254, 9, 22, 596700) If this is so, it is a bad sign.
('25', 254, 9, 23, 596733) A mere filling of the jails will not answer the whole purpose.
('25', 254, 9, 24, 596796) If India does not return to swadeshi, no amount of going to jail will make her self contained or fill the mouths of the hungry millions.
('25', 254, 9, 25, 596933) Without the four vital parts of the programme, which are meant not for particular classes but for all, we cannot establish swaraj.
('25', 254, 9, 26, 597064) The reader must not be tired of my repetition of them: Hindu, Muslim, Sikh, Parsi, Christian, Jew unity; swadeshi, i.e., manufacture and use of hand spun khadi to the exclusion of all foreign cloth; removal of untouchability by Hindus; and observance of non violence by all.
('25', 254, 9, 27, 597339) These are like the four posts of a bedstead.
('25', 254, 9, 28, 597384) Remove one of them and it cannot stand.

('25', 255, 1, 2, 597466) BAN ON KHADI CAP A friend has sent me papers in connection with a tussle that a local pleader is having with a Sub Judge of Devrukh in the District of Ratnagiri over his khadi cap.
('25', 255, 1, 3, 597647) Mr. J.V. Vaidya, the local pleader in question, had the following order passed against him by the Sub Judge: Mr. Vaidya has appeared in Court today in a khadi cap, commonly known as the”Gandhi cap”.
('25', 255, 1, 4, 597846) In conformity with the views of the High Court as expressed in the recent letter of the Chief Justice addressed to the District Judge, Ratnagiri, extract of which was forwarded to the Devrukh Bar, I have told Mr. Vaidya that I consider his appearance today in a khadi cap as amounting to disrespect of the Court and have ordered him to leave the Court at once and not to appear again before this Court in a cap unless and until the District Judge or the High Court directs otherwise.
('25', 255, 1, 5, 598330) I have also warned him that if he appears in a cap after this order, he will expose himself to all the consequences of a contempt of Court.
('25', 255, 1, 6, 598470) A copy of the statement of Mr. Vaidya and of this order will be forwarded to the District Judge for such action as he may deem fit to take in the matter.
('25', 255, 1, 7, 598624) The following is a copy of the extracts from the Chief Justice’s letter for communication to the Bar:
('25', 255, 2, 8, 598726) The High Court is decidedly against the wearing of Gandhi caps in Court by pleaders and would consider any pleader wearing a Gandhi cap in Court as guilty of disrespect to the Judge.
('25', 255, 3, 9, 598909) We hope that the good sense of the pleaders will prevail provided they know what the views of the High Court are.
('25', 255, 4, 10, 599023) No pleader should appear in Court if he wears any head dress except a turban.
('25', 255, 5, 11, 599101) Please inform these pleaders that the High Court strongly disapproves of their conduct.
('25', 255, 5, 12, 599189) To this the Sub Judge appended the following hope:
('25', 255, 6, 13, 599240) The undersigned hopes that the pleaders will conform to the views of the High Court herein expressed and that there would be no occasion for the undersigned to enforce them in this Court.
('25', 255, 6, 14, 599428) Side by side with a discussion of matters of urgency, I do not hesitate to occupy the space at my disposal for discussion of an order which affects only a few pleaders.
('25', 255, 6, 15, 599597) But the principle underlying this war against khadi caps is of the highest importance.
('25', 255, 6, 16, 599684) It shows how innocent but moral and economic movements are attempted to be killed by their adversaries.
('25', 255, 6, 17, 599788) Surely, the Chief Justice outside his official position could not possibly take exception to a headgear which is
('25', 256, 0, 1, 599901) VOL. 25 : 27 OCTOBER, 1921 22 JANUARY, 1922 257
('25', 256, 1, 2, 599949) accepted as respectable by thousands of men all over India occupying a high station in life.
('25', 256, 1, 3, 600042) Nor do pleaders who adopt the national cap do so out of any disrespect for the Court, but they do it out or respect for themselves and the nation to which they belong.
('25', 256, 1, 4, 600210) They do it because they do not wish to conceal their religion or their politics, whichever way one regards the adoption of the khadi cap.
('25', 256, 1, 5, 600348) A man who does not respect himself becomes menial.
('25', 256, 1, 6, 600399) Are pleaders menials or officers of the High Courts?
('25', 256, 1, 7, 600452) Custodians as they claim to be of the people’s liberty, are their to submit to a deprivation of their own?
('25', 256, 1, 8, 600559) I understand that Mr. Vaidya has decided to give up his practice, if he cannot carry it on with dignity and self respect.
('25', 256, 1, 9, 600681) He has, therefore, lodged a protest against the order, ceased to appear before the Sub Judge till the matter is decided in his favour.
('25', 256, 1, 10, 600816) And I learn further that the other members of the local Bar are also conferring among themselves as to the steps to be taken for vindicating their honour and freedom of action in the matter of dress.
('25', 256, 1, 11, 601016) One does hope that when pleaders are unable to suspend practice or students to withdraw from Government schools and colleges, they will at least put up a brave fight in order to sustain their own personal honour even as the medical students of Vizagapatam have done.

('25', 258, 2, 13, 606068) WHAT IS SWARAJ?
('25', 258, 3, 14, 606084) The Times of India questions whether I have any clear notion of swaraj.
('25', 258, 3, 15, 606156) If the writer will go through the back numbers of Young India, he will find a complete answer to the question.
('25', 258, 3, 16, 606267) But I may mention here briefly that the least that swaraj means is a settlement with the Government in accordance with the wishes of the chosen representatives of the people.
('25', 258, 3, 17, 606442) Therefore, the Congress representatives, if they can make good their claim by providing an inexhaustible supply of prisoners, will have a determining voice in any settlement that may be made.
('25', 258, 3, 18, 606634) Swaraj, therefore, means the capacity of the people of India to enforce their demands.
('25', 258, 3, 19, 606721) I totally dissent from the Viceroy’s view that swaraj must come from the BritishParliament, unless it comes through the sword.
('25', 258, 3, 20, 606848) The British Parliament will only ratify the people’s wish when the”sword” has made it irresistible.
('25', 258, 3, 21, 606948) Non co operators are trying to use the sword of self sacrifice in preference to that of steel.
('25', 258, 3, 22, 607043) India’s soul is pitted against British steel.
('25', 258, 3, 23, 607089) We shall not have to wait long to know what popular swaraj is.
('25', 258, 4, 24, 607152) WORK IN JAILS

('25', 259, 1, 6, 607746) Our civil disobedience, therefore, must not be carried beyond the point of breaking the unmoral laws of the country.
('25', 259, 1, 7, 607863) Breach of the laws to be civil assumes the strictest and willing obedience to the jail discipline because disobedience of a particular rule assumes a willing acceptance of the sanction provided for its breach.
('25', 259, 1, 8, 608073) And immediately a person quarrels both with the rule and the sanction for its breach, he ceases to be civil and lends himself to the precipitation of chaos and anarchy.
('25', 259, 1, 9, 608242) A civil resister is, if one may be permitted such a claim for him, a philanthropist and a friend of the State.
('25', 259, 1, 10, 608353) An anarchist is an enemy of the State and is, therefore, a misanthrope.

('25', 259, 1, 14, 608767) If the honesty of non violence be admitted, there is no warrant for condemnation even of the fiercest disobedience because of the likelihood of its leading to violence.

('25', 259, 1, 18, 609419) We do want to drive out the beast in man, but we do not want on that account to emasculate him.

('25', 259, 1, 22, 609927) Therefore, to revert to the original argument, as civil resisters we are bound to guard against universal indiscipline.

('25', 267, 1, 2, 627091) 119. OF SPINNING WHEELS
('25', 267, 2, 3, 627115) THE EDITOR, Young India
('25', 267, 4, 4, 627139) The District Congress Committee has no expert spinner appointed whom they can and should consult about the charkha to be selected for introducing to the public.
('25', 267, 5, 5, 627300) Most of the workers have yet to realize that a thin spindle with revolutions over 150 to one of the wheel is necessary for turning out good weavable yarn.
('25', 267, 5, 6, 627455) The charkha recommended in Young India is taken as a pattern in some places, but the revolutions of the spindle (which is generally at least half an inch in diameter) being lower than 40 increase the time as it is necessary after drawing out a length of yarn to turn the wheel so many times to ensure the proper twist.
('25', 267, 6, 7, 627774) The result of all this is seen in the number of charkhas Iying idle or producing yarn which is refused by weavers being undertwisted and uneven.
('25', 267, 6, 8, 627919) if the Committee is going to spend the major portion of the Tilak Swaraj Fund on this item, it must lay down a clear stipulation when giving the money, that every District body thus supplied with money must have an expert spinner .

('25', 268, 1, 2, 628598) 120. A PUZZLE AND ITS SOLUTION 1
('25', 268, 2, 3, 628631) Lord Reading is puzzled and perplexed.
('25', 268, 2, 4, 628670) Speaking in reply to the addresses from the British Indian Association and the Bengal National Chamber of Commerce at Calcutta, His Excellency said:
('25', 268, 3, 5, 628819) I confess that when I contemplate the activities of a section of the community, I find myself still, notwithstanding persistent study ever since I have been in India, puzzled and perplexed.
('25', 268, 3, 6, 629009) I ask myself what purpose is served by flagrant breaches of the law for the purpose of challenging the Government and in order to compel arrest.
('25', 268, 3, 7, 629154) The answer was partly given by Pandit Motilal Nehru when he said on being arrested 2 that he was being taken to the house of freedom.
('25', 268, 3, 8, 629288) We seek arrest because the so called freedom is slavery.
('25', 268, 3, 9, 629345) We are challenging the might of this Government because we consider its activity to be wholly evil.
('25', 268, 3, 10, 629445) We want to overthrow the Government.
('25', 268, 3, 11, 629482) We want to compel its submission to the people’s will.
('25', 268, 3, 12, 629537) We desire to show that the Government exists to serve the people, not the people the Government.
('25', 268, 3, 13, 629634) Free life under the Government has become intolerable, for the price exacted for the retention of freedom is unconscionably great.
('25', 268, 3, 14, 629765) Whether we are one or many, we must refuse to purchase freedom at the cost of our self respect or our cherished convictions.
('25', 268, 3, 15, 629890) I have known even little children become unbending when an attempt has been made to cross their declared purpose, be it ever so flimsy in the estimation of their parents.
('25', 268, 3, 16, 630061) Lord Reading must clearly understand that the non co operators are at war with the Government.
('25', 268, 3, 17, 630156) They have declared rebellion against it inasmuch as it has committed a breach of faith with the Mussulmans, it has humiliated the Punjab and it insists upon imposing its will upon the people and refuses to repair the breach and repent of the wrong done in the Punjab.
('25', 268, 3, 18, 630424) There were two ways open to the people, the way of armed rebellion and the way of peaceful revolt.
('25', 268, 3, 19, 630523) Non co operators havechosen, some out of weakness, some out of strength, the way of peace, i.e., voluntary suffering.
('25', 268, 4, 20, 630641) 1 This is one of the articles for which Gandhiji was tried and sentenced in March 1922 2 On December 6, 1921
('25', 269, 0, 1, 630750) 270 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('25', 269, 1, 2, 630792) If the people are behind the sufferers, the Government must yield or be overthrown.
('25', 269, 1, 3, 630876) If the people are not with them they have at least the satisfaction of not having sold their freedom.
('25', 269, 1, 4, 630978) In an armed conflict, the more violent is generally the victor.
('25', 269, 1, 5, 631042) The way of peace and suffering is the quickest method of cultivating public opinion, and, therefore, when victory is attained, it is for what the world regards as Truth.
('25', 269, 1, 6, 631212) Bred in the atmosphere of law courts, Lord Reading finds it difficult to appreciate the peaceful resistance to authority.
('25', 269, 1, 7, 631334) His Excellency will learn by the time the conflict is over that there is a higher court than courts of justice, and that is the court of conscience.
('25', 269, 1, 8, 631483) It supersedes all other courts.
('25', 269, 1, 9, 631515) Lord Reading is welcome to treat all the sufferers as lunatics, who do not know their own interest.
('25', 269, 1, 10, 631615) He is entitled, therefore, to put them out of harm’s way.
('25', 269, 1, 11, 631673) It is an arrangement that entirely suits the lunatics and it is an ideal situation if it also suits the Government.
('25', 269, 1, 12, 631789) He will have cause to complain if, having courted imprisonment, non co operators fret and fume or”whine for favours” as Lalaji puts it.
('25', 269, 1, 13, 631925) The strength of a non co operator lies in his going to jail uncomplainingly.
('25', 269, 1, 14, 632002) He loses his case if, having courted imprisonment, he begins to grumble, immediately his courtship is rewarded.
('25', 269, 1, 15, 632114) The threats used by His Excellency are unbecoming.
('25', 269, 1, 16, 632165) This is a fight to the finish.
('25', 269, 1, 17, 632196) It is a conflict between the reign of violence and of public opinion.
('25', 269, 1, 18, 632266) Those who are fighting for the latter are determined to submit to any violence rather than surrender their opinion.

('25', 269, 3, 20, 632406) 121. MUNICIPALITIES IN TROUBLE
('25', 269, 4, 21, 632437) The municipalities of Ahmedabad, Nadiad and Surat are again in trouble about their education departments.
('25', 269, 4, 22, 632543) 1 The Government intends to declare the municipalities unfit to run the departments and then take over their administration.
('25', 269, 4, 23, 632668) It has, therefore, issued notices to the three municipalities to the effect that it will take over the control of their education departments unless they carry out its directions before 5 p.m.
('25', 269, 4, 24, 632861) on the 17th instant.
('25', 269, 4, 25, 632882) Where the municipality has the support of a clear majority for its decision, it will be difficult
('25', 269, 5, 26, 632980) 1 These municipalities had decided to impart national education in their schools and to refuse Government grants; for Nadiad Municipality’s decision, vide”A Muncipal Enterprise”, 9 2 1921.
('25', 270, 0, 1, 633169) VOL. 25 : 27 OCTOBER, 1921 22 JANUARY, 1922 271
('25', 270, 1, 2, 633217) for the Government to take over the administration of a department.
('25', 270, 2, 3, 633285) In the present circumstances, a non co operator can continue as member of a municipality for one reason only, namely, to increase the strength of the people by every legitimate means and to reduce the control of the Government.
('25', 270, 2, 4, 633513) Where there is a majority of those who co operate with the Government and it is not possible to realize this aim, a non co operator should certainly not continue as a member merely for creating disorder or obstructing the proceedings.
('25', 270, 2, 5, 633748) He should realize that such tactics do not increase the strength of the people but are only a waste of time.
('25', 270, 2, 6, 633857) Experience shows us that a person who commands a majority cannot be clamoured out of his decision.
('25', 270, 2, 7, 633956) When his principles are involved he does not hesitate to make the fullest use of his majority.
('25', 270, 2, 8, 634051) The rule of majority yields excellent results in matters in which no fundamentals are involved.
('25', 270, 2, 9, 634147) Where, however, fundamentals are involved, the convention of bowing to a majority leads to society’s decline.
('25', 270, 2, 10, 634257) It is, therefore, desirable that we continue members of only those municipalities in which we command a majority.
('25', 270, 3, 11, 634371) Let us examine the present situation from this angle.
('25', 270, 3, 12, 634425) One way to prevent the control of education from passing into the hands of the Government, as also to cut short all argument with it, is to entrust the administration of education to the national institution in each town and to subsidize it with grants.
('25', 270, 3, 13, 634679) A municipality has the power to make such grants.
('25', 270, 3, 14, 634729) If this can be done, the Government’s taking over the education department will be of little significance.
('25', 270, 3, 15, 634836) It will not get control over the present students, who will remain self reliant.
('25', 270, 3, 16, 634917) The Government administrator may start new schools if he so chooses.
('25', 270, 3, 17, 634986) No citizen will prevent him.
('25', 270, 3, 18, 635015) From where, however, will the Government get the children to attend its new schools?
('25', 270, 3, 19, 635100) We believe that all children who want schooling are already attending the existing municipal schools.
('25', 270, 3, 20, 635202) Again, the Government will face difficulties in financing its new department.
('25', 270, 3, 21, 635280) The municipalities will never sanction the expenditure of their own free will.
('25', 270, 3, 22, 635359) The Government will have, therefore, to distrain upon the municipalities every time they need the money.
('25', 270, 3, 23, 635464) This, again, will lead to ultimate discomfiture of the Government.
('25', 270, 4, 24, 635531) The second way, if the (Government appoints its adminis trator, is that the municipality should advise the school teachers not to carry out the administrator’s orders and let him take whatever steps he
('25', 271, 0, 1, 635733) 272 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('25', 271, 1, 2, 635775) This too will wear out the Government.
('25', 271, 1, 3, 635814) The third way is to work among the voters in case the Government succeeds in taking over the administration of the existing schools.
('25', 271, 1, 4, 635947) That is, the people should be so educated that they will see to it that no child attends Government schools, and all people will send children to the new [national] schools instead.
('25', 271, 1, 5, 636129) All these three ways cannot be adopted simultaneously; we should select one of them and concentrate upon it.
('25', 271, 1, 6, 636238) It is the duty of the members to educate the voters so thoroughly that they would be ready for any step which might be necessary.

('25', 271, 3, 8, 636384) Navajivan, 15 12 1921
('25', 271, 4, 9, 636406) 122. MY NOTES
('25', 271, 5, 10, 636420) TO PARENTS
('25', 271, 6, 11, 636431) Parents who send their children to schools or Ashrams have certain obligations to fulfil.
('25', 271, 6, 12, 636521) Their failure to fulfil them harms the children, the institutions as also the parents themselves.
('25', 271, 6, 13, 636619) Parents should acquaint themselves with the rules of the institution to which they want their children to be admitted.
('25', 271, 6, 14, 636738) They should know the habits and needs of their children and adhere to the decision once it is taken.
('25', 271, 6, 15, 636839) During the time when the children are supposed to stay in the Ashram, they should not be called away to serve their parents’ convenience or in order that they might be of service to the latter; how, then, can they be called away to attend marriages?
('25', 271, 6, 16, 637089) Why should children be invited on such occasions?
('25', 271, 6, 17, 637139) Just as parents do not involve children in their other social affairs, so also they should not involve them in the business of marriages.
('25', 271, 6, 18, 637277) During student life, children’s attention should not be distracted from their studies; moreover, during this period, children should remain brahmacharis 1. If they are compelled to attend marriages and such other functions, they may find it difficult to do this.
('25', 271, 6, 19, 637540) It is, therefore, necessary that we deliberately keep children away from such celebrations.
('25', 271, 6, 20, 637632) Besides, at a time like this, when the very idea of marriage seems improper, it is an outrage on a child who, left to itself, would keep away from a marriage, to tempt it with the thought of attending one.
('25', 271, 6, 21, 637838) In these days when we have become
('25', 271, 7, 22, 637872) 1 Celibates
('25', 272, 0, 1, 637884) VOL. 25 : 27 OCTOBER, 1921 22 JANUARY, 1922 273
('25', 272, 1, 2, 637932) weak willed, when the strength to resist temptations has diminished, it is necessary to encourage a person in his determination to submit to a rule or make some sacrifice.
('25', 272, 1, 3, 638104) If, instead, we ourselves oblige him to disregard a rule, we shall be encouraging weakness.
('25', 272, 1, 4, 638196) What has been said with regard to marriage applies to many other affairs.
('25', 272, 1, 5, 638270) Parents who desire to bring up their children thoughtfully will be able to recall many such occasions when, instead of helping the progress of their children, they have retarded it.
('25', 272, 2, 6, 638452) [From Gujarati]

('25', 282, 0, 1, 652357) VOL. 25 : 27 OCTOBER, 1921 22 JANUARY, 1922 283
('25', 282, 1, 2, 652405) 139. THINGS THAT SINK
('25', 282, 2, 3, 652427) December 17, 1921
('25', 282, 3, 4, 652445) To imprison those who, whether high or low, break the commandments, to treat them as common felons, to deprive them of their prison privileges, one can understand.
('25', 282, 3, 5, 652609) I would not call that foul play.
('25', 282, 3, 6, 652642) If you incur the wrath of one who is over you or who has you under his power for the time being, to be punished by him for your disobedience is what you expect.
('25', 282, 3, 7, 652803) But if he humiliates you, if he makes your children do things you and they do not like and which you are not required in law to do, if he treats you like dirt, it becomes unbearable.
('25', 282, 3, 8, 652986) One learns that in Cocanada a Magistrate had the swaraj and the Khilafat flags pulled down, that he issued orders prohibiting the use of such flags for one week, that the children of a school were compelled to salute the Union Jack, that a distinguished Professor in Calcutta, going out in his academic costume and on the strength thereof going up to an officer to stop a wanton hunt of inoffensive men, was brutally assaulted for his innocent inquiry as to the cause of the hunt, that a party of brave cultured young men were kicked about by those who were their warders for the time being.
('25', 282, 3, 9, 653578) These are things that sink.
('25', 282, 3, 10, 653606) These humiliations show that there is little change in the manners of our”masters”.
('25', 282, 3, 11, 653690) The O’Dwyerian spirit has not died out.
('25', 282, 3, 12, 653730) Of what use is it that Lord Ronaldshay sends for the injured Professor, soothes him and assures him that the thing will not happen again?
('25', 282, 3, 13, 653868) What will not happen again?
('25', 282, 3, 14, 653896) The Professor will not be assaulted?
('25', 282, 3, 15, 653933) Of course he will not be during the present crisis.
('25', 282, 3, 16, 653985) The Professor himself will not again presume upon his academic costume and challenge an officer very soon.
('25', 282, 3, 17, 654092) But has the officer any respect for the Professor?
('25', 282, 3, 18, 654143) The Professor did not seek relief for himself.

('25', 286, 4, 9, 663334) 141. CIVILITY
('25', 286, 5, 10, 663348) Civility, good manners and humility—these virtues are at such discount these days that they seem to have no place at all in the building of our character.
('25', 286, 5, 11, 663503) If a person observes mere physical celibacy, he acts like a Bajirao 1, frowns upon and runs down everyone else and we tolerate his rudeness as we do kicks from a milchcow.

('25', 286, 5, 13, 663838) In like manner, a person who offers civil disobedience sometimes acts as if he had a licence to be insolent to others.
('25', 286, 5, 14, 663957) These corporals of the army of incivility are not a true brahmachari or a truth lover or a khadilover or a civil resister, as the case may be.
('25', 286, 5, 15, 664100) All the four of them are as far away from their vows as the north is from the south.

('25', 290, 1, 2, 671873) PARSI SISTERS
('25', 290, 2, 3, 671887) I have received a letter—an extremely painful one—from a Parsi sister in Bombay.
('25', 290, 2, 4, 671968) Her complaint is such that I would like to spend a life time investigating its root cause, but it is not possible to undertake an inquiry on the basis of her letter alone.
('25', 290, 2, 5, 672140) If that sister happens to read this, I request her to send me her name and address or to meet me.
('25', 290, 2, 6, 672238) I shall certainly not print her name, but I shall make all possible inquiries and assist her as much as possible if she gives me all the facts.
('25', 290, 2, 7, 672382) If men and women who are in distress write anonymous letters and do not give facts which can be verified, it is easy to see that nothing can be done to help them.
('25', 290, 2, 8, 672545) I should also like to request those Parsi sisters who know me that they should make all possible inquiries and inform me if they come across any cases of suffering.
('25', 290, 2, 9, 672710) However well ordered a society may be, there is bound to be an area of it in which, despite all measures, cruelties cannot be prevented.
('25', 290, 2, 10, 672847) We do not even come to know of the crimes which are committed today in London, New York, Chicago and Paris, the cruel things which are secretly done in these cities.

('25', 290, 2, 12, 673049) Even the alert police of these places cannot detect them.
('25', 290, 2, 13, 673107) I believe we cannot even imagine some of the crimes which are committed in these cities.
('25', 290, 2, 14, 673196) It is the duty of each one of us, men and women, to assist as many persons in distress as we can, and, through our services, bring relief to the distressed and thus discharge our social debt.
('25', 290, 2, 15, 673388) That country in which a large number of people regard others’ sufferings as their own and find remedies for them enjoys swaraj.
('25', 290, 3, 16, 673516) THE HABIT OF BLAMING THE POLICE
('25', 290, 4, 17, 673548) A slave, a coward, is usually afraid and, therefore, puts the blame always on others.
('25', 290, 4, 18, 673634) Among the letters which I have received regarding the painful incidents which took place in Bombay, there are some in which all the blame has been put on the police.

('25', 291, 3, 24, 676306) Even if they come wearing white caps, why should they be able to deceive anyone?
('25', 291, 3, 25, 676387) If we are good, the whole world is good.
('25', 291, 3, 26, 676428) Why should we be such cowards that we may be deceived?
('25', 291, 3, 27, 676483) Supposing a policeman, dressed in khadi, cruelly beats up someone.
('25', 291, 3, 28, 676550) Why should we get excited in consequence?
('25', 291, 3, 29, 676592) We should plead with him; If he does not listen, we should give up the effort and if we have the necessary strength, lay down our lives while trying to stop him in his evil course.
('25', 291, 3, 30, 676773) If we do this, we shall have given proof of our courage.
('25', 291, 3, 31, 676830) The police will
('25', 292, 0, 1, 676846) VOL. 25 : 27 OCTOBER, 1921 22 JANUARY, 1922 293
('25', 292, 1, 2, 676894) certainly improve when they see this courage of ours.
('25', 292, 1, 3, 676948) The police become brutalized by beating up cowards.
('25', 292, 1, 4, 677000) If a policeman attacks a brave person he will certainly get frightened afterwards.
('25', 292, 1, 5, 677083) I have received a letter from a friend in Lahore in which he says that when even strong young men do not resist the police, the latter lose courage.
('25', 292, 1, 6, 677232) They cannot harden themselves to beat such persons.
('25', 292, 1, 7, 677284) Of course they cannot.
('25', 292, 1, 8, 677307) I have had personal experience of many such instances.
('25', 292, 1, 9, 677362) This fearlessness cannot be taught, it can only be cultivated through one’s own effort.
('25', 292, 1, 10, 677450) My correspondents, therefore, should realize that it is certainly our task to gain control over the bad characters, but we would be throwing ourselves from the frying pan into the fire if we try to do so through flattery.
('25', 292, 1, 11, 677672) Although they are our brothers, they are like persons afflicted with a disease and we should treat them but should not place ourselves under their treatment.
('25', 292, 1, 12, 677830) The police will become our friends the day we cease to fear them.
('25', 292, 1, 13, 677896) Shedding fear of the police does not mean beating or abusing them, it means letting ourselves be beaten and abused by them, as the brave son of Chitta Ranjan Das did.
('25', 292, 1, 14, 678063) He could have beaten the police in return.
('25', 292, 1, 15, 678106) His friends were all strong young men.
('25', 292, 1, 16, 678145) But they let themselves be beaten.
('25', 292, 1, 17, 678180) To suffer being abused is one way; it is the way of non co operation.
('25', 292, 1, 18, 678250) But to return two words of abuse for one is co operation because then we shall be the guilty party.
('25', 292, 1, 19, 678350) To let ourselves be overborne by abuse is to be enslaved by it.
('25', 292, 1, 20, 678414) To suffer abuse does not mean doing the will of the person who abuses.
('25', 292, 1, 21, 678485) It means the contrary.
('25', 292, 1, 22, 678508) We should not even chant the name of Vishnu 1 if anyone tries to force us with abuse to do so.
('25', 292, 1, 23, 678603) If the person who abuses us asks us to crawl on our stomach, we should walk holding ourselves erect.
('25', 292, 1, 24, 678704) If he asks us to sit down, we should stand up and face his bullets.
('25', 292, 1, 25, 678772) If we act in this way, he will be totality defeated, because his aim of bending us will not be fulfilled.
('25', 292, 1, 26, 678878) Ravana carried away Sita on his shoulder but Sita did not do his bidding.
('25', 292, 1, 27, 678952) Though he had thus the privilege of carrying her, he failed to be sanctified by physical contact with this Mother Divine but she, a helpless woman, became the Goddess Mother of the world.
('25', 292, 1, 28, 679140) One should, therefore, let oneself be abused and beaten without fear.
('25', 292, 1, 29, 679210) In this lies true courage.
('25', 292, 1, 30, 679237) One who lets himself be abused through fear of being beaten is neither man nor beast.
('25', 292, 1, 31, 679323) India is today learning the lesson of manliness.
('25', 292, 1, 32, 679372) It will win swaraj if it masters this lesson aright.

('25', 293, 0, 1, 679462) 294 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('25', 293, 1, 2, 679504) THREE FEARS
('25', 293, 2, 3, 679516) The three articles of Shri Deshbandhu 1 published before his imprisonment are indicative of his ecstatic state of mind, and are worth pondering over.”Remain peaceful in thought, word and deed.””Win over the Moderates, too, with gentleness.” These are immortal words and are all the more beautiful for being penned at the time that they were.
('25', 293, 2, 4, 679858) There are equally beautiful sentences describing the three fears.
('25', 293, 2, 5, 679924) He says:”We have conquered the fear of prison”, and then, as if addressing his son:”We have almost conquered the second fear—that of being beaten.” The third fear is of facing bullets.
('25', 293, 2, 6, 680109) When we have conquered that, swaraj is bound to follow.
('25', 293, 2, 7, 680165) In fact, the key to swaraj lies in conquering this fear.
('25', 293, 2, 8, 680222) If we could shed our fear of beatings or of death, neither the Government nor the bad characters can lord it over us, and we can win swaraj only if we have among us people who have conquered these three types of fear, otherwise we shall never get it.
('25', 293, 3, 9, 680473) BREACH OF PROMISE
('25', 293, 4, 10, 680491) A gentleman writes: 2

('25', 293, 5, 15, 680704) A clerk cannot make promises on his own.

('25', 293, 5, 17, 680889) I will put it on the people of Bombay.

('25', 294, 2, 19, 683448) ERRORS IN”NAVAJIVAN”
('25', 294, 3, 20, 683469) Another gentleman has pointed out some errors in Navajivan.
('25', 294, 3, 21, 683529) My inquiry shows that there have been no such errors as he believes to have been made.
('25', 294, 3, 22, 683616) In case, however, other readers also are under such misapprehension, in order to clear it I should like to say that I do not write all that appears in Navajivan, that I cannot go through all of it and also that I do not translate my articles which appear in Young India.
('25', 294, 3, 23, 683887) Utmost care is taken to avoid errors.

('25', 294, 3, 26, 684085) Translating from one language into another is always more difficult than it appears.

('25', 295, 2, 3, 684712) WITH BLOWING OF CONCHES
('25', 295, 3, 4, 684736) The circumstances under which Deshbandhu Das was arrested are interesting.
('25', 295, 3, 5, 684811) He was arrested in his own house.
('25', 295, 3, 6, 684845) When the police arrived at about four in the afternoon, all were having tea.
('25', 295, 3, 7, 684922) Mr. Sasmal, the Secretary, went downstairs to meet the police.
('25', 295, 3, 8, 684985) On his introducing himself, he was arrested.
('25', 295, 3, 9, 685030) Meanwhile, Deshbandhu Das had also gone down.
('25', 295, 4, 10, 685076) “Do you wish to arrest me?”
('25', 295, 5, 11, 685104) “Yes, if you please.”
('25', 295, 6, 12, 685126) “Well, I am ready.”
('25', 295, 7, 13, 685146) Having said this, Deshbandhu did not go up to meet his wife but accompanied the police.
('25', 295, 7, 14, 685234) When the carriage taking him away came out, people outside shouted with joy and the women upstairs blew conches.
('25', 295, 7, 15, 685347) In Bengal, it is customary to blow the conch when welcoming a person or bidding farewell to anyone on an auspicious occasion.
('25', 295, 7, 16, 685473) This is regarded as a good omen.
('25', 295, 7, 17, 685506) When women give up crying on their husbands, sons or fathers being arrested and, instead, rejoice on the occasion, knowing that their imprisonment will serve the country and dharma, we shall see dharma prevail and adharma destroyed.
('25', 295, 7, 18, 685739) I, therefore, see in this blowing of the conch India’s victory.

('25', 300, 1, 2, 691457) 151. INTERVIEW TO ASSOCIATED PRESS ON ROUND TABLE CONFERENCE
('25', 300, 2, 3, 691518) [December 20, 1921] 1
('25', 300, 3, 4, 691540) Referring to Lord Ronaldshay’s speech at the Bengal Legislative Council on Monday last, Mr. Gandhi made the following statement to the correspondent of the Associated Press at his Ashram late in the night: I have read Lord Ronaldshay’s speech in the Bengal Legislative Council.
('25', 300, 3, 5, 691818) Whilst I appreciate the note of conciliation about it, I cannot help saying that it is most misleading.
('25', 300, 3, 6, 691922) I do not want to criticize those parts of the speech which lend themselves to criticism.
('25', 300, 3, 7, 692011) I simply want to say that the present situation is entirely his own and the Viceroy’s doing.
('25', 300, 3, 8, 692104) In spite of my strong ‘desire to avoid suspecting the Government of India and the Local Governments of a wish to precipitate a conflict with the people, up to now all that I have heard and read leads me to the conclusion that my suspicion is justified.
('25', 300, 3, 9, 692357) Whilst I do not wish to deny the existence of some sort of pressure, even intimidation, on the part of individuals, I do wish emphatically to deny that in connection with the phenomenal hartal on the 17th November in Calcutta, there was any intimidation, organized or initiated by or on behalf of the local Congress or the Khilafat Committees.
('25', 300, 3, 10, 692701) On the contrary, I am certain that the influence exerted by both these bodies was in the direction of avoiding all intimidation.
('25', 300, 3, 11, 692830) Moral pressure there certainly was and will always be in all big movements, but it must be clear to the simplest understanding that a complete hartal such as Calcutta witnessed on the 17th November would be an impossibility by mere intimidation.
('25', 300, 3, 12, 693076) But assume that there was intimidation.
('25', 300, 3, 13, 693116) Was there any reason for disbanding Volunteer Corps, prohibiting public meetings and enforcing laws which are under promise of repeal?
('25', 300, 3, 14, 693251) Why has no attempt been made to prove a single case of intimidation?
('25', 300, 3, 15, 693320) It grieves me to have to say that the Governor of Bengal has brought in the discovery of sword sticks in one place in Calcutta to discredit large public organizations.
('25', 300, 3, 16, 693488) Who intimidated the people into observing a complete hartal in Allahabad after all the leaders were arrested and in spite of the reported undue official pressure that was exercised upon shopkeepers and ghariwallas 2 at that place?
('25', 300, 3, 17, 693719) Again His Lordship says:
('25', 300, 4, 18, 693744) 1 A brief report of the interview appeared in The Bombay Chronicle, 21 12 1921, under the date line”Ahmedabad, December 20”.
('25', 300, 4, 19, 693869) 2 Drivers of carriages
('25', 301, 0, 1, 693892) 302 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('25', 301, 1, 2, 693934) If we are to assume that this development means there is genuine desire to bring about improvement, there must be a favourable atmosphere.
('25', 301, 1, 3, 694073) In other words, it will be generally agreed that truce must be an essential preliminary to any possible conference.
('25', 301, 1, 4, 694189) If responsible leaders of non co operation now come forward with the definite assurance that this is the correct interpretation, I should then say we were in sight of such a change of circumstances as would justify Government in reconsidering the position.
('25', 301, 1, 5, 694446) But words must be backed by deeds.
('25', 301, 1, 6, 694481) If I were satisfied only that there was a general desire for the conference and that responsible non co operation leaders were prepared to take action, then I should be prepared to recommend my Government to take steps in consonance with the altered situation.
('25', 301, 1, 7, 694742) This is highly misleading.
('25', 301, 1, 8, 694769) If wherever the words”non co operation leaders” occur, the word”Government” were put in and if the whole of the statement came from a non co operator, it would represent the correct situation.
('25', 301, 1, 9, 694962) Non co operators have really to do nothing, for they have precipitated nothing.
('25', 301, 1, 10, 695042) They are over cautious.
('25', 301, 1, 11, 695066) The disturbance in Bombay 1 was allowed to override their keen desire to take up aggressive civil disobedience but in the present circums tances the phrase”civil disobedience” is really a misnomer.
('25', 301, 1, 12, 695264) What non co operators are doing today, I claim, every co operator would do tomorrow under similar circumstances.
('25', 301, 1, 13, 695377) When the Government of India or the local Governments attempt to make our political existence or agitation, no matter how peaceful, an utter impossibility, may we not resist such attempt by every lawful means at our disposal?
('25', 301, 1, 14, 695603) I cannot imagine anything more lawful or more natural than that we should continue our volunteer organizations purging them of every tendency to become violent and continue also to hold public meetings taking the consequences of such a step.
('25', 301, 1, 15, 695845) Is it not proof of the law abiding instinct of hundreds of young men and old men that they have meekly, without offering any defence and without complaining, accepted imprisonment for having dared to exercise their elementary rights in the face of Government prosecution?
('25', 301, 1, 16, 696117) And so it is the Government which is to prove its genuine desire for a conference and an ultimate settlement.
('25', 301, 1, 17, 696227) It is the Government which has to arrest the fatal course along which repression is taking it.
('25', 301, 1, 18, 696322) It is the Government that is to prove to non co operators its bona fides before it can expect them to take part in any conference.
('25', 301, 1, 19, 696453) When the Government does that, it will find that there is an absolutely peaceful atmosphere.
('25', 301, 1, 20, 696546) Non co operation, when the Government is not resisting anything
('25', 301, 2, 21, 696610) 1 On November 17, 1921
('25', 302, 0, 1, 696633) VOL. 25 : 27 OCTOBER, 1921 22 JANUARY, 1922 303
('25', 302, 1, 2, 696681) except violence, is a most harmless thing.
('25', 302, 1, 3, 696724) There is really nothing for us to suspend.
('25', 302, 1, 4, 696767) We cannot be expected, until there is actual settlement or guarantee of settlement, to ask schoolboys to return to Government schools or lawyers to resume practice or public men to become candidates for the Councils or titleholders to ask for return of titles.
('25', 302, 1, 5, 697028) In the nature of things, it is, therefore, clear that non co operators have to do nothing.
('25', 302, 1, 6, 697119) Speaking personally, I can certainly say that if there is a genuine desire for a conference, I would be the last person to advise precipitating aggressive civil disobedience, which certainly it is my intention to do immediately I am entirely satisfied that the people have understood the secret of non violence; and let me say the last ten days’ events have shown that the people seem clearly to understand its inestimable value.
('25', 302, 1, 7, 697549) If then the Government recognizes that non co operators mean business and intend to suffer limitlessly for the attainment of their goal, let the Government unconditionally retrace its steps, cancel the notifications about disbandment of vol unteer organizations and prohibition of public meetings and release all those men in the different provinces who have been arrested and sentenced for so called civil disobedience or for any other purpose given under the definition of non cooperation but excluding acts of violence, actual or intended.
('25', 302, 1, 8, 698092) Let the Government come down with a heavy hand on every act of violence or incitement to it, but we must claim the right for all time of expressing our opinions freely and educating public opinion by every legitimate and non violent means.
('25', 302, 1, 9, 698332) It is, therefore, the Government who have really to undo the grave wrong they have perpetrated and they can have the conference they wish in a favourable atmosphere.
('25', 302, 1, 10, 698498) Let me also say that so far as I am concerned I want no conference to consider the ways and means of dealing with non co operation.
('25', 302, 1, 11, 698630) The only conference that can at all avail at this stage is a conference called to deal with the causes of the present discontent, namely, the Khilafat and the Punjab wrongs and swaraj.
('25', 302, 1, 12, 698815) Any conference again which can usefully sit at the present stage must be a conference that is really representative and not a conference to which only those whom the Government desire are invited.
('25', 302, 2, 13, 699012) Young India, 22 l 2 1921

('25', 305, 1, 2, 702937) 156. LETTER TO N. S. HARDIKAR
('25', 305, 2, 3, 702967) [Before December 22, 1921] 1
('25', 305, 3, 4, 702996) DEAR DR.
('25', 305, 3, 5, 703005) HARDIKAR, I would like you to tell the students in America that the best way in which they can serve the country there is to understand the non violent character of the struggle.
('25', 305, 3, 6, 703184) The violence which reigns supreme in the world today will only be conquered by non violence, i.e., love.
('25', 305, 3, 7, 703289) I would like the students also, when they write about the struggle, to be accurate in their facts and figures, which I often observe, they are not.
('25', 305, 4, 8, 703437) Yours sincerely,
('25', 305, 5, 9, 703454) M. K GANDHI

('25', 305, 7, 12, 703546) 157. NOTES
('25', 305, 8, 13, 703557) December 19, 1921
('25', 305, 9, 14, 703575) A DELECTABLE ASSORTMENT
('25', 305, 10, 15, 703599) Here are titbits I pick up from letters, wires, and reports which have deluged me during the week:
('25', 305, 11, 16, 703698) “Two Mohammedan workers have just returned with heads broken by a zemindar supporter of the Government.” Sind.
('25', 305, 12, 17, 703809) “Volunteer organizations declared unlawful.
('25', 305, 12, 18, 703853) Provincial, District, and other Congress offices, searehed throughout Bihar.
('25', 305, 12, 19, 703930) Papers, account books, cyclostyles, Congress seals, swaraj flags seized.
('25', 305, 12, 20, 704003) Provincial Committee resolved to continue Volunteer Corps enlistment.
('25', 305, 12, 21, 704073) Public enthusiastic and cheerful.” Bihar.
('25', 305, 13, 22, 704115) “Today (17th December) armed police took possession of the Shankar Hall, a religious institution of the Assam Mahapurushia sect in a part of which Barpeta Congress Committee established office.
('25', 305, 13, 23, 704309) The action was without notice to the Shankar Hall authorities.
('25', 305, 13, 24, 704372) The guarding constables are smoking inside the hall which is strictly prohibited, the wounding religious feeling of the people.
('25', 305, 13, 25, 704500) The belongings of the Congress were carelessly thrown out by police who have been using it as their dwelling house, thus preventing people from performing religious ceremonies.
('25', 305, 13, 26, 704677) People are still adhering to
('25', 305, 14, 27, 704706) 1 The addressee had quoted this letter in his letter dated 22 12 1921 to Indian residents in America.
('25', 306, 0, 1, 704808) VOL. 25 : 27 OCTOBER, 1921 22 JANUARY, 1922 307
('25', 306, 1, 2, 704856) non violence.
('25', 306, 1, 3, 704870) Work proceeding rapidly.” Barpeta, Assam.
('25', 306, 2, 4, 704912) “Houses of Pandit Rambhuj Dutt Chowdhary, Professor Ruchiram Sahany, Lala Lajpat Rai, Congress Committee offices, Khilafat offices, Sirajdin’s house, Sarala Devi’s 1 press searehed.
('25', 306, 2, 5, 705094) Volunteers in Lahore and Amritsar severely beaten by the police.
('25', 306, 2, 6, 705159) Prisoners reported to be caned in the Central Jail, Lahore.” I have given this assortment to show that swaraj is within easy grasp, if we can survive this treatment.
('25', 306, 2, 7, 705325) Surviving means bravely facing it without losing temper.
('25', 306, 2, 8, 705382) Let the administrators of an expiring system have the pleasure of being able to say, `’We tried but failed.” When the moth describes its violent revolutions round a lamp, he is surely dying.
('25', 306, 2, 9, 705573) So is this Government fast disintegrating under the weight of its own violence.
('25', 306, 2, 10, 705653) What is it, if it be not madness, to seareh private homes and public offices when they must know that there is nothing hidden, when they know that non co operators have no secrets?
('25', 306, 2, 11, 705834) But these searehes are no doubt intended to make the people feel as uncomfortable as they possibly could be made to feel.
('25', 306, 2, 12, 705956) A correspondent tells me that already the jails are feeling the pressure.
('25', 306, 2, 13, 706030) The jail authorities were unprepared for the number of men who are being daily sentenced.
('25', 306, 2, 14, 706120) They have no room and no work for so many.
('25', 306, 2, 15, 706163) Naturally, therefore, resort must be had to other methods of terrorizing.
('25', 306, 2, 16, 706237) Consequently, we must expect even assaults with greater frequency.
('25', 306, 2, 17, 706304) The reported caning is the worst thing yet come to light.
('25', 306, 2, 18, 706362) I still hope it is untrue.
('25', 306, 2, 19, 706389) I have taken the bit from The Tribune which is one of the most responsible journals that India has the good fortune to possess.
('25', 306, 2, 20, 706517) This report reminds one of the lashings during the martial law regime in Lahore.
('25', 306, 2, 21, 706598) It was at first denied but subsequently admitted.
('25', 306, 2, 22, 706648) The reader will remember Col.
('25', 306, 2, 23, 706678) Johnson justifying the use of the lash as a deterrent and as a swift method of punishment when imprisonment does not answer.
('25', 306, 2, 24, 706803) 2 Well, whether the report be true or not, we must prepare for the worst.
('25', 306, 2, 25, 706877) No suffering is too great a price for freedom.
('25', 306, 2, 26, 706924) It will be all the dearer when we have paid a heavy price for it.
('25', 306, 3, 27, 706990) But worse in some respects is the occupation of a temple in Barpeta.
('25', 306, 3, 28, 707059) It is a grave and uncalled for provocation.
('25', 306, 3, 29, 707103) But I must plead
('25', 306, 4, 30, 707120) 1 Sarladevi Chowdharani, wife of Pandit Rambhuj Dutt Chowdhari and niece of Rabindranath Tagore.
('25', 306, 4, 31, 707217) She and her husband became followers of Gandhiji in 1919. 2 Vide“Congress Report on the Punjab Disorders” On or Before March 25, 1920.
('25', 307, 0, 1, 707352) 308 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('25', 307, 1, 2, 707394) for non violence even under such grave provocation.
('25', 307, 1, 3, 707446) Let it be remembered that our pledge is unconditional.
('25', 307, 1, 4, 707501) We must stand by it at all cost.
('25', 307, 1, 5, 707534) An intruder cannot defile a temple.
('25', 307, 1, 6, 707570) Only votaries can by their unworthiness.
('25', 307, 1, 7, 707611) In the language of Maulana Abul Kalam Azad, let us think of the greater temple, namely, India, which has been defiled for so many years by our submission to slavery.
('25', 307, 1, 8, 707777) And if we have stood that defilement all these long years, let us not be provoked into madness by the illegal encroachments upon local temples and their still greater defilement by the intruders’ abuse of them.
('25', 307, 1, 9, 707988) Is Lord Reading prepared to plead extenuation even in this case on the ground that the officials are engaged in the performance of a very trying duty?
('25', 307, 2, 10, 708139) CHITTAGONG’S TOLL
('25', 307, 3, 11, 708157) The same day that I received a graphic description of things in Chittagong, I received too a wire advising me that Babu Prasanna Kumar Sen 1 who had sent the letter was also arrested.
('25', 307, 3, 12, 708341) The number of volunteers arrested there had reached a total of three hundred.
('25', 307, 3, 13, 708419) The reader will find the following excerpts from Babu Prasanna Kumar Sen’s letter to be interesting:
('25', 307, 4, 14, 708520) So long we have been literally at our wit’s end to find out the best means of beginning civil disobedience.
('25', 307, 4, 15, 708628) Following the resolution of the Working Committee at Delhi, we set out carefully educating our people to strict non violence.
('25', 307, 4, 16, 708754) Our propagandists were to return by the 8th December, but before the due date the Government of Bengal goaded by the Anglo Indian extremists went almost mad over the hartal in Calcutta on the 17th November, rushed on to take advantage of forgotten laws and forsaken methods and proclaimed volunteer associations illegal.
('25', 307, 4, 17, 709075) Thus it has come to our help.
('25', 307, 5, 18, 709105) For the last few days national volunteers in batches of not more than five have been going out with grim determination and cheerful anxiety to find themselves in jail.
('25', 307, 5, 19, 709273) The discipline and self restraint they are exhibiting are excellent, and if you do not think me guilty of exaggeration, I should not hesitate to declare them in this respect equal to best disciplined soldiers in the battle fields.
('25', 307, 5, 20, 709504) Within the last three days total arrests number sixty three.
('25', 307, 5, 21, 709565) Volunteers are pouring in from the moffussil and it is believed in no time authorities will find the Chittagong jail too small to accommodate the brave lads.
('25', 307, 5, 22, 709723) Thus the Government has declared peace to be unlawful and keepers of it to be criminals.
('25', 307, 5, 23, 709812) It puts the people through periodical
('25', 307, 6, 24, 709850) 1 Lawyer and Secretary District Congress Committee, Chittagong
('25', 308, 0, 1, 709913) VOL. 25 : 27 OCTOBER, 1921 22 JANUARY, 1922 309
('25', 308, 1, 2, 709961) discipline to observe peace not of their free will but only under restraint.
('25', 308, 2, 3, 710038) MIXED MOTIVES
('25', 308, 3, 4, 710052) A friend tells me that the Government is suppressing the volunteer organizations because it is not sure that they will always remain peaceful.
('25', 308, 3, 5, 710195) The correspondent adds:
('25', 308, 4, 6, 710219) They think at present under your mandate they are non violent, but any day your orders or the orders of your successors may change and the volunteers may be asked to be armed in military fashion—a standing rebel army against the Government army.
('25', 308, 4, 7, 710465) The other hypothesis suggested by the same correspondent is that the Government dread this non violence more than an armed revolt.
('25', 308, 4, 8, 710596) The police officers are getting tired and unnerved by being ordered to molest people who do not retaliate.
('25', 308, 4, 9, 710703) Some of them confess,
('25', 308, 5, 10, 710725) Non violence is a dreadful foe to meet.
('25', 308, 5, 11, 710765) Violence we understand and do not mind.
('25', 308, 5, 12, 710805) But it makes one feel so small to beat a man who does not beat you back.
('25', 308, 5, 13, 710878) The fact is that both the suggestions are sound.
('25', 308, 5, 14, 710927) The Government dread the future and want to guard against the people acquiring the power to offer armed resistance and they dread the rapid evolution of peaceful strength.
('25', 308, 5, 15, 711099) In short, they want us to be neither men nor women.
('25', 308, 5, 16, 711151) They would have us belong to the neuter gender.
('25', 308, 6, 17, 711199) UNSEXING PROCESS
('25', 308, 7, 18, 711216) Belgaum furnishes a forcible illustration of the unsexing process being tried at present in India.
('25', 308, 7, 19, 711315) A friend has prepared for me the following summary of a report from Belgaum:
('25', 308, 8, 20, 711392) The district authorities of Belgaum have devised an original method of suppressing non co operation.
('25', 308, 8, 21, 711493) Mr. Hayter, the Superintendent of Police, issued a circular calling upon all Sub Inspectors to use their power to stop the spread of non co operation.
('25', 308, 8, 22, 711644) The Sub Inspectors on their part circularized the village police that”all non co operation speakers should be forcibly suppressed.
('25', 308, 8, 23, 711775) They should not be allowed to enter villages and should be expelled from villages.
('25', 308, 8, 24, 711858) And speakers should be prevented from speaking.
('25', 308, 8, 25, 711906) The Deputy Superintendent of Police hopes that it is enough if police patels are
('25', 308, 9, 26, 711987) given to understand this.
('25', 308, 9, 27, 712013) Superior officers will render proper assistance in the matter.” But when the ex lawyers in the non co operation camp raised the question of law in this matter, the D.S.P. came down with his circular No.
('25', 308, 9, 28, 712216) 6359 of 1921 saying that section 51(B) of the District Police Act which
('25', 309, 0, 1, 712288) 310 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('25', 309, 1, 2, 712330) empowered the police to prevent the commission of offence was sufficient for his purpose.
('25', 309, 1, 3, 712420) The D.S.P. further says,”Wherever these N.C.O. 1 gentry open their mouths in public, they commit offences under section 124A or 153A Indian Penal Code.
('25', 309, 1, 4, 712572) Therefore, police officers should do everything possible, consistent with law, to render the offence difficult.” The humour of all this was that armed with these notifications, the Sub Inspector of Bailhongal, a taluka in Belgaum, actually proceeded physically to stop the mouth of one of the Secretaries of the District Congress Committee, when the latter was about to deliver a speech at Bailhongal.
('25', 309, 1, 5, 712974) Let the Secretary speak:
('25', 309, 2, 6, 712999) When I rose to address the meeting, the Sub Inspector of police stood in front of me and told me not to speak.
('25', 309, 2, 7, 713110) Asked for a written order he refused to give one but showed me Circular No.
('25', 309, 2, 8, 713186) 6359 referred to above .
('25', 309, 2, 9, 713211) He further told me that if I persisted in speaking, he would physically stop my mouth by laying his hand upon it .
('25', 309, 2, 10, 713326) This being a somewhat novel proceeding .
('25', 309, 2, 11, 713367) I obeyed the order and did not speak.
('25', 309, 2, 12, 713405) The local Magistrate and Mamlatdar was present throughout.
('25', 309, 2, 13, 713464) Let me complete this lurid picture by adding a summary of events in Allahabad:
('25', 309, 3, 14, 713543) On the 25th November last a Gazette Extraordinary was issued by the
('25', 309, 4, 15, 713611) Government extending the application of the Criminal Amendment Act of 1908 to the U.P. and declaring all Volunteer Corps of Khilafat, Congress and similar institutions having as their object boycott of foreign cloth, picketing or boycott of the Prince’s visit as unlawful assemblies.
('25', 309, 5, 16, 713895) On the same day, according to the announcement previously made, a meeting of the Provincial Congress Committee was held which resolved to form a Volunteer Board on the lines laid down by the Working Committee.
('25', 309, 5, 17, 714105) A form of pledge was drawn up and 75 members present at the meeting signed it as volunteers.
('25', 309, 5, 18, 714198) The first victim of Government wrath was Pandit Harkaran Nath Mishra of Lucknow who had gone to Lakhmipur to address a meeting.
('25', 309, 5, 19, 714326) Then followed the arrests at Lucknow of Maulana Khaliquzzaman and others of the Congress and Khilafat Committees on the morning of 6th December.
('25', 309, 5, 20, 714471) On the evening of the same day Pandits Motilal Nehru, Jawaharlal Nehru 2, Purushottamdas Tandon 3 and others were arrested, who have since been
('25', 309, 6, 21, 714615) 1 Non co operator 2 1889 1964; statesman and writer; India’s first Prime Minister, 1947 64; Bharat Ratna; author of Glimpses of World History, Autobiography, etc.
('25', 309, 7, 22, 714778) 3 1882 1962; lawyer and eminent leader of U.P.; founder, Hindi Sahitya Sammelan; President, Indian National Congress, 1950; Bharat Ratna.
('25', 309, 7, 23, 714916) He was at that time Chairman of the Allahabad Municipality.
('25', 310, 0, 1, 714976) VOL. 25 : 27 OCTOBER, 1921 22 JANUARY, 1922 311
('25', 310, 1, 2, 715024) sentenced to various terms of imprisonment for enlisting as volunteers.
('25', 310, 1, 3, 715096) Then followed a short pause which was broken on the 11th instant by the arrest of 67 volunteers, mostly while painting a placard on the walls of Anand Bhavan 1
('25', 310, 2, 4, 715256) requesting the people not to participate in the Prince’s reception.
('25', 310, 2, 5, 715324) The climax, however, was reached on the 13th instant when the whole Provincial Congress Committee was besieged by the police while in session, and the whole body of members excepting the two secretaries and two others were arrested.
('25', 310, 2, 6, 715557) The Committee sat at 1 p.m.
('25', 310, 2, 7, 715585) and continued the meeting till 9 in the evening.
('25', 310, 2, 8, 715634) At about half past five, the police under one D.S.P. named Mr. Fergusson arrived with some six motor vans for carrying prisoners, entered the premises of the Committee and blocked all passages.
('25', 310, 2, 9, 715828) They searehed the office till 9. When, the meeting having terminated, the members informed the D.S.P. of their intention to leave, the D.S.P. went over to the meeting and demanded the proceedings to be shown to him and finding a resolution therein recommending all district and tehsil Congress Committees to organize Volunteer Corps, declared that an offence had been committed under the Criminal Law Amendment Act.
('25', 310, 2, 10, 716244) He then asked all present one by one whether they were members of the committee and had supported the resolution.
('25', 310, 2, 11, 716358) All the members having replied in the affirmative, he arrested fifty five of them including all the prominent workers of the province.
('25', 310, 3, 12, 716493) During the search B. Shitalasahai editor of the Swaraj was kicked, boxed
('25', 310, 4, 13, 716566) and otherwise assaulted by Mr. Fergusson so much so that blood came out of his skin.
('25', 310, 4, 14, 716651) But he bore all that patiently.
('25', 310, 4, 15, 716683) Several others also were badly treated and pushed and assaulted by the same officer.
('25', 310, 4, 16, 716768) Everybody kept his temper.
('25', 310, 4, 17, 716795) There was no search or arrest warrant produced, nor did the officers have their bodies searched before beginning the search.
('25', 310, 4, 18, 716920) All papers, records and seals of the Provincial Congress Committee have been seized by the police and put under sealed locks.
('25', 310, 4, 19, 717046) It is evident to me that this utter disregard of law and decency is not an individual act but is part of a deliberate plan to suppress all healthy public life, to provoke popular violence and then issue a much enlarged edition of Jallianwala.
('25', 310, 4, 20, 717289) With the best intention to put a charitable construction on the series of acts described above, I have been unable to come to any other conclusion,
('25', 310, 5, 21, 717437) VICEROY’S SHARE
('25', 310, 6, 22, 717453) I am sorry that I suspect Lord Reading of complicity in the plot to unman India for eternity.
('25', 310, 6, 23, 717547) A friend has suggested an alternative.

('25', 321, 2, 8, 743884) REMARKABLE PLEDGE
('25', 321, 3, 9, 743902) To show the thorough nature of the work of ensuring peace that is being done in Delhi, I extract the following remarkable pledge from Mr. Asaf Ali’s 2 letter which he wrote when he offered himself and fifty two others for arrest:
('25', 321, 4, 10, 744132) With full consciousness of the omnipresence and omniscience of Gods I declare that it shall be my solemn duty, (I) to attain swaraj by peaceful means, (2) to preserve and foster unity between the members and followers of the various communities and religions of India, (3) to regard no class or community as contemptible or untouchable, (4) to sacrifice life and property for the honour and interests of my country, (5) to wear clothes made of cloth hand spun and hand woven in the country, (6) to obey without demur the orders of the officers, (7) so long as I am not discharged from the Corps, to observe myself and persuade others to observe nonviolence (for as long as the Congress continues to follow this policy) and (8) finally, I will cheerfully bear privations and troubles which may confront me during my connection with the National Volunteers Corps and neither I nor any of my dependents and relations expect any compensation.

('25', 324, 1, 2, 750248) THE”INDEPENDENT” SUPPRESSED
('25', 324, 2, 3, 750276) It will be remembered that immediately after Mr. George Joseph’s arrest when a new declaration was made by Mr. Mahadev Desai as publisher and printer, a security of Rs. 2,000 was demanded.
('25', 324, 2, 4, 750465) Under Panditji’s advice, the security demanded was lodged and the paper reappeared after a day’s suspension.
('25', 324, 2, 5, 750574) The security was deposited on the 7th instant.
('25', 324, 2, 6, 750621) It was forfeited on the 20th.
('25', 324, 2, 7, 750651) There was no change of tone or policy, for, there was nothing to change.
('25', 324, 2, 8, 750724) The Independent was edited by a barrister who wrote always under restraint and with dignity.
('25', 324, 2, 9, 750817) On Mr. Joseph’s incarceration it was taken up by Mr. Mahadev Desai with whose style the readers of Young India are not unfamiliar.
('25', 324, 2, 10, 750948) The security was forfeited because of its articles,”Let Us Also See It Through” and”Mrs. Nehru’s Message”.
('25', 324, 2, 11, 751055) The first contains a list of volunteers and the second is a balanced review of the position.
('25', 324, 2, 12, 751148) But the local Government contend that the articles”contain words which have a tendency to interfere with the administration of the law and with the maintenance of law and order.” The law we know, the notification of disbandment; the order too we know, the prohibition of the holding of public meetings.
('25', 324, 2, 13, 751451) And the Independent has certainly, in common with the whole of the nationalist Press, encouraged interference with such law and such order.
('25', 324, 2, 14, 751591) But the Government will soon find out its mistake.
('25', 324, 2, 15, 751642) The Independent may die but the spirit that it has evoked among the people cannot die.
('25', 324, 2, 16, 751729) The Independent may not be printed but it can be written.
('25', 324, 2, 17, 751787) If the editor is a trustee for his employers, he has also his own individuality to keep.
('25', 324, 2, 18, 751876) Mahadev Desai, the editor, lives, although the printer in him may sleep for a while.
('25', 324, 2, 19, 751961) And I am hoping that he will now write his paper instead of printing it.
('25', 324, 2, 20, 752034) The readers will benefit by the enforced condensation of news and editorial notes.
('25', 324, 2, 21, 752117) For multiplying copies I suggest the use of roneo, cyclostyle or chromograph.
('25', 324, 2, 22, 752195) And if the law or its arbitrary interpretation permits the Government to confiscate even a cyclostyle or a roneo, Mr. Desai’s pen can still serve the country until he himself is confiscated and lodged in the Central Jail of Allahabad.

('25', 327, 2, 17, 759501) CHARKHA IN THE MADRAS COUNCIL
('25', 327, 3, 18, 759531) The spinning wheel was the subject of a debate in the Madras Council when one of the members introduced a resolution recommending that the Government should introduce improved patterns of spinning wheels and stimulate hand spinning and hand weaving.
('25', 327, 3, 19, 759781) The resolution was thrown out after a full discussion, 23 members voting in its favour.
('25', 327, 3, 20, 759869) The arguments that were advanced against the resolution were that”khadi was nothing better than gunny and that no man of common sense would prefer it to cheap mill made cloth,” that”in this age of machinery, it would be criminal to go back to hand spinning,” that”hand spun yarn was weak,” and lastly, that”the spinning wheel had been found to be economically unsound and that therefore public money ought not to be spent on it”.
('25', 327, 3, 21, 760299) All these arguments were sufficiently met by the advocates of the wheel in the Council.
('25', 327, 3, 22, 760387) But the point of interest was that the doctrine of economic unsoundness of the wheel, enunciated by the Minister in charge of the Department in question, was opposed by the economics expert of the Madras Government, Dr. Slater, who appealed to the Minister”to keep an open mind” in the matter.
('25', 327, 3, 23, 760681) Dr. Slater appreciates the fact that the agriculturists of India who are growing poorer need
