('25', 329, 2, 3, 762833) Friday [On or before December 23, 1921]
('25', 329, 3, 4, 762873) BHAISHRI MAHADEV, I read your letter.
('25', 329, 3, 5, 762911) There is no end to your joy as there is none to your”grief”.
('25', 329, 3, 6, 762972) One can look at the matter as one wishes.
('25', 329, 3, 7, 763014) May you remain firm in your resolve.
('25', 329, 3, 8, 763051) You may stay on there or .
('25', 329, 3, 9, 763078) as long as you feel that your presence is necessary.
('25', 329, 3, 10, 763131) You have many obligations to your family to be discharged and have got to repay them.
('25', 329, 3, 11, 763217) It is not clear to me whether or not you should take the responsibility of seeing your sisters married.
('25', 329, 3, 12, 763321) If I were in your place I would make the position clear with my father.
('25', 329, 3, 13, 763393) And if it was left to me to arrange their marriage, I would depend upon Him Who gave away the customary presents on behalf of Narasinh Mehta 2 to his daughter’s in laws at the time of her first pregnancy, and would send my sister to her father in law’s with only a garland of yarn round her neck.
('25', 329, 3, 14, 763690) This is my advice.
('25', 329, 3, 15, 763709) You should discuss things with Durga 3 .
('25', 329, 3, 16, 763750) and if she is in mourning, .
('25', 329, 3, 17, 763779) father and seek his advice.
('25', 329, 3, 18, 763807) After doing all this, you should follow the dictates of your conscience.
('25', 329, 3, 19, 763880) If you give away everything, it will not matter; and if you do not give anything, I shall defend you before the whole world.
('25', 329, 3, 20, 764005) What I said yesterday was the outpouring of my soul.
('25', 329, 3, 21, 764058) I alone have to be carried away in its current.
('25', 329, 3, 22, 764106) Others have not to.
('25', 329, 3, 23, 764126) If, on their seeing the current that is carrying me, a similar current begins to flow in them, they may let themselves be carried away by it.
('25', 329, 3, 24, 764268) The thing simply cannot be done on the advice of others.
('25', 329, 3, 25, 764325) The reply Mathuradas gave was correct.
('25', 329, 3, 26, 764364) He who wants to give away everything will do so of his own accord.
('25', 329, 3, 27, 764431) Yes, you are right in consulting me.
('25', 329, 3, 28, 764468) I would give you the advice that I have given above.
('25', 329, 3, 29, 764521) What is necessary is that we should learn to be more and more self confident.

('25', 330, 1, 2, 764985) 160. INTERVIEW TO”THE BOMBAY CHRONICLE”
('25', 330, 2, 3, 765025) [December 23, 1921] 1
('25', 330, 3, 4, 765047) The Working Committee sat both this morning and evening and exhaustively discussed the main resolution dealing with the Congress programme and the future work.
('25', 330, 3, 5, 765207) Among other matters considered was the selection of the president to act for Mr. Das and, as had already been suggested, Hakim Ajmal Khan was selected for the office.
('25', 330, 3, 6, 765374) His name will be submitted to the All India Congress Committee for confirmation at its tomorrow’s sitting.
('25', 330, 3, 7, 765481) Mahatma Gandhi interviewed by a representative of The Bombay Chronicle after the meeting was over said that the meeting was noted for absolute harmony and complete unanimity of opinion among those who took part.
('25', 330, 3, 8, 765693) Besides the members of the Committee, there were leading representatives of the provinces and others specially invited.
('25', 330, 3, 9, 765813) There is considerable feeling among Karnatak, Maharashtra and one or two other provinces that foreign propaganda, which was dropped last year, 2 should be resumed and carried out on completely new lines so as to present the outside world with impartial information regarding India’s position.
('25', 330, 3, 10, 766106) It is understood that a resolution in this behalf will be brought forward at the Subjects Committee meeting.
('25', 330, 3, 11, 766215) It appears that Gandhiji is not in favour of such propaganda, but the outcome of the discussion will be awaited with interest.
('25', 330, 3, 12, 766342) With reference to the Viceroy’s speech 3 Gandhiji was not apparently disappointed since he himself had previously anticipated that result.
('25', 330, 3, 13, 766481) The speech had merely justified his own view regarding the futility of such deputation.
('25', 330, 3, 14, 766569) It was by mere accident, said Gandhiji, that he had seen the report of Lord Ronaldshay’s speech and had thought that it should be answered.
('25', 330, 3, 15, 766709) He had already replied 4 to it and nothing he had said was not justified by result.
('25', 330, 4, 16, 766793) The Bombay Chronicle, 24 l2 1921

('25', 330, 7, 19, 766944) 3 Delivered at Calcutta on December 21, 1921 in reply to the deputation led by Malaviya 4 Vide”Interview to Associated Press on Round Table Conference”, 20 12 1921.

('25', 332, 1, 2, 769149) 162. INTERVIEW TO ASSOCIATED PRESS ON VICEROY’S SPEECH
('25', 332, 2, 3, 769204) AHMEDABAD, December 24, 1921
('25', 332, 3, 4, 769233) Interviewed by an Associated Press correspondent, Mr. Gandhi made the following statement regarding His Excellency Lord Reading’s speech 1 at Calcutta in reply to the deputation led by Pandit Madan Mohan Malaviya: I must confess that I have read the Viceregal utterance with deep pain.
('25', 332, 3, 5, 769519) I was totally unprepared for what I must respectfully call his mischievous misrepresentation of the attitude of the Congress and the Khilafat organization in connection with the visit of his Royal Highness the Prince of Wales.
('25', 332, 3, 6, 769746) Every resolution passed by either organization and every speaker has laid the greatest stress upon the fact that there was no question of showing the slightest ill will against the Prince or exposing him to any affront.
('25', 332, 3, 7, 769966) The boycott was purely a question of principle and directed against what we have held to be the unscrupulous methods of the bureaucracy.
('25', 332, 3, 8, 770103) I have always held, as I hold even now, that the Prince has been brought to India in order to strengthen the hold of the civil service corporation which has brought India into a state of abject pauperism and political serfdom.
('25', 332, 3, 9, 770330) If I am proved to be wrong in my supposition that the visit has that sinister meaning I shall gladly apologize.
('25', 332, 3, 10, 770442) It is equally unfortunate for the Viceroy to say that the boycott of the welcome means an affront to the British people.
('25', 332, 3, 11, 770563) His Excellency does not realize what a grievous wrong he is doing to his own people by confusing them with the British administrators in India.
('25', 332, 3, 12, 770707) Does he wish India to infer that the British administrators here represent the British people and that the agitation directed against their methods is an agitation against the British people?
('25', 332, 3, 13, 770899) And if such is the Viceregal contention and if to conduct a vigorous and effective agitation against
('25', 332, 4, 14, 771000) 1 Delivered on December 21, 1921, in which Lord Reading had, according to lndia in 1921 22,”fully explained the reasons which led Government to enforce special Acts; emphasized his determination.
('25', 332, 4, 15, 771196) to protect law abiding subjects, and, further, in view of the approaching visit of His Royal Highness the Prince of Wales, conveyed grave warning as to the effect likely to be produced on the public and Parliament of the United Kingdom by affronts offered to the Heir to the Throne.
('25', 332, 4, 16, 771479) His Excellency insisted also as a condition precedent even to the discussion of any project of a conference, on the imperative necessity for the discontinuance of the unlawful activities of the non co operation party.”
('25', 333, 0, 1, 771698) 334 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('25', 333, 1, 2, 771740) the methods of the bureaucracy and to describe them in their true colours is an affront to the British people, then, I am afraid, I must plead guilty.
('25', 333, 1, 3, 771891) But, then, I must also say in all humility that the Viceroy has entirely misread and misunderstood the great national awakening that is taking place in India.
('25', 333, 1, 4, 772050) I repeat for the thousandth time that it is not hostile to any nation or any body of men, but it is deliberately aimed at the system under which the Government of India is being today conducted and I promise that no threats and no enforcement of threats by the Viceroy or any body of men will strangle that agitation or send to rest that awakening.
('25', 333, 1, 5, 772399) I have said in my reply 1 to Lord Ronaldshay’s speech that we have not taken the offensive.
('25', 333, 1, 6, 772491) We are not the aggressors.
('25', 333, 1, 7, 772518) We have not got to stop any single activity.
('25', 333, 1, 8, 772563) It is the Government that is to stop its aggravatingly offensive activity aimed, not at violence, but at lawful, disciplined, stern, but absolutely non violent, agitation.
('25', 333, 1, 9, 772735) It is for the Government of India and for it alone to bring about a peaceful atmosphere if it so desires.
('25', 333, 1, 10, 772841) It has hurled a bomb shell in the midst of material rendered inflammable by its own action and wonders that the material is still not inflammable enough to explode.
('25', 333, 2, 11, 773006) The immediate issue is not now the redress of the three wrongs 2. The immediate issue is the right of holding public meetings and the right of forming associations for peaceful purposes, and in vindicating this right, we are fighting the battle not merely on behalf of non co operators, but we are fighting the battle for all India down from the peasant up to the prince and for all schools of politics.
('25', 333, 2, 12, 773410) It is the one condition of any organic growth and I see in the Viceregal announcement an insistence on submission to a contrary doctrine, which an erstwhile exponent of the law of liberty has seen fit to lay down upon finding himself in an atmosphere where there is little regard for law and order on the part of those very men who are supposed to be the custodians of law and order.
('25', 333, 2, 13, 773794) 1 have only to point to the unprovoked assaults being committed not in isolated cases, not in one place, but in Bengal, in the Punjab, in Delhi and in the United Provinces.
('25', 333, 2, 14, 773967) I have no doubt that as repression goes on in its mad career the reign of terrorism will overtake the whole of this unhappy land.
('25', 333, 3, 15, 774097) 1 Vide”Interview to Associated Press on Round Table Conference”, 20 12 1921. 2 Of the Khilafat, of the Punjab and of the denial of swaraj; vide”Notes”, 22 12 1921, under the sub title”Round Table Conference”
('25', 334, 0, 1, 774305) VOL. 25 : 27 OCTOBER, 1921 22 JANUARY, 1922 335
('25', 334, 1, 2, 774353) But, whether the campaign is conducted on civilized or uncivilized lines, so far as I can see, there is only one way open to non co operators —indeed, I contend, even to.
('25', 334, 1, 3, 774524) the people of India.
('25', 334, 1, 4, 774545) On this question of the right of holding public meetings and forming associations there can be no yielding.
('25', 334, 1, 5, 774653) We have burnt our boats and we must march onward till that primary right of human beings is vindicated.
('25', 334, 1, 6, 774757) Let me make my own position clear.
('25', 334, 1, 7, 774792) I am most anxious for a settlement.
('25', 334, 1, 8, 774828) I want a round table conference.
('25', 334, 1, 9, 774861) I want our position to be clearly known by everybody Who wants to understand it.
('25', 334, 1, 10, 774942) I impose no conditions, but when conditions are imposed upon me prior to the holding of a conference, I must be allowed to examine those conditions and, if I find that they are suicidal, I must be excused if I do not accept them.
('25', 334, 1, 11, 775172) The amount of tension that is created can be regulated solely by the Government of India, for the offensive has been taken by that Government

('25', 334, 6, 20, 775612) 164. MY NOTES
('25', 334, 7, 21, 775626) GOOD INTENTION PUNISHED
('25', 334, 8, 22, 775650) I have discovered through long experience that editing a journal is no light task.
('25', 334, 8, 23, 775733) An editor should in the first place, accept responsibility for his own lapses.
('25', 334, 8, 24, 775812) Next, he is held responsible for anything which even his assistant may write, as also for the errors of
('25', 334, 9, 25, 775916) 1 This telegram was evidently sent soon after the conviction of Mahadev Desai on December 24, 1921, under the Criminal Law Amendment Act for publishing the manuscript edition of Independent.
('25', 335, 0, 1, 776107) 336 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('25', 335, 1, 2, 776149) reporters or other contributors.
('25', 335, 1, 3, 776182) If a compositor makes a slip, then again the res ponsibility is the editor’s; even if it is a proof reader who has slipped, the editor has to face the music.
('25', 335, 1, 4, 776340) If the machine fails and the copy misses the post or the types do not come out clearly, the editor will have to answer for the lapse.
('25', 335, 1, 5, 776474) He cannot just write and leave everything else to others.
('25', 335, 1, 6, 776532) I can cite incidents of all these types.
('25', 335, 1, 7, 776573) The latest one, however, is such as will make the reader smile.
('25', 335, 1, 8, 776637) It has led to a serious misunderstanding on the part of a friend.
('25', 335, 1, 9, 776703) In Navajivan’s issue of December 11, there was a note 1 about Parsis which contained the following sentence:”At any rate I assure my Parsi brothers and sisters that hundreds of Hindus and Muslims are ready to lay down their lives for them and for other communities except the Christians.” As originally written, the words were vi.
('25', 335, 1, 10, 777034) 2 nani 3. What I meant was:”that hundreds of Hindus and Muslims are ready to lay down their lives for them and for other small communities like the Christians”.
('25', 335, 1, 11, 777195) The point after vi.
('25', 335, 1, 12, 777215) having been left out, the result was another case of”[Kaka] Ajmer gaya” 4 becoming”[Kaka] aaj mari gaya.” 5 A Christian friend read the sentence wrong and has protested to me.
('25', 335, 1, 13, 777391) My other writings on this subject and the construction of the sentence leave no room for misunderstanding its purport.
('25', 335, 1, 14, 777510) One should not be surprised however, if a person not familiar with Navajivan happened to read only this passage and were to misconstrue it as above.
('25', 335, 1, 15, 777659) One of my aims in writing this paragraph is to apologize to this Christian friend and others who may have misread the sentence.
('25', 335, 1, 16, 777787) Another is to request all readers to take a lesson from the error in this case, that, even when an all favourable construction may seem justified, a favourable construction should be accepted if the statement will bear it.
('25', 335, 1, 17, 778010) My third aim is to plead for some sympathy for the editor.
('25', 335, 1, 18, 778069) Realizing that the editor cannot possibly look after everything, readers should excuse unavoidable errors in the paper published under his name.
('25', 335, 1, 19, 778214) I do not, however, say all this to secure a licence for mistakes.
('25', 335, 1, 20, 778280) The editor is bound to discharge properly the responsibility which has come upon him, or leave the job.
('25', 335, 1, 21, 778384) No one is forced to accept the editorship.
('25', 335, 1, 22, 778427) If the printers, the compositors and the proof readers are
('25', 335, 2, 23, 778486) 1 Vide”Notes”, 11 12 1921, Under Sub title”To Parsi Brothers and Sisters”.
('25', 335, 3, 24, 778561) 2 Abbreviation for”and others” 3 Small.
('25', 335, 3, 25, 778601) Vinani, read as one word, means”except”
('25', 335, 4, 26, 778641) 4 Uncle went to Ajmer 5 Uncle died today
('25', 336, 0, 1, 778682) VOL. 25 : 27 OCTOBER, 1921 22 JANUARY, 1922 337
('25', 336, 1, 2, 778730) not all of them efficient, the editor alone is to be held responsible.
('25', 336, 1, 3, 778801) Why did he, in such circumstances, accept the editorship?
('25', 336, 1, 4, 778859) This, however, is only an ideal.
('25', 336, 1, 5, 778892) If anyone decides not to start at all unless he can realize the ideal right now, he will never realize it.
('25', 336, 1, 6, 778999) The reader, therefore, may certainly regard himself as a whip with which to punish the editor.
('25', 336, 1, 7, 779094) Only, he should exercise discrimination in using the whip.
('25', 336, 1, 8, 779153) One person may use it like Dyer and another may, like the large hearted king, keep one for show and only on rare occasions let a restive horse know, when its misbehaviour is marked, that it is not entirely for show.
('25', 336, 2, 9, 779369) VISIT TO NEHRUJI IN JAIL
('25', 336, 3, 10, 779394) A letter received from an Ashram inmate who recently visited Pandit Motilal Nehru in Lucknow Jail is so good, most of it, that I reproduce it below: 1
('25', 336, 4, 11, 779545) RESIDENTS OF RAJKOT
('25', 336, 5, 12, 779565) How can I help being pained when anyone criticizes Rajkot?
('25', 336, 5, 13, 779624) A sister told me a few days ago that, if I went there now, I would see nothing but khadi everywhere and that I would see very few people wearing foreign cloth.
('25', 336, 5, 14, 779784) The lady lives in Rajkot at present and generally wears khadi outside her home.
('25', 336, 5, 15, 779864) From her own practice, she seems to have assumed that everyone in Rajkot wears khadi.
('25', 336, 5, 16, 779950) But a young man who observes the vow of complete swadeshi, is a resident of Rajkot and has not travelled much, has this to say about the city : 2
('25', 336, 6, 17, 780096) This is no mild stricture.
('25', 336, 6, 18, 780123) I found it confirmed, by chance, in what was said by another friend from Kathiawar who is a shrewd observer.
('25', 336, 6, 19, 780232) If we discount the element of exaggeration which the criticism may possibly contain, the rest of it is likely to be based on facts.
('25', 336, 6, 20, 780364) Kathiawar contributed handsomely to the Tilak Swaraj Fund.
('25', 336, 6, 21, 780423) Amreli has an excellent arrangement for khadi work.
('25', 336, 6, 22, 780475) Kathiawar produces a good quantity of khadi.
('25', 336, 6, 23, 780520) I know all this.
('25', 336, 6, 24, 780537) It is painful to know, however, that Kathiawaris living in big cities have not been able to give up their love of foreign cloth.
('25', 336, 6, 25, 780666) Kathiawar should have been less infected by so called progress.
('25', 336, 6, 26, 780730) Its rocky soil should produce hardy, straightforward, brave, simpleminded and generous people.
('25', 336, 6, 27, 780825) If, instead, we find love of pleasure increasing in its cities, what will come out of the high hopes which have been raised on its behalf?
('25', 336, 6, 28, 780964) If Kathiawar does not make its full contribution to the swaraj yajna, I, for one, feel
('25', 336, 7, 29, 781051) 1 The letter is not translated here.
('25', 336, 7, 30, 781088) 2 The extract is not translated here.
('25', 336, 7, 31, 781126) The correspondent had said that Rajkot had made no progress in the field of swadeshi.
('25', 337, 0, 1, 781212) 338 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('25', 337, 1, 2, 781254) that it should sever its connection with the rest of the country.
('25', 337, 1, 3, 781320) I have been hoping that, when the time for courting imprisonment comes, Kathiawaris will provide their quota of volunteers.
('25', 337, 1, 4, 781444) If, however, we have not by then cultivated sufficient simplicity to wear khadi, how shall we be able to endure the austerity of jail life?
('25', 337, 1, 5, 781584) When Deshbandhu Das wears khadi and plies the spinning wheel, when Maulana Shaukat Ali, for whom it was difficult to adopt khadi, has started wearing it and works on the spinning wheel in jail, should the residents of Kathiawar’s cities keep away from khadi?
('25', 337, 1, 6, 781843) I can now understand the reason for the complaint once made to me, to the effect that Kathiawar produces a good quantity of khadi but that the demand for it is not much.
('25', 337, 1, 7, 782013) Will a time also come when the robust women of Kathiawar will indeed make rotlas 1 of bajra 2 and, in the early morning, churn liquid curds to obtain rich butter from them, but will give the rotlas to dogs and, their stomach too weak to digest butter, have some tea and biscuits, eat fulkas 3 made from mill flour obtained from Bombay because the Kathiawar wheat is too heavy for their digestion and too red in colour to please them?
('25', 337, 1, 8, 782447) If someone, following Green, were to write a history of the rise and decline of our people, omitting the wars of kings, he would certainly be able to prove that as India took more and more to fine cloth, soft to the touch, the people also became increasingly weaker in constitution and lost their spirit.
('25', 337, 1, 9, 782752) Will a Rabari 4 woman of Kathiawar, six foot tall, wear a bhatigar 5 sari of Japanese muslin if somebody gave her one?
('25', 337, 1, 10, 782871) And will she go out grazing her cattle dressed in such a sari?
('25', 337, 1, 11, 782934) We have taken a wrong path altogether.
('25', 337, 1, 12, 782973) Giving up cultivation of inward beauty, we fell under the spell of outward adornment and lost the country, forsook our traditional ways, sacrificed our health and, as for the atman, sent it to sleep.
('25', 337, 1, 13, 783173) Will the young men of Kathiawar give up talking and start working?
('25', 337, 1, 14, 783240) Will the women of Kathiawar follow the example of Shrimati Vasantidevi and go round selling khadi?
('25', 337, 1, 15, 783339) Will the people of Kathiawar hear our Dhed 6 and Bhangi 77 brothers crying for justice?
('25', 337, 1, 16, 783427) People who consider themselves polluted by their touch will never go to jail, they are not fit to do so.

('25', 338, 2, 3, 783887) December 25, 1921
('25', 338, 3, 4, 783905) The All India Congress Committee met this morning and was engaged the whole day in a prolonged discussion of the main resolution moved by Mr. Gandhi regarding organization of volunteers?
('25', 338, 3, 5, 784092) extension of civil disobedience, investing Gandhi or his successors with the full authority of the All India Congress Committee to act in its name in case of emergency.
('25', 338, 4, 6, 784261) Before the debates the President Hakim Ajmal Khan was flooded with amendments from all sides.
('25', 338, 4, 7, 784355) Hasrat Mohani 1, the President elect of the All India Muslim League, persistently led the opposition demanding the deletion of those phrases in the resolution which excluded the possibility of resort to violence, or even the thought of it, so long as the pledge was in force.
('25', 338, 4, 8, 784631) on the ground that his religion allowed him to take to violence in case non violence failed.
('25', 338, 5, 9, 784724) The debate revealed difference of opinion on this point among Mahommedan members themselves.
('25', 338, 5, 10, 784817) Some expressed the opinion that the adoption of Maulana Hasarat’s amendments would be a change in the Congress Creed itself.
('25', 338, 6, 11, 784942) In moving his resolution in the morning Mr. Gandhi made a long speech announcing that he had agreed to slight additions or alterations in his original resolution as the result of a conference last evening with the leaders of the Maharashtra party who, whilst loyally accepting the programme of non cooperation in all its details, had made no secret of their dissatisfaction with some of its items.
('25', 338, 6, 12, 785340) He assured all that, while there was little of surrender of the main principle in those modifications, they could be sure of the hearty, willing and believing co operation of the party which was unrivalled in its strength and sacrifice and which had traditions behind it of great services and filled India with an indomitable spirit of democracy.
('25', 338, 6, 13, 785687) The great leader of that party, who became an All India leader and who found a lodgment in the hearts of millions of his countrymen, died developing that spirit of democracy.
('25', 338, 7, 14, 785862) Proceeding, Mr. Gandhi pointed out that this party had desired the introduction into the resolution of a provision offering shelter against mischievous insult to those lawyers, teachers and others who, though quite as patriotic and honest as any non co operator pretended to be, had not found their way to make sacrifices in the particular form demanded by the Congress.
('25', 338, 7, 15, 786233) But while he objected to the insertion of such provision, as it would lead to dangerous interpretation, he emphatically declared that they must fully respect all such people who, though considered weak from the non co operator’s standpoint, were patriots every inch of them.
('25', 338, 7, 16, 786508) He would not criticize lawyers in a carping spirit because it was the lawyers who had rendered

('25', 339, 0, 1, 786642) 340 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('25', 339, 1, 2, 786684) signal services to the country when everyone else was shivering with fear.
('25', 339, 2, 3, 786759) He continued: I ask everyone of you to go away with the spirit of goodwill towards Moderates, lawyers, schoolmasters, Government servants and C.I.D.s 1. The Moderates are our countrymen, they are rallying round us today and when they find that the liberty of the country is really at stake, they are giving full expression to their views.
('25', 339, 2, 4, 787098) It does one’s soul good to read the leading articles in The Leader and the Bengalee and, after all, are we going to wash away the services of Sir Surendranath Banerjee 2?
('25', 339, 2, 5, 787269) I cannot possibly help shedding a tear when anything is said disparagingly of him.

('25', 339, 6, 12, 788104) So it is a fight to the finish with the Government in our own special manner.
('25', 339, 6, 13, 788182) My belief in non violence is so great that, if the country can only assimilate the mental attitude needed for the practice of real non veiolence we can promise swaraj in form and substance even before the end of this month.

('25', 340, 7, 11, 789039) 167. SPEECHES AT SUBJECTS COMMITTEE MEETING, AHMEDABAD
('25', 340, 8, 12, 789094) December 27, 1921
('25', 340, 9, 13, 789112) After four hours’ sitting this morning, the All India Congress Committee came to definite decisions on the most momentous issued.
('25', 340, 9, 14, 789242) It not only adopted by a very overwhelming majority Mr. Gandhi’s central resolution, 3 but also defeated a formidable opposition of 52 members led by Hasrat Mohani who fought for a change in the Congress Creed in order to definitely lay down the attainment of swaraj without the British Empire as the object of the Congress .
('25', 340, 10, 15, 789568) In opening the meeting, the President, Hakim Ajmal Khan, announced that he had received notices of amendments to Mr. Gandhi’s resolution, which in their real meaning came into conflict with the Congress Creed itself.
('25', 340, 10, 16, 789785) He, therefore, ruled them out of order, but suggested that if the movers so desired they could bring them forward as substantive propositions.
('25', 340, 11, 17, 789928) As the position looked somewhat confused, Mr. Gandhi made a short speech in course of which he analysed the contending issues and placed them clearly before the House.
('25', 340, 11, 18, 790096) He said that if Hasrat Mohani and others desired, they could move separate resolutions urging change in the Congress Creed, but, as his resolution was then
('25', 340, 12, 19, 790252) 1 The year has been inferred from Gandhiji’s being in Ahmedabad on December 2 Daughter of Sarojini Naidu 3 Vide”Speech at Congress Session, Ahmedabad I”, 28 12 1921.
('25', 341, 0, 1, 790418) 342 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('25', 341, 1, 2, 790460) before the House, he wanted all to remember that those who thought like Hasrat Mohani should not vote for his (Gandhi’s) resolution, because the very basis of his motion was that the present Creed must remain intact and that non violence alone should be the weapon to fight their battle to the end The Hasrat Mohani party, on the other hand, he said, stood for complete independence and fighting the battle by all possible means.
('25', 341, 1, 3, 790890) The issue was plain and he desired that those who did not want a change in the existing Creed should vote at least for the spirit underlying his resolution, remembering that, if later on they voted for the resolution of Hasrat Mohani, they would nullify Mr. Gandhi’s resolution.
('25', 341, 2, 4, 791169) The speech over, Mr. Gandhi’s resolution was put to vote and carried amidst acclamation, only 10 voting against.
('25', 341, 3, 5, 791282) Hasrat Mohani then moved his first amendment to the Creed, proposing the attainment of swaraj by all possible and proper means in place of peaceful and legitimate means.
('25', 341, 4, 6, 791452) This amendment did not get any appreciable support and the mover thereupon withdrew it.
('25', 341, 5, 7, 791540) His next amendment declaring swaraj without the British Empire proved to be the main bone of contention.
('25', 341, 6, 8, 791645) He was supported by a dozen members .
('25', 341, 7, 9, 791683) An equal number of speakers opposed the amendment.
('25', 341, 8, 10, 791734) Mr. Gandhi then made a short speech.
('25', 341, 8, 11, 791771) He said he wanted to make it clear that today his hope of getting redress of Punjab and Khilafat through the British Government was ever so much greater than it was at any time 15 months ago.
('25', 341, 8, 12, 791963) Within the Congress Creed there was still a chance for two parties who wanted swaraj within or without the British Empire, but there could be no room for those who wanted to resort to violence, because the moment anyone joined the Congress he must sign a pledge of non violence in terms of the Creed.
('25', 341, 8, 13, 792264) Mr. Gandhi emphasized that the attainment of swaraj would by itself break imperialism.
('25', 341, 8, 14, 792351) India even then would be certainly free.
('25', 341, 8, 15, 792392) Concluding, he warned all against estranging from them the Moderates and others who were sympathizing with them, by taking steps which make the present easy task one of great difficult tasks.
('25', 341, 9, 16, 792584) Before the amendment of Mohani was put to vote all the visitors were asked to leave .
('25', 341, 9, 17, 792670) it was rejected by a great majority, only 52 voting for it .

('25', 344, 1, 2, 797446) 169. SPEECH AT CONGRESS SESSION, AHMEDABAD—I

('25', 344, 3, 4, 797509) As Mahatma Gandhi got down the platform to reach the rostrum in his usual

('25', 344, 6, 7, 797719) MR.PRESIDENT, BROTHERS AND SISTERS,
('25', 344, 7, 8, 797755) Hakimji Saheb 1 has allowed me 30 minutes and I hope to be able to keep within the limit prescribed.

('25', 344, 7, 10, 797983) (Laughter.)

('25', 344, 9, 13, 798110) He then read out the resolution in English rendering it in Hindi, paragraph by
('25', 344, 10, 14, 798189) paragraph, as he proceeded: Whereas, since the holding of the last National Congress, the people of India have found from actual experience that, by reason of the adoption of non violent non co operation, the country has made great advance in fearlessness, self sacrifice and self respect, and whereas the movement has greatly damaged the prestige of the Government, and whereas the country on the whole is rapidly progressing towards swaraj, this Congress confirms the resolution adopted at the special session of the Congress at Calcutta and reaffirmed at Nagpur, and places on record the fixed determination of the Congress to continue the programme of non violent non co operation with greater vigour than hitherto, in such manner as each province may determine, till the Punjab and the Khilafat wrongs are redressed and swaraj is established, and the control of the Government of India passes into the hands of the people from that of an irresponsible corporation.
('25', 344, 11, 15, 799159) And whereas by reason of the threat uttered by His Excellency the Viceroy in his recent speeches and the

('25', 345, 1, 2, 799325) consequent repression started by the Government of India in the various provinces by way of disbandment of Volunteer Corps and forcible prohibition of public and even committee meetings in an illegal and high handed manner and by the arrest of many Congress workers in several provinces, and whereas this repression is manifestly intended to stifle all Congress and Khilafat activities and deprive the public of their assistance, this Congress resolves that all activities of the Congress be suspended as far as necessary and appeals to all, quietly and without any demonstration, to offer themselves for arrest by belonging to thevolunteer organizations to be formed throughout the country in terms of the resolution of the Working Committee arrived at in Bombay on the 23rd day of November last, provided that no one shall be accepted as volunteer who does not sign the following pledge:

('25', 346, 2, 7, 802366) This Congress is further of opinion that civil disobedience is the only civilized and effective substitute for an armed rebellion, whenever every other remedy for preventing arbitrary, tyrannical and emasculating use of authority by individuals or corporations has been tried, and, therefore, advises all Congress workers and others, who believe in peaceful methods and are convinced that there is no remedy save some kind of sacrifice to dislodge the existing Government from its position of perfect irresponsibility to the people of India, to organize individual civil disobedience and mass civil disobedience, when the mass of people have been sufficiently trained in the methods of non violence and otherwise, in terms of the resolution thereon of the last meeting of the All India Congress Committee held at Delhi.
('25', 346, 3, 8, 803186) This Congress is of opinion that in order to concentrate attention upon civil disobedience, whether mass or individual, whether of an offensive or defensive character, under proper safeguards and under instructions to be issued from time to time by the Working Committee or the Provincial Congress Commi ttee concerned, all other Congress activities should be suspended whenever and wherever and to the extent to which it may be

('25', 347, 2, 4, 803907) In view of the impending arrests of a large number of Congress workers, this Congress, whilst requiring the ordinary machinery to remain intact and to be utilized in the ordinary manner whenever feasible, hereby appoints until further instructions Mahatma Gandhi as the sole executive authority of the Congress and invests him with the full powers of the All India Congress Committee including the power to convene a special session of the Congress or of the All India Congress Committee or the Working Committee, such powers to be exercised between any two sessions of the All India Congress Committee and also with the power to appoint a successor in emergency.
('25', 347, 2, 5, 804571) This Congress hereby confers upon the said successor and all subsequent successors appointed in turn by their predecessors all his aforesaid powers.
('25', 347, 3, 6, 804720) Provided that nothing in this resolution shall be deemed to authorize Mahatma Gandhi or any of the aforesaid successors to conclude any terms of peace with the Government of India or the British Government without the previous sanction of the All India Congress Committee, to be finally ratified by the Congress specially convened for the purpose, and provided also that the present Creed of the Congress shall in no case be altered by Mahatma Gandhi or his successors, except with the leave of the Congress first obtained.

('25', 348, 1, 5, 806125) If at the end of fifteen months, incessant activity, you, the delegates assembled in this Congress, do not know your own minds I am positive that I cannot possibly carry conviction to you even in a two hours’ speech; and what is more, if I could carry conviction to you today because of my speech, 1 am afraid I would lose all faith in my countrymen because it would demonstrate their incapacity to observe things and events; it would demonstrate their incapacity to think coherently; because I submit, there is absolutely nothing new in this resolution that we have not been doing all this time, that we have not been thinking all this time.
('25', 348, 1, 6, 806768) There is absolutely nothing new in this resolution which is at all startling.
('25', 348, 1, 7, 806846) Those of you who have followed the proceedings from month to month of the Working Committee, of the All India Congress Committee every three months, and have studied their resolutions, can but come to one conclusion, that this resolution is absolutely the natural result of the national activities during the past fifteen months; and if you have at all followed the course, the downward course, that the repressive policy of the Government has been taking, you can only come to the conclusion that the Subjects Committee has rightly come to this resolution; and that the only answer that a self respecting nation can return to the Viceregal pronouncements and to the repression that is overtaking this land, is the course mapped out in this resolution.

('25', 348, 3, 12, 808165) This resolution, whilst it shows the indomitable courage and the determination of the nation to vindicate its rights and to be able to stare the world in the face, also says in all humility to the Government: “No matter what you do, no matter how you repress us, we shall one day wring reluctant repentance from you; and we ask you to think

('25', 349, 1, 2, 808548) betimes, and take care what you are doing and see that you do not make 300 millions of India your eternal enemies.”

('25', 349, 2, 4, 808763) If the Moderate friends wish to rally round the standard of the Khilafat, and round the standard of the liberties of the Punjab and, therefore, of India, then this resolution leaves the door wide open for them too.
('25', 349, 2, 5, 808978) If this Government is sincerely anxious to do justice, if Lord Reading has really come to India to do justice and nothing less—and we want nothing more— then I inform him from this platform, with God as my witness, with all the earnestness that I can command, that he has got an open door in this resolution if he means well, but the door is closed in his face if he means ill, no matter how many people go to their graves, no matter what wild career this repression is to go through.

('25', 353, 2, 3, 817210) December 28, 1921
('25', 353, 3, 4, 817228) The following is the revised speech delivered in opposition to Maulana Hasrat Mohani’s proposition on independence:
('25', 353, 4, 5, 817344) FRIENDS, I have said only a few words (in Hindi) in connection with the proposition of Mr. Hasrat Mohani.
('25', 353, 4, 6, 817450) All I want to say to you in English is that the levity with which that proposition has been taken by some of you has grieved me.
('25', 353, 4, 7, 817579) It has grieved me because it shows a lack of responsibility.
('25', 353, 4, 8, 817640) As responsible men and women we should go back to the days of Nagpur and Calcutta and we should remember what we did only an hour ago.
('25', 353, 4, 9, 817775) An hour ago we passed a resolution which actually contemplates a final settlement of the Khilafat and the Punjab wrongs and transference of the power from the hands of the bureaucracy into the hands of the people by certain definite means.
('25', 353, 4, 10, 818015) Are you going to rub the whole of that position from your mind by raising a false issue and by throwing a bombshell in the midst of the Indian atmosphere?
('25', 353, 4, 11, 818170) I hope that those of you who have voted for the previous resolution will think fifty times before taking up this resolution and voting for it.
('25', 353, 4, 12, 818313) We shall be charged by the thinking portion of the world that we do not know really where we are.
('25', 353, 4, 13, 818411) Let us understand, too, our limitations.
('25', 353, 4, 14, 818452) Let Hindus and Mussulmans have absolute, indissoluble unity.
('25', 353, 4, 15, 818513) Who is here who can say today with confidence, “Yes, Hindu Muslim unity has become an indissoluble factor of Indian nationalism?” Who is here who can tell me that the Parsis and the Sikhs and the Christians and the Jews and the untouchables about whom you heard this afternoon—who will tell me that those very people will not rise against any such idea?
('25', 353, 4, 16, 818867) Think, therefore, fifty times before you take a step which will redound not to your credit, not to your advantage, but which may cause you irreparable injury.
('25', 353, 4, 17, 819026) Let us first of all gather up our strength; let us first of all sound our own depths.
('25', 353, 4, 18, 819112) Let us not go into waters whose depths we do not know, and this proposition of Mr. Hasrat Mohani lands you into depths unfathomable.
('25', 353, 4, 19, 819245) I ask you in all confidence to reject that proposition, if you believe in the proposition that you passed only an hour ago.
('25', 353, 4, 20, 819369) The proposition now before you rubs off the whole of the effect of the proposition that you passed only a moment ago.
('25', 354, 0, 1, 819487) VOL. 25: 27 OCTOBER, 1921 22 JANUARY, 1922 355
('25', 354, 1, 2, 819534) creeds such simple things like clothes which a man can change at will?
('25', 354, 1, 3, 819605) For creeds people die and for creeds people live from age to age.
('25', 354, 1, 4, 819671) Are you going to change the Creed which with all deliberation, and after great debate in Nagpur, you accepted?
('25', 354, 1, 5, 819782) There was no limitation of one year when you accepted that Creed.

('25', 354, 3, 9, 820223) 173. A MODEL PRISONER
('25', 354, 4, 10, 820245) Should non co operators shout Vande Mataram 1 inside jails against jail discipline which may excite ordinary prisoners to violence, should non co operators go on hunger strike for the improvement of food or other conveniences, should they strike work inside jails on hartal days and other days?
('25', 354, 4, 11, 820540) Are non co operators entitled to break rules of jail discipline unless they affect their conscience?
('25', 354, 4, 12, 820641) Such is the text of a telegram I received from a non co operator friend in Calcutta.
('25', 354, 4, 13, 820726) From another part of India when a friend, again a non co operator heard of the indiscipline of non co operator prisoners, he asked me to write on the necessity of observing jail discipline As against this I know prisoners who arc scrupulously observing in a becoming spirit all the discipline imposed upon them.
('25', 354, 4, 14, 821038) It is necessary, when thousands are going to jail, to understand exactly the position a non co operator prisoner can take up consistently with his pledge of non violence.
('25', 354, 4, 15, 821209) Non co operation, when its limitations are not recognized, becomes a licence instead of being a duty and, therefore, becomes a crime.
('25', 354, 4, 16, 821343) The dividing line between right and wrong is often so thin as to become indistinguishable.
('25', 354, 4, 17, 821434) But it is a line that is breakable and unmistakable.
('25', 354, 4, 18, 821487) What is then the difference between those who find themselves in jails for being in the right and those who are there for being in the wrong?
('25', 354, 4, 19, 821629) Both wear often the same dress, eat the same food and are subject outwardly to the same discipline.
('25', 354, 4, 20, 821729) But whilst the latter submit to discipline most unwillingly and would commit a breach of it secretly, and even openly if they could, the former will Willingly and to the
('25', 354, 5, 21, 821899) 1 The refrain of a patriotic song composed by Bankim Chandra Chatterjee
('25', 355, 0, 1, 821971) 356 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('25', 355, 1, 2, 822013) best of their ability conform to the jail discipline and prove worthier and more serviceable to their cause than when they are outside.
('25', 355, 1, 3, 822149) We have observed that the most distinguished among the prisoners are of greater service inside the jails than outside.
('25', 355, 1, 4, 822268) The coefficient of service is raised to the extent of the strictness with which jail discipline is observed.
('25', 355, 1, 5, 822377) Let it be remembered that we are not seeking to destroy jails as such.
('25', 355, 1, 6, 822448) I fear that we shall have to maintain jails even under swaraj.
('25', 355, 1, 7, 822511) It will go hard with us, if we let the real criminals understand that they will be set free or be very much better treated when swaraj is established.
('25', 355, 1, 8, 822662) Even in reformatories by which I would like to replace every jail under swaraj, discipline will be exacted.
('25', 355, 1, 9, 822770) Therefore, we really retard the advent of swaraj if we encourage indiscipline.
('25', 355, 1, 10, 822849) Indeed the Swift programme of swaraj has been conceived on the supposition that we being a cultured people are capable of evolving high discipline within a short time.
('25', 355, 1, 11, 823017) Indeed whilst on the one hand civil disobedience authorizes disobedience of unjust laws or unmoral laws of a state which one seeks to overthrow, it requires meek and willing submission to the penalty of disobedience and, therefore, cheerful acceptance of the jail discipline and its attendant hardships.
('25', 355, 1, 12, 823321) It is now, therefore, clear that a civil resister’s resistance ceases and his obedience is resumed as soon as he is under confinement.
('25', 355, 1, 13, 823456) In confinement he claims no Privileges because of the civility of his disobedience.
('25', 355, 1, 14, 823540) Inside the jail by his exemplary conduct he reforms even the criminals surrounding him, he softens the hearts of jailors and others in authority.
('25', 355, 1, 15, 823686) Such meek behaviour springing from strength and knowledge ultimately dissolves the tyranny of the tyrant.
('25', 355, 1, 16, 823792) It is for this reason that I claim that voluntary suffering is the quickest and the best remedy for the removal of abuses and injustices.
('25', 355, 1, 17, 823930) It is now manifest that shouts of Bande Mataram or any other in breach of jail discipline are unlawful for a non co operator to indulge in.
('25', 355, 1, 18, 824070) It is equally unlawful for him to commit a stealthy breach of jail regulations.
('25', 355, 1, 19, 824150) A non co operator will do nothing to demoralize his fellow prisoners.
('25', 355, 1, 20, 824220) The only occasion when he can openly disobey jail regulations or hunger strike is when an attempt is made to humiliate him or when the warders themselves break, as they often do, the rules for the comfort of prisoners, or when food that is unfit for human consumption is issued, as it often is.
('25', 355, 1, 21, 824515) A case for civil disobedience also arises when there is interference with any obligatory religious practice.

('25', 356, 4, 5, 824763) MAHATMAJI: What I suggest is that you ask me what you like.
('25', 356, 5, 6, 824823) A DELEGATE: The question is difficult.
('25', 356, 5, 7, 824862) We like to know what would be the procedure of our work.
('25', 356, 6, 8, 824919) MAHATMAJI: The resolutions that we have passed may be summed up really in this manner that we want to answer the repression of the Government expressed in the two notifications about the disbandment of volunteers and the prohibition of public meetings.
('25', 356, 6, 9, 825172) Therefore we meet them by simply enrolling all men and women as volunteers and we meet the notification prohibiting public meetings by holding public meetings and committee meetings whenever necessary and even when unnecessary.
('25', 356, 6, 10, 825400) But there are two ways; one is by goading the Government to take action against us by holding public meetings even when it is unnecessary.
('25', 356, 6, 11, 825539) But my advice is: Do not do that.
('25', 356, 6, 12, 825573) That will become offensive, not in the offensive sense of the term, but as the opposite of defensive.
('25', 356, 6, 13, 825675) We need not and we ought not to take the offensive till we have exhausted the defensive.
('25', 356, 6, 14, 825764) Therefore, so long as you can go on with enrolment of volunteers and taking work from them in the ordinary course, and so long as you can go on with your public meetings that may be required for your purpose—for your propaganda— for instructing the people —you should go on ceaselessly.
('25', 356, 6, 15, 826051) That by itself is bound to result in risks.
('25', 356, 6, 16, 826095) Do not worry so long as you are doing your duty.
('25', 356, 6, 17, 826144) Do not worry as to what is happening to prisoners.
('25', 356, 6, 18, 826195) There are ways.
('25', 356, 6, 19, 826211) Naturally one way of releasing prisoners is to go to jail; but our goal is not the release of prisoners, our goal is, the attainment of swaraj and getting the key of the jail in our possession.
('25', 356, 6, 20, 826405) That is our goal.
('25', 356, 6, 21, 826423) Therefore, if you can reach that goal by doing all the national work that you have been doing but in an honest spirit, ceaselessly, without waiting for a single minute, then I tell you that it is more and more blessed to be in jail than to be outside—that is from a selfish standpoint.
('25', 356, 6, 22, 826709) I assume that you are all true and honest men, and I am sure that you are so; and if you are not—all of you—I want you to be so.

('25', 366, 1, 10, 849169) Picketing of shops selling foreign cloth is unnecessary.
('25', 366, 1, 11, 849226) But picketing of liquor shops should continue.
('25', 366, 1, 12, 849273) National schools should be turned into hand spinning and hand weaving factories.
('25', 366, 1, 13, 849354) Boys below eighteen years of age should work in them and women should supervise them.
('25', 366, 1, 14, 849440) Students over eighteen years of age and teachers who refuse to be volunteers should be expelled from schools The Hindi Swarajya published from Allahabad should be handwritten.
('25', 366, 1, 15, 849616) Those whose properties are attached should renounce them with pleasure, for it is a sin even to own property in such a tyrannical regime.
('25', 366, 1, 16, 849754) The properties will be given back to the owners as soon as swaraj is attained.

('25', 372, 1, 2, 857329) 184. INTERVIEW TO “SWARAJYA” 1
('25', 372, 2, 3, 857360) [Before January 5, 1922]
('25', 372, 3, 4, 857385) The special correspondent of the Swarajya writes from Ahmedabad:
('25', 372, 4, 5, 857450) I interviewed Mahatmaji on the present situation, regarding the proposed truce 2.
('25', 372, 5, 6, 857532) QUESTION: What is the opinion of Lala Lajpat Rai and Motilal Nehru?
('25', 372, 6, 7, 857600) ANSWER: As regards Motilalji, his opinion is contained in the latest issue of Young India 3. Lalaji has asked me not to worry about those who are in jail.
('25', 372, 7, 8, 857755) Suppose volunteer organizations arc not declared unlawful in other provinces and public meetings are not prohibited, then what should volunteers and Congress workers do, to get into jails?
('25', 372, 7, 9, 857944) In their case civil disobedience can only be of an offensive nature.
('25', 372, 7, 10, 858013) For this they should wait till I have launched upon it.
('25', 372, 7, 11, 858069) Meanwhile, they must go on organizing the volunteers, must spin at least four hours a day, and produce at least one tola per hour, of even, twisted yarn of about 10 or 12 counts.
('25', 372, 8, 12, 858248) Should the volunteers picket foreign cloth shops and liquor shops?
('25', 372, 8, 13, 858315) They may be picketed by people who understand their responsibility, and do it peacefully.
('25', 372, 9, 14, 858405) How long do you expect the struggle to continue in the new year?
('25', 372, 9, 15, 858470) I don’t know.
('25', 372, 9, 16, 858484) In the present state, it may not continue for more than two months.
('25', 372, 9, 17, 858552) We must be prepared for indiscriminate flogging and shooting by the Government from all parts of India.
('25', 372, 9, 18, 858656) We must not flinch even then.
('25', 372, 9, 19, 858686) The present struggle is not so much to right the Punjab and Khilafat wrongs, much less for swaraj.
('25', 372, 9, 20, 858785) We are now fighting for the elementary rights of free speech and freedom to form associations, and on this question we expect Moderates and others to be with us.
('25', 372, 9, 21, 858947) When this intermediate skirmish will be finished, our way will be clear.
('25', 372, 10, 22, 859020) Mahatmaji added that any swaraj scheme must include the control of the military and the police.
('25', 372, 11, 23, 859116) The Bombay Chronicle, 5 1 1922
('25', 372, 12, 24, 859147) 1 Reproduced by the source from the Swarajya
('25', 372, 13, 25, 859192) 2 Being negotiated by Malaviya
('25', 372, 14, 26, 859223) 3 Dated 29 12 1921, under the caption “Another Gaol Letter” Motilal had written: “.
('25', 372, 14, 27, 859307) ‘No reduction in the triple demand,’ should be the only basis of any negotiations .
('25', 373, 0, 1, 859391) 374 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('25', 373, 1, 2, 859433) 185. NOTES
('25', 373, 2, 3, 859444) JAIL TREATMENT
('25', 373, 3, 4, 859459) Starvation, or its alternative, canine food, no covering much less any worth the name to protect against the severe Delhi winter, microbe infected, lice laden, blood stained tatters, the worn off relics of common felons, and finally, the awful ghastly climax, preferential treatment or release, constantly suggested and enforced in favour of the very rare civil resister, whose frailty succumbs to the temptation.
('25', 373, 3, 5, 859873) Such is the report sent by Lala Shankar Lal of Delhi as he was being taken from the Delhi Jail to Mianwali.
('25', 373, 3, 6, 859981) The friend that has sent me the report says:
('25', 373, 4, 7, 860026) We have heard of the closed Moplah death wagon, but this Delhi Jail wherein some of the best and noblest of our workers have been clapped, has by ingenious cunning been converted for non co operators into an open area where death and the devil hold their court.
('25', 373, 4, 8, 860288) Emotion chokes me as I write.
('25', 373, 4, 9, 860318) Is it that the hand which is silencing many a Shankar Lal in our beautiful and lovable country is stifling also my feeble voice?
('25', 373, 4, 10, 860447) Woeful tales of non co operators being flogged till the hand that flogs them tires of the process, of civil resisters being stripped of all vestige of human covering and subjected to a slow and gradual death from toxicity and infection, have filled my ears.
('25', 373, 4, 11, 860705) The writer is a highly cultured sensitive young man.
('25', 373, 4, 12, 860758) I have removed some of the descriptive passages from the letter.
('25', 373, 4, 13, 860823) Unused to suffering he has been deeply touched by the version of the ill treatment given in the Delhi Jail to non co operators.
('25', 373, 4, 14, 860951) But the substance of the charge is true.
('25', 373, 4, 15, 860992) For it is corroborated from many sources unconnected with one another.
('25', 373, 4, 16, 861063) There seems to be no doubt that the Government having failed to bend the non co operators and to extort an apology from them by mere confinement, the order has gone round for inflicting physical hardships on civil resisters.
('25', 373, 4, 17, 861288) There does come a time when with all the will in the world the flesh refuses to suffer any further and makes the spirit its unwilling slave.
('25', 373, 4, 18, 861429) The administrators are exploiting their knowledge of this to humble the proud spirit of civil resisters.
('25', 373, 4, 19, 861534) And I would not be surprised if some of them not being able to stand the inhuman treatment that is evidently being systematized apologize in order to escape unbearable torture of the flesh.
('25', 373, 4, 20, 861724) But if the spirit has at times been found weak enough to yield to the flesh after a certain point, it has also been found superior to the
('25', 374, 0, 1, 861862) VOL. 25: 27 OCTOBER, 1921 22 JANUARY, 1922 375
('25', 374, 1, 2, 861909) most excruciating tortures.
('25', 374, 1, 3, 861937) Given sufficient previous mental preparation, the very extreme of suffering becomes an anaesthetic that deadens pain; where the spirit is willing, the exultation induced by the willingness counteracts the sensation of pain.
('25', 374, 1, 4, 862161) The pleasure of serving one’s country or religion more than balances the pain involved in it.
('25', 374, 1, 5, 862255) It is then the duty of a civil resister to bear all torture of the flesh but it is equally his duty to resist insanitation or humiliation.
('25', 374, 1, 6, 862394) He will cheerfully take the lash.
('25', 374, 1, 7, 862428) He must not crawl.
('25', 374, 1, 8, 862447) He will cheerfully go bare bodied and shiver to death.
('25', 374, 1, 9, 862502) He must resolutely reject germ laden filthy blankets or shirts.
('25', 374, 1, 10, 862566) He may go without food, but he must refuse to take bread or dal laden with pebbles.
('25', 374, 1, 11, 862650) He may do without his bath but he must refuse to bathe in foul water.
('25', 374, 1, 12, 862720) Where submission is unmanly resistance becomes a duty.
('25', 374, 1, 13, 862775) Well have the civil resisters got the privilege of voluntary suffering.
('25', 374, 1, 14, 862847) It is the noblest service.
('25', 374, 1, 15, 862874) They are purifying the jails.
('25', 374, 1, 16, 862904) Even felons are entitled to human treatment.
('25', 374, 1, 17, 862949) Let the authorities give the Plainest food and clothing but both must be clean and sufficient.
('25', 374, 2, 18, 863044) It is no pleasure to me to publish accounts of inhuman treatment no matter where and by whom meted out.
('25', 374, 2, 19, 863148) I do not want to believe that human beings can be so brutal as many stories related about them would prove them to be.
('25', 374, 2, 20, 863267) I am most anxious that this fight is fought in a sportsmanlike spirit.
('25', 374, 2, 21, 863338) It cuts my human flesh to the quick to find human beings not playing the game.
('25', 374, 3, 22, 863417) But if it is to be a dirty game on the other side, so be it.
('25', 374, 3, 23, 863478) Non co operators have made no stipulation, they have no choice but to take things as they come to them and cut their way through every difficulty.
('25', 374, 3, 24, 863625) Is it not reported of the Japanese that when they came to a ditch their army could not cross, they filled it with human corpses?
('25', 374, 3, 25, 863754) Shall we do less because we are vowed not to kill but only to be killed?
('25', 374, 3, 26, 863827) Our pledge exacts from us more than from the Japanese soldier.
('25', 374, 3, 27, 863890) For we must go through the fire without the drum beat of war.
('25', 374, 4, 28, 863952) The charge brought by my correspondent is serious.
('25', 374, 4, 29, 864003) Let me adduce corroborative evidence.
('25', 374, 4, 30, 864041) Here is a graphic and detailed description of the treatment of Mahadev Desai, the editor of the Independent.
('25', 374, 4, 31, 864150) Readers of Young India know his connection with this journal.
('25', 374, 4, 32, 864212) 1 He is one of the soberest of workers.
('25', 374, 4, 33, 864252) He has a most sensitive frame.
('25', 374, 4, 34, 864283) A friend visited him with Mrs. Desai.
('25', 374, 4, 35, 864321) The writer says:
('25', 374, 5, 36, 864338) 1Mahadev Desai was the publisher of Young India.
('25', 375, 0, 1, 864387) 376 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('25', 375, 1, 2, 864429) We are preparing for strong repression.
('25', 375, 1, 3, 864469) I have wired you regarding Mahadevbhai’s imprisonment.
('25', 375, 1, 4, 864524) He had received a summons to attend court for trial.
('25', 375, 1, 5, 864577) He was quite joyful when he went to jail.
('25', 375, 1, 6, 864619) We went yesterday to see him but the jailer would not let us.
('25', 375, 1, 7, 864681) I took food, clothing and books.
('25', 375, 1, 8, 864714) But the jailer would not take them.
('25', 375, 1, 9, 864750) This morning we were able to meet him.
('25', 375, 1, 10, 864789) He has been put with the ordinary criminals and is being subjected to all the jail regulations.
('25', 375, 1, 11, 864885) He was dressed in jail clothes.
('25', 375, 1, 12, 864917) He had a black shirt with sleeves reaching to the elbow and half pants.
('25', 375, 1, 13, 864989) The clothes were dirty, stinking and lousy.
('25', 375, 1, 14, 865033) He had two blankets which could not have been washed for months and which must have been and were full of lice.
('25', 375, 1, 15, 865145) He had a rusty iron bowl for water, so rusty as to make the water unfit in a few minutes for drink.
('25', 375, 1, 16, 865245) Therefore, that water could not be drunk during night.
('25', 375, 1, 17, 865300) It would be found perfectly yellow in the morning There is a dirty tank from which drinking water is taken and which is used for bathing too.
('25', 375, 1, 18, 865442) I do not know whether buckets are supplied.
('25', 375, 1, 19, 865486) A loin cloth is supplied for bathing.
('25', 375, 1, 20, 865524) But no towel is allowed for drying.
('25', 375, 1, 21, 865560) After the body is dried in the sun the same dirty clothes have to be worn again.
('25', 375, 1, 22, 865641) It is impossible in the cold climate of this place for the weak body of Mahadevbhai to wash these clothes and to remain bare bodied whilst these clothes are drying.
('25', 375, 1, 23, 865806) He has only jail food.
('25', 375, 1, 24, 865829) He took nothing last night.
('25', 375, 1, 25, 865857) He had something like gruel this morning.
('25', 375, 1, 26, 865899) It contained pebbles and other dirt.
('25', 375, 1, 27, 865936) For natural purposes the prisoners have to go out.
('25', 375, 1, 28, 865987) And they use the drinking pot to carry their water in.
('25', 375, 1, 29, 866042) For night use an uncovered pot is supplied.
('25', 375, 1, 30, 866086) The only thing not yet done is to put irons on.
('25', 375, 1, 31, 866134) I hear from another quarter that special instructions have been issued to subject him to ill treatment for the reason that Mahadev Desai’s was a calculated defiance of authority.
('25', 375, 1, 32, 866313) That the Independent could be issued independently of printing and the consequent declaration proved too much for the authorities.
('25', 375, 1, 33, 866444) Well, I have no doubt that Mahadev Desai will prove his editorial skill inside the prison walls by retaining his independence in the face of physical tortures.

('25', 377, 2, 8, 869948) THE NEW “INDEPENDENT”
('25', 377, 3, 9, 869970) The written edition of the Independent commenced by Mr. Mahadev Desai when the security of Rs. 2,000 was forfeited continues its difficult career.
('25', 377, 3, 10, 870117) It has been regularly published in its new form.
('25', 377, 3, 11, 870166) Arrangements have been made for a succession of editors should the present one be arrested.

('25', 377, 3, 18, 870853) I do hope that the Allahabad public will watch the experiment with sympathy and support the appeal made by its youthful editor.
('25', 377, 3, 19, 870981) The enterprise is fraught with great possibilities.
('25', 377, 3, 20, 871033) The Government may not stop at anything and arrest every one of the editors.

('25', 377, 3, 22, 871305) Before we feel and become free we must be able to dispense with all its favours.

('25', 377, 3, 25, 871606) All it cannot curb without our consent is the spirit within us.
('25', 377, 3, 26, 871670) And in order that India’s spirit may be and remain free, we must be prepared to face and conquer every obstacle the Government may place in our way.
('25', 377, 3, 27, 871819) Indeed, if the editor can secure the services of good copyists, he will be able to make a thousand copies without difficulty.
('25', 377, 3, 28, 871945) I would advise him to be still more sparing of words.
('25', 377, 3, 29, 871999) He will find that by a
('25', 377, 4, 30, 872022) 1 C.S. Ranga Iyer

('25', 378, 1, 2, 872087) little practice he will be able to say all that he has to say in two sides of a foolscap sheet.
('25', 378, 1, 3, 872183) I promise that the compressed newspaper will be far more readable than the long drawn out agony that the printed sheets inflict on the public from day to day.
('25', 378, 1, 4, 872342) When all the padding, the verbiage, the flaring headlines and advertisements are removed from the average daily, one will find that the remainder can be easily reduced to a foolscap sheet.
('25', 378, 1, 5, 872531) Let the editor try to give the news and the thoughts the others do not give and he will find that his copy will be multiplied a thousandfold without effort.
('25', 378, 1, 6, 872688) At the same time let him remember that a written daily requires a different type of organization.
('25', 378, 1, 7, 872786) Its agents are more copyists than distributors.
('25', 378, 1, 8, 872834) The manager of a written daily will keep a list of agents and subscribers who are served by such agents.
('25', 378, 1, 9, 872939) The agents in their turn will have local copyists who will make enough copies for their respective areas.
('25', 378, 1, 10, 873045) Thus a more intimate and living relation can be established between the staff of a written daily and its readers.
('25', 378, 1, 11, 873159) What is more, when the idea is properly worked out, it will be found that there is less worry, less waste of time, energy and money and more lasting and quicker results.

('25', 379, 2, 3, 874488) THE SUBSTANCE
('25', 379, 3, 4, 874502) The Congress week was a week of joy and celebration.
('25', 379, 3, 5, 874555) None thought that swaraj was not attained.
('25', 379, 3, 6, 874598) Every one seemed to be conscious of the growing national strength.
('25', 379, 3, 7, 874665) There was confidence and hope written in every face.
('25', 379, 3, 8, 874718) The Reception Committee had provided for admitting one hundred thousand visitors to the Congress pandal.
('25', 379, 3, 9, 874823) But the lowest calculation puts down the figure at two lacs.
('25', 379, 3, 10, 874884) The rush was so great that it became impossible to issue either season tickets or the entrance tickets.
('25', 379, 3, 11, 874988) And this phenomenal attendance would have been still larger if all kinds of false rumours had not been started to scare away people.
('25', 379, 3, 12, 875121) The imprisonment of leaders and workers and their courage has filled the people with a new hope and a new joy.
('25', 379, 3, 13, 875232) There was a feeling in the air that the people had found in suffering the surest remedy for the attainment of freedom and breaking down the mightiest force that might be pitted against it.
('25', 379, 3, 14, 875421) The Constitution has worked for a year and in my humble opinion it has proved a thorough success.
('25', 379, 3, 15, 875519) There was a serious business air about the Subjects Committee which had ample time for deliberation.
('25', 379, 3, 16, 875620) It was a Committee not chosen haphazard, but deliberately by electors who knew what they were doing.
('25', 379, 3, 17, 875721) The Congress itself was an impressive spectacle.
('25', 379, 3, 18, 875770) Hakimji 1 made an ideal and patient President in the place of Deshbandhu Chitta Ranjan Das.
('25', 379, 3, 19, 875862) The delegates insisted upon their doubts being solved before they voted.
('25', 379, 3, 20, 875935) They insisted on understanding everything that was going on.
('25', 379, 3, 21, 875996) Mr. Vallabhbhai Patel, Chairman of the Reception Committee, took no more than fifteen minutes to read his address in Hindi.
('25', 379, 3, 22, 876120) There were no speeches to induct the President.
('25', 379, 3, 23, 876168) The whole of the function was performed by the All India Congress Committee.
('25', 379, 3, 24, 876245) That saved at least two hours of the twelve thousand delegates and visitors.
('25', 379, 3, 25, 876322) The President’s address took no more than twenty minutes.
('25', 379, 3, 26, 876380) Every speech was to the point and not a minute was allowed to be wasted in idle talk.
('25', 379, 3, 27, 876466) In the nature of things too it could not well be otherwise.
('25', 379, 3, 28, 876526) The resolutions were addressed to the nation.
('25', 379, 3, 29, 876572) They presented a programme of earnest work that had got to be done if the nation was to find her place in the world.
('25', 379, 3, 30, 876689) Extraordinary care was, therefore, taken both in the Subjects

('25', 380, 1, 2, 876817) Committee and the Congress to see that the resolutions were properly understood before they were voted upon.
('25', 380, 1, 3, 876926) So much for the business side.
('25', 380, 2, 4, 876957) THE EXHIBITION
('25', 380, 3, 5, 876972) The spectacular was no less impressive.

('25', 381, 1, 2, 879153) KHADI IN EVIDENCE
('25', 381, 2, 3, 879171) The Khadi Nagar, the adjoining Muslim Nagar, and the Khilafat pandal next to it were a triumphant demonstration of Hindu Muslim unity and an ocular demonstration of the hold that khadi has on the public.
('25', 381, 2, 4, 879375) The Reception Committee used only khadi manufactured in Gujarat and worth three hundred and fifty thousand rupees.

('25', 381, 3, 8, 879811) The sanitary arrangements were a special feature.
('25', 381, 3, 9, 879861) Trenches were dug for the purpose.
('25', 381, 3, 10, 879896) Perfect privacy was secured by khadi partitions.
('25', 381, 3, 11, 879945) And the excreta were covered over with clean earth after every use.
('25', 381, 3, 12, 880013) Every time the trench was used, it was, therefore, found to be in a clean condition.
('25', 381, 3, 13, 880098) The work of attending to the trenches was done not by paid Bhangis 1 but by unpaid volunteers belonging to all castes and religions.
('25', 381, 3, 14, 880231) Those only were taken who had no repugnance to this necessary work.
('25', 381, 3, 15, 880299) The reader may not know that the process is so clean and so expeditious that the cleaner does not have to touch either the excreta or the earth.
('25', 381, 3, 16, 880444) He has but to take a few shovelfuls of the cleanest earth, and with it carefully cover up the dirt.
('25', 381, 3, 17, 880544) The result of this simple attention was that the camp was clean, sweet and free from the plague of flies.
('25', 381, 3, 18, 880650) All the camps were lighted by electricity.

('25', 382, 2, 3, 881555) THE DARK SIDE
('25', 382, 3, 4, 881569) So far I have given the bright side of the picture.
('25', 382, 3, 5, 881621) But like every picture the Congress picture, too, has its shades.
('25', 382, 3, 6, 881687) Though there was the greatest enthusiasm, there was at times unruliness on the part of the visitors.

('25', 382, 5, 25, 883529) Whatever others may be able to do being free from any such pledge, bound by our own pledge we are sure to, fall to pieces if we break our own deliberate pledge.
('25', 382, 5, 26, 883690) As, therefore, I have often said in these pages, the thorough working of the Congress Constitution leads automatically to the establishment of swaraj.

('25', 383, 0, 1, 883853) 384 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('25', 383, 1, 2, 883895) FINANCIAL
('25', 383, 2, 3, 883905) Though the All India Congress Committee has a fair balance still at hand, the provinces undoubtedly will have used up the monies left with them.
('25', 383, 2, 4, 884050) They have an automatic source of income.
('25', 383, 2, 5, 884091) Every Congress member is liable to pay four annas per year to enable him to retain his or her vote.
('25', 383, 2, 6, 884191) If, therefore, each province has its quota of members, it must be able to collect at least Rs. 50,000, counting two lacs to be the least number on the roll of membership.
('25', 383, 2, 7, 884362) I have been told that this is merely a mirage, that it costs more to collect the amount than it is worth.
('25', 383, 2, 8, 884468) A government that spends more than it earns is a despotic or a corrupt government.
('25', 383, 2, 9, 884551) The Congress is claimed to be a voluntary organization.
('25', 383, 2, 10, 884607) And if we are unable to collect our subscriptions at a nominal cost, we have no right to exist.
('25', 383, 2, 11, 884703) Under swaraj we shall expect to get our revenue at no more than 2_ per cent cost and then not by force but by the free will of the people.
('25', 383, 2, 12, 884842) The least, therefore, that we are entitled to expect is that every province must now be able to finance itself.
('25', 383, 2, 13, 884954) It ought not to be difficult again to get at least one crore members, i.e., twenty five lacs of rupees throughout all India for membership.
('25', 383, 2, 14, 885094) Indeed, if we are a growingly popular organization, say a government, we should be able to double our membership.
('25', 383, 2, 15, 885208) We should be able to have enough number of unpaid honest volunteers to do just this one work of collection and no more.
('25', 383, 2, 16, 885328) If we have not them, we must declare our bankruptcy.
('25', 383, 2, 17, 885381) If we represent a healthy and natural growth, we must be able to collect this nominal personal annual tax without any effort whatsoever.
('25', 383, 2, 18, 885518) And as with the Congress organizations, so with its many institutions, colleges, schools, weaving factories, etc.
('25', 383, 2, 19, 885632) No institution is worth keeping that does not command local support by reason of its own moral strength.
('25', 383, 2, 20, 885737) Only that institution is a necessity in a district which is supported by its inhabitants.
('25', 383, 2, 21, 885827) The biggest missionary institutions financed from America or England are a superimposition and have nowhere been assimilated by the people.
('25', 383, 2, 22, 885967) If the missionaries had from the very commencement relied purely upon the goodwill and support of the people, they would have rendered infinitely greater service to India.
('25', 383, 2, 23, 886139) Even so if Congress organizations and institutions are supported from the central body, they are likely to become foreign growths and hardly beneficial to the people.
('25', 383, 2, 24, 886306) It may be laid down as a general rule that no local institution should exist which is not locally supported.
('25', 383, 2, 25, 886415) Self reliance is the surest test of capacity for self government.
('25', 384, 0, 1, 886481) VOL. 25: 27 OCTOBER, 1921 22 JANUARY, 1922 385
('25', 384, 1, 2, 886528) possible that there are places or provinces which have not yet become self conscious.
('25', 384, 1, 3, 886614) They will need to be developed and helped in the initial stages.
('25', 384, 1, 4, 886679) They cannot today be counted in any scheme of battle we may devise.
('25', 384, 1, 5, 886747) In this swift struggle we must rely only upon those places that have developed political consciousness.
('25', 384, 1, 6, 886851) It must, therefore, be in the rarest cases that the central body may be expected to finance local effort.
('25', 384, 2, 7, 886957) UNTOUCHABILITY
('25', 384, 3, 8, 886972) Similarly we must make a Herculean effort to deal with the question of untouchability.
('25', 384, 3, 9, 887059) Not until the “untouchables” certify to the reformation in Hinduism, may we claim to have done anything in the matter.
('25', 384, 3, 10, 887178) To my dismay I have found much misunderstanding on this question even in one of the most advanced and best awakened provinces, namely Andhra.

('25', 384, 3, 13, 887538) He should freely exercise all the rights of a non Brahmin.
