('25', 390, 3, 5, 901515) 189. THE IMMEDIATE ISSUE
('25', 390, 4, 6, 901540) Swaraj, the Khilafat, the Punjab occupy a subordinate place to the issue sprung upon the country by the Government.
('25', 390, 4, 7, 901656) We must first make good the right of free speech and free association before we can make any further progress towards our goal.
('25', 390, 4, 8, 901784) The Government would kill us if they could by a flank attack.
('25', 390, 4, 9, 901846) To accept defeat in the matter of free speech and free association is to court disaster.
('25', 390, 4, 10, 901935) If the Government is allowed to destroy non violent activities in the country, however dangerous they may be to its existence, even the Moderates’ work must come to a standstill.
('25', 390, 4, 11, 902114) In the general interest, therefore, we must defend these elementary rights with our lives.
('25', 390, 4, 12, 902205) We cannot be coerced into welcoming the Prince nor can we be coerced into disbanding volunteer associations or giving up any other activities which we may deem desirable for our growth.
('25', 390, 4, 13, 902391) The safest and the quickest way to defend these rights is to ignore the restriction.
('25', 390, 4, 14, 902476) We must speak the Truth under a shower of bullets.
('25', 390, 4, 15, 902527) We must band together in the face of bayonets.
('25', 390, 4, 16, 902574) No cost is too great for purchasing these fundamental rights.
('25', 390, 4, 17, 902636) And on this there can be no compromise, no parleying, no conference.
('25', 390, 4, 18, 902705) Withdrawal of notifications of disbandment and prohibition orders and discharge of all who are imprisoned for non violent activities must precede any conference or settlement.
('25', 390, 4, 19, 902881) We must be content to die, if we cannot live as free men and women.
('25', 390, 4, 20, 902949) I wish I could persuade everybody that civil disobedience is the inherent right of a citizen.
('25', 390, 4, 21, 903043) He dare not give it up Without ceasing to be a man.
('25', 390, 4, 22, 903095) Civil disobedience is never followed by anarchy.
('25', 390, 4, 23, 903144) Criminal disobedience can lead to it.
('25', 390, 4, 24, 903182) Every State puts down criminal disobedience by force.
('25', 390, 4, 25, 903236) It perishes, if it does not.
('25', 390, 4, 26, 903265) But to put down civil disobedience is to attempt to imprison conscience.
('25', 390, 4, 27, 903338) Civil disobedience can only lead to strength and purity.
('25', 390, 4, 28, 903395) A civil resister never uses arms and hence he is harmless to a State that is at all willing to listen to the voice of public opinion.
('25', 390, 4, 29, 903529) He is dangerous for an autocratic State, for
('25', 391, 0, 1, 903574) 392 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('25', 391, 1, 2, 903616) he brings about its fall by engaging public opinion upon the matter for which he resists the State.
('25', 391, 1, 3, 903716) Civil disobedience, therefore, becomes a sacred duty when the State has become lawless, or which is the same thing, corrupt.
('25', 391, 1, 4, 903841) And a citizen that barters with such a State shares its corruption or lawlessness.
('25', 391, 1, 5, 903924) It is, therefore, possible to question the wisdom of applying civil disobedience in respect of a particular act or law; it is possible to advise delay and caution.
('25', 391, 1, 6, 904088) But the right itself cannot be allowed to be questioned.
('25', 391, 1, 7, 904145) It is a birthright that cannot be surrendered without surrender of one’s self respect.
('25', 391, 1, 8, 904232) At the same time that the right of civil disobedience is insisted upon, its use must be guarded by all conceivable restrictions.
('25', 391, 1, 9, 904361) Every possible provision should be made against an outbreak of violence or general lawlessness.
('25', 391, 1, 10, 904457) Its area as well as its scope should also be limited to the barest necessity of the case.
('25', 391, 1, 11, 904547) In the present case, therefore, aggressive civil disobedience should be confined to a vindication of the right of free speech and free association.
('25', 391, 1, 12, 904695) In other words non co operation, so long as it remains non violent, must be allowed to continue without let or hindrance.
('25', 391, 1, 13, 904817) When that position is attained it is time for a representative conference to be summoned for the settlement of Khilafat, the Punjab and swaraj but not till then.

('25', 393, 1, 2, 906939) 193. WELL DONE, BUT WILL THIS CONTINUE?
('25', 393, 2, 3, 906979) Gujarat can claim to have given an excellent account of itself.
('25', 393, 3, 4, 907043) Khadi tents were erected at a cost of three and a half lakhs, canopies constructed, electric lights installed, a picturesque exhibition was held, bhajans were sung and the splendour of Indian music demonstrated.
('25', 393, 3, 5, 907255) Hindus and Muslims lived side by side.
('25', 393, 3, 6, 907294) Not an angry word was uttered by either.
('25', 393, 3, 7, 907335) Gujarati girls worked as volunteers, Gujarati youths served the delegates even by performing the tasks of scavengers; a huge meeting was held for women and speeches were delivered.
('25', 393, 3, 8, 907516) All who spoke in the Congress pandal respected the law of economy and talked to the point.
('25', 393, 3, 9, 907607) No one indulged in long harangues and an effective but moderately worded resolution was passed in answer to the policy of repression adopted by the Government.
('25', 393, 3, 10, 907767) No one doubts that by doing all this Gujarat has enhanced its prestige as also that of India.
('25', 393, 3, 11, 907861) But what is to follow?
('25', 393, 3, 12, 907884) Nothing has been left undone to present a bold appearance nor have brave words been lacking; but will brave deeds follow?
('25', 393, 3, 13, 908006) WillGujaratis be able to compete with Bengal, U.P. and the Punjab?
('25', 393, 3, 14, 908073) Will they win the credit of getting the prisoners released and securing swaraj?
('25', 393, 3, 15, 908153) Will they go to jail?
('25', 393, 3, 16, 908175) Will they submit to beatings and face even death, without anger?
('25', 393, 3, 17, 908240) If we understand things properly, this will be but child’s play.
('25', 393, 3, 18, 908305) If not, it will be as difficult as breaking boulders.
('25', 393, 3, 19, 908359) We must be non violent in thought, word and deed.
('25', 393, 3, 20, 908409) Even a Bhangi must be regarded as a brother.
('25', 393, 3, 21, 908454) We must behave with consideration and love towards our Parsi, Jew and Christian brothers and also those who co operate with the Government.
('25', 393, 3, 22, 908594) Nor may we show anger to a British neighbour.

('25', 398, 1, 2, 918630) 195. MY NOTES
('25', 398, 2, 3, 918644) AWAKENING AMONG CHRISTIANS
('25', 398, 3, 4, 918671) I have noted that non co operation has brought about a great awakening among Christians too.
('25', 398, 3, 5, 918764) A conference representing all the Christians in the country was held a short time ago in Lahore under the presidentship of Mr. Mukerji.
('25', 398, 3, 6, 918900) Very good resolutions regarding swadeshi and prohibition were adopted at the Conference.
('25', 398, 3, 7, 918989) The swaraj spirit can be felt in all their proceedings.
('25', 398, 3, 8, 919045) Speakers dwelt at length on the need for adopting khadi.
('25', 398, 3, 9, 919102) Everyone has realized now that khadi is the poor man’s life line and that the spinning wheel means prosperity in the poor man’s home, and so Indian Christians have also embraced the movement.
('25', 398, 3, 10, 919294) Although the President spoke against non co operation, he, too, wants swaraj.
('25', 398, 3, 11, 919372) In his speech, he strongly criticized the Government’s repressive policies.
('25', 398, 4, 12, 919448) THE PRINCE OF WALES IN INDIAN STATES
('25', 398, 5, 13, 919485) A question has arisen what the subjects of Indian States should do when the prince visits their States.
('25', 398, 5, 14, 919589) It seems to me that, since they have not started non co operation against their rulers, they may not do anything which might embarrass the State.
('25', 398, 5, 15, 919735) They are not bound to honour a guest of the State, but at the same time they are not entitled to agitate against such a guest being honoured.
('25', 398, 5, 16, 919877) When, therefore, the Prince visits an Indian State, the public should not declare a hartal or hold a protest meeting.
('25', 398, 5, 17, 919995) Thoughtful subjects of these States, however, are sure to feel bound up with the rest of the country and, therefore, they should as far as possible refrain from taking part in functions held in honour of the Prince.
('25', 398, 5, 18, 920211) In the States, there is very little democracy, in fact none at all.
('25', 398, 5, 19, 920279) the public there does not have to associate itself with the actions of the ruler.
('25', 398, 5, 20, 920361) People join only in activities which interest them or under compulsion.
('25', 398, 5, 21, 920433) In all such matters, therefore, a person will be admired for courteously exercising his freedom as an individual.
('25', 398, 5, 22, 920547) In Indian States, the relationship between the ruler and the ruled is governed entirely by self interest.
('25', 398, 5, 23, 920653) If the ruler is a good man, he can do some good; if he is a bad man, the subjects have no appeal against him other than to take up arms or offer non co operation.
('25', 398, 5, 24, 920816) This seems to be the state of relations between the rulers and the ruled in British India, where the Government acts in
('25', 399, 0, 1, 920936) 400 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('25', 399, 1, 2, 920978) disregard of the people’s interests and, as a result, non co operation has been launched.
('25', 399, 1, 3, 921068) The condition of the Indian States is at present so difficult that it would be a serious matter for their subjects to start non co operation.
('25', 399, 1, 4, 921210) Such a step can be taken only where oppression has become intolerable and the subjects have developed collective soul force.

('25', 417, 1, 2, 962288) It will be noticed that out of the total permissible (6,173) as many as 4,726 attended the Congress.
('25', 417, 1, 3, 962389) Hitherto the number has been swelled by local delegates who could under the old constitution become delegates for the asking by simply paying Rs. 10. This time not even Pandit Malaviyaji could be regarded as a delegate because he was not elected.
('25', 417, 1, 4, 962636) The actual attendance of 4,726 was, therefore, a fine record.
('25', 417, 1, 5, 962698) That the United Provinces and Bengal, in spite of so many arrests, could have sent 888 and 373 respectively and the far off Assam should have sent 17 and Utkal 108, shows the keen interest that is being taken in the National Assembly.
('25', 417, 1, 6, 962933) No less remarkable is the attendance of 106 lady delegates representing almost all the provinces.
('25', 417, 1, 7, 963031) The attendance of 65 Sikh delegates must also be regarded as altogether remarkable.
('25', 417, 1, 8, 963115) Hardly few [sic] Sikhs attended two years ago.
('25', 417, 1, 9, 963162) But now that community is everywhere pushing itself forward in all national movements.
('25', 417, 1, 10, 963249) The number of 469 Mussulman delegates is a good number, but we must not be satisfied till we have got the full quota which must be more than 1,200. I am sure that there were more than 2 “untouchable” delegates.
('25', 417, 1, 11, 963460) I cannot imagine the Punjab and the Andhra provinces not sending any such delegates.
('25', 417, 1, 12, 963545) The presence of 5 Parsi delegates is, of course, beyond their numerical proportion which is 2. The Parsis, as I have so often remarked, have in proportion to their numbers occupied the foremost place whether in point of sacrifice, attendance, ability or generosity.
('25', 417, 1, 13, 963811) I know, as a matter of fact, that there were at least two Christians.
('25', 417, 1, 14, 963881) And of course, if Messrs Stokes and George Joseph had been free, they would have attended.
('25', 417, 1, 15, 963972) But it is up to the Hindus and the Mussulmans to go out of their way to induce a more general interest in the movement on the part of the Christian community.

('25', 418, 2, 4, 965013) ALL INDIA CHRISTIAN CONFERENCE
('25', 418, 3, 5, 965044) This Conference held under the presidency of Mr. Mukerji was striking for the interest it evinced in the political life of the country.
('25', 418, 3, 6, 965180) From the President down to the ordinary delegate, there was insistence on the necessity of Indian Christians sharing the national awakening.
('25', 418, 4, 7, 965321) We must demonstrate by words and deeds that Christianity has made us neither un Indian nor un national.
('25', 418, 4, 8, 965425) Can it be for a moment conceived that we as a community shall dissociate ourselves from our brethren, Hindus and Mussulmans, whatever differences there may be in our religious convictions ?, says Professor S. C. Mukerji.
('25', 418, 4, 9, 965646) The Conference adopted sixteen resolutions touching almost every phase of national life.
('25', 418, 4, 10, 965735) It condemned the repressive measures, urged withdrawal of Government notifications and discharge of prisoners, it advised non co operators to suspend the campaign of non co operation, urged a round table conference, approved of total prohibition, sympathized with the Indians beyond the seas.
('25', 418, 4, 11, 966028) I must give the full text of the swadeshi resolution showing as it does the extent to which the spirit of swadeshi has touched the Indian Christian mind:
('25', 418, 5, 12, 966182) This Conference is strongly of opinion that a true swadeshi spirit should dominate every sphere of Indian Christian life which would, in its turn, serve to give a real impetus to all indigenous enterprises in the country.
('25', 418, 5, 13, 966404) That as an art expression of our swadeshi spirit we must forthwith start wearing clothes of Indian manufacture.
('25', 418, 5, 14, 966516) In view of the fact that the Indian Christian community has been very frequently and severely accused of lacking the swadeshi spirit, this Conference recommends that all Provincial Leagues make strenuous efforts to find ways and means of inculcating the swadeshi spirit in the Indian Christians through the local leagues and lose no time in putting such a programme into effect.
('25', 418, 5, 15, 966895) All this is very encouraging.
('25', 418, 5, 16, 966925) I hope that the resolution will be followed up by corresponding action and that charkha and khadi will be as popular among the Indian Christians as they have become among the Hindus and Mussulmans.
('25', 418, 5, 17, 967123) It remains for the Hindus and Mussulmans to cherish the response of the Conference and make it a point to cultivate the friendliest relations with the Christian countrymen.

('25', 421, 1, 2, 972030) ABOUT LAWYERS
('25', 421, 2, 3, 972044) The Jamnalal Bajaj 1 fund of one lac of rupees that was given last year for the support of lawyers who had suspended practice as a result of the Nagpur resolution 2 is nearly, as it was intended to be, exhausted.
('25', 421, 2, 4, 972257) The lawyers cannot go back to practice with any show of decency, and I am sure that many will not countenance even the idea of a return when the country is showing such a wonderful example of self sacrifice.
('25', 421, 2, 5, 972465) But it would not be proper to leave thelawyers to their own resources.
('25', 421, 2, 6, 972536) I would, therefore, certainly suggest to the Provincial Committees that they should take up the burden subject to assistance from the central fund, if it was at all found necessary.
('25', 421, 2, 7, 972718) The rearrangement should be quickly made so as to avoid suspense and delay in the even tenor of national work.
('25', 421, 2, 8, 972829) This, however, is the least among the difficulties that surround the lawyer class at the present moment.
('25', 421, 2, 9, 972934) They are eager to take part in the national awakening.
('25', 421, 2, 10, 972989) The spirit is willing, the flesh is weak.
('25', 421, 2, 11, 973031) I still feel that practising lawyers cannot lead.

('25', 422, 2, 6, 975216) DISTRESS WARRANTS
('25', 422, 3, 7, 975234) Inquiries are being made in several places as to what should be done in cases where fines are imposed and distress warrants issuedfor recovery.
('25', 422, 3, 8, 975378) One finds a readiness to suffer imprisonment and assaults but not loss of goods.
('25', 422, 3, 9, 975459) The anomaly is at first sight difficult to understand but it is really easy to appreciate.
('25', 422, 3, 10, 975550) We are so much tied down to our goods and other possessions that when no disgrace attaches to imprisonment, we prefer the inconvenience to loss of property.
('25', 422, 3, 11, 975707) But we must perceive that we will lose a winning game if we are not prepared to sacrifice our earthly possessions as well as bodily ease for the sake of it.
('25', 422, 3, 12, 975864) In an ill managed State, a man with conscience pawns to it his goods, all other wealth, and his body and sets his conscience free.
('25', 422, 3, 13, 975995) This struggle, therefore, can give us victory only if we become indifferent to everything through which the State can press us into subjection to its will.
('25', 422, 3, 14, 976151) We must be prepared, therefore, to let our goods and our land be taken away from us and rejoice over the dispossession even as we rejoice today over imprisonments.
('25', 422, 3, 15, 976315) We may rest assured that the Government will be more quickly tired of selling our chattels than it is already of taking charge of our bodies.
('25', 422, 3, 16, 976457) And if we are sure, as we must be, of winning full swaraj before long, we must have faith enough to know that all the land that can be taken away will return to us intact and the best part even of money.
('25', 422, 3, 17, 976661) When Belgium was overrun by the Germans, the Belgians knew that they would return to their own lands so long as they retained the will to suffer for the restoration of their property.
('25', 422, 3, 18, 976845) The late General Botha 1 was a fugitive from his own rich possessions including hundreds of acres of land

('25', 425, 3, 12, 982398) 199. DESHBANDHU’S ADDRESS 1
('25', 425, 4, 13, 982426) I must apologize to the public for the delay in issuing Deshbandhu Das’s presidential address.
('25', 425, 4, 14, 982521) It was received by me in a fragmentary condition with instructions to revise it and put it in shape.
('25', 425, 4, 15, 982622) The reader will be glad to learn that beyond restoring one sentence which had been ruled out and adding one to complete a thought and beyond slight verbal immaterial alterations, the address is being printed as received.
('25', 425, 4, 16, 982843) I see from the sentences ruled out in the original that Deshbandhu’s intention was to give a review of the year’s work and his considered opinion in detail on non co operation.
('25', 425, 4, 17, 983020) But sufficient appears in the printed text to enable us to know his opinion.
('25', 425, 4, 18, 983097) We know it, too, from his emphatic and stirring messages to the country just before he was silenced.
('25', 425, 4, 19, 983198) In appreciating the address the reader will be helped to know that it was prepared just before his arrest.
('25', 425, 4, 20, 983305) The reader will not fail to note the marked self restraint with which the address is prepared as also the fact that Deshbandhu believes in non violence as his final creed.
('25', 425, 4, 21, 983477) That the only use the Government has for such a man is to put him in prison is about the greatest condemnation it can pronounce upon itself.

('25', 426, 1, 2, 983904) 200. LIBERTY OF THE PRESS
('25', 426, 2, 3, 983930) One by one the pretensions of the Government that the reforms 1
('25', 426, 3, 4, 983994) represent more liberty and more concession to popular feeling are dropping out under the stress of circumstances.
('25', 426, 3, 5, 984108) The pretensions can be justified only if they can stand the test under a severe strain.
('25', 426, 3, 6, 984196) Liberty of speech means that it is unassailed even when the speech hurts; liberty of the Press can be said to be truly respected only when the Press can comment in the severest terms upon and even misrepresent matters, protection against misrepresentation or violence being secured not by an administrative gagging order, not by closing down the Press but by punishing the real offender, leaving the Press itself unrestricted Freedom of association is truly respected when assemblies of people can discuss even revolutionary projects, the State relying upon the force of public opinion and the civil police, not the savage military at its disposal, to crush any actual outbreak of revolution that is designed to confound public opinion and the State representing it.
('25', 426, 3, 7, 984963) The Government of India is now seeking to crush the three powerful vehicles of expressing and cultivating public opinion and is thus once more, but happily for the last time, proving its totally arbitrary and despotic character.
('25', 426, 3, 8, 985192) The fight for swaraj, the Khilafat, the Punjab means fight for this threefold freedom before all else.
('25', 426, 3, 9, 985295) The Independent is no longer a printed sheet.
('25', 426, 3, 10, 985341) The Democrat is no more.
('25', 426, 3, 11, 985366) And now the sword has descended upon the Pratap and the Kesari of Lahore.
('25', 426, 3, 12, 985440) The Vande Mataram, Lalaji’s child, has warded off the blow by depositing Rs. 2,000 as security.
('25', 426, 3, 13, 985536) The other two have had their first security forfeited and are now given ten days’ notice to deposit Rs. 10,000 each or close down.
('25', 426, 3, 14, 985667) I hope that the security of Rs. 10,000 will be refused.
('25', 426, 3, 15, 985723) I assume that what is happening in the United Provinces and the Punjab will happen in the others in due course unless the infection is prevented from spreading by some action on the part of the public.
('25', 426, 3, 16, 985925) In the first place I would urge the editors of the papers in question to copy the method of the Independent and publish their views in writing.
('25', 426, 3, 17, 986069) I believe that an editor who has anything worth saying and who commands a clientele cannot be easily hushed so long as his body is left free.
('25', 426, 3, 18, 986211) He has delivered his finished message as soon as he is put under duress.
('25', 426, 3, 19, 986284) The Lokamanya spoke more eloquently
('25', 426, 4, 20, 986320) 1 The Montford Reforms of 1919

('25', 427, 1, 2, 986393) from the Mandalay fortress than through the columns of the printed Kesari.

('25', 427, 1, 4, 986646) By his death he is editing his paper without pen and speech through the sacred resolution of the people to realize his life’s dream.

('25', 428, 1, 2, 988688) 201. INTERVIEW TO “THE BOMBAY CHRONICLE”
('25', 428, 2, 3, 988729) [Before January 14, 1922]
('25', 428, 3, 4, 988755) Mahatma Gandhi who has expressed his readiness to attend the Conference, interviewed by our representative, stated that there was no budging from the position that had been taken up by the Congress regarding the Round Table Conference and the conditions 1 that he had defined in the Congress Subjects Committee as precedent to any such conference must be satisfied by Government before the Congress could be expected to fall in with the idea.
('25', 428, 3, 5, 989198) So far as he was concerned, his object in accepting the invitation, said Mahatmaji.
('25', 428, 3, 6, 989282) was to see if he could bring round his Moderate friends on the narrow issue which he had presented to the readers of Young India lastweek 2—namely, the issue of freedom of speech and freedom of association.
('25', 428, 3, 7, 989489) Mahatmaji hoped it would be possible to persuade his Moderate friends to see eye to eye with the Congress on that issue.
('25', 428, 3, 8, 989610) The Bombay Chronicle, 14 1 1922

('25', 430, 6, 8, 995697) 203. WOMEN OF GUJARAT
('25', 430, 7, 9, 995719) When Smt.
('25', 430, 7, 10, 995729) Vasanti Devi Das, Urmila Devi Sen and, Suniti Devi were arrested 2, some sisters from Ahmedabad decided to form a Volunteer Corps and court arrest.
('25', 430, 7, 11, 995877) Consequently, forms of the pledge were placed before them.
('25', 430, 7, 12, 995936) The first idea was to publish the list after fifty names had been enrolled.
('25', 430, 7, 13, 996012) This happened before the Congress session.
('25', 430, 8, 14, 996055) Meanwhile, the Bengali ladies were released.
('25', 430, 8, 15, 996100) The Government did not have the strength to hold them for long.
('25', 430, 8, 16, 996164) In consequence, the publication of the Ahmedabad list was suspended, though signatures continued to be obtained.
('25', 430, 8, 17, 996277) As a result of the effort, about 140 women signed up and more are following suit.
('25', 430, 8, 18, 996359) Of these, three women have had some experience of jail in the past.
('25', 430, 9, 19, 996427) Of what consequence, however, are the signatures by themselves?

('25', 439, 3, 6, 1017027) Where has Congress made any mention of property ?” So say some brave warriors who are ready to die but not to let go their land or allow their cattle or goods to be sold.
('25', 439, 3, 7, 1017198) The reference to the Congress is meaningless.
('25', 439, 3, 8, 1017244) It made no separate mention of property assuming that one who is ready to die will be ready to lose his all.
('25', 439, 3, 9, 1017353) But our attachment to property, movable and immovable, is such that even when giving up our life we are not willing to part with it!
('25', 439, 3, 10, 1017486) This is, therefore, a matter to which we must give some thought.
('25', 439, 3, 11, 1017551) For terrorizing us, the Government will use every means which can bring us to our knees.
('25', 439, 3, 12, 1017640) If it discovers that we regard a fine as more of a hardship than imprisonment, it will impose fines.
('25', 439, 3, 13, 1017741) Already in some places imprisonment and fines are imposed simultaneously.
('25', 439, 4, 14, 1017815) We must completely give up our fear of losing property.
('25', 439, 4, 15, 1017871) Under a tyrannical government, the rich also have to be partners in tyranny.
('25', 439, 4, 16, 1017948) Under such a government, therefore, poverty becomes the path of virtue.
('25', 439, 4, 17, 1018020) We should thus realize that, if we want to non co operate, we must give up all attachment to wealth.
('25', 439, 4, 18, 1018121) Only when we are ready to starve to death rather than submit to tyranny will our non co operation be complete.
('25', 439, 5, 19, 1018232) It should also be noted that when large numbers have shed the fear of punishment by fine, it becomes difficult for the Govenmentto collect the amounts.
('25', 439, 5, 20, 1018384) It is far more troublesome to auction the property of a thousand people than to send them to jail, Punishment can be imposed only on a comparatively small number.
('25', 439, 5, 21, 1018547) When many people act in a particular way, it becomes almost impossible to stop them.
('25', 439, 5, 22, 1018632) Property may be confiscated, but to whom is it to be sold?
('25', 439, 5, 23, 1018691) Land may be taken over, but it cannot be picked up and put down somewhere else.
('25', 439, 5, 24, 1018771) Is there anyone who would be willing to bid for another’s land?
('25', 439, 5, 25, 1018835) Moreover, those who believe in swaraj should have faith in their expectation about the ultimate result.
('25', 439, 5, 26, 1018939) They should, therefore, have confidence that, even if their property is confiscated by the Government today, they will get it back when swaraj is won.
('25', 439, 5, 27, 1019090) General Botha owned thousands of acres.
('25', 439, 5, 28, 1019130) None possessed cattle like his.
('25', 439, 5, 29, 1019162) All this was seized by the British.
('25', 439, 5, 30, 1019198) But he did not yield.
('25', 439, 5, 31, 1019220) He held out with
('25', 440, 0, 1, 1019237) VOL. 25 : 27 OCTOBER, 1921 22 JANUARY, 1922 441
('25', 440, 1, 2, 1019285) determination and, finally, not only did he regain his property but became the de facto king of the whole of South Africa.
('25', 440, 1, 3, 1019408) He was confident that, if he survived, he would get back his property and, if he died, he would go to heaven.
('25', 440, 1, 4, 1019518) We who do not wish to resort to violence in our struggle should be even more unconcerned about our property.
('25', 440, 1, 5, 1019627) The question will be asked how we can maintain ourselves if our property is seized by the Government.
('25', 440, 1, 6, 1019729) If we have taken the pledge not to yield even if we starve, why should we worry about ourselves or our people starving?
('25', 440, 1, 7, 1019849) In this large country there will always be someone to give us food, and, moreover, we have with us now our beloved spinning wheel.
('25', 440, 1, 8, 1019980) Why, then, should we worry?
('25', 440, 1, 9, 1020008) When a whole family has become expert in spinning and weaving, its members do not have the slightest reason to worry about their livelihood.
('25', 440, 1, 10, 1020149) All our fear arises from lack of faith.
('25', 440, 1, 11, 1020189) If we put our faith in God, that is, if we trust that everything will happen as ordained by Him, we would never worry.
('25', 440, 1, 12, 1020308) But it is only when we on our part have done our best that we can console ourselves with “whatever is to happen will happen”.
('25', 440, 1, 13, 1020434) Man’s efforts are assuredly rewarded by God’s grace.
('25', 440, 1, 14, 1020487) Putting faith in God means that, even when our property is being seized, we continue to give Him our praise.
('25', 440, 1, 15, 1020596) If we praise Him in anticipation of our property being spared, that is only a bargain.
('25', 440, 1, 16, 1020683) God is not pining for bargains He wants devotion and He severely tests the love of His devotee.
('25', 440, 1, 17, 1020779) He is as cruel as He is merciful.
('25', 440, 1, 18, 1020813) When He judges, He shows consideration to none.
('25', 440, 1, 19, 1020861) He shows no favour.
('25', 440, 1, 20, 1020881) He rewards both devotees and unbelievers according to their deserts.
('25', 440, 1, 21, 1020950) The devotee does good and receives the right reward.
('25', 440, 1, 22, 1021003) The bad man’s actions are wicked and he gets his punishment.
('25', 440, 1, 23, 1021064) In our struggle there is no room for hypocrisy, hatred or impatience.
('25', 440, 1, 24, 1021134) It is for this reason that it has been called a holy war.
('25', 440, 1, 25, 1021192) May Gujarat demonstrate religious spirit—I live in the confidence that she will.
('25', 440, 2, 26, 1021273) THE PURCHASER WILL PERISH!
('25', 440, 3, 27, 1021300) I hear that the Kheda District is pure only in name.
('25', 440, 3, 28, 1021353) The people there will not attack any Government employee but, should anyone come forward to bid for a Patidar’s property which is being auctioned, he cannot hope to escape with his life.
('25', 440, 3, 29, 1021540) The Patidar, so proud of his blood, will not miss an opportunity to have his revenge.
('25', 440, 3, 30, 1021626) What sort of non violence is this?
('25', 440, 3, 31, 1021661) Whoever buys our property automatically becomes a Government man.
('25', 440, 3, 32, 1021727) If so, how can we, having
('25', 441, 0, 1, 1021753) 442 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('25', 441, 1, 2, 1021795) passed a resolution saying that no supporter of the Government should be injured, kill the person who buys our property?
('25', 441, 1, 3, 1021916) Moreover our pledge makes no such exception.
('25', 441, 1, 4, 1021961) If Patidars or others compromise their pledge in this manner, be it only in thought, we cannot win swaraj.
('25', 441, 1, 5, 1022068) Our pledge is not that we will secure swaraj by any means, fair or foul.
('25', 441, 1, 6, 1022141) It is the general principle of the Congress, which is especially binding on non co operators, that it will fight for swaraj by peaceful and truthful means.
('25', 441, 1, 7, 1022297) It must not be forgotten that the conditions of truth and non violence are binding on all who join the Congress.
('25', 441, 1, 8, 1022410) There are innumerable occasions in non co operation when people may get provoked and start fighting.
('25', 441, 1, 9, 1022511) That is why, by way of added precaution, the adjective “non violent” has been joined to it.
('25', 441, 1, 10, 1022603) I, therefore, hope that Patidars and others who are anxious to save the honour of Gujarat will banish from their minds all evil thoughts and shed every fear.
('25', 441, 2, 11, 1022761) BARDOLI ANAND
('25', 441, 3, 12, 1022775) These two talukas owe a special duty.
('25', 441, 3, 13, 1022813) If they do not quickly get ready, Gujarat will be put to shame.
('25', 441, 3, 14, 1022877) The Hindus and Muslims of U.P. and Bengal and the Hindus, Sikhs and Patham of the Punjab have already passed the test of fearlessness, of readiness for imprisonment and ability to endure beating.
('25', 441, 3, 15, 1023073) If, now, Bardoli and Anand which have been much talked of do not get ready soon, we shall lose face.
('25', 441, 3, 16, 1023174) We are, of course, ready for imprisonment, but we have to make ourselves fit, and cultivate the strength, to lay down our lives.
('25', 441, 3, 17, 1023303) If we become fit, we shall get the necessary strength.
('25', 441, 3, 18, 1023358) All should start wearing khadi.
('25', 441, 3, 19, 1023390) The Committee has with it some sacred khadi which was used in Khadi Nagar.
('25', 441, 3, 20, 1023465) This should be used first, and afterwards only khadi producedin one’s own district should be worn.
('25', 441, 3, 21, 1023564) Women, too, should accept this common dharma.
('25', 441, 3, 22, 1023610) In every home people should work hard and spin strong, good quality yarn.
('25', 441, 3, 23, 1023684) Every village should take up carding, people should treat Dheds and Bhangis as brothers and serve them, admit their children to national schools and go personally to fetch them and show them kindness.
('25', 441, 3, 24, 1023885) They should also remove the fear of those in their midst who may be co operating with the Government.
('25', 441, 3, 25, 1023987) Hindus, Muslims, Parsis, and Christians should cultivate good relations with one another.
('25', 441, 3, 26, 1024077) What is difficult in all this?
('25', 441, 3, 27, 1024108) What sacrifice does it involve?
('25', 441, 3, 28, 1024140) The spinning wheel and khadi bring us money.
('25', 441, 3, 29, 1024185) The other things require abandoning our wrong ideas.
('25', 441, 3, 30, 1024238) That cannot be a burden.
('25', 441, 3, 31, 1024263) I want the people of Bardoli to labour day and night to qualify
('25', 442, 0, 1, 1024327) VOL. 25 : 27 OCTOBER, 1921 22 JANUARY, 1922 443
('25', 442, 1, 2, 1024375) themselves and on the 20th at the latest send me an assurance, through their Secretary or President, or a written statement from either of them, that they are now fit and ready [for the campaign].
('25', 442, 1, 3, 1024572) Similarly, the residents of Anand should by that date, or even earlier, send an assurance through Abbas Saheb.
('25', 442, 2, 4, 1024683) IF THEY ARE TRUE
('25', 442, 3, 5, 1024700) If these friends are true and bold, they should stop paying revenue to the Government from today onwards.
('25', 442, 3, 6, 1024806) Those, at any rate, who have resolved to join the fight should stop doing so.
('25', 442, 3, 7, 1024884) I hope the residents of the taluka will not first pay up the revenue and then declare that they are ready to fight.
('25', 442, 4, 8, 1025000) WHAT ABOUT THE OTHERS ?
('25', 442, 5, 9, 1025024) Some people tell me that the whole of Gujarat is ready to suspend payment of revenue and ask me if I would not advise them to do so.
('25', 442, 5, 10, 1025157) I can give no such advice.
('25', 442, 5, 11, 1025184) I would not restrain anyone who voluntarily withholds payment.
('25', 442, 5, 12, 1025247) Who am I to compel him?
('25', 442, 5, 13, 1025271) But I would not take the risk of advising all the people to stop payment of revenue.
('25', 442, 5, 14, 1025356) We seek to serve no interest of our own by refusing to pay it.
('25', 442, 5, 15, 1025419) Our refusal must be civil.
('25', 442, 5, 16, 1025446) If we wish to disobey the revenue law civilly, it is essential that we purify ourselves.
('25', 442, 5, 17, 1025535) Hence, those who regard unity of Hindus, Muslims, Christians and Parsis as a moral obligation, who have understood the significance of non violence, who treat Dheds and Bhangis as brothers and do not think themselves defiled by their touch, who wear khadi exclusively and have the courage to die and to let their property be confiscated, these may certainly withhold payment without seeking my advice.
('25', 442, 5, 18, 1025937) This, however, refers to individuals.
('25', 442, 5, 19, 1025975) I can never advise the whole population to withhold payment so long as the slightest need remains to educate the people further.
('25', 442, 5, 20, 1026104) The main reason for this is that I am not convinced that people in all the talukas of Gujarat are ready to the extent that they will not give way to anger when their properties are auctioned on their withholding payment.
('25', 442, 5, 21, 1026325) It is, therefore, wiser to advise the general mass of people to pay.
('25', 442, 5, 22, 1026394) If any of them still refuse to pay, they may do as they choose.
('25', 442, 5, 23, 1026458) Those who pay may help in any other way they can.
('25', 442, 5, 24, 1026508) All people in the rest of the country will be paying revenue and will not, by doing so, have betrayed the cause.
('25', 442, 5, 25, 1026621) We shall seek their help in many other ways.
('25', 442, 5, 26, 1026666) I have, therefore, two
('25', 443, 0, 1, 1026689) 444 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('25', 443, 1, 2, 1026731) different courses to advise: 1. If Bardoli and Anand want to offer mass civil disobedience, the people in these talukas should withhold payment even if, in consequence, Inami lands 1 are taken over by the Government.
('25', 443, 1, 3, 1026948) 2. To the people in the remaining talukas, my advice is that they should pay up the revenue dues but help the non co operation movement in other ways.
('25', 443, 1, 4, 1027099) Those who, despite this advice, withhold payment on their own responsibility, having firmly resolved to abide by all the conditions of the pledge, will deserve our congratulations.
('25', 443, 1, 5, 1027280) But they must not be puffed up with pride, thinking that they have displayed great courage and the rest have been timid, Believing that everyone serves according to his capacity, even those who make heavy sacrifices should remain humble and come forward to give even more.

('25', 444, 1, 2, 1029159) 205. EXTRACT FROM LETTER TO M. R. JAYAKAR 1
('25', 444, 2, 3, 1029203) Sunday Morning [January 15, 1922] 2
('25', 444, 3, 4, 1029239) I got your note just when I was in the thick of a meeting.
('25', 444, 3, 5, 1029298) I have now got up early to reply to your note and to frame resolutions for the 10 o’clock meeting.
('25', 444, 4, 6, 1029397) I have taken the insult offered to you as I have taken the insults offered to me by Mr. Patel 4 not once but on many occasions.
('25', 444, 4, 7, 1029525) It has become second nature with him.
('25', 444, 4, 8, 1029563) I had really come to think that you and he had, somehow or other, become the best of friends.
('25', 444, 4, 9, 1029657) Now, if you permit me, I should like to show your letter to Mr. Patel for his own good.
('25', 444, 4, 10, 1029745) I take it, you know, that he and I frankly do not agree.
('25', 444, 4, 11, 1029802) His way is not my way.
('25', 444, 4, 12, 1029825) He knows that we travel in different directions, so much for Mr. Patel.
('25', 444, 4, 13, 1029897) I have no party save that of Truth.
('25', 444, 4, 14, 1029933) I want to live for nothing but Truth.
('25', 444, 4, 15, 1029971) Whether you remain in the non co operation ranks,or whether you do not, I cannot desert you, even as Icannot desert Malaviyaji, no matter where I find him for the time being.
('25', 444, 4, 16, 1030146) For, I consider you to be a man of Truth.
('25', 444, 4, 17, 1030188) You have left in me the impression that you are too cultured to do anything wrong, knowing it to be such.
('25', 444, 5, 18, 1030294) The Story of My Life, Vol. I, p.

('25', 445, 1, 2, 1031083) 206. SPEECH AT LEADERS’ CONFERENCE, BOMBAY 1
('25', 445, 2, 3, 1031128) January 15, 1922 MR. CHAIRMAN AND FRIENDS, It is quite proper that Mr. N. V. Gokhale should ask three or four questions.
('25', 445, 2, 4, 1031249) He has asked those questions and I think I should render full explanation of what part I have taken in assisting the Committee to frame these resolutions.
('25', 445, 2, 5, 1031404) You will see there are not many vital changes in the resolutions as they were read to you yesterday.
('25', 445, 2, 6, 1031505) The Conference should remember that I do not propose to be a party to the resolutions of this Conference and so far as I am concerned, the non co operators also will not become parties.
('25', 445, 2, 7, 1031691) (“Hear, hear.”) They will not take part in the discussion either.
('25', 445, 2, 8, 1031757) I am humbly of opinion that it is the special prerogative and duty of those who are not non co operators to consider fully the bearings of these resolutions and to accept them or to reject them as they choose.
('25', 445, 2, 9, 1031967) I defined the functions of non co operators yesterday and I repeat every word of what I said yesterday, and their function is this, namely, of advisers; but they do not identify themselves with these resolutions.
('25', 445, 2, 10, 1032180) That does not mean that they do not hold any opinion about these resolutions.
('25', 445, 2, 11, 1032258) They do certainly hold an opinion about these resolutions.
('25', 445, 2, 12, 1032317) There are certain things which the non co operators are called upon to do in the event of certain contingencies.
('25', 445, 2, 13, 1032430) Personally, I may explain to you what the attitude of the non co operators will be with reference to the obligations that these resolutions seek to impose upon them.
('25', 445, 2, 14, 1032596) With reference to the first resolution, I have absolutely nothing to say beyond what I said yesterday.
('25', 445, 2, 15, 1032699) I say it remains intact.
('25', 445, 2, 16, 1032724) The second resolution also remains intact.
('25', 445, 2, 17, 1032767) With reference to that I have to tell the Conference, that I repeat the remark I made before the [Conference] Committee, that the resolution will be placed before the Working Committee 2, if it is sent to it officially by this Conference, and the Working Committee will consider that resolution, and I have assured the Conference Committee, and I repeat the assurance, that I
('25', 445, 3, 18, 1033143) 1 According to The Hindu, 17 1 1922, the Committee appointed by the Conference on January 14 had met on January 15 before the resumption of the Conference and Gandhiji had attended this meeting “as an adviser and unofficially”.
('25', 445, 3, 19, 1033371) The Conference resumed its session at 6 p.m.
('25', 445, 3, 20, 1033416) and this speech, taken from The Hindu, 18 1 1922, was published under the description “full text of Mahatma Gandhi’s speech”
('25', 445, 4, 21, 1033541) 2 Of the Congress
('25', 446, 0, 1, 1033559) VOL. 25 : 27 OCTOBER, 1921 22 JANUARY, 1922 447
('25', 446, 1, 2, 1033607) shall advise the Working Committee to suspend general civil disobedience contemplated by the Ahmedabad Congress resolution pending the negotiations that the Committee to be appointed by this House will enter into with Government in the hope that there will be a round table conference granted.
('25', 446, 1, 3, 1033901) But beyond the 31st of this month, it will not be possible for me to advise the country to suspend general civil disobedience.
('25', 446, 1, 4, 1034028) I must also tell you that I was pressed to extend that limit of time but I feel grieved that I could not do so.
('25', 446, 1, 5, 1034140) I want to tell the reason very briefly for my inability to do that.
('25', 446, 1, 6, 1034208) To me even 15 days matter.
('25', 446, 1, 7, 1034235) Another reason I placed before you yesterday in view of what was going on in the country today.
('25', 446, 1, 8, 1034331) As to the repressive acts in the country, in spite of the faults or the crimes that the non co operators may have committed, hold these acts of repression to be absolutely indefensible and the only answer that the non co operators can give is general civil disobedience.
('25', 446, 1, 9, 1034602) But in order to buy the support of those countrymen of mine who are not non co operators, in order to enlist their sympathy on our side, I have reluctantly said that we shall postpone general civil disobedience for a fortnight.
('25', 446, 1, 10, 1034830) (“Hear, hear.”) I expect I shall be able to carry the Working Committee with me in this matter.
('25', 446, 1, 11, 1034926) We had an informal discussion on the subject last night amongst ourselves—the non co operators, and I was authorized by them to say that they had decided to wait for a fortnight in order to enable the Committee appointed by this Conference to enter into negotiations with the Viceroy.
('25', 446, 1, 12, 1035211) That will put us square with the Viceroy and show that we are reasonable people.
('25', 446, 1, 13, 1035292) We do not taboo a round table conference if a round table conference can be summoned with any prospect of success.
('25', 446, 1, 14, 1035407) And what is most important of all is that we want to place ourselves right with those of our countrymen who do not see eye to eye with us.
('25', 446, 1, 15, 1035546) Discharge the fatwa prisoners, discharge political prisoners against whom convictions exist or prosecutions are pending under the ordinary law or under the Criminal Law Amendment Act and the Seditious Meetings Act.
('25', 446, 1, 16, 1035761) This is what we asked for yesterday and they are the conditions which I have been urging.
('25', 446, 1, 17, 1035851) My non co operator friends will perhaps be angry that I have been yielding to the blandishments of my Moderate friends.
('25', 446, 1, 18, 1035971) If they charge me with that, I am guilty.
('25', 446, 1, 19, 1036013) (Laughter.) With reference to political prisoners convicted or under prosecution under the ordinary law, I told you yesterday that it would be the Committee to be appointed by this Conference which could decide whether all such prisoners could
('25', 447, 0, 1, 1036257) 448 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('25', 447, 1, 2, 1036299) be covered by the recommendations of this Conference, but I was borne down by the logic of facts and the pressure of friends.
('25', 447, 1, 3, 1036425) Therefore, I said, “If you want to appoint one nominee from yourselves and another from Government with power to appoint an umpire, I shall accept the proposal”.
('25', 447, 1, 4, 1036587) I hope that my non co operator friends will not be angry with me for having accepted this proposal.
('25', 447, 1, 5, 1036687) As regards the persons who have been imprisoned in virtue of the normal law of the country which has been misused or misapplied, this small Committee will consider their cases and recommend their discharge.
('25', 447, 1, 6, 1036894) I have no hesitation in feeling that in the hands of that Committee the interests of our imprisoned countrymen will be quite safe.
('25', 447, 1, 7, 1037025) You will see that in yesterday’s resolution there was a condition that activities of a hostile nature would cease today.
('25', 447, 1, 8, 1037146) I placed a phrase before the Committee in this connection and I found that I had landed myself into difficulties.
('25', 447, 1, 9, 1037260) (Laughter.) You will be surprised to find that the keen intellect of Pundit Kunzru detected a flaw in it, and that flaw put me on the proper track, and I said “No”.
('25', 447, 1, 10, 1037425) I do not want to use any phrase of a general character, not for one moment.
('25', 447, 1, 11, 1037501) Our struggle is of the purest character.
('25', 447, 1, 12, 1037542) We have nothing to conceal from the country or from the Viceroy.
('25', 447, 1, 13, 1037607) So far as I am concerned, they should all know exactly what is in our minds.
('25', 447, 1, 14, 1037684) There is the question of activities of a general hostile character to be suspended pending this Round Table Conference.
('25', 447, 1, 15, 1037804) I can only bring myself to accept a definite thing, and, therefore, in order to enter into a compromise have sacrificed the interest of a number of women of Erode (Madras) and of Mr. Lavate of Poona.
('25', 447, 1, 16, 1038004) I have said that we shall suspend even the liquor shop picketing during the time the Conference is going on.
('25', 447, 1, 17, 1038113) This sacrifice I have made in order that I can gain the other purpose that neither the Viceroy nor anybody else can charge us with breach of faith.
('25', 447, 1, 18, 1038261) Provided those conditions that are to be fulfilled by Government are accepted by Government, we shall suspend hartal, we shall suspend picketing, and we shall suspend civil disobedience.

('25', 450, 1, 2, 1043447) 208. THE LAW OF FRIENDSHIP
('25', 450, 2, 3, 1043474) Many Hindus have been offended by Maulana Hasrat Mohani’s speech about the Moplahs.
('25', 450, 2, 4, 1043558) 1 Some Congress workers in Madras have written letters 2 complaining against him.
('25', 450, 2, 5, 1043640) It would be better for the reader to pay attention to neither side.
('25', 450, 2, 6, 1043708) The Maulana takes one view while the Hindus of Malabar take another.
('25', 450, 2, 7, 1043777) The Maulana, assuming a certain state of affairs, is applying the law of war to it.
('25', 450, 2, 8, 1043861) The Hindus of Malabar have described the situation as they believe it to be, and have protested against the Maulana’s remarks.
('25', 450, 2, 9, 1043988) The Maulana considers that the Moplahs had started a jehad and, according to the rules of jehad, those who help the enemy become enemies themselves.
('25', 450, 2, 10, 1044137) The Hindus gave information to the Government’s officers and, therefore, became enemies; in such circumstances, the Moplahs would have fought even Muslims, let alone Hindus.
('25', 450, 2, 11, 1044311) The Malabar Hindus say: “The Moplah uprising cannot be called a war, or, even if it is regarded as war; Hindus, who are themselves slaves, cannot be regarded as enemies.
('25', 450, 2, 12, 1044481) Even if some Hindus, to protect their lives, reported the whereabouts of the Moplahs, they should not for that reason be regarded as enemies; if, nevertheless, they are so in the eyes of the Moplahs, at least their women and children and their temples should remain inviolate.
('25', 450, 2, 13, 1044758) All Hindus should not be regardeds enemies because of a few.
('25', 450, 2, 14, 1044819) What the Moplahs have done does not exemplify neighbourliness nor have they followed the law of war.
('25', 450, 2, 15, 1044920) Defence of the Moplahs is not justified and is likely to create suspicion in the minds of the Hindus.” I think this argument is reasonable, but I do not blame the Maulana.
('25', 450, 2, 16, 1045092) He looks upon the British Government as an enemy.
('25', 450, 2, 17, 1045142) He would defend anything done in fighting it.
('25', 450, 2, 18, 1045188) He thinks that there is much untruth in what is being said against the Moplahs and he is, therefore, not prepared to see their error.
('25', 450, 2, 19, 1045322) I believe that this is his narrowness, but it should not hurt the Hindus.
('25', 450, 2, 20, 1045396) The Maulana speaks what is in his mind.
('25', 450, 2, 21, 1045436) He is an honest and courageous man.
('25', 450, 2, 22, 1045472) All know that he has no ill will against the Hindus.
('25', 450, 3, 23, 1045525) 1 During their uprising in August 1921, the Moplahs had committed atrocities on the Hindus and Hasrat Mohani in his Presidential speech at the Muslim League session in Ahmedabad, had justified their conduct as legitimate retaliation.
('25', 450, 3, 24, 1045759) 2 For excerpts from two of these letters, vide footnote I to “Hindus and Moplahs”, 26 1 1922.
('25', 451, 0, 1, 1045853) 452 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('25', 451, 1, 2, 1045895) What he says is not out of hatred for the Hindus but out of anger against the British rule.
('25', 451, 1, 3, 1045987) What should the Hindus do in these circumstances?
('25', 451, 1, 4, 1046037) They should defend the Malabar Hindus and explain their view to the Muslims without getting angry with the Maulana or Muslims in general.
('25', 451, 1, 5, 1046175) Those Hindus who believe that some Moplahs indulged in criminal acts have a right to criticize them.
('25', 451, 1, 6, 1046276) Those Muslims who deny the charge are free to defend the Moplahs.
('25', 451, 1, 7, 1046342) Neither party speaks from first hand knowledge.
('25', 451, 1, 8, 1046390) It should be remembered, besides, that all Muslims do not argue as the Maulana has done.
('25', 451, 1, 9, 1046479) Many of them have condemned the Moplahs’ conduct.
('25', 451, 1, 10, 1046529) The Government has thoroughly exploited the Moplahs’ madness.
('25', 451, 1, 11, 1046591) They have punished the entire Moplah community for the madness of a few individuals and have incited the Hindus by exaggerating the facts.
('25', 451, 1, 12, 1046730) Malabar Hindus, like the Moplahs, are an excitable people and the Government has incited them against the latter.
('25', 451, 1, 13, 1046844) The measures which the Government has taken are not for the protection of the Hindus; they are only for its own protection.
('25', 451, 1, 14, 1046968) Both Hindus and Muslims are weak.
('25', 451, 1, 15, 1047002) It is the weak who get angry and hate others.
('25', 451, 1, 16, 1047048) The elephant does not hate the ant.
('25', 451, 1, 17, 1047084) One ant hates another ant.
('25', 451, 1, 18, 1047111) Neither the Hindus who are filled with fear because of the Moplahs’ misdeeds or the Maulana’s defence of them, nor the Muslims who, without examining the facts, rush to the defence of the Moplahs, have understood Hindu Muslim unity, which is one of the conditions [for the success of non co operation].
('25', 451, 1, 19, 1047414) Hindus should not lose hope merely on account of the misconduct of a few Muslims or the Maulana’s ignorance.
('25', 451, 1, 20, 1047523) The Muslims should stop putting up a defence like the Maulana’s.
('25', 451, 1, 21, 1047588) If, however, both sides to a quarrel could show wisdom simultaneously, would the quarrel or the bitterness ever have come about?
('25', 451, 1, 22, 1047717) There must always be two sides for a dispute to arise.
('25', 451, 1, 23, 1047772) When one party commits an error, it behoves the other to remain calm.
('25', 451, 1, 24, 1047842) Only then can Hindu Muslim unity survive.
('25', 451, 1, 25, 1047884) To remain good provided the other side remains good—this is no law of friendship, nor of war.
('25', 451, 1, 26, 1047978) It is but a bargain.
('25', 451, 1, 27, 1047999) In friendship, there is no room for bargaining.
('25', 451, 1, 28, 1048047) Friendship can exist only between brave parties and bargaining between weak parties.
('25', 451, 1, 29, 1048132) We are both weak and strong.
('25', 451, 1, 30, 1048161) Consequently, the relationship of Hindus and Muslims is both one of friendship and of bargaining.
('25', 451, 1, 31, 1048259) Let us hope that, day by day, the element of bargaining will disappear and that of friendship grow.
('25', 451, 1, 32, 1048359) Ifone side progressively purifies itself and becomes stronger, this
('25', 452, 0, 1, 1048427) VOL. 25 : 27 OCTOBER, 1921 22 JANUARY, 1922 453
('25', 452, 1, 2, 1048475) friendship will become permanent.
('25', 452, 1, 3, 1048509) Bravery does not mean browbeating others.
('25', 452, 1, 4, 1048551) He is not a brave man who uses his strength to terrorize others.
('25', 452, 1, 5, 1048616) The brave man is he who, though possessing strength, does not use it to intimidate others but, on the contrary, protects the weak.
('25', 452, 1, 6, 1048747) Can a brave man know fear?
('25', 452, 1, 7, 1048774) Muslims are physically strong.
('25', 452, 1, 8, 1048805) Even if they have the support of the whole world, Hindus should not be afraid of them but, placing their trust in God, should refrain from deviating, by a hair’s breadth, from the path of justice.
('25', 452, 1, 9, 1049002) Muslims, too, should be ashamed to seek help from outside and should trust the Hindus despite the latter’s numerical superiority.
('25', 452, 1, 10, 1049132) However, even if both sides do not act in this civilized manner and only one side does so, there need be no disruption of Hindu Muslim unity.
('25', 452, 1, 11, 1049274) That is, even if one side is firm in doing its dharma, there will be no enmity between the two.
('25', 452, 1, 12, 1049370) He alone may be said to be firm in his dharma who trusts his safety to God and, untroubled by anxiety, follows the path of virtue.
('25', 452, 1, 13, 1049501) If Hindus apply this rule to the Moplah affair, they will not, even when they see the error of the Moplahs, accuse the Muslims.
('25', 452, 1, 14, 1049629) They will help those Hindus who have suffered losses and will enable them to stand on their feet.
('25', 452, 1, 15, 1049727) Swaraj means that even if a person is in a minority of one, he may oppose the rest and be unafraid.
('25', 452, 1, 16, 1049827) Hindus should not depend wholly on the Muslims good sense.
('25', 452, 1, 17, 1049886) Nor should the Muslim be frightened by the meanness of some Hindus.
('25', 452, 1, 18, 1049954) Each community should rely on its own strength and help the other.
('25', 452, 1, 19, 1050021) Why should a single Hindu have run away on account of the Moplahs’ atrocities?
('25', 452, 1, 20, 1050100) Why should even one Hindu have reported the whereabouts of the Moplahs out of fear of the British troops?
('25', 452, 1, 21, 1050206) No Hindu was bound to report where the Moplahs had taken shelter.
('25', 452, 1, 22, 1050272) Why should a single Hindu have made a show of going through Islamic religious rites out of fear of the Moplahs?
('25', 452, 1, 23, 1050384) The rule which we follow in our fight against the British rule, viz., laying down our lives, should be followed in all cases of oppression.
('25', 452, 1, 24, 1050524) If we are ready to die at the hands of the tyrant rather than do his bidding, we shall be stronger than even the lion.
('25', 452, 1, 25, 1050643) Anyone who overpowers a tyrant by killing him will one day be tempted to become a tyrant himself, for, instead of looking to God for support, he will have learnt to depend on his own brute strength.
('25', 452, 1, 26, 1050842) A person who regards himself as God is bound to be destroyed.
('25', 452, 1, 27, 1050904) He can never be free because he has sought to usurp God’s place and, in consequence, has lost his own rightful place.
('25', 452, 1, 28, 1051022) He has yet to strive and know what he is.

('25', 453, 1, 2, 1051143) 209. MY NOTES
('25', 453, 2, 3, 1051157) A GUJARATI’S REMORSE
('25', 453, 3, 4, 1051178) If I do not admonish Gujaratis, who else will?
('25', 453, 3, 5, 1051225) I have heard that the person who had attempted to enter the Congress meeting with another’s ticket 1 now feels extremely sorry.
('25', 453, 3, 6, 1051353) I am glad to hear this.
('25', 453, 3, 7, 1051377) The incident had pained me greatly because I trusted everyone.
('25', 453, 3, 8, 1051440) After one has repented, there is no more need for shame.
('25', 453, 3, 9, 1051497) Abbas Saheb once told me a story about himself, and that too very proudly.
('25', 453, 3, 10, 1051572) Though he lived like a king, once in a light moment he felt tempted to defraud the railway.
('25', 453, 3, 11, 1051664) However light hearted, his action was theft all the same.
('25', 453, 3, 12, 1051722) He bought a second class ticket for a relation of his and put her in a first class carriage.
('25', 453, 3, 13, 1051815) The Tyabji family having become younger in spirit, now enjoy travelling third class.
('25', 453, 3, 14, 1051900) In the past, they always travelled by first class.
('25', 453, 3, 15, 1051951) When he reached home, he felt ashamed of himself.”I am the nephew of Badruddin”, he thought.”If the world hears of my dishonesty, what will it say?
('25', 453, 3, 16, 1052099) And even if my action is not known, what would Badruddin have said?
('25', 453, 3, 17, 1052167) How can I forgive myself?” Repenting thus, the gentleman returned to the station.
('25', 453, 3, 18, 1052249) Remitting money for the purpose, he sent a wire asking her to pay the excess and get the ticket changed at the next station.
('25', 453, 3, 19, 1052374) By thus spending double the amount that he would have saved by his dishonesty and publicizing his misdeed to the entire station, he atoned for his error immediately.
('25', 453, 3, 20, 1052540) He can now narrate the incident to illustrate the nobility of the Tyabji family.
('25', 453, 3, 21, 1052621) Similarly, if this friend has felt sincere remorse—and everyone tells me he has—then he has indeed escaped a great danger.
('25', 453, 3, 22, 1052744) He has no longer any reason to feel ashamed and now he serves both the country and himself with great vigilance.
('25', 453, 3, 23, 1052857) There are no degrees in purity.
('25', 453, 3, 24, 1052889) Just as all right angles are of equal magnitude, so is all purity.
('25', 453, 3, 25, 1052956) As long as there is even a trace of impurity in us, we cannot be regarded as pure.
('25', 453, 3, 26, 1053039) Therefore, when judging ourselves, we should forgive nothing.
('25', 453, 3, 27, 1053101) We have a perfect right to be merciless to ourselves, to get angry with ourselves.
('25', 453, 3, 28, 1053184) If we learn this art, our attachments and aversions, poor things, may have some rest—and it is our duty to see that they get it.

('25', 454, 2, 13, 1054177) POETIC QUALITY
('25', 454, 3, 14, 1054192) Once when I was talking with the Poet 1 about the Jallianwala Bagh Memorial and trying to persuade him to interest himself in it, he replied,”What poetry is there in it to attract me?
('25', 454, 3, 15, 1054376) Only what is poetic can have interest for me, a poet.

('25', 455, 1, 2, 1055893) why now, at the end of the Great War, England and Germany are not progressing; on the contrary, poison has spread in them.

('25', 455, 2, 24, 1057630) DESHBANDHU’S ROAD

('25', 462, 4, 12, 1072918) 213. INTERVIEW TO”THE BOMBAY CHRONICLE”
('25', 462, 5, 13, 1072958) January 17, 1922
('25', 462, 6, 14, 1072975) Mahatma Gandhi was interviewed yesterday by our representative about the letter 1 written by Sir Sankaran Nair to The Times of India in regard to the recent Round
('25', 462, 7, 15, 1073138) Table Conference held in Bombay.
('25', 462, 7, 16, 1073171) Sir Sankaran, it might be remembered, walked out of the Committee meeting owing to difference of opinion.
('25', 462, 8, 17, 1073277) The Mahatma said: I have read Sir Sankaran Nair’s letter to The Times of India with deep pain.
('25', 462, 8, 18, 1073372) It bears in itself traces of hurried draftsmanship and anger.
('25', 462, 8, 19, 1073434) I propose, therefore, not to answer seriatim the many misrepresentations it contains, but to give only broad facts.
('25', 462, 8, 20, 1073550) Between the Conference and myself there was perfect harmony in spite of differences of opinion.
('25', 462, 8, 21, 1073646) I make bold to say that on matters
('25', 462, 9, 22, 1073681) 1 For excerpts from the letter, vide Appendix I.
('25', 463, 0, 1, 1073730) 464 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('25', 463, 1, 2, 1073772) that were not of vital importance I yielded without hesitation.
('25', 463, 1, 3, 1073836) The resolutions are the result of mutual discussion and deliberations.
('25', 463, 1, 4, 1073907) It is undoubtedly true that I want the Government to bepenitent, not in order to humiliate it, but in order to set it right with the people, and there will, certainly, be no peace in the land and no settlement until the Government acknowledges its mistakes and retraces its steps.
('25', 463, 1, 5, 1074188) The resolutions are calculated to enable the Government to do so gracefully.
('25', 463, 1, 6, 1074265) Nobody questions the right of the Government to put down violence.
('25', 463, 1, 7, 1074332) Sir Sankaran forgets what I said in reply to Mr. Jehangir B. Petit, namely, that I could conceive even the existence of justifiable martial law, when it is introduced to protect people and has the endorsement of public opinion.
('25', 463, 1, 8, 1074560) The present proceedings of the Government, which bear all the characteristics of martial law, without the odium of the name, are intended neither to protect the people, nor have any public backing whatsoever.
('25', 463, 1, 9, 1074769) They are intended to consolidate the power of an utterly irresponsible bureaucracy.
('25', 463, 1, 10, 1074853) The Khilafat claim certainly includes the evacuation of Syria by the French, but Sir Sankaran should remember what I said.
('25', 463, 1, 11, 1074976) I declared in the clearest possible language that I would be satisfied if Great Britain sincerely supported the Mussulman claim regarding Syria.
('25', 463, 1, 12, 1075121) I said that the Mussulmans, and I, in common with them, thoroughly distrusted Great Britain’s intentions regarding the aspiration of Turkish Nationalists and the just claims of Indian Mussulmans.
('25', 463, 1, 13, 1075317) It is open in a round table conference to the Government to demonstrate to the satisfaction of non co operators that Great Britain is ready to do all in her power to satisfy the Mussulman claim.
('25', 463, 1, 14, 1075512) Sir Sankaran hardly does justice to himself, or to me, when he reports me as having said that I wanted the evacuation of Egypt, as a term of peace.
('25', 463, 1, 15, 1075660) In answer to an ejaculation about Egypt I remarked that although the Khilafat demand did not, and would not include the evacuation of Egypt, when India had full swaraj she could certainly not permit a single Indian soldier to leave India in order to coerce the brave Egyptians into submission to a foreign yoke.
('25', 463, 1, 16, 1075972) Sir Sankaran’s attack upon the Ali Brothers is hardly worthy of him.
('25', 463, 1, 17, 1076041) The Ali Brothers do believe in the possibility and necessity of the use of violence for the vindication of religious or national rights.
('25', 463, 1, 18, 1076178) But, I know that they are absolutely at one with the Congress programme and that they are more than ever convinced that as India is circumstanced, non violence is the only remedy open to her for the attainment of her freedom.
('25', 464, 0, 1, 1076404) VOL. 25 : 27 OCTOBER, 1921 22 JANUARY, 1922 465
('25', 464, 1, 2, 1076452) Sir Sankaran ought to know better than to impute to me a promise of swaraj within one year.
('25', 464, 1, 3, 1076544) If I had made any such promise I would not have kept my head on my shoulders.
('25', 464, 1, 4, 1076622) All that I said was that India could have swaraj within one year, less time, if she fulfilled the conditions categorically named at Calcutta 1 and repeated at Nagpur 2 in 1920.
('25', 464, 2, 5, 1076799) Lastly let me correct Sir Sankaran by saying that the case of the Ali Brothers does not fall within the reference to the arbitration, but, being included among the fatwa cases, falls in the same category as imprisonments in virtue of the recent notifications.
('25', 464, 2, 6, 1077059) It surprises me to notice that Sir Sankaran imagines that a round table conference is possible without the presence of the Ali Brothers.
('25', 464, 2, 7, 1077196) That the Government might not see its way to release such formidable opponents as the Ali Brothers.
('25', 464, 2, 8, 1077296) I can well understand, and they will release them only if Government desires to placate Indian opinion and substitute the force of public opinion for the force of arms.
('25', 464, 3, 9, 1077465) The Bombay Chronicle, 18 1 1922
('25', 464, 4, 10, 1077497) 214. THE MALAVIYA CONFERENCE
('25', 464, 5, 11, 1077526) The Conference was both a success and a failure.
('25', 464, 5, 12, 1077575) It was a success in that it showed an earnest desire on the part of those who attended to secure a peaceful solution of the present trouble, and in that it brought under one roof people possessing divergent views.
('25', 464, 5, 13, 1077789) It was a failure in that, though certain resolutions have been adopted, the Conference did not leave on my mind the impression that those who assembled together as a whole realized the gravity of the real issue.
('25', 464, 5, 14, 1078001) The mind of the Conference seemed to be centred more on a round table conference than upon asserting the popular right of free speech, free association and free Press which are more than a round table conference.
('25', 464, 5, 15, 1078214) I had expected on the part of the Independents to declare their firm attitude that no matter how much they might differ regarding the method of non co operation, the freedom of the people was a common heritage and that the assertion of that right was three fourths of swaraj; that, therefore, they would defend that right even with civil disobedience, if need be.
('25', 464, 6, 16, 1078578) 1 In the Congress session held in September 2 ibid
('25', 465, 0, 1, 1078629) 466 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('25', 465, 1, 2, 1078671) However, as the attention of the Conference could not be riveted on that point but on a round table conference, the discussion turned upon the essentials of such a conference.
('25', 465, 2, 3, 1078847) My own position was clear.
('25', 465, 2, 4, 1078874) I would attend any conference as an individual, without any conditions.
('25', 465, 2, 5, 1078946) My purpose as a reformeris to convert people to the view I hold to be right and therefore to see everybody who would care to listen to me.
('25', 465, 2, 6, 1079085) But when I was asked to mention the conditions necessary for an atmosphere favourable for a successful conference, I had to press home certain conditions.
('25', 465, 2, 7, 1079240) And I must own that the Resolutions Committee approached my viewpoint with the greatest sympathy and showed every anxiety to accommodate me.
('25', 465, 2, 8, 1079381) But side by side with this, I observed an admirable disposition on its part to consider the Government’s difficulties.
('25', 465, 2, 9, 1079500) Indeed the Government’s case could not have been better presented, if it had been directly and officially represented in the Conference.
('25', 465, 3, 10, 1079637) The result was a compromise.
('25', 465, 3, 11, 1079666) The withdrawal of notifications and the discharge of prisoners coming under the notifications and of the fatwa prisoners, i.e., the Ali Brothers and others who have been convicted in respect of the fatwas regarding military service, was common cause.
('25', 465, 3, 12, 1079917) The Committee saw the force of the suggestions that the distress warrants should be discharged, the fines imposed upon the Press, etc., should be refunded and that the prisoners convicted for non violent or otherwise innocent activities under cover of the ordinary laws should be discharged upon the proof of their non violence.
('25', 465, 3, 13, 1080246) For this purpose I had suggested the Committee appointed by the Conference.
('25', 465, 3, 14, 1080322) But on the Resolutions Committee showing that it would be difficult for the Government to accept such an uncontrolled recommendation, I agreed to the principle of arbitration now imported in the resolution.
('25', 465, 3, 15, 1080529) The second compromise is regarding picketing.
('25', 465, 3, 16, 1080575) My suggestion was that in the event of the round table conference being decided upon, non co operation activities of a hostile nature should be suspended and that all picketing except bona fide peaceful picketing should also be suspended, pending the result of the Conference.
('25', 465, 3, 17, 1080852) As the implications of hostile activities appeared to me to be too dangerous to be acceptable, I hastily withdrew my own wording and gladly threw over even bona fide peaceful picketing, much though I regretted it.
('25', 465, 3, 18, 1081066) I felt that the friends interested in liquor picketing for the sake of temperance would not mind the temporary sacrifice.
('25', 466, 0, 1, 1081188) VOL. 25 : 27 OCTOBER, 1921 22 JANUARY, 1922 467
('25', 466, 1, 2, 1081236) I agreed too to advise the Working Committee to postpone general mass civil disobedience contemplated by the Congress to the 31st instant in order to enable the Committee and the Conference to enter into negotiations with the Government.
('25', 466, 1, 3, 1081474) This, I felt, was essential to show our bona fides.
('25', 466, 1, 4, 1081526) We could not take up new offensives whilst negotiations for a conference were being conducted by responsible men.
('25', 466, 1, 5, 1081640) I further undertook to advise the Committee, in the event of the proposed conference coming off, to stop all hartals, pending the Conference.
('25', 466, 1, 6, 1081782) This I hold to be inevitable.

('25', 467, 2, 5, 1083995) THE DEMANDS
('25', 467, 3, 6, 1084007) In order that all may approach the Round Table Conference with perfect knowledge of the Congress demands, I laid all our cards on the table and reiterated the claims regarding the Khilafat, the Punjab and swaraj.
('25', 467, 3, 7, 1084220) Let me repeat them here: 1. So far as I can write from memory, full restoration to the Turks of Constantinople, Adrianople, Anatolia including Smyrna and Thrace.
('25', 467, 3, 8, 1084382) Complete withdrawal of non Muslim influence from Arabia, Mesopotamia, Palestine and Syria and, therefore, withdrawal of British troops, whether English or Indian, from these territories.
('25', 467, 3, 9, 1084569) 2. Full enforcement of the report of the Congress Sub committee 1 and, therefore, the stopping of the pensions of Sir Michael O’Dwyer, General Dyer and other officers named in the report for dismissal.
('25', 467, 4, 10, 1084771) 3. Swaraj means, in the event of the foregoing demands being granted, full Dominion Status.
('25', 467, 4, 11, 1084863) The scheme of such swaraj should be framed by representatives duly elected in terms of the Congress constitution.
('25', 467, 4, 12, 1084977) That means four anna franchise.
('25', 467, 4, 13, 1085009) Every Indian adult, male or female, paying four annas and signing the Congress Creed, will be entitled to be placed on the electoral roll.
('25', 467, 4, 14, 1085148) These electors would elect delegates who would frame the swaraj constitution.
('25', 467, 4, 15, 1085226) This shall be given effect to without any change by the British Parliament.
('25', 467, 4, 16, 1085302) “If the Congress programme is so cut and dried, where is the necessity for a conference?”—asks the critic.
('25', 467, 4, 17, 1085409) I hold that there is and there always will be.
('25', 467, 4, 18, 1085456) The method of execution of the demands has to be considered.
('25', 467, 4, 19, 1085517) The Government may have a reasonable and a convincing answer on the claims.
('25', 467, 4, 20, 1085593) The Congressmen have fixed their minimum, but the fixing of the minimum means no more than confidence in the justice of one’s cause.
('25', 467, 4, 21, 1085726) It further means that there is no room for bargaining.
('25', 467, 5, 22, 1085781) 1 Appointed to enquire into the Punjab disorders of April 1919. For its report, vide””Congress Report on the PunjabDisorders”, On or Before 25 3 1920.

('25', 468, 1, 2, 1085980) There can, therefore, be no appeal to one’s weakness or incapacity.
('25', 468, 1, 3, 1086048) The appeal can only be addressed to reason.
('25', 468, 1, 4, 1086092) If the Viceroy summons the conference, it means either that he recognizes the justice of the claims or hopes to satisfy the Congressmen, among others, of the injustice thereof.
('25', 468, 1, 5, 1086269) He must be confident of the justice of his proposals for a rejection or reduction of the claim.
('25', 468, 1, 6, 1086365) That is my meaning of a meeting of equals who eliminate the idea of force, and instantly shift their ground as they appreciate the injustice of their position.
('25', 468, 1, 7, 1086525) I assure His Excellency the Viceroy and everybody concerned that the Congressmen or non co operators are as reasonable beings as may be found on earth or in India.
('25', 468, 1, 8, 1086689) They have every incentive to be so for theirs is the duty of suffering as a result of rejection of any just offer.
('25', 468, 1, 9, 1086804) I have heard it urged that on the Khilafat the Imperial Government is powerless.
('25', 468, 1, 10, 1086885) I should like to be convinced of this.
('25', 468, 1, 11, 1086924) In that case, and if the Imperial Government make common cause with the Mussulmans of India, I should be quite satisfied and take the chance with the Imperial Government’s genuine assistance of convincing the other powers of the justice of the Khilafat claim.
('25', 468, 1, 12, 1087184) And even when the claim is admitted much requires to be discussed regarding the execution.

('25', 468, 2, 14, 1087307) The principle being granted, the details have to be settled.
('25', 468, 2, 15, 1087368) Legal difficulties have been urged about stopping the pensions to the dismissed officials.

('25', 468, 2, 17, 1087640) I believe that service regulations do provide for removing officers and officials from the pensions list on proof of gross neglect of duty or disloyal service.
('25', 468, 2, 18, 1087800) Anyway, let the Government prove a case for refusal to grant the Punjab demand save the plea of the past services of these officials.
('25', 468, 2, 19, 1087934) I must refuse to weigh their service to the Empire against their disservice to India, assuming the possibility of two such things coexisting.
('25', 468, 3, 20, 1088076) The swaraj scheme is undoubtedly a matter on which there will be as many minds as there are men and women.
('25', 468, 3, 21, 1088183) And it is eminently a thing to be debated in a conference.
('25', 468, 3, 22, 1088242) But here again there must be a clean mind and no mental reservations.
('25', 468, 3, 23, 1088312) India’s freedom must be the supreme interest in everybody’s mind.
('25', 468, 3, 24, 1088378) There should be no obstruction such as the preoccupation of the British elector or the indifference of the House of Commons or the hostility of the House
