('25', 470, 4, 10, 1091969) 215. WORSE THAN MARTIAL LAW
('25', 470, 5, 11, 1091997) For the time that savage repression continues, I must fill the pages of Young India with authentic tales of repression till India puts an end to it by an act of supreme sacrifice.
('25', 470, 5, 12, 1092177) I call the repression savage because it is wooden, wild, uncultivated, cruel.
('25', 470, 5, 13, 1092255) Grant that there is intimidation and even violence resorted to by some non co operators in pursuit of hartal or other activity.
('25', 470, 5, 14, 1092383) Is it difficult to find and punish the culprits?
('25', 470, 5, 15, 1092432) If the Government cannot get witnesses, does it not show that the whole populace is behind the so called intimidation?
('25', 470, 5, 16, 1092551) An act, however reprehensible in itself, when it becomes the act of a people, ceases to be a crime capable of being dealt with by its laws.
('25', 470, 5, 17, 1092691) Therefore, repression by an irresponsible government can never be a popular act or an act designed for the safety of the people.
('25', 470, 5, 18, 1092820) But in the present instance, repression is designed to suppress the rising agitation directed against the misdeeds of the Government and is, therefore, doubly unpardonable.
('25', 470, 5, 19, 1092993) However, it is not the purpose of this article to demonstrate its unjustifiable character, but to demonstrate its brutal quality, to show that it is worse than martial law.
('25', 470, 5, 20, 1093166) The Punjab martial law was comparatively a civilized measure and being so named at least served the purpose of producing a shock.

('25', 474, 4, 22, 1101440) I hold the firing by the cinema man to be justifiable inasmuch as his theatre would have been destroyed if he had not fired.
('25', 474, 4, 23, 1101565) The mob’s increased fury was an exhibition of insolent rage against deserved punishment.
('25', 474, 4, 24, 1101654) The investment of Sir Thyagaraj Chettiar’s house was a cowardly inter ference with personal liberty.
('25', 474, 4, 25, 1101755) The crowd that prevented the knight from doing honour to the Prince dishonoured itself and enhanced the value of the honour Sir Thyagaraj Chettiar was prevented from doing.
('25', 474, 4, 26, 1101928) It might be the crowd’s way, but it was not non co operators’ way of”doing business”.
('25', 474, 5, 27, 1102014) Dr. Rajan and his lieutenants left no stone unturned to make and keep the hartal peaceful.
('25', 474, 5, 28, 1102105) All honour to them.
('25', 474, 5, 29, 1102125) But Madras teaches us a lesson as Bombay has.
('25', 474, 5, 30, 1102171) We have still much work to do before we can really establish a swaraj atmosphere.
('25', 474, 5, 31, 1102253) Either we believe in a successful peaceful revolution or we believe that non violence is merely a preparation for violence.
('25', 474, 5, 32, 1102377) If the latter represents the true state of things,
('25', 475, 0, 1, 1102428) 476 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('25', 475, 1, 2, 1102470) we must revise our creed.
('25', 475, 1, 3, 1102496) But I am optimistic enough to believe that India has imbibed the spirit of non violence in a most remarkable way.
('25', 475, 1, 4, 1102610) The exemplary self restraint exercised in Amritsar, Lahore, Aligarh, Allahabad, Calcutta, Barisal and other places too numerous to mention, shows that where only pledged non co operators work, we can rely upon non violence being observed, but where, as in Madras, an undisciplined mob gathers together, non co operators have no control.
('25', 475, 1, 5, 1102947) We must not despair of devising a remedy against repetition of the Madras hooliganism.
('25', 475, 1, 6, 1103034) Equally unfortunate is the attack in Hardoi upon Mr. Baker who has fortunately escaped death.
('25', 475, 1, 7, 1103128) The stray maniacs are most difficult to trace or handle.
('25', 475, 1, 8, 1103185) I doubt not that it is the work of some unknown person unconnected with non co operation.
('25', 475, 1, 9, 1103275) But we must deal with such cases also.
('25', 475, 1, 10, 1103314) In a non violent atmosphere such occurrences must be almost impossible.
('25', 475, 1, 11, 1103386) But it must be confessed that the requisite atmosphere has not yet been reached.
('25', 475, 1, 12, 1103467) It will only be, when we have eradicated violence from our thoughts.
('25', 475, 2, 13, 1103536) Young India, 19 1 1922
('25', 475, 3, 14, 1103559) 218. N0TES
('25', 475, 4, 15, 1103570) NON PAYMENT OF TAXES
('25', 475, 5, 16, 1103591) I observe a desire in some places to precipitate mass civil disobedience by suspending payment of taxes.
('25', 475, 5, 17, 1103696) But I would urge the greatest caution before embarking upon the dangerous adventure, We must not be indifferent about violence, and we must make sure of masses exercising self control whilst they are witnesses to the confiscation of their crops and cattle or forfeiture of their holdings.
('25', 475, 5, 18, 1103985) I know that withholding of payment of taxes is one of the quickest methods of overthrowing a government.
('25', 475, 5, 19, 1104090) I am equally sure that we have not yet evolved that degree of strength and discipline which are necessary for conducting a successful campaign of non payment of taxes.
('25', 475, 5, 20, 1104258) Not a single tahsil in India is yet ready, except perhaps Bardoli and to a lesser degree Anand.
('25', 475, 5, 21, 1104354) More than fifty per cent of the population of such tahsil has to rid itself of the curse of untouchability, must be dressed in khadi manufactured in the tahsil, must be non violent in thought, word and deed, and must be living in perfect friendliness with all whether co operators or non co operators.
('25', 475, 5, 22, 1104656) Non payment of taxes without the necessary discipline will be an act of unpardonable madness.
('25', 475, 5, 23, 1104750) Instead of leading to swaraj, it is likely to
('25', 476, 0, 1, 1104796) VOL. 25 : 27 OCTOBER, 1921 22 JANUARY, 1922 477
('25', 476, 1, 2, 1104844) lead to no raj.
('25', 476, 1, 3, 1104860) I must, therefore, repeat the caution I have so often uttered that mass civil disobedience ought not to be tried in the first instance, except under my personal supervision, and certainly never without the fulfilment of the conditions laid down at Delhi 1
('25', 476, 2, 4, 1105116) “SARKAR SALAAM”
('25', 476, 3, 5, 1105132) I have reproduced the letter from Sind, showing what is required of prisoners in Hyderabad.
('25', 476, 3, 6, 1105224) 2 A telegram has been received from Noakhali, enquiring whether non co operation prisoners should utter the formula”Sarkar Salaam”.
('25', 476, 3, 7, 1105356) In my opinion that formula, as also Sarkar ek hai, is degrading, and the latter is even profane.
('25', 476, 3, 8, 1105453) No religiously minded person can say or believe: Sarkar is only one!
('25', 476, 3, 9, 1105522) That can be said only of God, and Him alone.
('25', 476, 3, 10, 1105567) Therefore, whilst I would advise political prisoners to conform to the jail regulations in so far as they are intended to keep discipline, they must evenat the risk of their lives resist all degrading practices which may be imposed in the name of discipline.
('25', 476, 3, 11, 1105826) Similar to the”Sarkar Salaam” formula is the practice of stretching forth the palm of one’s hands in front of officials or that of sitting in a crouching posture.
('25', 476, 3, 12, 1105989) These things may be necessary for dangerous criminals, but a non co operator must not be expected to conform to such unmanly exhibitions of themselves.
('25', 476, 4, 13, 1106141) NEW SPINNING WHEEL
('25', 476, 5, 14, 1106160) An improved spinning wheel with many spindles was exhibited at the Ahmedabad exhibition.
('25', 476, 5, 15, 1106249) It is perhaps the most successful of all efforts.
('25', 476, 5, 16, 1106299) But I warn the public against waiting for revolutionary inventions.
('25', 476, 5, 17, 1106367) The existing charkha is perfect of its type.
('25', 476, 5, 18, 1106412) In the interest of economy of mental effort and national time, I would urge lovers of swadeshi to forget improved charkhas that are expected to give much larger output of yarn than the ancient type.
('25', 476, 5, 19, 1106611) Let all energy be devoted to making the ancient pattern more durable and cheap and portable.

('25', 479, 3, 6, 1111863) Money should be provided so long as the intentions are not dishonest.
('25', 479, 3, 7, 1111933) We are not providing from the special fund because something must be done by the Provincial Committee also.

('25', 479, 3, 11, 1112339) Hence we should forget the temple and remember that the money is to be paid only for helping the Harijan cause.

('25', 480, 1, 2, 1113255) 223. WHERE IS SWARAJ?
('25', 480, 2, 3, 1113277) After the arrest of Lalaji, Das, Nehru and Maulana Abul Kalam, God knows what happened, but people have ceased to ask,”Where is swaraj?” My anxiety has disappeared and I feel that nobody will henceforth ask me for any explanation.
('25', 480, 2, 4, 1113508) People have started sending wires:”Congratulations on attainment of swaraj.” Paul Richard came and spoke on December 31 as if a new era had dawned.
('25', 480, 2, 5, 1113656) Pearson wrote from Shantiniketan saying that, on returning after an absence of five years, he found that India had become free.
('25', 480, 3, 6, 1113784) Swaraj is a state of the mind.
('25', 480, 3, 7, 1113815) When it becomes permanent, swaraj will take visible shape.
('25', 480, 3, 8, 1113874) But, the state of mind having changed, it has already arrived.
('25', 480, 4, 9, 1113937) Although I never let go an opportunity for a settlement, I am hesitant to seek one now after discovering India’s strength.
('25', 480, 4, 10, 1114060) If there is a political settlement before we have developed our full strength, what will be our fate?
('25', 480, 4, 11, 1114162) Such a settlement will be like a baby born before its time and dying soon after.
('25', 480, 4, 12, 1114243) There was an overnight revolution in Portugal and a new government was established with the result that revolutions followed one another and there was no stable government.
('25', 480, 4, 13, 1114416) Everybody congratulated Turkey when there was a sudden change of government there in 1906. It, however, turned out to be a short lived affair.
('25', 480, 4, 14, 1114559) The revolution came and vanished like a dream.
('25', 480, 4, 15, 1114606) Turkey has had to suffer much since then and no one knows how much more still its brave people will have to suffer.
('25', 480, 5, 16, 1114722) With these experiences in my mind, 1 feel perplexed and do not know what is good.
('25', 480, 5, 17, 1114804) At this juncture, I positively shake with fear.
('25', 480, 5, 18, 1114852) If there is a settlement, who knows where it will lead us?
('25', 480, 6, 19, 1114911) People have not yet realized clearly that swaraj can be secured with the help of a contrivance which even an inexperienced village carpenter can make and which an innocent and tender girl can operate.
('25', 480, 6, 20, 1115112) As days pass, however, I get more convinced that India will win freedom only though this machine and in no other way.
('25', 480, 6, 21, 1115230) Have we been convinced, even now, that the real education of the people consists not in literacy but in building up character and in learning to use one’s hands and feet—to work with the body?
('25', 480, 6, 22, 1115423) Parents even in Gujarat have not overcome their hankering after literacy.
('25', 480, 6, 23, 1115497) They, too, have not yet recognized the right place of literacy ineducation and do sot concede that children should first be taught
('25', 481, 0, 1, 1115628) 482 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('25', 481, 1, 2, 1115670) respect for moral rules, then comes the training of their bodies and proficiency in some craft which will secure them their livelihood, and then the training of the intellect, instruction in the three R’s by way of embellishment.
('25', 481, 1, 3, 1115900) Abbas Saheb informs me that most parents are simply unwilling to withdraw their children from the Government high school at Nadiad.
('25', 481, 1, 4, 1116032) All parents in Gujarat are not yet ready to send their children to the national schools which inculcate a better outlook in them, or to appreciate the value of the training in freedom which they impart.
('25', 481, 1, 5, 1116235) As regards lawyers, the position is worse still.
('25', 481, 1, 6, 1116284) Have they overcome their infatuation for law courts?
('25', 481, 1, 7, 1116337) Have we started settling our disputes among ourselves?
('25', 481, 1, 8, 1116392) Have the lawyers realized that justice should not be costly?
('25', 481, 1, 9, 1116453) Even now, religious leaders who are considered to be pillars of their respective faiths hope to secure justice in the Privy Council in disputes concerning their religious affairs.
('25', 481, 1, 10, 1116633) Lawyers have not yet overcome the allurement of fat fees and, in consequence, the cost of justice continues to be counted in terms of gold and guineas.
('25', 481, 1, 11, 1116785) If there is a settlement today, we shall not have suffered to the very soul and, after the settlement, who will be interested in these matters?
('25', 481, 1, 12, 1116929) The law courts will carry on as they are doing today.
('25', 481, 1, 13, 1116983) How, then, shall we establish Ramarajya?
('25', 481, 1, 14, 1117024) In Ramarajya, justice cannot be sold.
('25', 481, 1, 15, 1117062) Have the Hindus and Muslims achieved complete unity?
('25', 481, 1, 16, 1117115) Has their mutual distrust disappeared?
('25', 481, 1, 17, 1117154) Is there an identity of ideals in regard to the future of the country?
('25', 481, 1, 18, 1117225) Both have realized the need for friendship, but their hearts have not yet united; they are in the process of being united.
('25', 481, 1, 19, 1117348) If there is a settlement, this process will be interrupted.
('25', 481, 1, 20, 1117408) It is, therefore, fruitless to talk of freedom as long as the two have not united.
('25', 481, 1, 21, 1117491) As long as the truth about the self Is not understood, Your spiritual effort Has not borne fruit.
('25', 481, 2, 22, 1117589) These lines are completely true about swaraj.
('25', 481, 2, 23, 1117635) We may substitute”swaraj” for self and we shall clearly see how.
('25', 481, 2, 24, 1117700) We have yet to understand the meaning of the different aspects of swaraj.
('25', 481, 2, 25, 1117774) If Hindu Muslim unity means enmity towards Parsis, Christians or Jews,
('25', 481, 3, 26, 1117845) 1 The lines are from a poem by Narasinh Mehta.
('25', 482, 0, 1, 1117892) VOL. 25 : 27 OCTOBER, 1921 22 JANUARY, 1922 483
('25', 482, 1, 2, 1117940) that unity will be a curse for the world.
('25', 482, 1, 3, 1117982) So long, therefore, as we have not fully understood the meaning of Hindu Muslim unity, the very desire for settlement is wrong.
('25', 482, 2, 4, 1118110) Have we, besides, imbibed the spirit of non violence, which is the prerequisite of dedicated effort?
('25', 482, 2, 5, 1118211) Have we accepted the fact that our peaceful non co operation is a sign of strength?
('25', 482, 2, 6, 1118295) We still regard our non violence to be the weapon of the weak, do not recognize its real worth and so we bring discredit to it.
('25', 482, 2, 7, 1118423) This is as foolish as giving away a guinea taking it to be a half rupee coin.
('25', 482, 2, 8, 1118501) Non violence is a weapon of the strong and is respected only when employed by them.
('25', 482, 2, 9, 1118585) Non violence means forgiveness and this is the glory of the brave.
('25', 482, 2, 10, 1118652) He who does not eat because he has no appetite does not acquire the merit of fasting.
('25', 482, 2, 11, 1118738) If someone does not kill because he cannot kill, he practises no virtue.
('25', 482, 2, 12, 1118811) There can be no virtue in anything done unwillingly.
('25', 482, 2, 13, 1118864) When the fighters who are getting ready in Bardoli and Anand do not harass or do not harbour ill will against any Parsi or Englishman or any other person co operating with the Government, then only will they be considered fit to be enrolled in a non violent army.
('25', 482, 2, 14, 1119128) One who uses non violence as a cover for violent thoughts is not only a traitor to his own country but to the entire world, because the world is watching intently, like a person thirsting for water, our experiment with the weapon of non violence.
('25', 482, 2, 15, 1119375) As long as the country has not learnt to regard non violence as a weapon of the strong, we should look upon a settlement as something which will defile us and we should keep miles away from it.
('25', 482, 3, 16, 1119569) What shall I say, moreover, to Hindu readers?
('25', 482, 3, 17, 1119615) Though I regard myself to be a devout Hindu, I make bold to say that, as long as Hindus do not treat Dheds and Bhangis as their own blood brothers, they are not themselves Hindus.
('25', 482, 3, 18, 1119795) There will be a shower of flowers from the heavens when caste Hindus embrace Bhangis with affection.
('25', 482, 3, 19, 1119896) Then alone will the cow receive real protection.
('25', 482, 3, 20, 1119945) Compassion and hatred of man by man cannot go hand in hand.
('25', 482, 3, 21, 1120005) The shortcomings of Dheds and Bhangis have to be overcome through love.
('25', 482, 3, 22, 1120077) The words of Anandshankar Dhruva always ring in my ears.
('25', 482, 3, 23, 1120134) Our enemies are the Dheds and Bhangis in our hearts.
('25', 482, 3, 24, 1120187) They are the real untouchables.
('25', 482, 3, 25, 1120219) The human beings in flesh and blood, whom we commit the sin of treating as untouchable, are our kith and kin.
('25', 482, 3, 26, 1120329) We should mix with them andserve them and thereby earn the merit which accrues to virtuous
('25', 483, 0, 1, 1120420) 484 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('25', 483, 1, 2, 1120462) If a Vaishnava 1 sucks out poison injected by the bite of a serpent into the body of a Dhed or a Bhangi and afterwards enters a temple without taking a bath, even the temple will be sanctified.
('25', 483, 1, 3, 1120656) It would be like Sudama 2 or Vidura 3 visiting Krishna at his home.
('25', 483, 1, 4, 1120724) As long as we have not plucked out the weed of untouchability or have not understood, as Anandshankar Dhruva has done, the real meaning of untouchability, we should not even think of a settlement.
('25', 483, 1, 5, 1120921) We can fulfil these great tasks and purify ourselves only by suffering.
('25', 483, 1, 6, 1120993) He alone who is prepared to die for liberation can attain it.
('25', 483, 1, 7, 1121055) Those who do not welcome their death go to miserable worlds.
('25', 483, 1, 8, 1121116) One who dies voluntarily becomes fit for liberation.
('25', 483, 1, 9, 1121169) Similarly, if we steadfastly cling to the means indicated above, give up the fear of death, then, and then only, shall we win freedom—swaraj.
('25', 483, 1, 10, 1121311) Das, Lalaji, Motilalji, Abul Kalam Azad and others are teaching us the mantra of dying willingly.
('25', 483, 1, 11, 1121409) It seems we have learnt that lesson, and so no one asks the question,”Where is swaraj?” Everyone says that, now that we have the strength to die willingly, we have won swaraj.
('25', 483, 1, 12, 1121585) The rest is all a mirage.
('25', 483, 2, 13, 1121611) [From Gujarati]

('25', 487, 1, 2, 1129859) 225. MISERY IN HAPPINESS
('25', 487, 2, 3, 1129884) One who has a conscience and thinks cannot easily get bodily happiness.
('25', 487, 2, 4, 1129956) He is oppressed by the misery of others and pines away.
('25', 487, 2, 5, 1130012) He cannot bear to see the suffering round him.
('25', 487, 2, 6, 1130059) Such a pitiable condition is Mahadev Desai’s, for, he tries to judge the rightness of every action of his.
('25', 487, 2, 7, 1130166) He was happy as long as he was suffering physically, since he had been all too eager to go to jail in order that he might suffer.
('25', 487, 2, 8, 1130296) But now that he is happy in jail and the jailor is favourably inclined, he suffers inwardly.
('25', 487, 2, 9, 1130389) Others are more or less in the same plight as Mahadev Desai.
('25', 487, 2, 10, 1130450) The discussion which has started in the Agra Central Jail, 1 where all the non co operators have been brought together, could not have taken place when these same prisoners were themselves suffering and were even sometimes flogged.
('25', 487, 2, 11, 1130682) At that time, they had a glimpse of the sun of swaraj peeping from behind the mountain of suffering and they used to forget their pain in the warmth of its rays.
('25', 487, 2, 12, 1130844) But now, when they have swaraj in jail, enjoy some freedom, these freebooters in the army of swaraj are fighting among themselves just as robbers fight for a share of the booty.
('25', 487, 2, 13, 1131022) The description of the fight had better be read in Mahadev Desai’s own words.
('25', 487, 2, 14, 1131100) I have not reproduced every word of the letter, as I did in the case of the previous letter, but have omitted certain sentences and given only the relevant part.
('25', 487, 2, 15, 1131262) It was written on the 15th.
('25', 487, 3, 16, 1131290) There is a lot for us to learn from this letter.
('25', 487, 3, 17, 1131339) Mahadev Desai’s letter clearly shows that after we have secured power, we shall not be able to maintain the propriety and the restraint which we have been showing during the struggle.
('25', 487, 4, 18, 1131523) Let us recognize that there is a great difference between power and swaraj.
('25', 487, 4, 19, 1131599) At present, most of us are fighting merely for power and authority.
('25', 487, 4, 20, 1131667) In this scramble, I see obstacles and impediments in our path.
('25', 487, 4, 21, 1131730) I see violence coming out of it.
('25', 487, 4, 22, 1131763) In the struggle for swaraj, there can be only healthy rivalry.
('25', 487, 4, 23, 1131826) Swaraj means self rule, rule over oneself.
('25', 487, 4, 24, 1131869) In this struggle, he wins who bends and bears.
('25', 487, 4, 25, 1131916) It requires great self restraint.
('25', 487, 4, 26, 1131950) In a scramble for power, everyone wants to be the first, so everyone fights against everyoneelse.
('25', 487, 4, 27, 1132048) Under autocratic rule, the foremost wins; under swaraj, on the contrary, the hindmost wins.
('25', 487, 5, 28, 1132140) 1 Whether they should agitate against distinctions of class among political prisoners arrested in connection with the non co operation movement

('25', 488, 4, 8, 1133105) 226. MY NOTES
('25', 488, 5, 9, 1133119) “THERE IS ONLY ONE GOVERNMENT”
('25', 488, 6, 10, 1133150) There is a letter from Sind which contains the news that prisoners in jails are made to say,”There is only one Government”, and the words are shouted from a distance when some official visits the jail and the prisoner is obliged to stand up.
('25', 488, 6, 11, 1133392) News has been received from another place that prisoners are made to shout,”Salutation to the Government”.
('25', 488, 6, 12, 1133499) Jairamdas of Sind, who is in the Sabarmati Jail, was ordered to hold his arms down, palms outwards, and stand up, when any official approached him.
('25', 488, 6, 13, 1133647) He disobeyed the order and hence the permission granted to him to read newspapers has been withdrawn.
('25', 488, 6, 14, 1133749) In some other place, a prisoner is asked to bow down his head, put his hands on the floor and stay in that uncomfortable position.
('25', 488, 6, 15, 1133880) It has been asked whether a non co operator prisoner should obey such orders.
('25', 488, 6, 16, 1133958) Doubts have arisen in people’s minds because of the article 2 on the model prisoner which appeared in Young India.
('25', 488, 6, 17, 1134073) The matter is easily decided.
('25', 488, 6, 18, 1134103) It is our principle never to obey any rule
('25', 488, 7, 19, 1134146) 1 Mahadev Desai had started group prayers in the manner of the Satyagraha Ashram at Ahmedabad and some prisoners had objected to the inclusion of Sanskrit verses.
('25', 488, 7, 20, 1134309) 2 Vide”A Model Prisoner”, 29 12 1921.

('25', 489, 1, 2, 1134389) which inflicts humiliation or which is intended to insult our manhood.
('25', 489, 1, 3, 1134460) Certain things can never be permitted in jail.
('25', 489, 1, 4, 1134507) Generally, the prisoners are rough people who are in jail for crimes involving moral turpitude.
('25', 489, 1, 5, 1134603) It is only now that prisons have become a gateway to freedom.
('25', 489, 1, 6, 1134665) The jails, therefore, have certain rules to which lovers of liberty will never submit.
('25', 489, 2, 7, 1134752) If a statement like”There is only one God”, the kind of statement that can be made about God alone, is applied to the Government, no prisoner who really understands dharma or cares for self respect can ever accept it, so that there is no choice but to disobey a rule of this sort without fear of the consequences.
('25', 489, 2, 8, 1135066) One should not mind if one is severely punished for this in jail, is put in a dark cell, has to suffer hardships or endure flogging or is even made to starve.
('25', 489, 2, 9, 1135225) One may have to bear all this, but one must civilly disobey a rule of the kind described.
('25', 489, 3, 10, 1135315) I for one welcome this opportunity.
('25', 489, 3, 11, 1135351) The many evils of prison life will now get automatically reformed.

('25', 489, 3, 13, 1135485) The very basis of this Government is force.
('25', 489, 3, 14, 1135529) Where flattery of the few and oppression of the many is the general policy, we say that the Government follows the methods which prevail in a demon’s kingdom.

('25', 489, 4, 18, 1135932) We should also understand the difficult position in which the jail officials are placed.
('25', 489, 4, 19, 1136021) Since they are always thrown among criminals, they are rough in their methods and occasionally cruel.

('25', 489, 4, 21, 1136238) Moreover, so long as the jail regulations remain in force, they are bound to follow them.
('25', 489, 4, 22, 1136328) We have, therefore, no option but to put up with certain hardships and hence we should use our judgment and take thought every time we are inclined to resist.
('25', 489, 4, 23, 1136487) For instance, we may not say,”Salutation to the Government”, but we should certainly salute the warder, respect him and stand up when he comes.

('25', 490, 1, 2, 1136926) KATHIAWAR
('25', 490, 2, 3, 1136936) A friend wants to know whether volunteers should be enrolled in Kathiawar.
('25', 490, 2, 4, 1137011) My advice is,”No.” A resident of Kathiawar who is willing to be enrolled as a volunteer should himself sign the pledge in British territory and give his name and address.
('25', 490, 2, 5, 1137182) In Kathiawar, only constructive activities like swadeshi, abolition of untouchability, propaganda against drinking, national education, etc., should be taken up.
('25', 490, 2, 6, 1137344) The same friend says further that they have started producing khadi in several places but that the people have become so comfort loving that many of them do not like to wear it, with the result that while stocks of khadi have accumulated in many places, the people use mill made or foreign cloth.
('25', 490, 2, 7, 1137641) This is disquieting news.
('25', 490, 2, 8, 1137667) It is of course like ordering rice from elsewhere, refusing to use bajra growing in one’s own field.
('25', 490, 2, 9, 1137768) And it is because of this thoughtless attitude that we have become beggars and slaves and, if we do not change it, we shall be impoverished still further.
('25', 490, 2, 10, 1137923) If Kathiawar, which grows cotton, red wheat and bajra, has to import cloth or foodgrains, how can it remain prosperous?
('25', 490, 3, 11, 1138043) “SWARAJ ASHRAM”
('25', 490, 4, 12, 1138059) Shri Phooken has written a letter from Silchar Jail in Assam in which he has called the jail”Swaraj Ashram”.
('25', 490, 4, 13, 1138168) He adds that anyone who wants swaraj will be admitted into this”Swaraj Ashram” and says further that as long as there can be no peace with honour, the prisoners have no desire for peace at all, and that, in jail one can get a very fine idea of what swaraj means.
('25', 490, 5, 14, 1138431) REFUSAL TO PAY TAXES
('25', 490, 6, 15, 1138452) In Gujarat, as also in the rest of the country, it is being debated whether the people should withhold payment of land revenue.
('25', 490, 6, 16, 1138580) The more I think about this, the clearer it becomes to me that we are still not fit to do this.
('25', 490, 6, 17, 1138676) Anyone who refuses to pay taxes with a view to saving money is certainly a thief, and we shall not win swaraj with the help of thieves.
('25', 490, 6, 18, 1138812) Such swaraj will be a government of thieves.
('25', 490, 6, 19, 1138857) The swaraj will be of the same quality, as, and will be controlled by, the people with whose help we win it.
('25', 490, 6, 20, 1138966) And hence I have been telling the people that they should not desire swaraj to be secured even by my efforts.
('25', 490, 6, 21, 1139076) Even Gandhi rule will not be swaraj.
('25', 490, 6, 22, 1139113) Therefore, my only desire is that all should try to copy me—that is, cultivate self restraint to the extent at least that I have done; be truthful in speech, firm,

('25', 491, 1, 2, 1139319) determined, self possessed and fearless.
('25', 491, 1, 3, 1139360) We can thus see that we should hesitate even to seek help.
('25', 491, 1, 4, 1139419) I often caution my co workers and tell them that, in their impatience, they should not obtain help from all and sundry.
('25', 491, 1, 5, 1139539) They should see that their means are the purest.
('25', 491, 1, 6, 1139588) A surgeon who does not keep his instruments clean and well sharpened sometimes kills his patient or, at any rate, inflicts on him avoidable pain.
('25', 491, 1, 7, 1139734) From this, we should understand that, so long as the cultivators have not been trained to make sacrifices in a peaceful manner and to work in the national cause, it would be a great sin to turn them towards the path of non payment of taxes and we ourselves would have to suffer the consequences.
('25', 491, 1, 8, 1140030) It is my advice, therefore, that individuals may, after full consideration, do what they like, but it will be in the country’s interest that all others, save people in Bardoli and Anand, should pay up the taxes.

('25', 491, 2, 11, 1140499) WHAT ABOUT PICKETING?
('25', 491, 3, 12, 1140521) All our activities except mass civil disobedience continue in the intervening period till January 31 and, therefore, we go on with the picketing of liquor shops and schools where we have been doing it.
('25', 491, 3, 13, 1140723) If we stop it at any place for our own reasons, it will be a different matter.

('25', 491, 4, 17, 1141080) HELP FROM AMERICA
('25', 491, 5, 18, 1141098) Some of our leaders still believe that we should maintain an agency to publicize our activities in England, America and other countries.
('25', 491, 5, 19, 1141235) I am convinced that this will mean mere waste of money; not only that, it will actually do us harm.
('25', 491, 5, 20, 1141335) We shall have to engage some persons [for the work] and we shall in that case lose the independence which we enjoy today.
('25', 491, 5, 21, 1141457) Our present attitude is that we will fight with our own strength and not with any help from abroad.
('25', 491, 5, 22, 1141557) I believe, moreover, that in the measure that our work here is solid, it will get known by itself.

('25', 492, 3, 13, 1142789) Another paper, named Swaraj, has also ceased publication in Prayag 2 as its security has been forfeited.
('25', 492, 3, 14, 1142894) Hence this paper, too, is being now brought out as a hand written paper.
('25', 492, 3, 15, 1142967) I have before me its first issue.
('25', 492, 3, 16, 1143001) It is published in Hindi and has four pages.
('25', 492, 3, 17, 1143046) The editor lets himself go now; he is free to commit as many nominal crimes as he may wish.
('25', 492, 3, 18, 1143138) I see in it nothing but crimes from the point of view of the bureaucracy.
('25', 492, 3, 19, 1143212) But the paper will certainly continue to appear until all the contributors are arrested.
('25', 492, 3, 20, 1143301) With more help from copyists, its circulation will increase.
('25', 492, 4, 21, 1143362) [From Gujarati]
('25', 492, 5, 22, 1143378) Navajivan, 22 1 1922
('25', 492, 6, 23, 1143399) 1 The letter is not translated here
('25', 492, 7, 24, 1143435) 2 Traditional name for Allahabad
('25', 493, 0, 1, 1143468) 494 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('25', 493, 1, 2, 1143510) 227. LETTER TO DEVDAS GANDHI
('25', 493, 2, 3, 1143539) Sunday [January 22, 1922] 1
('25', 493, 3, 4, 1143567) DEVDAS, I at last got your letter today.
('25', 493, 3, 5, 1143608) The copy of the Independent is not clear.
('25', 493, 3, 6, 1143650) It should be such that there should be no difficulty in reading it.
('25', 493, 3, 7, 1143718) It does not matter if you can make fewer copies.
('25', 493, 3, 8, 1143767) Should not your articles also be clear?
('25', 493, 3, 9, 1143807) To bring out such a newspaper is also an art.
('25', 493, 3, 10, 1143853) You should find out how lithographing is done.
('25', 493, 3, 11, 1143900) Send me the full details of your meeting Joseph in connection with the Modern High School.
('25', 493, 3, 12, 1143991) Blessing from
('25', 493, 4, 13, 1144005) BAPU MASTER DEVDAS GANDHI ANAND BHAVAN ALLAHABAD
('25', 493, 5, 14, 1144054) From a photostat of the Gujarati: S.N. 7809
('25', 493, 6, 15, 1144098) 228. LETTER TO MATHURADAS TRIKUMJI
('25', 493, 7, 16, 1144133) Sunday [January 22, 1922] 2
('25', 493, 8, 17, 1144161) MATHURADAS, If the Bombay Committee has the money earmarked then certainly the amount can and should be given from it.
('25', 493, 8, 18, 1144280) The money so set apart is not meant to be kept.
('25', 493, 8, 19, 1144328) It is only desirable that the Provincial Committee should pay it.
('25', 493, 8, 20, 1144394) Even now I would take it to mean that the money is to be given not for the temple but for the uplift of Harijans.
('25', 493, 8, 21, 1144508) Even then, I see no harm in your arguing the case with the Provincial Committee.
('25', 493, 8, 22, 1144589) I have consulted Bhai Shankerlal.
('25', 493, 9, 23, 1144623) Blessings from
('25', 493, 11, 24, 1144638) From the Gujarati original: Pyarelal Papers.

('25', 494, 1, 2, 1144919) APPENDICES
('25', 494, 2, 3, 1144930) APPENDIX 1
('25', 494, 3, 4, 1144941) CITIZENS’ APPEAL
('25', 494, 4, 5, 1144958) The following appeal signed by representatives of all communities was issued
('25', 494, 5, 6, 1145035) to the public:
('25', 494, 6, 7, 1145050) The citizens of Bombay will be glad to learn that, thanks to the concerted
('25', 494, 7, 8, 1145125) efforts of Hindu, Mussulman and Parsi leaders, peace has been restored in most parts
('25', 494, 8, 9, 1145210) of the town.
('25', 494, 8, 10, 1145223) From morning till night they went about in the town, in carriages,
('25', 494, 9, 11, 1145290) pleading with people to be quiet and to preserve peace, and the latter responded to
('25', 494, 10, 12, 1145374) their appeals.
('25', 494, 10, 13, 1145389) Some excitement still, no doubt, prevails in a few localities.
('25', 494, 10, 14, 1145452) Everyone
('25', 494, 11, 15, 1145461) should endeavour to restore quiet in those parts.
('25', 494, 11, 16, 1145511) It behoves us all to forgive and forget
('25', 494, 12, 17, 1145551) the errors of one another.
('25', 494, 12, 18, 1145578) Hindus, Mussulmans, Parsis, Christians and Jews, who
('25', 494, 13, 19, 1145631) have their homes in India, ought to live as brothers and sisters and bear with the
('25', 494, 14, 20, 1145714) differences and failings of one another.
('25', 494, 14, 21, 1145755) We have all to be ashamed of the stain on the
('25', 494, 15, 22, 1145801) fair name of Bombay.
('25', 494, 15, 23, 1145822) Only by restoring and preserving peace can that stain be wiped
('25', 494, 16, 24, 1145885) out, and we appeal to all the citizens of Bombay for hearty co operation in the matter.
('25', 494, 17, 25, 1145973) Young India, 24 11 1921
('25', 494, 18, 26, 1145997) APPENDIX II
('25', 494, 19, 27, 1146009) EXTRACTS FROM SI R SANKARAN NAIR’S LETTER
('25', 494, 21, 28, 1146051) THE EDITOR, The Times of India
('25', 494, 23, 29, 1146082) In view of certain statement which have already appeared in the Press, may I seek the hospitality of your columns for this letter.
('25', 494, 24, 30, 1146213) We were called to confer together and devise means to come to an honourable settlement.
('25', 494, 24, 31, 1146301) I have come to the conclusion along with many others that any further conference with Mr. Gandhi and his followers is useless, and he will not be a party to what I consider any honourable settlement, or that any settlement will be faithfully carried out.
('25', 494, 25, 32, 1146556) It is only right that I should give my reasons.
('25', 494, 26, 33, 1146604) The signatories to the manifesto placed certain proposals before the Conference yesterday.
('25', 494, 26, 34, 1146695) Gandhi did not accept those resolutions.
('25', 494, 26, 35, 1146736) This morning the
('25', 495, 0, 1, 1146753) 496 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('25', 495, 1, 2, 1146795) Committee, appointed by the Conference, which at his own request—the reason will be apparent later—did not contain himself or any of his followers, framed, however, in consultation with him, resolutions to meet his wishes as far as possible.
('25', 495, 1, 3, 1147037) They also were not accepted by him.
('25', 495, 1, 4, 1147073) In the two long speeches he delivered he defined his own position so far as any conference with the Viceroy is concerned as follows:
('25', 495, 2, 5, 1147206) “Penitence” on the part of Government must be shown.
('25', 495, 2, 6, 1147259) In order to create a favourable atmosphere the Government must unconditionally retrace all steps they have recently taken; not only cancel the notifications extending certain provisions of law; release all Congress and Khilafat volunteers arrested and convicted but all others convicted recently under what I shall call the ordinary provisions of the Penal Code and the Procedure Code.
('25', 495, 2, 7, 1147645) This later demand was subsequently modified in one particular.
('25', 495, 2, 8, 1147708) This, Mr. Gandhi said, is not due to any sympathy with them but only to create a favourable atmosphere and to show penitence on the part of Government.
('25', 495, 3, 9, 1147860) He further expressed his opinion, referring no doubt to the Government: “You dare not declare martial law, however far we go.” Mr. Gandhi’s followers, even those who expressed a mild dissent in some respects, support him in his attitude.
('25', 495, 4, 10, 1148098) Mr. Gandhi does not want a conference or a settlement except on his own impossible terms .
('25', 495, 5, 11, 1148189) In regard to the Punjab he emphasized the fact that the Congress party would be satisfied with nothing less than carrying out the proposals made in the Congress Sub Committee report.
('25', 495, 5, 12, 1148372) It includes not only the punishment of the subordinate officials but the practically impossible condition of the deprivations of pensions of Sir Michael O’Dwyer, Dyer, etc.
('25', 495, 6, 13, 1148545) With reference to the Khilafat matter, Mr. Gandhi said that the French must leave Syria—of course an impossible condition.
('25', 495, 6, 14, 1148668) They want England to leave Egypt.
('25', 495, 6, 15, 1148702) On this it is not necessary to make any comment.
('25', 495, 7, 16, 1148751) So far as swaraj is concerned, he wants at once in the central and provincial Governments full Dominion status, as may be determined by the duly elected representatives of the people.
('25', 495, 7, 17, 1148935) For the election of representatives the Congress constitution as to franchise, etc., should be accepted.
('25', 495, 8, 18, 1149040) He emphasized over and over again that these are the minimum demands which must be accepted by the Government and the Round Table Conference.
('25', 495, 9, 19, 1149182) The release of some of the convicted persons like the volunteers, the constitution of a tribunal to consider the cases of others are made conditions precedent to holding a conference.
('25', 495, 9, 20, 1149366) I do not object to a tribunal for reconsideration if the Government are willing to accept the suggestion, though all the judges are not to be appointed by Government.
('25', 495, 9, 21, 1149533) This observation does not apply to the cases of the Ali Brothers and others in their position whose (fatwa prisoners) release is, however, demanded as an essential preliminary to any conference.
('25', 495, 10, 22, 1149728) The demand however that certain prisoners should be released before we can agree to such a conference mast in my opinion be dropped if we want a conference.
('25', 496, 0, 1, 1149885) VOL. 25 : 27 OCTOBER, 1921 22 JANUARY, 1922 497
('25', 496, 1, 2, 1149933) agree that the Government should not interfere with Mr. Gandhi’s movement as long as there is no apprehension of any violence.
('25', 496, 2, 3, 1150060) As regards Messrs Mahomed Ali and Shaukat Ali and others in that category the Government’s position is stronger.
('25', 496, 2, 4, 1150173) It is within the knowledge of Mr. Gandhi and many of us that they do not accept the principle of non violent agitation.
('25', 496, 2, 5, 1150293) In view of the promise of Mr. Gandhi that he would obtain swaraj within a year if his method of non violent agitation is followed, they did not press for violence.
('25', 496, 2, 6, 1150457) That year has elapsed, and the Mussulmans feel that the pact with Mr. Gandhi is over ....
('25', 496, 2, 7, 1150547) the Mussulmans are not under the restraint of the self imposed obligations of Mr. Gandhi....
('25', 496, 2, 8, 1150640) they will not hesitate to resort to violence not only against Government but also against others who may not join them in their agitation.
('25', 496, 2, 9, 1150779) Recent occurrences also support this.
('25', 496, 3, 10, 1150817) All circumstances point to the conclusion that they and their friends will continue the agitation on their release.
('25', 496, 3, 11, 1150933) I do not think it right, therefore, to insist for their unconditional release or make it a condition precedent for the conference with the Government.
('25', 496, 3, 12, 1151084) The only ground of differentiation, the superior obligation to follow the religious injunctions even against the laws of the country, has only to be stated in view of what is happening in Malabar to be discarded.
('25', 496, 3, 13, 1151297) It is on the other hand, a strong argument against unconditional release which would leave them free to follow a line of conduct declared illegal by the courts and which may be attended by disastrous consequences.
('25', 496, 3, 14, 1151511) An additional reason is the fact that Mr. Gandhi and his friends and the accused themselves welcome the arrest and convictions.
('25', 496, 3, 15, 1151639) I trust, therefore, that I shall not be deemed uncharitable if I state that the demand for the release by them is for the humiliation of Government or to preclude a round table conference as suggested.
('25', 496, 3, 16, 1151841) It is possible that the refusal to release these persons might be used as a pretext for civil disobedience, i.e., non payment of taxes etc.
('25', 496, 3, 17, 1151981) The movement will then stand naked in all its illegality and hideousness.
('25', 496, 3, 18, 1152055) It is a fitting consummation of a policy which had its origin in false promise of attainment of swaraj within a year—a statement calculated and therefore made to mislead the ignorant masses which all its intelligent supporters must have known to be impossible of attainment .
('25', 496, 4, 19, 1152331) Being of opinion that I cannot associate with Mr. Gandhi and his followers in asking for a conference or in any other respect, for reasons some of which are given above, and differing from the Conference on these vital questions, on which the Conference agrees with Mr. Gandhi, I have felt bound to Ieave the Conference, of which I was the speaker.
('25', 496, 4, 20, 1152680) C. SANKARAN NAIR The Times of India, 17 1 1922
